webTitle: US state laws limiting damages against the tobacco industry

fields.headline: US state laws limiting damages against the tobacco industry
fields.trailText:
Florida and several tobacco-producing states have passed laws designed to protect the tobacco industry in case of a crippling verdict in the
class-action lawsuit brought by Florida smokers. In Florida, defendants who appeal a verdict generally must post the full award as bond
while appealing damages.
fields.body:
Florida and several tobacco-producing states have passed laws designed to protect the tobacco industry in case of a crippling verdict in the class-action lawsuit brought by Florida smokers. In Florida, defendants who appeal a verdict generally must post the full award as bond while appealing damages.

But these new laws cap the bond that tobacco companies would have to post during appeals.

State legislators and the tobacco industry say the laws protect companies from certain bankruptcy. But anti-tobacco forces say the caps unfairly shield cigarette makers and violate the Constitution by failing to respect court decisions from other states.

Following is a list of state caps on the bond cigarette makers would have to post during appeals:

 Florida: $100m or 10% of the companies' net worth, whichever is lower.

 Georgia: $25m  Kentucky: $100m  North Carolina: $25m

 Virginia: $25m

fields.headline: An enemy of the people
fields.standfirst: Norman Finkelstein's book shows him as a Jew who doesn't like Jews
fields.trailText: Perhaps he thought the sky would fall in. Perhaps Norman Finkelstein imagined his explosive new polemic, The Holocaust Industry, serialised in the Guardian, would drive the Jewish world crazy with fury. Maybe he is a little disappointed that, in Britain at least, that hasnt happened yet.
fields.body:
Perhaps he thought the sky would fall in. Perhaps Norman Finkelstein imagined his explosive new polemic, The Holocaust Industry, serialised in the Guardian, would drive the Jewish world crazy with fury. Maybe he is a little disappointed that, in Britain at least, that hasnt happened yet.

But there is good reason. For though Finkelstein likes to cast himself as the brave prophet, nobly confronting his wayward people with a truth only he dare tell, his claims are not nearly as shocking to Jews as he would like to imagine. Indeed, the chief questions he raises have been at the heart of Jewish debate for at least a decade. So he tells us that the Holocaust should not be treated as a sacred mystery, impervious to human inquiry - and that its lessons must be applied to genocide and suffering the world over. Most Jews accepted that long ago. More controversially, he insists that the Holocaust is not unique - as if unaware that a debate has long raged on this very question.

Some insist that the Shoah did indeed witness an unprecedented convergence of state bureaucratic power and modern technology in a systematic, industrialised attempt to extinguish an entire people. Others counsel against hierarchies of oppression, in which Jews claim first place in an Olympic games of world suffering. It is a loud, important debate - but it did not begin with Norman Finkelstein.

The same goes for the memory industry, the abundance of museums, films, books and conferences commemorating the Holocaust. Finkelstein is no pioneer here either. Indeed it was a former Israeli foreign minister, Abba Eban, who first quipped that Theres no business like Shoah business (a trade, incidentally, which this latest book has now joined).

Thoughtful Jews have been questioning for a while the wisdom of making the Holocaust the centre of Jewish identity. Peter Novicks landmark book, The Holocaust in American Life, makes this case far more powerfully than Finkelstein. He offers a moving plea for todays Jews to define themselves as a people with a rich, vibrant culture - rather than as a ghost-nation, a walking version of the corpses of Auschwitz and Treblinka.

Novick is just as appalled by Holocaust theme parks and Auschwitz tourism as Finkelstein. But theres a crucial difference - which explains why Novicks book was welcomed for posing some awkward but necessary questions, while Finkelsteins has been dismissed or condemned. Novick wrote as a Jew, concerned that his fellow Jews were taking a path that could only end in harm. This new book has none of that sensitivity or human empathy - surely prerequisites of any meaningful debate about the Holocaust. It asks some legitimate questions, among them whether the Shoah was used unfairly to immunise Israel from criticism. But it reads like a rant, with splenetic attacks on individuals, many of them survivors, and vast generalisations about the whole of world Jewry.

In a telephone call to Brooklyn yesterday, I asked Finkelstein why he reserved his most scathing language for his fellow Jews - much harsher than any words he had for the Nazis themselves. If I was writing a book about the Nazis, Im sure Id use scathing language about them, he said, rather feebly. It is perhaps too easy to write off a critic like Finkelstein as a self-hating Jew, but it is striking to hear someone who appears to have nothing but contempt for his own people. He issues the same call sent out by David Irving in the high court this year - that Jews should not simply condemn anti-semitism, but examine their own role in provoking it. Like Irving, Finkelstein sees Jews as the authors of their own suffering. He claims that Jews have made up stories of persecution and that there are too many survivors to be true - another Irving favourite. In fact, what this claim amounts to is the fair statement that Jews expanded their definition of survivor to mean not just those who were held in camps, but those who fled or hid from the Nazis. But to put it like that would be to give Jews the benefit of the doubt. And Finkelstein, like Irving, is not in that game.

Besides the animus and the vitriol, there is a subtler way in which Finkelstein does the anti-semites work for them. He constructs an elaborate conspiracy theory, in which the Jews were pushed from apathy to obsession about the Holocaust by a corrupt Jewish leadership bent on building international support for Israel. He has no truck with the idea that Jews might themselves have changed their attitude to the Shoah, for a complex range of reasons. Instead Jews are mere sheep, pushed around by a wicked Jewish elite.

Finkelstein sees the Jews as either villains or victims - and that, I fear, takes him closer to the people who created the Holocaust than to those who suffered in it.

fields.headline: Avalanche of sound
fields.trailText:
Attica Blues
Dingwalls, London
* * *

Attica Blues - production team Charlie Dark (D'Afro) and Tony Nwachukwu, and singer Roba El-Essawy - were described as a low-rent Massive Attack in some quarters when they released their debut single Blueprint in 1995.
fields.body:
Attica Blues
Dingwalls, London * * *

Attica Blues - production team Charlie Dark (D'Afro) and Tony Nwachukwu, and singer Roba El-Essawy - were described as a low-rent Massive Attack in some quarters when they released their debut single Blueprint in 1995.

It's not a comparison that sits well. Where Massive Attack were initially influenced by New York hip-hop, Attica Blues named themselves after a track by saxophonist Archie Shepp, in homage to their first inspiration: jazz. Originally signed to James Lavelle's fledgling Mo'Wax label, Attica Blues were dropped in the Mo'Wax fallout when A&M were taken over by Universal; now they have returned with a new album, Test Not Test, and a new record label, Sony.

They have spent the past four years acquiring new technological expertise, wising up to new sounds, specifically two-step, and doing countless remixes. Tonight, their first date in three years, was a showcase of all these experiences and quite a passionate affair, the trio genuinely giving their all.

They ambled on stage to the words of Trinadadian poet Roger Robinson: 'Test, Don't Test, this is just an intro, a small example of what the lyrical machine can do.'

Then the avalanche of sounds began.

In a genre predominantly fuelled by samples and break beats, Attica Blues have always preferred to create 'sounds' for themselves. If you listened closely to The Man, you would find anything from string arrangements to original keyboard breaks. They might seem like they have been sampled from an obscure free jazz album, but D'Afro and Nwachukwu create them with the aid of session musicians.

On Just an Avenue, an irregular synth fanfare started up that sounded curiously like a wall of revved-up guitars, only to be scrawled across by D'Afro's insane beats. This was instrumental hip-hop played at a pitch of ferocity and precision that few could emulate.

Attica Blues came across as a hip-hop jazz group that puts as much emphasis on the complexities of beat science as to what is being said. But the music is rooted by the introspective lyricism and energetic singing of El-Essawy, who might not have an amazing voice, but does have presence and a poetic soul. Despite being hampered by technical problems, she pushed the music forward with her sheer enthusiasm.

fields.headline: Just a quickie
fields.trailText:
The Blue Room
Minerva Studio, Chichester
* *

When it premiered at London's Donmar Warehouse 18 months ago, the vision of Nicole Kidman without her clothes largely obscured the view of David Hare's free adaptation of Arthur Schnitzler's La Ronde.
fields.body:
The Blue Room
Minerva Studio, Chichester * *
When it premiered at London's Donmar Warehouse 18 months ago, the vision of Nicole Kidman without her clothes largely obscured the view of David Hare's free adaptation of Arthur Schnitzler's La Ronde.

The two-hander now has the kind of slightly naughty reputation that guarantees good box office, and this Chichester revival, following hard on the heels of the regional premiere at Bolton, suggests that it is going to pop up regularly at cash-strapped reps.

I wish I felt more enthusiastic about the prospect, but Loveday Ingram's smart and sharp revival, beautifully acted by Camilla Power and Michael Higgs, exposes Hare's contemporary take on Schnitzler's sexual daisy chain as a glibly entertaining but hollow evening. Unusually for Hare, the great romantic of our theatre, the play is stained with a stylish cynicism. Watching it makes you feel as if someone has walked all over you in stilettos.

This wouldn't be such a bad thing if Hare further pursued the idea of sex as a transaction. Sour indifference replaces the salty sting of desire as the prostitute couples with the cabbie who sleeps with the au pair who has sex with the student who is having an affair with a woman who is married to an MP who seduces a 17-year-old and so on.

But these brief encounters or serial exploitations are not only between crudely drawn characters but are set in a hazy blue no-man's-land reminiscent of a smart Conran restaurant. This has the effect of making the audience a kind of voyeur at a peep-show, but lacks the power of Schnitzler's version, which was firmly grounded in fin-de-siecle Austrian society.

Thankfully, there are scenes when the writing rejects style and irony in favour of something more searching, most notably in the exchanges between the already unfaithful MP's wife and her government minister husband where the lies and evasions of politics have insidiously infected the marital bed.

But although Hare occasionally seems poised to say something interesting about the way love fades like a suntan and the gap between our imagination and reality, he never spits it out and appears far too amused by his creations to capture the soulless hole at the heart of all their relationships.

If he had concentrated as much on the state of the characters' hearts and heads as he does on the state of their genitals it would be infinitely more satisfying. At the close of each sexual encounter, the length of the coupling is detailed above the stage in hours, minutes and, in one sorry case, seconds. Hare's engagement with his audience takes precisely 90 minutes. All right as a quickie, but definitely not a meaningful relationship.

Until July 29. Box office: 01243 781312.

webTitle: Treasury wary as banks reward best customers

fields.headline: Treasury wary as banks reward best customers
fields.trailText: HSBC is piloting a scheme which could reduce loan rates for customers depending on how many products they have bought from the bank. The bank joins rivals Barclays and Abbey Nationals internet bank Cahoot in trying to reward customers with good track records and penalising those with bad ones.
fields.body:
HSBC is piloting a scheme which could reduce loan rates for customers depending on how many products they have bought from the bank.

The bank joins rivals Barclays and Abbey Nationals internet bank Cahoot in trying to reward customers with good track records and penalising those with bad ones.

The Treasury made it clear yesterday that it was closely monitoring all the new products coming on the market.

The comment from the Treasury came as a pilot scheme to be started by Barclays in September, whereby customers with a poor payments record will be kept on higher interest rates, faced criticism. Critics said its plan, which might be extended to include mortgages, would exacerbate financial exclusion.

Barclays, which has also been criticised for branch closures at the same time as running an advertising campaign emphasising its size, was said by Andrew Simms of the New Economics Foundation to be widening the gap between the rich and the poor.

My heart sinks whenever I hear something like this. It seems that the bank that likes to be big only wants big customers, Mr Simms said.

However, Barclays yesterday insisted that the move to lower the average repayment rate on its Barclayloan products was designed to reward existing customers rather than exclude sectors of society.

Barclays will ensure that assessment criteria and discounts given to customers will be fully transparent. This does not affect the loan application criteria for customers, the bank said.

HSBC, which refused to confirm that it was already piloting its reward scheme, is understood to be looking at offering better mortgage rates to those customers who have a number of its products.

One banking expert noted that the moves represented attempts by the banks to tackle the statistic in banking folklore that 20% of a banks customers generate 80% of its profit.

While HSBCs plan does not appear to depend on the credit standards of customers, Abbey National is making a virtue of the individual pricing being offered by its internet bank, Cahoot.com.

Cahoot, currently offering a 0% interest rate on its credit card, will determine the rate to which the repayments will rise on the creditworthiness of customers when the offer ends next year.

The rate would be set at between 7% and 11% and an Abbey spokesman said last night that at least it would have a years knowledge of its customers before setting the rate.

Some sources argued that the move to differential pricing might actually improve peoples financial management.

webTitle: Vickers quits Bank to run OFT

fields.headline: Vickers quits Bank to run OFT
fields.trailText: One of the business world's most politically sensitive jobs, running the office of fair trading, is to be taken on by the Bank of England's chief economist, John Vickers.
fields.body:
One of the business world's most politically sensitive jobs, running the office of fair trading, is to be taken on by the Bank of England's chief economist, John Vickers.

The surprise appointment to the office, recently given new powers to fine companies for anti-competitive behaviour, followed frenzied speculation about who would replace John Bridgeman at the powerful competition watchdog.

Mr Vickers' move to the OFT leaves the bank with a vacancy on the nine-member monetary policy committee, which sets interest rates. The Bank's governor, Eddie George will be eager to fill the gap quickly to avoid the danger of a tied vote.

The economist was named amid speculation that the role had been offered to a highly regarded Brussels-based lawyer, Philip Collins, as well as repeated rumours that Denise Kingsmill, the deputy head of the competition commission, was a frontrunner for the job.

Mr Bridgeman will leave the OFT in September after five years. He is thought to have wanted to extend his term but Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, has been said to be keen to replace him.

Mr Byers, who yesterday said he was grateful to Mr Bridgeman for his determined work is rumoured to have felt Mr Bridgeman did not support his rip-off Britain campaign.

Mr Vickers, 42, chosen for his knowledge and experience of business issues and markets, was also considered a surprise choice as Bank of England chief economist because his background was not in macroeconomics.

A microeconomist, his reputation rested on academic research into the regulation of the privatised industries.

Before joining the Bank of England, he was Drummond professor of political economy at Oxford.

fields.headline: Post office cash machine spurned
fields.standfirst: Plan to counter branch closures flounders
fields.trailText: The government's plan to provide local communities with financial services through post offices is under question before it has even launched. The first Woolwich cash machine installed by an independent provider in a post office is barely being used and is failing to cover the costs of its upkeep.
fields.body:
The government's plan to provide local communities with financial services through post offices is under question before it has even launched.

The first Woolwich cash machine installed by an independent provider in a post office is barely being used and is failing to cover the costs of its upkeep. It experiences only one-tenth of the use of other Woolwich machines - fewer than 600 transactions a month, with withdrawals costing £1.

It is understood that some banks are no longer interested in installing cash machines because of the negative publicity surrounding moves to charge for withdrawals, since reversed by many major banks. The disclosure comes at a time when the Post Office is trying to finalise contracts with other banks and building societies about putting 3,000 cash machines in post offices.

The introduction of new cash machines in post offices was announced by Tony Blair early this year as a way to tackle financial exclusion. About 1.5m householders lack even a basic bank or building society account, according to the financial services authority. The cashpoints plan was also heralded as one way to help secure the viability of the post office network. The Post Office said last night it was still committed to installing the 3,000 cash machines by the end of next year - but admitted that contracts had not yet been completed after the furore over charges for cash withdrawals.

Woolwich, Nationwide and Alliance & Leicester are all thought to be in negotiations but have yet to sign agreements. Woolwich intends to charge £1 for withdrawals from its post office machines, as it does at the first one - installed last month at Chickerell, in Weymouth.

The machine, installed even though the contract with the Post Office is not yet sealed, is branded Woolwich but owned by an independent provider. The bank has arrangements with Euronet, Money Box and TRM. The bank said the machine had been used 387 times in May, and 461 in June, about half the use expected from other convenience sites. This is well below the 70,000 transactions a year at which machines become viable and for which Woolwich does not charge.

A spokeswoman said: "This low usage explains why we have to charge." But she insisted that, based on previous experience, the £1 charge was not a deterrent. Nationwide and Alliance & Leicester do not charge customers for withdrawing money from cash machines. A&L, which already has 160 dispensers in post offices, is expected to be interested in another 300. Its ownership of Girobank, formerly part of the Post Office, means itshould be able to secure some of the busier and more attractive sites. This suggests that sub post offices in rural areas are likely to be left for the other providers.
fields.bodyText: The government's plan to provide local communities with financial services through post offices is under question before it has even launched. The first Woolwich cash machine installed by an independent provider in a post office is barely being used and is failing to cover the costs of its upkeep. It experiences only one-tenth of the use of other Woolwich machines - fewer than 600 transactions a month, with withdrawals costing £1. It is understood that some banks are no longer interested in installing cash machines because of the negative publicity surrounding moves to charge for withdrawals, since reversed by many major banks. The disclosure comes at a time when the Post Office is trying to finalise contracts with other banks and building societies about putting 3,000 cash machines in post offices. The introduction of new cash machines in post offices was announced by Tony Blair early this year as a way to tackle financial exclusion. About 1.5m householders lack even a basic bank or building society account, according to the financial services authority. The cashpoints plan was also heralded as one way to help secure the viability of the post office network. The Post Office said last night it was still committed to installing the 3,000 cash machines by the end of next year - but admitted that contracts had not yet been completed after the furore over charges for cash withdrawals. Woolwich, Nationwide and Alliance & Leicester are all thought to be in negotiations but have yet to sign agreements. Woolwich intends to charge £1 for withdrawals from its post office machines, as it does at the first one - installed last month at Chickerell, in Weymouth. The machine, installed even though the contract with the Post Office is not yet sealed, is branded Woolwich but owned by an independent provider. The bank has arrangements with Euronet, Money Box and TRM. The bank said the machine had been used 387 times in May, and 461 in June, about half the use expected from other convenience sites. This is well below the 70,000 transactions a year at which machines become viable and for which Woolwich does not charge. A spokeswoman said: "This low usage explains why we have to charge." But she insisted that, based on previous experience, the £1 charge was not a deterrent. Nationwide and Alliance & Leicester do not charge customers for withdrawing money from cash machines. A&L, which already has 160 dispensers in post offices, is expected to be interested in another 300. Its ownership of Girobank, formerly part of the Post Office, means itshould be able to secure some of the busier and more attractive sites. This suggests that sub post offices in rural areas are likely to be left for the other providers.

fields.headline: Sonatas at midnight
fields.trailText:
York Early Music Festival
Various venues
* * *

For 20 years the York Early Music Festival has had an international reputation and nowhere to live. Now the Lottery has rescued the medieval St Margaret's church from semi-dereliction, facilitating its transformation into the cool, stone-clad multi-purpose research, recording and performance space of the National Centre for Early Music, an elegant base for a selection of this year's events.
fields.body:
York Early Music Festival
Various venues * * *
For 20 years the York Early Music Festival has had an international reputation and nowhere to live. Now the Lottery has rescued the medieval St Margaret's church from semi-dereliction, facilitating its transformation into the cool, stone-clad multi-purpose research, recording and performance space of the National Centre for Early Music, an elegant base for a selection of this year's events.

The festival would not be half so much fun, however, were it not for an exhaustive itinerary of international specialists unveiling arcane items at strange hours of the day and night. A bracing, midnight vigil on the unyielding pews of St Olave's church provided the evocative ambience for Rachel Podger's candle-lit presentation of Bach's sonatas and partitas for solo violin. The setting was a reminder that the sonatas were spiritual pieces originally performed in church; and her final sprint through the fugue of the C Major Sonata felt thrillingly apposite.

The university concert hall provided a less historic background to the Swiss-based Ensemble 415's programme of Bach concertos. The unexpected humidity of a sodden, Yorkshire July put paid to one of Lars-Ulrik Mortensen's harpsichord strings, which exploded with an almighty crack during a furious passage from the A major harpsichord concerto. He didn't turn a hair. Historically informed performance doesn't come more authentic than this.

Celebrating Bach's centenary is a relatively mainstream activity. The festival, however, is never on better form than in its excursions to the remotest corners of the repertory. Other than Bach, this year's theme is 16th- and 17th-century biblical narrative. Admittedly this sounds a bit dry, and in Stephen Varcoe's stiff, midday recital of Purcell and Blow it came close to positively parched.

But lutenist Anthony Rooley's evening, the Phoenix Rising, demonstrated that this little-known repertory still shows signs of life and even an unexpected grain of humour. With distinguished contributions from soprano Evelyn Tubb and mezzo Lucy Ballard, Rooley directed a ravishing election of religious mini-dramas, including the first modern performance of John Weldon's elegantly rococo Dissolution, the singers performing from memory and perambulating through the isles to striking effect.

Festival continues until Sunday. Box office: 01904 658338

fields.headline: Are you worth the risk?
fields.standfirst: How lenders decide
fields.trailText: How lenders decide.
fields.body:
Banks can use external or internal data to judge credit worthiness. Barclays insists it will only use its own information.

External data, used by most British credit card and loan companies, involves credit scoring. This counts "positive" and "negative" lifestyles and other personal attributes to come up with a total which is compared against a pass mark. The raw figures usually come from the application form and a credit reference agency; the main agencies are Experian and Equifax.

Positive factors include appearing on the electoral register,living at one address for more than three years, working full time, and having other loans and credit cards which are paid off on time.

Negatives range from self-employment to county court judgements. Not appearing on the electoral roll usually results in instant rejection.

Failing to have existing credit facilities will also depress the score. Banks prefer someone with a handful of cards rather than a "plastic virgin", although a few worry that someone with many cards might use them all at once then disappear.

Credit scoring can be less than scientific. The external data may be incomplete and records of late repayments do not take account of legitimate reasons such as illness.

Banks using internal data try to replicate the old fashioned bank manager who would make a decision following a personal interview - but by using computers.

This approach looks at spending patterns which can be tracked through current account activity rather than home or job mobility. It is more concerned with how money is spent and whether the individual ends up in the black or red at the end of the month.

Banks believe this approach filters out applicants who have potential problems and takes account of savings, which credit scoring ignores.

fields.headline: Halifax delays IF launch
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Intelligent Finance (IF), the Halifax's much-hyped new internet and telephone bank, was yesterday forced to postpone its start-up - due today - after identifying a fault in its computer systems which cast doubt over its ability to cope with the expected surge in demand.
fields.body: Intelligent Finance (IF), the Halifax's much-hyped new internet and telephone bank, was yesterday forced to postpone its start-up - due today - after identifying a fault in its computer systems which cast doubt over its ability to cope with the expected surge in demand. IF is the latest online bank to fall foul of technical problems, and the delay is a severe embarrassment for the venture, which had arranged for Gordon Brown to open its new Edinburgh call centre today. Advertisements for the bank were about to air on television, featuring the Fatboy Slim hit Right Here, Right Now - a choice of anthem now looking inappropriate. Going live has been put back to some time in August, although IF's chief executive, Jim Spowart, admitted he was unable to give a cast-iron guarantee that it would go live even then. During the course of testing the bank's systems and carrying out live simulations, experts identified an intermittent fault which caused the system to grind almost to a halt. Mr Spowart said the fault cast doubts over the bank's ability handle the expected high levels of demand. The bank had been carrying out tests based on 15,000 calls a day - the number of people who have already registered. "It [the system] slowed right down. We decided we were clearly not going to have time to fix this before we launch," he said. "It is embarrassing but we think it is better to disappoint customers than to anger them should we have had any problems. We simply cannot launch until we are sure we can handle the anticipated levels of customer activity." Testing will continue over the next few weeks. The delay means the loss of a month's sales. Halifax is investing £120m over two years in IF, including £10m on an advertising push which started earlier this month with a national billboard campaign. Only last month IF was still assuring customers that its "cutting-edge systems" would be able to cope with the expected large volume of applications. It was quick to highlight the problems experienced by Abbey National's rival online offering, Cahoot, which was brought to its knees by a glitch on its start-up day a month ago. Mr Spowart said that, while the plan was to go live next month, "we are not going to go until we are ready". The bank is contacting all those who have registered during recent weeks to explain the situation and apologise for any inconvenience. Mr Spowart said that the problem "would not have put customers at risk". IF was due to open for telephone business today and for internet applications 10 days later. It decided on a two-stage start-up following Cahoot's technical problems, and said it had made a "substantial investment in the most advanced technology available" to ensure it could meet the pent-up demand for its products, which include a current account, flexible mortgage, savings account, credit cards and personal loans. The phone banking operation is supported by 1,200 call centre staff. The Livingston and Edinburgh operations are said by IF to add up to the largest integrated call and web centre in Europe.

fields.headline: Flintoff throws weight around
fields.trailText: Andy Flintoff's weight has been bulking out the column inches for the best part of a week, but it now turns out that everyone got it wrong. He is fatter than we thought. Paul Weaver reports.
fields.body:
Andy Flintoff's weight has been bulking out the column inches for the best part of a week, but it now turns out that everyone got it wrong. He is fatter than we thought.

Flintoff, the player known as "Fat Slogger" to his team-mates, is listed in the Cricketers' Who's Who as 13st 10lb. In fact he is 17st 12lb, which means he is heavier than Britain's world heavyweight champion Lennox Lewis, who is expected to weigh 17st 9lb when he faces Frans Botha on Saturday.

Yesterday Duncan Fletcher, the England coach, was on the defensive when he said: "His weight is very slightly down on what it was in April. But now everyone is saying he's fat.

"He's upset about what's been written about him. There is a slight difference in Freddie's attitude at the moment. He's under a lot of pressure. He realises he's got to prove a point."

Fletcher then revealed that Flintoff's current weight was "114 kilos". He added that the player's target weight was 108kg, or about a stone less than he is at the moment. "We got him down to this in South Africa."

Fletcher also set the imagination boggling when he said: "If you have a look at his weight when he was 20, it was far in excess of what it is now." Clearly the Who's Who is crying out for a reprint.

The England management are upset about the player's weight problem and do not mind if they shame him into doing something about it.

Fletcher looked very serious indeed when he said: "He's got to work on his weight if he's going to maintain his progress in cricket." Widening his point to take in the entire squad he added: "Careers are at stake. We can give guidelines but at the end of the day it's up to the individual to take on board what we are offering."

Flintoff, 22, also known as Freddie, as in Flintstone, has been represented as English cricket's long lost Ian Botham, a destructive hitter and a bowler capable of generating pace from a short approach.

There is nothing wrong with his weight that a bludgeoning century or a five-wicket return would not put right. Shane Warne's waistline is rarely the subject of criticism from the Australian Cricket Board.

Flintoff's weight is not his only worry as England prepare for their first home international under lights. His back injury will prevent him from bowling today against Zimbabwe - who have already qualified for the final - and he will play as a specialist batsman, if he plays at all.

In the nets yesterday Fletcher spoke to Flintoff after he had miscued one particular cow shot and the batsman knocked over his stumps in frustration when he played the same stroke a little later.

England will again be without their captain Nasser Hussain, whose hand injury has not improved. Nick Knight, who also misses today's game, could return for Saturday's match against West Indies.

fields.headline: Round-up
fields.trailText: Congratulating the England and Wales Cricket Board may be as trendy as confessing to a penchant for the halcyon days of skiffle but credit where credit's due. With the championship campaign at its halfway point, the new bonus points system, revamped to offset the twin evils of greedy quicks and duff pitches, appears to be having at least a smidgin of the desired effect.
fields.body:
Congratulating the England and Wales Cricket Board may be as trendy as confessing to a penchant for the halcyon days of skiffle but credit where credit's due. With the championship campaign at its halfway point, the new bonus points system, revamped to offset the twin evils of greedy quicks and duff pitches, appears to be having at least a smidgin of the desired effect.

Standing atop the divisions at the start of the current round, after all, were Surrey and Warwickshire, whose respective hauls of 23 and 25 batting points also led the way in their respective tables. Similarly, the limpest blades - Hampshire and Kent upstairs, Gloucestershire and Northamptonshire downstairs - dominate the cellars.

Runs, nevertheless, remain nearly as elusive as a contemporary British sitcom worthy of the "com". Of the four centuries in yesterday's eight matches, only one, Jeff Cook's against Gloucestershire in only his second such outing for Northamptonshire, led to a score of 250. That the two most impressive edifices were constructed at Cheltenham and Arundel, where Sussex rallied from 45 for four to 265 against Essex, tells you pretty much all you need to know about the shameful superiority of outground pitches.

The dishonourable exception - forgivably - was Southgate, where 17 wickets fell on a square that had spent the previous four days being drenched: the last 40 wickets taken there have cost 15.83 apiece.

Mark Ramprakash contributed more than half Middlesex's 164 whereupon Richard Johnson enhanced his growing lustre with three quick strikes as Glamorgan, unbowed in all competitions since losing the Benson & Hedges Cup final a month ago, slid to 111 for seven.

The Durham seam battery kept up the good work at Grace Road with another full hand of points, taking its collective spoils to 139 victims after removing both Leicestershire openers for ducks. That the hosts made it to 222 was almost exclusively down to Ben Smith. Atoning splendidly after failing to reach 50 in his previous 13 championship knocks, he emerged unbeaten with 111 off 265 balls - only 59 fewer than the entire defiance of the other 10 batsmen.

Better luck for another pair of new-ball recipients at New Road, where Worcestershire's Phillip Weston and Elliott Wilson, who had combined for three ducks at Southgate, added 123 against Nottinghamshire. Wilson, 23, proceeded to his second hundred of the summer, and third in his last 10 championship games.

Those to whom Oxford and Cambridge's annual squabble typifies the class-ridden soul of English cricket may deem it rather fitting that the first century of what may well turn out to be the final Varsity match at Lord's - six university centres of excellence will be in place next year - came courtesy of a chap named Quentin.

Hughes of the Light Blues hit his second successive hundred, the 106th of the 173-year-old debate being closely followed by the 107th, from Jamie Pymont, whose championship debut for Derbyshire brought a king pair.

In Colombo, South Africa qualified to meet Sri Lanka in the final of the Singer Triangular series by dint of a seven-wicket victory over Pakistan, to whom 153 constituted something of a triumph after David Terbrugge and Shaun Pollock reduced them to 19 for six. Gary Kirsten scored an uncharacteristically quick 46 for South Africa.

Among the face-savers was Shoaib Malik, an 18-year-old off-spinner whose name suggests he ought to become the greatest all-rounder ever to strap on pads. That or an inveterate gambler with an iffy bouncer.

fields.headline: Yorkshire thrive on banana power
fields.standfirst:
Surrey 226
Yorkshire 33-1
fields.trailText:
Surrey 226
Yorkshire 33-1.
fields.body:
The championship season might just have passed its mid-point but for Yorkshire it has already reached the critical phase. They have faded too often in recent seasons for their recent indifferent form not to cloud the county in pessimism.

For Yorkshire to respond by overturning Surrey, reinstalled as leaders and defending their title with their usual bullishness, represents a monumental but probably essential task.

At least they could take heart from a productive beginning, dismissing Surrey for 226 and finishing on 33 for one in 19.5 overs, the fall of David Byas at silly point to the concluding ball of the day being a harbinger of the threat they will face from the spinners Saqlain Mushtaq and Ian Salisbury as the match progresses.

Surrey have won their last three matches, two by an innings, and are embarking on a run of four home games. Their sense of well-being was disturbed yesterday, though, by Ryan Sidebottom, the left-arm fast-medium bowler with the famous Yorkshire CCC lineage and insubordinate hairstyle of a 70s rock star, who took his fourth five-wicket haul in six innings.

Sidebottom has the ability to swing the ball late and, if his wonderful form - and smoother run-up - continues, it will be uplifting news not just for Yorkshire but also for the economy of the Windward Islands.

By lunch Sidebottom had munched so many bananas on the third-man boundary that it was remarkable every fielder managed to reach the dressing room without mishap. Graham Clinton, the former Surrey opener and famously hospitalised in every first-class county, would have been un-insurable.

The Oval pitches are a blessing, their pace and bounce giving them a quality rarely seen elsewhere. Matthew Hoggard was another Yorkshire seamer enlivened by the challenge. For all his England Test debut, Hoggard remains uncapped by Yorkshire, and committeemen gripe harshly about inconsistency. Four wickets, including Ian Ward, who clung on through 36 overs for 28, was a sound response.

But it was Sidebottom's wickets that stood out. The off-stump yorker that unhinged Nadeem Shahid gave Yorkshire the second wicket that their sparky pre-lunch efforts deserved and late in-dip ended Martin Bicknell's innings of infuriating glides and deflections after he had rescued Surrey from 148 for seven.

Sidebottom also claimed both Hollioake brothers, which for many county bowlers is as good as being the child in the playground Pokémon game who has just destroyed Charizard and Blastoise in one move.

Adam held Surrey together throughout the afternoon, although he should have been caught by Anthony McGrath on 11 when he hooked Chris Silverwood to long leg. He moved vigorously to 48 before he nicked one to the wicketkeeper.

Ben flicked languidly to square leg where Gary Fellows held the catch to the sighs that forever communicate the Ben Hollioake, Great Underachiever message.

Ben also caused Yorkshire's most heart-stopping moment when his square drive, stopped by Michael Vaughan at backward point, brought frantic signalling for the physio Carol Becker but fortunately no further damage to the thumb injury that has disrupted his season.

Four wickets, including Ian Ward, who clung on through 36 overs for 28, was a sound response. But it was Sidebottom's wickets that stood out. The off-stump yorker that unhinged Nadeem Shahid gave Yorkshire the second wicket that their sparky pre-lunch efforts deserved and late in-dip ended Martin Bicknell's innings of infuriating glides and deflections after he had rescued Surrey from 148 for seven. Sidebottom also claimed both Hollioake brothers, which for many county bowlers is as good as being the child in the playground Pokémon game who has just destroyed Charizard and Blastoise in one move. Adam held Surrey together throughout the afternoon, although he should have been caught by Anthony McGrath on 11 when he hooked Chris Silverwood to long leg. He moved vigorously to 48 before he nicked one to the wicketkeeper. Ben flicked languidly to square leg where Gary Fellows held the catch to the sighs that forever communicate the Ben Hollioake, Great Underachiever message. Ben also caused Yorkshire's most heart-stopping moment when his square drive, stopped by Michael Vaughan at backward point, brought frantic signalling for the physio Carol Becker but fortunately no further damage to the thumb injury that has disrupted his season.

webTitle: Confident Cork struggles to keep Kent bottled up

fields.headline: Confident Cork struggles to keep Kent bottled up
fields.standfirst:
Derby 181
Kent 27-1
fields.trailText:
Derby 181
Kent 27-1
fields.body:
It is only July but the county game's latest creation, the relegation 40-pointer, is already being contested by these two struggling sides. Both are in the First Division's bottom three and after a day on which 11 wickets fell, one of them should gain a valuable win before Saturday evening. And despite the efforts of Dominic Cork, Kent appear much the better placed.

Derbyshire are clearly benefiting from the confidence Cork has gained from his match-winning performance in the second Test at Lord's. In the previous championship match against Lancashire he took six for 41 and made 52. Here he scored his second half-century of the season. They will miss their captain when he is on England duty in August.

At least England's one-day squad for the current triangular tournament was picked before Cork's heroics at Lord's. "I'd love to be involved," he said. "Five years ago I would expect to be in the side but no longer. I've got no hard feelings about anything."

Only once in his 141-ball innings did he look seriously troubled. He needed treatment after being struck on the left boot by a Martin Saggers delivery when he had made four. The whole of England held its breath but he got up to stroke his next ball for four.

His batting contrasted with what came before. There was help for the seam bowlers in the first hour and Saggers made good use of the new ball but Derbyshire's batsmen underachieved on a slow pitch.

Saggers took three wickets in his opening spell of 10 overs to return his best figures of a modest season, four for 62. Steve Titchard, almost caught at backward point in his first over, was neatly taken at third slip by Min Patel in his next. Luke Sutton edged to Rahul Dravid at first slip and Simon Lacey gloved a leg-side catch to the wicketkeeper Paul Nixon.

At the other end, Michael Di Venuto presented Ben Trott with his first championship wicket for Kent. The Australian drove extravagantly at Trott's 11th delivery and was caught behind.

It was left to a semi-Australian to effect a recovery. Steve Stubbings - born in Huddersfield, raised in Victoria - endured for four hours before driving loosely to Robert Key at cover, the first of three wickets in three overs for David Masters. Seventy-two runs had been gathered with admirable application.

Patel claimed the last two wickets after tying down one end for 27 miserly overs. Tim Munton lost patience and drove to extra-cover and Cork, aiming a leg-side blow, sent the ball to Dravid at slip.

When Kent batted, David Fulton was aggrieved to be given out caught behind in Munton's first over. Somerset's players will note with interest Fulton's displeasure at Merv Kitchen's decision. Twelve days ago in Maidstone the opener escaped after a plausible appeal for a catch at the wicket was turned down; he went on to score a century.

Bad light spared Kent their full allocation of overs. Eight remained to be bowled when Cork risked a bouncer against Key. Derbyshire's captain clearly thought he had done enough for one day.

webTitle: Atherton enjoys his time out for the county

fields.headline: Atherton enjoys his time out for the county
fields.standfirst:
Lancashire 239
Somerset 48-0
fields.trailText:
Lancashire 239
Somerset 48-0.
fields.body:
Six months or so ago, Mike Atherton woke thousands of county members from their winter slumber by questioning the value of the championship. How ironic it would be if he were now to help Lancashire win it for the first time since 1934.

Atherton's contribution to the Lancashire cause this past decade had always been the subject of much debate. But his omission from England's one-day squad will allow him to play in four consecutive championship matches at the height of the season for the first time since his Test debut in 1989, and the way he batted here indicated not only what Lancashire have been missing over the years but also what a bonus his presence may be in the coming weeks.

Lancashire were put in and lost four wickets before lunch on a seaming pitch, but Atherton was masterful in reaching a 73-ball half-century with seven fours and two hooked sixes off Steffan Jones, one of which landed in the car park.

There were only two minor scares, both off Peter Trego, Somerset's skiddy new seamer who was named in the England Under-19 squad this week. But Atherton was predictably unruffled in reaching his first 50 in 11 championship innings since a magnificent unbeaten 268 against Glamorgan in Blackpool almost exactly a year ago when the conditions were much more friendly.

After lunch he cruised serenely into three figures from 140 balls with seven more boundaries. It was the 51st first-class century of his career but only his 24th in the championship for Lancashire, with only five of them in the past five years, which tells its own story.

He did not, however, receive much support. Early on John Crawley was bowled shouldering arms to Jones, and Trego claimed the scalps of Sourav Ganguly and Graham Lloyd in a lively spell - the wicket of Ganguly especially welcome for those Somerset members who remembered his 183 here in the World Cup last summer.

But Lancashire were still sitting pretty at 214 for four when rain forced an early tea, the Australian Joe Scuderi contributing a championship-best 46 to a fifth-wicket stand of 112 with Atherton.

Then Keith Parsons started to wobble his occasional medium-pacers in the evening gloom and took career-best figures of five for 13 as the last six wickets tumbled for 23. Lancashire were willing accomplices, for although Atherton was deceived by in-swing and Warren Hegg trapped half- forward, both Scuderi and Glen Chapple slashed wide half-volleys to backward point and Chris Schofield drove loosely at Jones for Peter Bowler to take a juggling catch off Rob Turner's left glove.

Parsons, who had previously managed a single first-class wicket this summer at a cost of 214, accepted his presents gratefully and then took a sharp one-handed return catch to dismiss Gary Keedy for a duck and end the Lancashire innings.

An untroubled opening stand between Jamie Cox and Mark Lathwell, on his second game back from serious knee ligament problems, completed an excellent day for a Somerset team without Andy Caddick and Marcus Trescothick, if not, in the end, for Lancashire's title hopes.

webTitle: Arsenal back Edu despite forged passport

fields.headline: Arsenal back Edu despite forged passport
fields.trailText: The proposed £6m transfer of the Brazilian midfielder Edu to Arsenal, thrown into doubt when he was refused entry to Britain on Tuesday with a forged Portuguese passport, is back on.
fields.byline: Simon Burnton  and Alex Bellos  in Rio de Janeiro
fields.body:
The proposed £6m transfer of the Brazilian midfielder Edu to Arsenal, thrown into doubt when he was refused entry to Britain on Tuesday with a forged Portuguese passport, is back on.

According to his father Edu has a Portuguese grandfather named Manuel Gaspar. That would make him eligible for a passport and with it EU status.

When Edu signed for Arsenal a week ago he held only a Brazilian passport. To avoid having to apply for a work permit it was decided that he should get Portuguese papers, a process that can take months. His agent, Juan Figger, undertook to sort this out and returned with the passport in a matter of days. It now appears this had been forged.

But an Arsenal spokeswoman yesterday confirmed the club were willing to wait for their man. "We still want him and are hopeful that he will be able to join the squad shortly," she said. "It's just a matter of time." Figger has promised genuine papers by tomorrow.

It appears that the forgery came to light only because Edu, who had entered on a Brazilian passport for his medical and planned to do the same on Tuesday, decided to use his Portuguese papers when he saw the queue for non-EU passport control at Heathrow.

This is the latest in a rash of forgery cases in football. The most high-profile of them involves Juan Veron, Lazio's Argentina midfielder, and the former Derby County striker Esteban Fuertes, who was turned away by immigration officials last November with a forged Spanish passport and never played for the club again.

"This is part of a problem which is only going to get worse," said Gordon Taylor of the Professional Footballers' Association. "We have had arranged marriages; now it seems to be forged passports."

In a presumably unconnected move Sao Paulo yesterday decided not to sell their Brazilian defender Edmilson to Arsenal.

webTitle: Toner gives Welsh champions partial solution

fields.headline: Toner gives Welsh champions partial solution
fields.standfirst: Maloney 58, Toner 89 | Bragin 51, Krasnopjorov 88
fields.trailText: The Total Network Solutions dream of making history by becoming the first League of Wales side to reach the second qualifying round of the Champions League is still alive.
fields.body:
The Total Network Solutions dream of making history by becoming the first League of Wales side to reach the second qualifying round of the Champions League is still alive.

A goal a minute from time when substitute Nicky Ward sent in John Toner for a dramatic equaliser crowned a spirited performance by the village side after Andrei Krasnopjorov's close-range shot had seemed to kill off the tie less than a minute earlier.

After being outplayed in the first half, TNS fell behind soon after the interval before staging a remarkable comeback.

TNS made their intentions clear by threading five men across midfield and leaving Toner as their lone striker.

As befits a side 10 points clear at the top of their league at the halfway stage of the Estonian season, Levadia settled quickly into their stride. In the fourth minute, Indro Olumets' fierce shot was beaten away by Lee Williams at the near post. Anthony Wright then had to deflect a spectacular Sergei Bragin volley for a corner.

But the part-timers of Llansantffraid-ym-Mechain had their moments. Edwards flashed a header across goal and then Toner's sidefooted shot was well saved by Sergei Pareiko, one of six internationals in the Levadia side.

Ten minutes before the break, a poor back-pass let in Toner but, after rounding Pareiko he shot into the side netting from an acute angle.

The overworked TNS defence cracked six minutes into the second half. When a corner landed at his feet 25 yards out, Bragin sent a sweet, low, left-foot volley past Williams.

A masterstroke of a substitution provided the home side with an unlikely equaliser on the hour. Michael Maloney left the bench to take a right-wing corner which skidded across the goal for Wright to head home from close range.

Total Network Solutions FC (4-5-1): Williams; Parry, Edwards, Evans, Coathup; Powell (Maloney, 58min), Alexander, Roberts, Edge (Webster, 83), Wright (Ward, 78); Toner.

Levadia Maardu (4-4-2): Pareiko; Vinogradov, Prins, Staleliunas, Krasnopjorov; Leitan (Tselnokov, 72), Bragin, Rotskov, Kolbasenko; Olumets, Fenin (Krom, 64).

Referee: J Micallef (Malta)

fields.headline: Big-spending Lazio snap up Fiore
fields.trailText: The Italian champions Lazio continued their summer spending spree yesterday when they announced the signing of the midfielders Stefano Fiore and Giuliano Giannichedda from Udinese for a combined fee of £29m.
fields.body:
The Italian champions Lazio continued their summer spending spree yesterday when they announced the signing of the midfielders Stefano Fiore and Giuliano Giannichedda from Udinese for a combined fee of £29m.

The move came one day after Lazio announced the capture of the Argentine striker Hernan Crespo in a deal worth a world-record £36m.

Although two midfielders, Matias Almeyda and Sergio Conceicao, were makeweights in that deal, yesterday's signings are unlikely to replace them in next season's line-up as the club said it was negotiating to loan both players back to Udinese for next season before bringing them to Rome for the 2001-2002 campaign.

Instead the Roman club appear to have turned to Barcelona's Dutch midfielder Boudewijn Zenden, according to Italian press reports which suggest an £8.6m deal is close to being finalised.

Fiore had an excellent season for Udinese and was one of the best players in Italy's march to the Euro 2000 final. Giannichedda briefly broke into the national side last year.

Lazio have already spent £17.5m bringing the Argentine striker Claudio Lopez from Valencia and they bought the goalkeeper Angelo Peruzzi from Internazionale for £10.7m. The club have also signed the Sampdoria defender Emanuele Pesaresi for £4m.

Tottenham have called for the FA to punish players rather than clubs for misbehaviour on the pitch after having their appeal against a record £150,000 fine dismissed yesterday. The fine was imposed after an 18-man brawl during a Premiership game at Elland Road on February 12. Leeds were fined the same sum.

Spurs' press officer John Fennelly said the club was disappointed: "No club can control the actions of their players on the pitch. The only solution to the problem of player misbehaviour is to punish the players themselves."

The Middlesbrough manager Bryan Robson has been fined £7,500, warned and asked for a written assurance about his future conduct over his confrontation with the referee Neale Barry during last season's defeat at Coventry.

The Cambridge striker Trevor Benjamin has signed for Leicester in a deal which could eventually earn the Second Division club £1.5m. The former England defender Tony Dorigo has joined Stoke from Derby on a free transfer. Mitch Ward has joined Barnsley from Everton for £200,000 and Sheffield Wednesday's Lee Briscoe has moved to Burnley on a free.

 President Thabo Mbeki of South Africa renewed his criticism of Fifa yesterday for awarding the 2006 World Cup to Germany, saying the decision "shattered the hopes of our people and the peoples of Africa". "When will some in Europe be ready to accept that Africa is part of the global human family, and not an irrelevant appendage?" he said.

webTitle: Flintoff and Hick hurry England to victory

fields.headline: Flintoff and Hick hurry England to victory
fields.standfirst:
Zimbabwe 114 (38.4 overs)
England 115 for 2 (20.3 overs)
England won by eight wickets
fields.trailText: England have recovered some of the pride they lost over the weekend with a thumping eight-wicket victory over Zimbabwe at Old Trafford. After dismissing the Zims for 114 in the 39th over, they raced to a crucial win with almost 30 overs to spare. It was England's first day/nighter in this country - but the lights were hardly needed. England now have three points from three games, two more than West Indies and with a significantly better run-rate.
fields.body:
England have recovered some of the pride they lost over the weekend with a thumping eight-wicket victory over Zimbabwe at Old Trafford. After dismissing the Zims for 114 in the 39th over, they raced to a crucial win with almost 30 overs to spare. It was England's first day/nighter in this country - but the lights were hardly needed. England now have three points from three games, two more than West Indies and with a significantly better run-rate.

Zimbabwe had won the toss and elected to bat on a firm wicket. It was the right decision at the time, and when the 50 came up in the 15th over for the loss of Neil Johnson, caught behind off Andy Caddick for 7, and Guy Whittall, also held by Alec Stewart, off Darren Gough, for 15, Zimbabwe were all set for the onslaught.

It never happened. England, inspired by Alan Mullally and Mark Ealham, bowled a superbly disciplined line outside offstump. The runs dried up and the wickets began to fall.

Alistair Campbell started the collapse by running himself out for 10 after having second thoughts about a sharp single and failing to beat Marcus Trescothick's return to Stewart from short square-leg. That made it 55 for 3. Six miserly overs later, it was 64 for 4 when Murray Goodwin (21) aimed a cut at Ealham but had his off-bail trimmed as the ball jagged back into him.

Mullally put an end to a comical six-ball slog from Bryan Strang by bowling him off the bottom edge for a single (65 for 5), and then had Grant Flower caught behind for a duck in his next over to leave the Zims in the mire at 65 for 6.

Andy Flower momentarily broke the shackles by cutting Gough for four - Zimbabwe's first boundary for 21 overs - and the 100 came up in the 34th over as he and Stuart Carlisle forced the pace. Even so, Ealham completed the tidiest of spells with figures of 10-4-19-1.

But the end came as swiftly as a Brett Lee bouncer. Craig White had Andy Flower caught behind for 28, then dismissed Dirk Viljoen the same way four balls later. And Trescothick, in his second over in international cricket, had Carlisle caught behind - to give Stewart a world-record-equalling sixth catch in one-dayers - and Paul Strang leg before first ball. The last four wickets had fallen for no runs in nine balls.

England wasted no time in reply. Trescothick slapped Johnson for four through point in the third over, and Stewart cut Bryan Strang for another boundary three overs later.

Zimbabwe fought back in the ninth over when Heath Streak won a bizarre leg before decision from umpire Holder: he appealed after the ball hit Stewart's pads, gave up when the umpire appeared not to respond, then turned round to discover he had been successful after all. Streak raised his eyebrows in surprise and Stewart trudged off, shaking his head. For the third consecutive one-day innings he had been dismissed for 12, and England were 28 for 1.

Andy Flintoff, with a point to prove after recent media stories surrounding his girth, was promoted to No.3 and got off the mark with a well-timed cover-driven boundary off Bryan Strang.

Then Trescothick got to work. Giving himself room outside leg, he mowed Whittall's first ball over long-off for six, before punching his third through the covers for four and pulling his fourth for four more.

But Streak struck back for Zimbabwe with the first ball of his next over, trapping Trescothick leg before for 29 with a ball that probably pitched just outside leg stump to make it 57 for 2.

That was as good as it got for Zimbabwe. Flintoff thrashed Streak through the covers for four, then on-drove him with perfect timing to the boundary in Streak's next over. Legspinner Paul Strang was introduced into the attack, and Flintoff launched him meatily over cow corner for six, a shot he repeated two overs later. At last Freddie was playing without the inhibitions that have marked his international career to date. And his home crowd were loving it.

Hick completed the rout by smacking Strang through the covers for four, then lifting him for the biggest six of the day the ball after and cutting the next delivery for the winning run. Hick finished unbeaten on 23, while Flintoff was not out 42, from just 45 balls. It was enough to give him the match award. Not bad for a fat boy, as he himself said in the post-match interview.

England and Zimbabwe are now equal at seven one-day wins each. If only it was always this easy.

Lawrence Booth is assistant editor of wisden.com
fields.bodyText: England have recovered some of the pride they lost over the weekend with a thumping eight-wicket victory over Zimbabwe at Old Trafford. After dismissing the Zims for 114 in the 39th over, they raced to a crucial win with almost 30 overs to spare. It was England's first day/nighter in this country - but the lights were hardly needed. England now have three points from three games, two more than West Indies and with a significantly better run-rate. Zimbabwe had won the toss and elected to bat on a firm wicket. It was the right decision at the time, and when the 50 came up in the 15th over for the loss of Neil Johnson, caught behind off Andy Caddick for 7, and Guy Whittall, also held by Alec Stewart, off Darren Gough, for 15, Zimbabwe were all set for the onslaught. It never happened. England, inspired by Alan Mullally and Mark Ealham, bowled a superbly disciplined line outside offstump. The runs dried up and the wickets began to fall. Alistair Campbell started the collapse by running himself out for 10 after having second thoughts about a sharp single and failing to beat Marcus Trescothick's return to Stewart from short square-leg. That made it 55 for 3. Six miserly overs later, it was 64 for 4 when Murray Goodwin (21) aimed a cut at Ealham but had his off-bail trimmed as the ball jagged back into him. Mullally put an end to a comical six-ball slog from Bryan Strang by bowling him off the bottom edge for a single (65 for 5), and then had Grant Flower caught behind for a duck in his next over to leave the Zims in the mire at 65 for 6. Andy Flower momentarily broke the shackles by cutting Gough for four - Zimbabwe's first boundary for 21 overs - and the 100 came up in the 34th over as he and Stuart Carlisle forced the pace. Even so, Ealham completed the tidiest of spells with figures of 10-4-19-1. But the end came as swiftly as a Brett Lee bouncer. Craig White had Andy Flower caught behind for 28, then dismissed Dirk Viljoen the same way four balls later. And Trescothick, in his second over in international cricket, had Carlisle caught behind - to give Stewart a world-record-equalling sixth catch in one-dayers - and Paul Strang leg before first ball. The last four wickets had fallen for no runs in nine balls. England wasted no time in reply. Trescothick slapped Johnson for four through point in the third over, and Stewart cut Bryan Strang for another boundary three overs later. Zimbabwe fought back in the ninth over when Heath Streak won a bizarre leg before decision from umpire Holder: he appealed after the ball hit Stewart's pads, gave up when the umpire appeared not to respond, then turned round to discover he had been successful after all. Streak raised his eyebrows in surprise and Stewart trudged off, shaking his head. For the third consecutive one-day innings he had been dismissed for 12, and England were 28 for 1. Andy Flintoff, with a point to prove after recent media stories surrounding his girth, was promoted to No.3 and got off the mark with a well-timed cover-driven boundary off Bryan Strang. Then Trescothick got to work. Giving himself room outside leg, he mowed Whittall's first ball over long-off for six, before punching his third through the covers for four and pulling his fourth for four more. But Streak struck back for Zimbabwe with the first ball of his next over, trapping Trescothick leg before for 29 with a ball that probably pitched just outside leg stump to make it 57 for 2. That was as good as it got for Zimbabwe. Flintoff thrashed Streak through the covers for four, then on-drove him with perfect timing to the boundary in Streak's next over. Legspinner Paul Strang was introduced into the attack, and Flintoff launched him meatily over cow corner for six, a shot he repeated two overs later. At last Freddie was playing without the inhibitions that have marked his international career to date. And his home crowd were loving it. Hick completed the rout by smacking Strang through the covers for four, then lifting him for the biggest six of the day the ball after and cutting the next delivery for the winning run. Hick finished unbeaten on 23, while Flintoff was not out 42, from just 45 balls. It was enough to give him the match award. Not bad for a fat boy, as he himself said in the post-match interview. England and Zimbabwe are now equal at seven one-day wins each. If only it was always this easy. Lawrence Booth is assistant editor of wisden.com

fields.headline: The moral maze
fields.standfirst: 'You're never going to please everyone' say the duo behind the Patriot. They attempt to persuade Xan Brooks why the critics have got them, and their movie, wrong.
fields.trailText: 'You're never going to please everyone' say the duo behind the Patriot. They attempt to persuade Xan Brooks why the critics have got them, and their movie, wrong.
fields.body:
It used to be that the ultimate in salesmanship was selling sand to the Arabs. These days it may be a case of flogging The Patriot to the British. Camped in a London hotel suite, director Roland Emmerich and producer Dean Devlin seem oddly unperturbed by the task ahead. No, they say, they haven't encountered many rabid limey journalists as yet. Yes, they're sanguine over the attention the film has received thus far. "So long as they spell the film's name right, they can keep right on talking about it," quips Devlin. Needless to say, the talk looks set to continue.

After all, few Hollywood blockbusters of recent years have drawn quite the same heat of criticism as The Patriot. Certainly not the lumbering Godzilla, Devlin and Emmerich's last mega-budget collaboration; nor the adept Independence Day (the one before that). But on this occasion the erstwhile kings of multiplex cinema have forsaken their traditional sci-fi japery for a serious-minded yarn that's rooted in historical reality.

The Patriot carves a course through the turbulent years of the American War of Independence. In doing so it casts Mel Gibson as a revolutionary war hero and replaces the invading aliens or Japanese monsters of old with a swarming army of evil English redcoats. The film's Brit-bashing has understandably raised press hackles over here. But The Patriot's uneasy marriage of history with Hollywood has landed it in all kind of other trouble. What should have been a tea-party has blossomed by degrees into a veritable riot of charge and counter-charge.

The result is that an interview with Emmerich (the film's laid-back, German-born director) and Devlin (its mercurial, wisecracking producer) soon shoots off on what is to become a permanent detour. They'd rather talk about the impressively staged battle scenes and the quality of Mel's acting. Instead, they find themselves forced to defend their picture, point-by-point, against accusations ranging from fascism to racism.

Let's first look at Jonathan Foreman's scathing attack in Salon, which damned The Patriot for painting the English army as "cartoonish paragons of evil", and went on to remark that the picture was fascist. "If the Nazis had won the war in Europe," Foreman claimed, ". . .The Patriot is exactly the movie you could expect to see."

Mention of the f-word prompts Emmerich to draw heavily on his cigarette. "That's pretty hard to deal with," he drawls in an accent one-part Berlin versus two-parts Beverly Hills. "I would have to talk about what I've learned all my life about fascism in my own country. But [Foreman's] using the word 'fascism' very lightly." Devlin agrees: "It's a real disrespect to those people who've actually suffered under fascism. It's not really worthy of our comment."

To call The Patriot a fascist movie may be stretching things, but the film's glossy re-ordering of history still raises troublesome issues. Possibly its UK success depends on your own feelings about the American War of Independence. Triumph of liberty and democracy, or - to quote the hippie history teacher in Richard Linklater's Dazed and Confused - "a bunch of slave-owning, aristocratic white males who didn't want to pay their taxes" ? Resistance to England's taxation of a slave-owning economy was central to the War of Independence. Its heroes were predominantly wealthy plantation owners who saw their slaves switch sides and fight with the English army against them.

In tidying up its tale, The Patriot opts to gloss over this side of the story. Spike Lee, for one, is not impressed (see our news story). In a damning letter to The Hollywood Reporter, the Afro-American director dismissed Emmerich and Devlin's film as "pure blatant Hollywood propaganda; a complete whitewashing of history." Lee continued: "When talking about the history of this great country, one can never forget that America was built upon the genocide of the Native Americans and the enslavement of African people. To say otherwise is criminal."

Devlin shakes his head. "Look, there is a very interesting movie to be made about the American Revolution, and when Spike Lee wants to make it I'll be the first in line to see it. But this is not that movie. It's one man's story. It's the story of a man trying to protect his family." Emmerich: "If we were making a film about the Revolution we would have made a film about George Washington. This is more in the tradition of Gone With the Wind or The Last of the Mohicans. The historical event is a backdrop."

Lee, however, was particularly incensed by the rose-tinted presentation of Gibson's character (a South Carolina landowner) as a tolerant soul morally opposed to slavery.

Gibson's character is based on true-life revolutionary hero Francis Marion. However, a bit of homework revealed that Marion was actually a slave-owner who raped his slaves and hunted Indians for fun (see our news story). A spot of hasty re-writing was called for, and Francis Marion became Benjamin Martin.

"Yes, we fictionalised him," admits Devlin. "He's a fictional character. Look, when we started this movie we believed that everyone at the time of the Revolution was of the same opinion about slavery. And they weren't. Slavery was a hotbed even then. There was a small minority of farmers in South Carolina who made a moral choice not have slaves and to hire free men. So we thought: 'If we're going to turn this man into a hero, should we take one who's a slave-owner and inherently a racist, or should we put the spotlight on somebody who made that moral choice?'. We thought it was more responsible. Now Spike Lee's upset about that. Would he rather we made a hero out of a slave-owner? I just don't understand the logic."

In a sense the man's confusion is understandable. It typifies America's greatest dilemma. The contradiction that lies at the very heart of the country: a great libertarian community forged on the back of slave labour.

So how does your average movie-maker tackle this incongruity? Does he make a warts-and-all overview of the War of Independence and risk offending Middle America, or does he airbrush away the unpleasant bits and find themselves accused of irresponsibly doctoring the facts? The Patriot, by and large, has gone for the second option. In doing so it has reaped the rewards in box-office, and paid the price in adverse criticism. "Whatever you do," sighs Devlin, "you're never going to please everyone."

Next Devlin and Emmerich are taking a back-seat away from the front-lineof film-making. The duo are currently preparing to produce a monster movie about giant spiders who invade a small Nevada township. "I think it's going to be a lot of fun and a real change of pace," Emmerich says happily. Humans versus monsters. Good Americans versus evil spiders. The moral terrain, thankfully, is much more clear-cut.

webTitle: Sketch: Ooh, Betty: Speaker's retirement shocks MPs

fields.headline: Ooh, Betty: Speaker's retirement shocks MPs
fields.trailText:
"Order, order!" shouted Betty Boothroyd . Most MPs did not even know
        that this was one of the last times she will have cleared the tubes with her
        famous catchphrase.
fields.body:
"Order, order!" shouted Betty Boothroyd . Most MPs did not even know that this was one of the last times she will have cleared the tubes with her famous catchphrase.

What I've always liked is the way that when she is genuinely angry, the genteel voice fades and her Yorkshire accent returns, like a barmaid declaring that she will throw you buggers out if she doesn't get a bit of hush - Sue Lawley turns into Annie Walker.

She then announced that, after eight years, she would retire as Speaker just before the next session begins. It was a tremendous shock. For some Tories, it must have been like hearing that nanny is leaving to get married. They'd pretend to be happy for her, but inside they'd be screaming "what about me?".

Betty then said that she would also resign from her seat in West Bromwich West. A startled "ooh" swept round the chamber, and you can bet there were plenty of MPs who at that point could actually recall her majority when she was last opposed by a Tory (7,830 should be just about safe barring another rise in petrol tax).

But she clearly thought the "ooh" was one of dismay, because she departed from her script and said passionately, "Be happy for me!" - and for the first time I have ever heard, the House of Commons started clapping.

It was an extraordinary sight and an extraordinary sound. Clapping is not what they do. You are simply not supposed to clap, in the same way as you are not meant to throw toilet rolls.

You can go "year, year, year" like a manatee with indigestion. You may shout and jeer and yell. You can wave your order paper in the air. You can even, like Le Petomane, fart Frere Jacques, and you will find nothing to forbid it in Erskine May.

But against all the rules they clapped, wildly, with warmth and gratitude and affection, as if she were Judi Dench at the Oscars, Shirley Bassey on the Des O'Connor Show, or the Williams sisters at Wimbledon.

Or at least the Labour and Liberal benches clapped. Some strange atavistic impulse stopped almost all the Tories from joining in (Michael Ancram and Ann Widdecombe did clap, but in a rather tired, thanks-due-to-our-hon-sec kind of way). Did the rest imagine that on this day of all days the Speaker would reprove them?

Betty does not - how can I put this - have serious problems with her self-esteem, and I suspect she was awfully pleased to find that the announcement of her going was greeted by a total break-down in parliamentary order.

Then Margaret Beckett announced that there would be a full valediction in a fortnight, allowing Betty to represent the house in Ukraine, New York, Scotland and other foreign climes. (In the US I saw, on Saturday Night Live, a take-off of our own prime minister's question time, based on the assumption that viewers would recognise it. That's like Rory Bremner spoofing the Danish parliament and expecting us to get the gags.)

Mrs Beckett added that the election of Speaker will be held when the house returns for autumn, when the father of the house - Ted Heath - will take the chair. So instead of the Speaker saying, "Order, order!" MPs will have to yell "Wakey, wakey!"

MPs filed away to discuss the succession. They love elections for Speaker they can conspire and wheedle and trade without caring two hoots what their constituents think.

Oh, and thanks to the Tory u-turn on taxes, Tony Blair did much better at question time, which left his troops in a very good mood, with a leader who looks once more like a winner, and 15 blissful weeks of plotting to come.

Politics, page 11

David McKie, page 19
