fields.headline: Speaker's decision takes MPs unawares
fields.trailText: The Speaker, Betty Boothroyd , drew gasps and sparked an unprecedented burst of applause across the Commons floor and public gallery yesterday when she announced she was standing down as Speaker this autumn after eight turbulent years in the post.
fields.byline: By: Patrick Wintour, chief political correspondent
fields.body:
The Speaker, Betty Boothroyd , drew gasps and sparked an unprecedented burst of applause across the Commons floor and public gallery yesterday when she announced she was standing down as Speaker this autumn after eight turbulent years in the post.

She had been expected to continue at least until the election, but she told MPs she wanted to retire earlier, partly so the present crop of MPs could choose her successor. Her decision will prompt a by election in her West Bromwich constituency, where Labour party members are keen to select an Asian or black candidate. With many MPs expressing their sadness with sighs and low moans as she made her retirement announcement, she said to laughter: "Be happy for me."

It was announced she would make a valedictory address on July 26 before the summer recess, when she is likely to let loose some of her frustration at the growing dominance of the executive, the gradual decline in importance of the Commons chamber, and the tendency for government ministers to make their announcements outside the Commons. Ms Boothroyd is 70, smokes heavily, and has suffered a minor stomach ailment, but illness did not prompt her decision. Her successor will be elected when MPs return on October 23, prompting months of discreet electioneering. The vote will be presided over by Sir Edward Heath, father of the house. The Conservative party will argue it is its turn to take the Speakership, but two Liberal Democrat MPs, Alan Beith and Menzies Campbell, are also being touted.

The televised coverage of Commons proceedings has made Ms Boothroyd a national symbol and she is often cited in polls as the public's first choice for president if the country ever became a republic.

Leading an early flood of tributes, Tony Blair said: "She is a really outstanding Speaker, not just because she is sharp and to the point but because she has a marvellous way of using humour and fun to try to deflect really difficult situations. She will be really missed, deeply missed, on all sides of the house."

The Liberal Democrat leader, Charles Kennedy, said: "She has been a magnificent ambassador for parliamentary democracy in this country." Former prime minister John Major said Ms Boothroyd had been "outstanding" and was a hard act to follow.

Sir Alan Haselhurst, the Deputy Speaker, has been installed as even-money favourite by William Hill to become Ms Boothroyd's successor. Labour MP John McWilliam (Blaydon) became the first to declare his candidacyt, but few rate his chances.

fields.headline: Ministers admit dome was mistake
fields.trailText: The two government ministers in charge of the Millennium Dome yesterday attempted to distance themselves from the flagging attraction when they admitted it should never have been built in its present form.
fields.body:
The two government ministers in charge of the Millennium Dome yesterday attempted to distance themselves from the flagging attraction when they admitted it should never have been built in its present form.

The culture secretary, Chris Smith , said he had never wanted the dome to be built, and the dome minister, Lord Falconer, admitted the government would have chosen "a different proposal" if it had had more accurate forecasts of visitor numbers than the 12m originally envisaged for the £758m project. Just 6m visitors are now expected.

Both ministers made their comments in evidence to the Commons culture, media and sport committee, which is investigating the dome problems.

Mr Smith, as chairman of the millennium commission, has overall responsibility for the dome and was forced to bail the dome out with an extra £29m of public money in May. He told MPs: "I had recommended that we should go ahead with something perhaps smaller, and more educationally focused, than we in fact ended up with."

Sources close to Mr Smith, whose commission has provided £539m of national lottery cash, confirmed that he had argued against the ideas for the dome in 1997. But the government decided to continue with the plans initiated by the last Tory regime after Tony Blair and Peter Mandelson won the argument against opposition from the chancellor, Gordon Brown.

Mr Smith's statement to the cross-party committee was the first time he has broken cabinet ranks to publicly admit his disapproval of the project, although he added that he had "happily" backed the dome when it was decided to proceed with it.

Lord Falconer owns the sole share in the New Millennium Experience Company, which built and runs the dome .

He told MPs: "I had recommended that we should go ahead with something perhaps smaller, and more educationally focused, than we in fact ended up with." Sources close to Mr Smith, whose commission has provided £539m of national lottery cash, confirmed that he had argued against the ideas for the dome in 1997. But the government decided to continue with the plans initiated by the last Tory regime after Tony Blair and Peter Mandelson won the argument against opposition from the chancellor, Gordon Brown. Mr Smith's statement to the cross-party committee was the first time he has broken cabinet ranks to publicly admit his disapproval of the project, although he added that he had "happily" backed the dome when it was decided to proceed with it. Lord Falconer owns the sole share in the New Millennium Experience Company, which built and runs the dome .

fields.headline: Winning back the people
fields.standfirst:
Frustrated by what it sees as its failure to penetrate a wall of cynicism in its efforts to convince voters of its achievements, the government has adopted a new style in its annual report, reports Madeleine Bunting.
Blair spells out Labour successes
fields.trailText: Frustrated by what it sees as its failure to penetrate a wall of cynicism in its efforts to convince voters of its achievements, the government has adopted a new style in its annual report, reports Madeleine Bunting.
fields.body:
The government is trying a new tack. Frustrated by what it sees as its failure to penetrate a wall of cynicism in its efforts to convince voters of its achievements, it has adopted a new style in its annual report. Out go the politicians, out go the big numbers, in comes an intimate chatty collection of tales of ordinary folk. So we get to hear about David Bardsley who is a driver on the Manchester Metrolink and Sue Trott who runs a restaurant in Newton Abbott.

Tony Blair has been accused of soap opera politics with himself at the centre of the plot. This is the government's attempt to shift the Blair Family - Euan, Leo and Cherie - from centre stage and bring on a huge supporting cast of what it describes as government "frontline staff". But this is more than just a marketing gimmick, it is about personalising government. It is trying to re-establish the trust and respect for government by getting people to see the human face of government - the teachers, doctors, nurses who deliver public services. It is an attempt to bypass the problem that politicians have lost credibility.

It's an astute move. Given that while people have little time for politicians or politics, they are often hugely grateful to dedicated public sector workers such as doctors and teachers. Whether this will win them back into loving the government is another matter. Grudges can last a long time and the voters have yet to forgive what the government now admits was a mistaken tone and presentational style early on in this parliament. Part of the reason for the current cynicism is the government's own triumphalism of the first 100 days, its declarations of policies as if the problems they were designed to address were almost solved. That sat at odds with people's day to day experience in their schools and hospitals. A gap yawned between unbelievable rhetoric and the reality.

What is still missing is a proper timescale. The government has to come clean and own up that many of its most cherished ambitions will take decades of dogged persistence to achieve. It inherited a country which was suffering from nearly 20 years of low investment in schools, hospitals and transport. It was always going to take more than a few years for people to feel a tangible improvement. Wise government is not a game of quick fix and clever soundbites. The annual report is at least a start in acknowledging that.

fields.headline: Damaging youngsters
fields.standfirst:
The education secretary David Blunkett responds angrily to Nick Davies's articles in the Guardian

Read Nick Davies's investigations - and David Blunkett's previous responses on Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The education secretary David Blunkett responds angrily to Nick Davies's articles in the Guardian
fields.body:
Regrettably, Nick Davies's latest series on schools took us no further towards solving the problems which many of our children face. If anything, Tuesday's anonymous allegations of cheating will have reinforced the idea that it is all hopeless. This corrosive proposition, that nothing can be done until poverty has been completely eliminated, undermines the drive to raise standards and the excellent results which teachers are achieving. It suggests that those of us who found education to be the ladder out of poverty should have accepted our lot in life rather than seizing the opportunity which lifelong learning gave us.

Davies suggested that the exam system was fraudulent, without providing a shred of evidence. This is a disgraceful slur on hard-working heads and teachers across the country. The implication was that if they weren't cheating, they should be because several people whom Davies declined to name said they knew someone who cheated.

This is not only poor journalism but, more importantly, is deeply damaging to the youngsters whose life chances are being transformed. Should he let me have any names, I will ensure each case is investigated. But over the past three years, I have made sure that the procedures we use are consistent, fair and rigorous.

Literacy and numeracy standards have increased because we introduced a clearer focus through daily hour-long lessons, better teaching and extra money for training. I know it is difficult for cynics to accept, but the reality is that the literacy and numeracy hours have made a difference and teachers and parents know it.

Expectation is what matters most. If you assume that children from a disadvantaged background will fail, they will do so. If you believe they can and should fulfil their potential, there is a much greater chance that they will. I know because I was there myself. I know also because I've seen how good schools in poorer areas can and do make a difference.

That is what "Excellence in cities" is about. It started in 450 secondary schools last September and extends to others this coming school year. Each school ensures that the curriculum meets the needs of its most able pupils, regardless of background. They have money for on-site learning support units so that teachers can get pupils who misbehave out of the classroom quickly and without red tape.

The units are based on a model of proven success. They were piloted for three years and were independently evaluated. They improved behaviour, reduced the need for exclusions and were cost effective. That is why we recently announced funding for more than 1,000 units by 2002. These inner-city schools also get money for learning mentors, who, as full-time staff members, can tackle truancy and other social issues quickly, leaving teachers free to teach. Casually dismissing them as Davies does is to ignore the idea that such help should be available quickly and when it is needed.

This government is doing more to tackle the problems of discipline, exclusion and truancy than has ever been attempted before. We are spending £140m this year - compared to £17m four years ago - which is certainly not leading to any "simultaneous cuts" in spending on disaffected children. Quite the opposite.

On-site units are not a replacement for off-site pupil referral units. Where schools do have to exclude - and headteachers have my full support in excluding where they need to, for example, violent or seriously disruptive pupils - they will get a full-time education instead of an average of three hours a week as in the past. By 2002, all education authorities will be required to offer 25 hours a week to excluded pupils. In the past year there has been a net increase of 28 pupil referral units - there are more pupils on roll and contact time is increasing.

Education authorities most certainly do continue to have a statutory responsibility for truants outside school, contrary to Davies's assertions. They are responsible for making sure that children go to school regularly, and for taking action against parents who deprive children of their education. Far from simply "relying on heavier fines and home-school contracts" to cut truancy, we are funding schools to improve their monitoring of attendance and to chase up truants.

Davies is right that we do need more good vocational education. That is why we have provided more work-related alternatives for 14 to 16-year-olds, with new vocational GCSEs planned. It is why we are introducing more and better apprenticeships, new vocational A-levels and vocationally oriented foundation degrees.

Nobody is suggesting that schools can "be expected to completely neutralise the harsh conditions in which many of these adolescents live", as his article puts it. That would be absurd. It will take time, but we are doing more than ever before to confront and tackle the complex issues of social exclusion, both in our education and social policy. We are confronting the challenge head on, and putting our money where our mouth is.

I know there is more to do both to improve standards overall and to give youngsters from poorer backgrounds the help they need to succeed. I know we need to do more to help failing schools turn themselves around - pretending such failure doesn't exist would be a profound betrayal of children and their families.

However, in three years, we have seen real improvements in literacy and numeracy. We are spending far more on schools - in real terms £300 more per pupil this year than in 1997 and three times as much on capital. We are employing more teachers, have cut infant class sizes, introduced a better pay structure for teachers, turned around failing schools far quicker than before, improved access to computers greatly, provided 120,000 more free nursery places and are spending seven times as much on directly dealing with the problems Davies identified on Monday.

With next week's spending review, I hope we can continue this progress. But one thing is certain: we will only do it when pupils, parents and teachers believe they can make a difference and know that they can do it. To pretend otherwise, as Davies does, would be to consign a large number of today's youngsters to the scrapheap. I for one have no intention of accepting such a counsel of despair. I have more faith than that in the ability of our pupils and in the capacity of our teachers to make a real difference.

David Blunkett is secretary of state for education and employment.

webTitle: Stress of changes is driving one in four heads to drink, says union

fields.headline: Stress of changes is driving one in four heads to drink, says union
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Almost one in four headteachers are either alcoholics or drinking more than they should because of stress, according to a report by their union issued yesterday.
fields.body:
Almost one in four headteachers are either alcoholics or drinking more than they should because of stress, according to a report by their union issued yesterday.

Of 127 headteachers in Warwickshire who took part in a survey by the National Association of Head Teachers, 22 said they were "alcohol dependent" and eight were "drinking more than they should, - a significant amount every day".

David Hart, general secretary of NAHT, told MPs on the education sub-committee there was "clear and increasing evidence" that the introduction of performance-related pay and new management systems, combined with the government's standards agenda, was "taking its toll" on headteachers.

More than half the 250 headteachers in Warwickshire replied to the survey. Of those who replied, 61 had visited a doctor in the last year for complaints including high blood pressure, severe depression, bulimia, skin problems and sleepless nights, 44 are or had been on medication, and 42 are actively looking for less stressful work.

The local education authority has been named as one of the top three in the country by Ofsted inspectors and its schools have a good reputation.

"Warwickshire is the last place in the world where you would expect these sort of results," Mr Hart said. "The pressures that heads in leafy lanes suffer from are different from the deprived areas. But they all suffer from stress."

If the Warwickshire pattern was repeated across the country, between 5,000 and 6,000 headteachers would have a drink problem.

A primary school headteacher from Essex wrote to him this week that "a frightening proportion" of headteachers were "on medication related to stress or other psychological illness, brought on largely by trying to do the impossible".

Mr Hart said he was sure the government would reach its targets for key stage tests, but said: "Headteachers are just sick and tired of the target-setting agenda, with those targets being ratcheted up year after year after year."

In general evidence from unions to the education sub-committee yesterday, Nigel de Gruchy, general secretary of the National Association of Schoolmasters Union of Women Teachers, described pupil behaviour, government-generated bureaucracy and aspects of Ofsted inspections as the main problems facing teachers.

John Bangs, assistant general secretary of the National Union of Teachers, said teachers were being kept "outside the loop" when government developed policy.

Peter Smith, general secretary of the Association of Teachers and Lecturers, said that when 50% of teachers were over 45 and 40% over 50, the government had to motivate these teachers whose highest aspiration had been premature retirement.

In evidence on the sub-committee's inquiry into elitism in higher education, Neil Hopkins, principal of Peter Symonds sixth form college in Winchester, said state school pupils were discouraged by Oxbridge's admissions. "To an outsider Oxford and Cambridge admissions seem arcane... When you are a confused teenage that's just one more little barrier."

He added that there was "good intentions" at Oxbridge but few people there knew anything about further education colleges. John Brennan, director of further education at the Association of Colleges, said only 5% of Oxbridge applicants were from FE colleges.

John Dunford, general secretary of the Secondary Heads Association, said links between private schools and Oxbridge did help their candidates, despite Oxford's claim that they did not.

Tory MP Nick St Aubyn said 30 comprehensive pupils had withdrawn their admissions to three Oxford colleges as a result of chancellor Gordon Brown's "outburst" on elitism at Oxford. But applications for next year do not have to be in until the autumn and Oxford University could shed no light on the claim.

fields.headline: Roads to reform
fields.standfirst:
Mr Blunkett is too defensive
Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Ministers are upset by our latest three-part instalment of Nick Davies's schools in crisis series. David Blunkett condemns it in today's comment pages and was even more ferocious at a Downing Street press conference yesterday. The education secretary is once again too sensitive to the faults which the series has uncovered.
fields.body:
Ministers are upset by our latest three-part instalment of Nick Davies's schools in crisis series. David Blunkett condemns it in today's comment pages and was even more ferocious at a Downing Street press conference yesterday. The education secretary is once again too sensitive to the faults which the series has uncovered. He should be less defensive. Labour inherited an education system riddled with inequalities - 80% of children of unskilled fathers still leaving school at 16, most of them without qualifications. No one expected the government to turn this round overnight. Similarly, the stark gap in standards between Britain and the continent, documented by the Dearing report among many others, will take a decade to correct.

Ministers were faced with the need to improve standards and change the school structure. They opted to concentrate on standards in their first term. They were right: gaps within the system as well as with outside systems were unacceptably wide. They were right to start with primary schools (more than half of all 11-year-olds were failing to reach expected standards); right to set bold and ambitious targets (75% to achieve the maths standards and 80% the literacy standard by 2002); and right to use tests to monitor progress. Schools are well on their way to achieving these targets, which is why ministers must start turning their attention to the structural faults documented by Nick Davies. Moreover, as yesterday's article highlighted, changing the structure can help raise standards. The best way of recapturing an interest in schools among the seriously disaffected is to make them more relevant. That means vocational education getting a huge increase in resources and esteem.

Our current system dates back to the start of the welfare state, but came with a hidden 1940s agenda: how would agriculture, mill towns and the coal industry attract the millions they needed if every child was offered a proper secondary education? This was one reason why Britain introduced a two-tier system, under which vocational education was starved of resources. Fifty years on, another Labour government, attuned to the need to ensure that all its citizens have skills, is ideally placed to make sure that a proper structure is now put in place. Vocational education on the continent (two-thirds of the British workforce lacks the vocational qualifications of Germany) was driven by fear of Britain's industrial revolution. Continental countries were only too ready to ensure that vocational and academic education achieved equal status. Economic survival depended on it.

Nick Davies described the Dutch system yesterday: a system in which students from 11 can move between academic and vocational pathways. Both are within the same school, but there is more money for vocational courses, given their higher costs. One London school which has copied this scheme - within the restricted limits of the current national curriculum - has seen significant improvement in standards. These columns have long argued against forcing all children through academic courses, but have suggested 14 - as in Italy and Germany - as a more appropriate age to introduce a dual track. By then, pupils are more aware of their interests and competence. Better still, this would move basis of the secondary system from parental to pupils' choice. Keeping both tracks within every comprehensive school would allow the change to be introduced far faster than having them in separate schools. And still more important, it offers a better chance of parity of esteem.

fields.headline: Blair challenge on exam cheats 'slur'
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The government yesterday rejected as "slurs" allegations that extensive cheating took place in the conduct of exams and tests in British schools and challenged critics to produce evidence.
fields.body:

webTitle: Corinthians: Edu deal will go ahead

fields.headline: Corinthians: Edu deal will go ahead
fields.trailText: The transfer of Brazilian midfielder Edu to Arsenal will go ahead later this month, according to his club Corinthians. They have hit back at claims that Edu was deported from England because of forged documents and maintain that he qualifies for a European passport through his Portuguese grandfather.
fields.body:
The transfer of Brazilian midfielder Edu to Arsenal will go ahead later this month, according to his club Corinthians. They have hit back at claims that Edu was deported from England because of forged documents and maintain that he qualifies for a European passport through his Portuguese grandfather.

The 22-year-old - who earlier this month signed a four-year contract with the Gunners - was refused entry to the UK by immigration officers when he arrived with Arsenal left-back Silvinho at Heathrow airport on Tuesday. However, the Brazilian club today denied that Edu had been detained for holding a false passport and their chairman Nujud claimed both Arsenal vice-chairman David Dein and Edu's agent Juan Figer were certain there would be no problems with the deal.

"This business about a bogus passport is incorrect," he said. "What happened was that the trip to do the medical with Arsenal was brought forward and Edu was missing some documentation. Juan Figer is guaranteeing that we will have the necessary paperwork in a few days."

"Arsenal have called us to let us know that there won't be any problems" he added.

However, Corinthians have also stressed that it would be "extremely difficult" for Edu to return to Brazil and continue playing for them.

"Edu no longer has anything to do with Corinthians," said the club's chief executive Jefferson Yassuda. "He has been bought by Arsenal. It's not just a simple case of us handing the money back, we would have to renegotiate and buy him back.

"The other option would be to take him on loan, but either way it would be extremely difficult. It's easier for him to resolve his problems in England than come back to us," he added.

Should Edu not be able to prove that he is indeed entitled to a EU passport, there would be virtually no hope of him being granted a work permit as he has yet to make his international debut.

Meanwhile, Arsene Wenger been told by Sao Paolo that £4.6million-rated defender Edmilson is no longer for sale.

fields.headline: Labour's changing promises
fields.standfirst:
Today Tony Blair launches the government's third annual report. What claims does it make - and how do they stand comparison to Labour's manifesto promises?

Prosperity | Education | Health | Crime | Welfare | Modern government | Quality of life | Modern government | Leading abroad
fields.trailText: On 1 May, 1997 Labour won a landslide victory on the back of its five "key pledges" covering class sizes, punishment of young offenders, NHS waiting lists, youth employment and income tax rates. All of these - say the government - have been kept or are "on course".
fields.body:
On 1 May, 1997 Labour won a landslide victory on the back of its five "key pledges" covering class sizes, punishment of young offenders, NHS waiting lists, youth employment and income tax rates. All of these - say the government - have been kept or are "on course".

But how does the government rate its performance across the whole range of policy? Watch the short films launched today on the Number 10 website for one view - and the read our guide to the government's changing promises to make up your own mind.

Prosperity

The 1997 general election manifesto:
"Delivering economic prosperity for the many not the few."

The 1998 annual report:
"We inherited an economy with fundamental weaknesses. The familiar cycle of boom and bust was beginning to reappear. Over the last year we have embarked on a radical programme of reform to address these fundamental priorities and put Britain on course for long-term economic stability."

The 1999 annual report:
"The government is forging a healthy and constructive partnership with business. The chief obstacle holding back business over the past two decades has been the cycle of boom and bust. That is why one of the government's very first measures was to set a new framework for stability by granting independence to the Bank of England."

The 2000 annual report:
"The government is delivering a platform of stability and steady growth.There are now 970,000 more people in work than in 1997Inflation and mortgage rates are low, and the public finances are under control. The government's commitment to stability allows us to invest in better public services. We are providing an immediate boost of £2 billion for the NHS this year. Achieving this has meant tough decisions over the last three years. But it provides the base on which to build a stronger, fairer Britain where opportunity and enterprise are open to all."

Education

The 1997 general election manifesto 1997:
"Education is the government's number one priority."

The 1998 annual report:
"We have moved beyond the sterile debates about school structures. What matters is what works. We will let excellence flourish with a light touch from the centre. The government promised that it would spend more on education. We will increase education spending by an average of 5.1 percent in real terms over the next three years which totals £19 billion.

The 1999 annual report:
"The government will spend £19 billion more over the next three years to bring more schools up to the highest standards, with this extra money tied to the modernisation and reform of the education system. Failing schools are being turned around more quickly than ever before. Since May 1997 the average turn-around time has been cut from 25 to 18 months.

The 2000 annual report:
"Education remains the bedrock of the government's programme. Rebuilding run-down facilities, raising standards, or encouraging more teachers to train in areas like maths and science cannot be done overnight. The money is going in but tied to modernisation and reform, so that it has the maximum effect. Already, this new approach is making a difference.

Health

The 1997 general election manifesto:
"Modernisation and reform of the NHS to raise standards and improve patient care."

The 1998 annual report:
"In the spending review the government has allocated £21 billion extra for the NHS. We are saving £100 million by cutting the bureaucracy of the internal market and transferring the money into patient care. There are few things worse than waiting months in pain for treatment. That is why we have put so much effort into reducing waiting lists. The early indications are that this strategy is working and, having risen initially, waiting lists are starting to come down."

The 1999 annual report:
"Over the last two years the government has stopped the NHS's decline, cut bureaucracy and put doctors and nurses back in the driving seat. We have cut waiting lists after years of rises and launched the largest-ever hospital-building programme. Now we are raising investment to modernise and reform the NHS."

The 2000 annual report:
"People's day-to-day experience of the NHS often falls short...People have to wait far too long for treatment. The quality of that treatment varies enormously. And in other ways - in everything from the convenience of booking an appointment to the cleanliness of hospital wards - the level of service does not always match the expectations of patients or staff. But improvements are starting to come through."

Crime

The 1997 general election manifesto:
"Tough on crime, tough on the causes of crime."

The 1998 annual report:
"The government has set our strategies to deal with young offenders, drugs and petty offending because we believe that allowing small crimes to go unpunished leads to greater disorder."

The 1999 annual report:
"The most recent crime figures showed the biggest fall in recorded crime for five years - and the first-ever fall in unrecorded crime. But we cannot relax. The long-term trend is still upwards."

The 2000 annual report:
"This year the rate of recorded crime in England and Wales rose by 3%. But crime can be beaten. The government has increased the resources available to fight crime. Police budgets have risen on average by 3.6%."

Welfare

The 1997 general election manifesto:
"Making work pay, helping people into work and providing security for those who need it most."

The 1998 annual report:
"What we have done: getting long-term unemployed off benefit and into work Young people should be offered real opportunities, nor time-wasting schemes. The New Deal means that life on the dole doing nothing is no longer an option for young people."

The 2000 annual report:
"The government's welfare reforms are working. Economic stability and steady growth means more people than ever before are in work. The national minimum wage and the Working Families Tax Credit are making work pay. The New Deal is on course to get 250,000 young people into jobs. Unemployment is down and employment is up across the UK. Social security spending is rising on average at 1.2% across this Parliament, the lowest increase of any Parliament since the war. This allows us to spend more on improving public services for all."

Quality of Life

The 1997 general election manifesto:
"Improving everyone's quality of life, from the environment to arts and sports."

The 1998 annual report:
"The government is increasing the amount spent on transport by £1.8 billion"

The 1999 annual report:
"It will take time to transform our transport system, but already the government has made a start".

The 2000 annual report:
"New investment is delivering better services, attracting more users, and so helping to fund further investment through higher revenue. Public transport is once again a growth industry."

Modern government

The 1997 general election manifesto:
"Reform of government itself, and modern, quality public services."

The 1998 annual report:
"People said we would get bogged down on our constitutional agenda and have no time for legislation on health, education or law and order. That has not been the case."

The 1999 annual report:
"The government is modernising the way we govern ourselves and giving more power to the individual. As well as devolution, these reforms cover Parliament, freedom of information, human rights, local government, and modernising government itself."

The 2000 annual report:
"The government has launched a huge investment programme to give the country the public services it deserves. But money alone will not bring about the improvements we want. Reforms are needed as well, so that the money goes further".

Leadership abroad The 1997 general election manifesto:
"Promoting security, prosperity and sustainable development around the world."

The 1998 annual report:
"The government sees Britain as a pivotal nation in the world."

The 1999 annual report:
"This country cannot isolate itself from the wider world."

The 2000 annual report:
"The government is also working with other countries to tackle the issues raised by international migration."

Useful links
The government's annual reports
The government's five election pledges

fields.headline: Gregory: No offers for Southgate
fields.trailText: Gareth Southgate may have to tough it out at Aston Villa after manager John Gregory revealed he had received no offers for the England international, who asked for a transfer on the eve of Euro 2000.
fields.body:
Gareth Southgate may have to tough it out at Aston Villa after manager John Gregory revealed he had received no offers for the England international, who asked for a transfer on the eve of Euro 2000.

Gregory admitted: "Yes, I'm surprised for he is a good player. But it pleases me there has not been a single approach."

Southgate is due to return to training next week and will miss the Intertoto Cup match against FC Pribram on Sunday in the Czech Republic. He was given extended leave after Euro 2000.

Gregory said: "The skipper has got a wife and family and needs a breather. He'll be back on Monday. I keep saying that I won't worry about the situation until I have to discuss it.

"It was the same with Dwight Yorke when he was being linked to Manchester United. You can't keep waiting for the phone to ring, it will drive you crackers" he added. Southgate is not the only player who is unsettled at Villa, with Ugo Ehiogu, Julian Joachim and Alan Thompson also appearing to be on their way out of the club. But Gregory confirmed that all three players will travel to the Czech Republic this weekend.

Sunderland have made an enquiry about Ehiogu but Gregory admitted they are not the only club interested. He was guarded about giving further details, but he dismissed rumours linking the defender with Tottenham and said it was an English club not in the Champions League.

Thompson has been linked to Celtic but Gregory said: "I have not heard a thing and was surprised to read some comments from him."

Joachim has been outspoken in his criticism of the manager, but Gregory said: "Anything that has to be discussed will be discussed with him in the privacy of my office. He has not been fined."

webTitle: Upbeat PM hails new jobs for 1m

fields.headline: Upbeat PM hails new jobs for 1m
fields.standfirst:
Upbeat Blair hails 1m new jobs since taking office
New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair yesterday swept away uncertainty about his government's strategic direction when he capped an upbeat Downing Street press conference with a bravura Commons performance that restored his tarnished authority.
fields.body:
Tony Blair yesterday swept away uncertainty about his government's strategic direction when he capped an upbeat Downing Street press conference with a bravura Commons performance that restored his tarnished authority.

After weeks of unwelcome setbacks, the prime minister seized on official employment figures - showing that 1m jobs have been created since his 1997 election victory - to explain directly to impatient voters how his strategy is gradually becoming reality.

Using No 10's dining room for a rare press conference in the presidential White House style, Mr Blair set the scene for the chancellor's £40bn spending review next Tuesday: the investment-oriented third stage of Labour's programme of national rejuvenation which will pour billions into health, education, transport and science.

In a foretaste of Labour's election campaign he said: "Britain is stronger because we are delivering on the fundamentals but there is a lot more hard work to be done. We are not in the least complacent. Over 1m people are still unemployed, but at least we are getting there."

Not only did he proclaim record levels of employment - 28m people in work and the jobless total of 1,098,000 the lowest since 1980 - Mr Blair said the cost of welfare, "the price of social and economic failure", is finally falling.

Showing no signs of recent fatigue he even said that, with the pound dropping in value, "we are beginning to turn the position round on manufacturing" - of crucial importance to Labour's core vote. At his side David Blunkett, the education and employment secretary, added: "Full employment is within our grasp."

William Hague later used question time to mock the phrase "we are getting there" and accused Labour of another desperate relaunch after a succession of mishaps, including rows over the euro and the much-mocked "cashpoint" plan for lager louts.

But in contrast to a week ago, when the Tory leader hammered him at the dispatch box, Mr Blair was in fighting form. During fierce exchanges he sprang what he called a "spending cuts guarantee" trap on the Conservatives, which his advisers believe could keep them in opposition for the rest of the decade.

Deriding the series of guarantees Mr Hague made last October - on which he has been forced to retreat - Mr Blair seized upon every Conservative complaint about failing local services. The new Conservative pledge to cut public spending by up to £16bn would make matters worse - "fewer nurses, fewer teachers, fewer police, fewer hospitals" in their constituencies, he predicted.

Downing Street - which now plans to hold regular prime ministerial press conferences to circumvent what it calls a cynical and hostile media - believes that with their u-turn, Mr Hague and his shadow chancellor, Michael Portillo, have committed a blunder from which it will take years to escape. Building on Mr Blair's bid to drive home the government's message that it is delivering on its pledges to improve public services, the chancellor will today announce an unexpected windfall of £2bn-3bn to be spent on education, transport and law and order over the next three years.

The chancellor will say that Whitehall's big departments are to receive extra funding in next week's comprehensive spending review, on top of the £40bn they were expecting to receive, thanks to falling levels of unemployment and lower interest payments on the national debt.

According to the Treasury, proceeds from the £22bn sale of licences for the third generation of mobile phones will reduce debt interest payments by just over £1bn by 2003/04 and this will be more than matched by savings from the shortening of dole queues.

In a speech to the Royal Economic Society in St Andrews, Mr Brown will say that this "allows us to devote more to the country's priorities for vital public services - spending on education, health, transport and policing which this government is committed to delivering.

"This is extra public spending which comes not at the expense of our prudence, but because of our prudence."

Labour sources said last night that Mr Brown's announcement would put extra pressure on the Tories to say how they would find the reductions in spending to pay for their promised tax cuts.

Mr Blair's spokesman, Alastair Campbell, who has recently been taking a back seat, later confirmed that Mr Blair intends to become more visible as the general election - probably next May or June - looms.

"The more his voice is heard, the better it is, because when his voice is heard and listened to, they understand what this government is about," he explained.

Today the prime minister will appear before MPs to present the government's annual report.

At the press conference yesterday Mr Blair took questions across a range of policies for an hour.

He kept emphasising how Labour's 1997 plans are now bearing fruit because of Mr Brown's commitment to economic stability and to the welfare-to-work programme.

The third stage, huge investment in what he called an "under-invested-in country", is now happening.

"Good economic management is essential but not enough, falling unemployment is essential but not enough. We now need the next stage - to tackle the problem of poor productivity and lack of essential investment in the nation's future."

Ministers faced expert criticism yesterday over the performance of the flagship New Deal programme for getting long-term and young unemployed people into work. But ministers insist it is getting 7,000 people into jobs each month and virtually pays for itself. Mr Blair told reporters that New Deal recruits who were inarticulate and unemployable when they joined the programme were transformed in three months.

Building on Mr Blair's bid to drive home the government's message that it is delivering on its pledges to improve public services, the chancellor will today announce an unexpected windfall of £2bn-3bn to be spent on education, transport and law and order over the next three years. The chancellor will say that Whitehall's big departments are to receive extra funding in next week's comprehensive spending review, on top of the £40bn they were expecting to receive, thanks to falling levels of unemployment and lower interest payments on the national debt. According to the Treasury, proceeds from the £22bn sale of licences for the third generation of mobile phones will reduce debt interest payments by just over £1bn by 2003/04 and this will be more than matched by savings from the shortening of dole queues. In a speech to the Royal Economic Society in St Andrews, Mr Brown will say that this "allows us to devote more to the country's priorities for vital public services - spending on education, health, transport and policing which this government is committed to delivering. "This is extra public spending which comes not at the expense of our prudence, but because of our prudence." Labour sources said last night that Mr Brown's announcement would put extra pressure on the Tories to say how they would find the reductions in spending to pay for their promised tax cuts. Mr Blair's spokesman, Alastair Campbell, who has recently been taking a back seat, later confirmed that Mr Blair intends to become more visible as the general election - probably next May or June - looms. "The more his voice is heard, the better it is, because when his voice is heard and listened to, they understand what this government is about," he explained. Today the prime minister will appear before MPs to present the government's annual report. At the press conference yesterday Mr Blair took questions across a range of policies for an hour. He kept emphasising how Labour's 1997 plans are now bearing fruit because of Mr Brown's commitment to economic stability and to the welfare-to-work programme. The third stage, huge investment in what he called an "under-invested-in country", is now happening. "Good economic management is essential but not enough, falling unemployment is essential but not enough. We now need the next stage - to tackle the problem of poor productivity and lack of essential investment in the nation's future." Ministers faced expert criticism yesterday over the performance of the flagship New Deal programme for getting long-term and young unemployed people into work. But ministers insist it is getting 7,000 people into jobs each month and virtually pays for itself. Mr Blair told reporters that New Deal recruits who were inarticulate and unemployable when they joined the programme were transformed in three months.

webTitle: Hague's 'fourth way' is just a fancy contradiction

fields.headline: Hague's 'fourth way' is just a fancy contradiction
fields.standfirst:
The Conservative disarray makes New Labour seem quite coherent
New Labour in power: special report
Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: The Conservative disarray makes New Labour seem quite coherent.
fields.body:
I f you're tired of the third way, consider for a moment the fourth. The third way has produced the most tedious political meditations of our time. It's a confusion of opposites, a blur of contradictions, a proud denial of the need for a party to choose. Touted as the New Labour vision, it can be marked down as the prime reason for the government now having no vision. When people say Tony Blair is an unprincipled opportunist, roaming over the spectrum to offer all things to all men and women, the vacuities of the third way, his theology, are what they have in mind.

But the third way is a model of clarity by comparison with the fourth way. That's what we discover as these July days unfold. By this time next week, Labour will have put some first-way flesh on the third-way bones. The party line is emerging from its nebulous obscurity. It's becoming clear what all-purpose Blairism really stands for, just at the time when the fourth wayers, led by William Hague, reveal the philosophical chaos of their project.

New Labour is making a rendezvous with old Labour, as the comprehensive spending review will show. New Labour believes in public spending, and will apply unprecedented quantities of it to the problems of our time. It is true that Mr Blair boxes the compass. Of all the things he said at his press conference yesterday, what seemed to fill him with most pride was citing the global survey which found the UK to be the world's second favourite economy in which to invest: something the last Labour government could not have dreamed of, might indeed have been horrified to learn.

But next week's spending announcements will make Labour feel comfortable with itself. Not only Labour, but its leader. Though he hasn't had time to become a statesman, he is a state-man. He believes in the enabling role of public money in the services at the core of daily life. This is not an apologetic stance, born of temporary convenience. Mr Blair delivers it with passion. Reeling off the record of the new deal, and the promise of money to come in schools and hospitals and police stations, he speaks to the same moral code, out of the same political impulses, as Harold Wilson or Tony Benn. He may frame the money as social investment, and place the emphasis on preparing people for the capitalist world of work. But he has no doubt the state must do it.

The fourth way has no such clarity. In 1997, Labour got to power on the basis of maintaining Tory spending plans for two years ahead. In 2001, the Conservatives will seek power on the basis of rejecting Labour's spending plans for three years ahead. Labour was shedding its reputation as the party that couldn't be trusted with the economy. The Tories are hellbent on confirming their reputation as the party that is anti-state - yet also, somehow, compassionate. They are not making themselves clear to us, because they cannot resolve the unclarity in their own head.

For Mr Hague to reverse his tax guarantee is an embarrassment. How a policy which, only months ago, was pledged with "no escape clauses, no fudges" can now become expendable will confuse people who might have been warming to a bit of upright, downright, Yorkshire common sense. But the language has changed more than the policy. Tax-cutting will be suspended only if the economy is in a bad way. Spending cuts, which are the main consequence of tax cuts, remain the goal. The guarantee is redirected, but with the same purpose, of declaring against the state as the necessary agent of provision in the areas where it has performed that role for a very long time.

Yet the Tories are not prepared to spell that out in honest detail. Their stance is half-hearted. It lacks philosophical coherence. They attitudinise, but do not organise. On tax and spending, their strategy partly resembles what they've done on asylum seekers and criminals, who are being promised the kind of hard time the Tory heartland voters are slavering to watch. But in the end, the stance on this core issue of the state and its size is different. It is much warier of the voters. While some voters may warm to the promise of extreme measures against muggers and burglars, most would be displeased to hear that public investment in education and health was to be dramatically reduced, as the minimal state materialised before our eyes.

So the Tories announce a general priority against state spending, in keeping with their prejudice. Under Mrs Thatcher, their anti-state ideology was satisfied by the privatisation of industries and utilities, but unfortunately there are none of these left to sell. In their heart, Tories would like to do more - hence the promise to hold spending below growth, even if this means, as it would on present forecasts, cutting £17bn from the public budget. The party is pleased to hear it. The number of Conservative politicians who believe in the positive merits of state spending has much diminished. Whereas a cohort of ministers, not just the Priors and the Gilmours but Geoffrey Howe and Nigel Lawson, ensured that the Thatcher government left the state taking as much of national wealth in 1990 as it had in 1979, Mr Hague and Mr Portillo think of themselves as crusaders against the state.

But they will not say how or where to cut. They have a dogmatic preference, which they pragmatically shrink from. They want the state to reduce in general but not, it seems, in particular. Their retreat from the tax guarantee into a cuts guarantee has been welcomed by commentators as very wise. But the nature of the cuts is not an academic question, to which the answer can be patiently awaited. It is the essence of the matter. Until the choice of cuts is declared, the retreat seems like the tactical manoeuvre of a party, torn between heart and head, that cannot decide what to do or think.

Even Mr Hague, in other words, seems to suspect that his position is at odds with the preferences of the British people. Popular attachment to public services is very great, and a party that promises to cut spending on them, in a time of so much private prosperity, will be unelectable. Yet here is a party which combines anti-state ideology with rhetoric that indicates more not less spending on health, defence, law and order, to name but three. It wants to take Conservatism further right, on the model of the Texas Republicans, while pretending that nobody will pay.

The truth is that it cannot do that. The muddle is too obvious, the opportunism too shallow. The British belief in the welfare state not the minimal state is so strong, as the Thatcherites discovered long ago, that serious cutting back on education and health could be done after a long, serious, bruising ideological campaign. Mr Hague dare not try that. So he dabbles in obscure undertakings and fancy contradictions. It is the fourth way, which makes the third seem a model of harmony and coherence.

fields.headline: Dempsey resigns as Oceania president
fields.trailText: Charles Dempsey, whose decision to abstain on the final ballot handed Germany the 2006 World Cup, has retired from his post as president of the Oceanian Football Confederation (OFC).
fields.body:
Charles Dempsey, whose decision to abstain on the final ballot handed Germany the 2006 World Cup, has retired from his post as president of the Oceanian Football Confederation (OFC).

Clearly upset by events in Zurich last week, 79-year-old Dempsey handed his daughter - OFC general secretary Josephine King - a letter confirming his retirement.

"My family has been harassed and I'm not prepared to let that continue," said Dempsey. "My wife Annie and I are going on holiday. She has stood up to it well but it is not fair to let it continue.

"The pressure had been too much for me. My family is more important than football," he added.

Dempsey had earlier indicated he would step down on Oct. 1 - two years ahead of schedule, but decided to retire even earlier because of the continual criticisms of his actions in Zurich.

The vote for his successor is expected to be held on October 1, with Vanuatu's Johnny Tinsley Lulu, the current vice-president, and Australian Basil Scarsella the front-runners.

fields.headline: Thugs, Mugs and Drugs
fields.trailText: SMUG A THUG TODAY
fields.body:
SMUG A THUG TODAY

The Fiver agrees with Tony Blair when he advises us all to concentrate on substance and not spin. Which is why we wholeheartedly support the Labour MP for Eastwood, Jim Murphy, in his little survey of all the "so-called fans" ("s-cfs") who are currently banned or restricted from watching their clubs play.

Of course, the survey doesn't say why the "s-cfs" have been banned, whether the numbers are the tip of an iceberg or just a sign that clubs are acting more vigilantly. But Mr Murphy finds them "shocking" all the same, and has chosen to release his findings on the day Jack Straw looks to push through his enlightened Football (disorder) bill aimed at stopping "s-cfs" (or indeed anyone) from leaving the country if the fuzz take a dislike to them.

There are currently 402 "s-cfs" banned from England's 92 league clubs, and Mr Murphy (a Celtic supporter) found that Leeds United came out top with a total of 59. Busy as he is, Peter Ridsdale found time today to comment on this very substantial and in no way superficial report. "I am surprised to find us at the top of such a list, given all the hard work we have put in over recent years," Ridsdale said. "And if you look at the arrests at Elland Road and away grounds involving Leeds games recently then there would hardly be an incident of note."

Stoke City came second in the hate club list with 43 "s-cfs" and Man City's notoriously humourless support came third with 23. This was no consolation to a very uncool daddy Ridsdale however. "I am not trying to pretend that we have eradicated problems 100% and we will never rest on our laurels," he said. "But I have no knowledge or statistics that would put us at the top of such a list." Not that this impressed Mr Murphy. "I am sure that the clubs near the top will be up in arms at the findings," he smugged, "but then again, so they should be." If that's the substance, perhaps spin ain't that bad after all.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

YOU CAN'T BEAT THE REAL THING

Pledges are made. Deals are struck, and things generally get downright dirty. And then after a long, drawn-out campaign what happens? Germany win. Is it any wonder no one votes any more? So thank God for Lorenzo Sanz and Florentino Perez, whose increasingly ludicrous fight for the presidency of Real Madrid is putting the 'Excitement' back into election.

It all started when the outsider Florentino made an outrageous pledge to bring Barecelona's Luis Figo to Real if he won the election - despite the player possessing a contract with a whopping £40m buy-out clause. A certain Zinedine Zidane might be on his way as well, he hinted. Yeah right, claimed an upstaged Sanz, who dismissed Perez's prattle as "a joke, probably to be followed by the signing of Claudia Schiffer."

Then, strangely, it turned out to be true. Well the Figo part anyway. Because a day after claiming he would be "mad" to do any such thing, the Portuguese playmaker admitted: "I have an offer from senor Florentino Perez and that is why I want him to win the elections." And the offer? A cool £5m a year. Furthermore, Spanish paper Marca claims that Figo's agent has signed a bizarre pre-contract which means Figo would have to pay £20m if he didn't sign for the European champions once Florentino became president.

Yesterday Sanz struck back with the launch of a "save Real Madrid campaign" which urged voters to concentrate on Sanz's record (the two Champions League victories, not the estimated £163m debt we assume). When that didn't work Sanz then decided to send a video of Figo insulting Real ("Madridistas, cry babies, hail the champions!") to all 66,000 club members with a vote in Sunday's ballot. Not to be outdone, Florentino then promised a free season ticket to each member - out of his own money - if he wins the election and Figo doesn't sign. Makes Ken Bates look like a bearded joke really, doesn't it?

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"I'm 26 so I don't know if England has passed me by. Tim Sherwood was called up late in his career so perhaps there's still a chance."

Alan Thompson is still pining for an England call-up. And who better than Tim Sherwood to serve as his inspiration?

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

MIND THE GAP!

You need a little extra to get on in the modern world of professional football. And seeing that a diet of horse hormones and freebase cocaine has been outlawed by recent EU legislation (but don't quote us on that) it's probably no surprise that players and coaches are looking elsewhere for stimulation.

Take the incoming coach of Germany, Christoph Daum, for example. This nutter, sorry, highly qualified coach, is set to use the power of positive thought to improve his country's recent rubbish form. It may even get a couple more internationals out of Lothar Mattheus too. Daum explains his theories thus: "If I do everything to implement a strong thought," mmm hmmm, "then the probability is high of this visualisation coming to reality." Right. "In the beginning of the world there was only an idea." Great. "You can hear the earth you know". Fine.

Just a pity he's not taking the job until next season really (although he will be in charge for Germany v England in 2001). Meantime we'll have to make do with another cerebrally-involved character, Argentinian international keeper Carlos Roa. Roa is a seventh day adventist and retired from football last year to become a monk. This year he's changed his mind and will return to Real Mallorca - as long as he doesn't have to play on Saturday. "I won't train or play during the day, but there will be no problem," he said today. "I will play after the sun goes down." By himself? He'd be better off on the crack.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

AC Milan president Silvio Berlusconi has admitted he is interested in signing David Beckham. "I like the Manchester United midfielder a lot," he said. "I am Milan's biggest supporter and my promise to other Milan supporters is that there will be an important arrival."

Parma are believed to have offered £15m for Bordeaux's French international striker Sylvain Wiltord, who had been expected to move to Arsenal.

Newcastle United have been linked with a move for Barcelona striker Dani.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

Charles Dempsey has stepped down from his post as president of the Oceanian Football Confederation with immediate effect. Dempsey was heavily criticised last week after his abstention in the second round of voting to decide the host of the 2006 World Cup handed the tournament to Germany.

John Hartson has been fined £5,000 by the FA after instigating a scuffle in the tunnel before Wimbledon's match with Bradford on April 30. Hartson, who Halle described as acting "pretty wild" and going "up to Stuart McCall and raising his knee into his stomach" pleaded guilty to the charge of misconduct today. After hearing his case, the FA decided against imposing a ban and instead settled for a financial penalty and a warning as to his future conduct.

Meanwhile, Hartson's former West Ham team-mates Marc-Vivien Foe and John Moncur were each fined £8,000 and £1,000 for their part in the after-match scenes following the London derby defeat by Arsenal on May 2.

Manchester United midfielder Nicky Butt will not be leaving Old Trafford, despite reports linking him with Sporting Lisbon and Sunderland. "As far as I know it's speculation," he said. "I had a bit of speculation last year as well.

Cameroonian international Joseph-Desire Job has arrived in Middlesbrough for a 10-day trial.

David Ginola's agent, Chantal Stanley, says that the French winger wants to remain at Tottenham, despite Aston Villa's interest.

Burnley boss Stan Ternent has signed defender Lee Briscoe from First Division rivals Sheffield Wednesday.

Everton have agreed to sell John Collins to Fulham for an undisclosed fee.

Charlton have signed Middlesbrough goalkeeper Ben Roberts on a free transfer under the Bosman ruling.

Tranmere have signed midfielder Sean Flynn from West Brom on a two-year contract.

Crystal Palace have agreed terms for the transfers of Arsenal youngsters Tommy Black and Julian Gray, subject to medicals.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

ITV: World football (3am) Futbol Mondial before the nouveau fan got hold of it.

Channel 4: The other side (12.35am) Boro's Libyan jaunt captured on camera. Brian Deane and Colonel Gadaffi as you've never seen them before!

Channel 5: Major League Soccer (4.25am) Baton Rouge Lipstick v Baltimore Bumfluff

Sky Sports 1: Fifa TV (12.30am) Sepp introduces an hilarious new section: "Gunk the dissenting 78-year-old Fifa executive!" Charles Dempsey co-stars.

Sky Sports 2: Schoolboy football (7pm) Phil Neville presenting.

He'd be better off on the crack. * * * * * * * * * * * * * THE RUMOUR MILL AC Milan president Silvio Berlusconi has admitted he is interested in signing David Beckham. "I like the Manchester United midfielder a lot," he said. "I am Milan's biggest supporter and my promise to other Milan supporters is that there will be an important arrival." Parma are believed to have offered £15m for Bordeaux's French international striker Sylvain Wiltord, who had been expected to move to Arsenal. Newcastle United have been linked with a move for Barcelona striker Dani. * * * * * * * * * * * * * NEWS IN BRIEF Charles Dempsey has stepped down from his post as president of the Oceanian Football Confederation with immediate effect. John Hartson has been fined £5,000 by the FA after instigating a scuffle in the tunnel before Wimbledon's match with Bradford on April 30. Hartson, who Halle described as acting "pretty wild" and going "up to Stuart McCall and raising his knee into his stomach" pleaded guilty to the charge of misconduct today. After hearing his case, the FA decided against imposing a ban and instead settled for a financial penalty and a warning as to his future conduct. Meanwhile, Hartson's former West Ham team-mates Marc-Vivien Foe and John Moncur were each fined £8,000 and £1,000 for their part in the after-match scenes following the London derby defeat by Arsenal on May 2. Manchester United midfielder Nicky Butt will not be leaving Old Trafford, despite reports linking him with Sporting Lisbon and Sunderland. "As far as I know it's speculation," he said. "I had a bit of speculation last year as well. Cameroonian international Joseph-Desire Job has arrived in Middlesbrough for a 10-day trial. David Ginola's agent, Chantal Stanley, says that the French winger wants to remain at Tottenham, despite Aston Villa's interest. Burnley boss Stan Ternent has signed defender Lee Briscoe from First Division rivals Sheffield Wednesday. Everton have agreed to sell John Collins to Fulham for an undisclosed fee. Charlton have signed Middlesbrough goalkeeper Ben Roberts on a free transfer under the Bosman ruling. Tranmere have signed midfielder Sean Flynn from West Brom on a two-year contract. webTitle: 'I'd be very cross if the people who collected my recycling just sent it to the dump'

fields.headline: 'I'd be very cross if the people who collected my recycling just sent it to the dump'
fields.standfirst: Merope Mills finds out what really happens to the refuse we carefully save, sift and separate
fields.trailText: Merope Mills finds out what really happens to the refuse we carefully save, sift and separate
fields.body:
Every week, Mary Lea sifts through her rubbish to separate her recyclables. Like thousands of other conscientious consumers, Lea divides her plastics from her paper and her cans from her cardboard, before transferring them into the coloured containers her local council provides. Every Thursday, the containers get hauled away with the dustbin and delivered to a company which further separates the contents. But after she has done her bit, the fate of Lea's empty bottles and crushed cans barely crosses her mind.

The reality of what happens to much of this recyclable rubbish is not always what the scrupulous consumer intends. An increase in the amount of recycling collected and a drop in the market for recycled materials means that collections are being incinerated or dumped at tips. "I'd be very, very cross if I thought the people who collected my recycling just sent it to the dump," says Paula Brockes. "I go out of my way to put it into the right containers and drive four miles to the recycling dump each week. But, of course, I don't know what happens once it is collected."

While the amount of domestic waste collected for recycling rose from 1.7m tonnes in 1997 to more than 2m tonnes last year, processing has been unable to meet demand. In Aberdeenshire, more than 1,000 tonnes of newspaper were collected last year but sent to the tip. "We couldn't get anybody to take it so it had to be dumped," admits Pam Walker, the region's recycling officer. "Now the market has picked up and we have a contractor sending it south for us because the mill here is still only taking cardboard from us. There's a green glass mountain in the UK due to the massive imports from abroad. We still recycle it, but we're not getting any money from it at the moment." Some of the materials we are used to recycling are so unwanted that companies charge councils to take them off their hands.

Adam Read, a research fellow in waste management, has been monitoring the situation. "When central government started putting emphasis on local governments to deliver on recycling the targets were optional and the local authorities just didn't have the resources. It was impossible for them to achieve the kind of targets set because it just wasn't economical. It was a trade-off between having more money and having more materials recycled. Dumping things at landfills was nearly always the cheaper option."

Now recycling targets are becoming mandatory, Read argues the pressure is now on the consumer to change their purchasing habits. "We know that recycling with the public is a definite yes because 80% to 90% say they want to get involved. However, when we ask whether these people are actually buying recycled goods the usual answer is they are not." Apparently, the days of brown and blotchy pads of recycled paper still weighs heavily on consumers' minds. "There's still a stigma attached to recycled goods and people still see them as poor quality," says Read. "If recycling is to be a success we need to extend the "let's buy green" message and get all the big shopping chains to promote that."

Still, compared with other countries, Britain's recycling record is shameful. While Germany, Holland and much of Scandinavia can manage an impressive 50% recycling rate, Britain limps in with a pitiful 10%. In Milton Keynes, one of the first and most successful council schemes, most pick-ups are put to good use. "We have an arrangement that the waste management group has to recycle over 90% of what we pick up. We allow a 10% waste because people sometimes put out the wrong things, but generally we don't have a problem with selling it on," assures waste minimisation officer, Jill King.

The council's success lies in a mutually beneficial contract with the group that processes the material. "Because we pick up so much from the houses we have bigger negotiating power. Smaller councils with only 50 or so tonnes a year have trouble selling or can't get a very good price. We pick up around 10,000 tonnes a year so we've got more power to contract definite recycling. Small councils should get together with others so they have more pulling power," suggests King.

Sarah Oppenheimer of Friends of the Earth agrees that the issue is one of reprocessing capacity rather than collection. New government recycling targets - 25% by 2005, 30% by 2010 and 33% by 2015 - should ensure a large recycling quota to the reprocessing plants, which will lead to progress, says Oppenheimer. The chancellor, Gordon Brown, plans to inject £500m into the scheme which should help develop the habit and ensure that recycling is worthwhile.

In the meantime, Oppenheimer's advice is that consumers should not be disheartened. "It would be a shame to be disenchanted because, with time, reprocessing capacity will expand."

For those who are concerned about the fate of their carefully husbanded refuse, Oppenheimer suggests talking to the council to find out which firm has its reprocessing contract and what percentage gets recycled. "The key is to address the blockages in the system rather than give up altogether," she says. "If Germany and Switzerland can manage it, there's no reason we can't."

fields.headline: Cybershopping
fields.standfirst: Shopping Unlimited
fields.trailText: Summer toys
fields.body:
Summer toys

The summer holidays are just around the corner which means that, irrespective of the weather, it must be time to indulge in frivolous things.

The ever-so-cool www.kitschensync co.uk has got most things covered. The sunloungers in a funky pink or blue (£37.50) and garden candles (£3) are great if you can't be bothered to move beyond the back garden. If you are planning to travel further afield and don't want your beers to get warm, check out the portable fridge (pictured left, £99), which you can plug into the lighter socket of your car.

For an altogether more laddish experience, go to www.boystuff.co.uk Surfers stranded inland can practice their skills with all-terrain skateboard for skating on grass, while those keen to recreate the snowboarding experience can do so with the Alpha freeboard (£189). For those with an alarming disregard for appearances, there's the adult space hopper - a big, blue version of the kid's toy (£16).

www.iwantoneofthose.com has plenty to satisfy the 'I want to chuck something urge'. The X-Zylo Ultra (£6), which looks suspiciously like the bottom half of a coke bottle, has been known to travel up to 600ft. The Aerobie Frisbee (£9) could be a safer option. But set to rise higher than the Frisbee this summer is the boomerang. The Rang Aussie Flyer (£19.99) at www.bbtpaintball.com/ co.uk might look like a pair of pants, but its "state of the art aerodynamic design" will guarantee an impressive throw for even the very limp-wristed.

webTitle: How much can you pay for

fields.headline: How much can you pay for
fields.standfirst:
... perfume

Shopping Unlimited
fields.trailText: ... perfume
fields.body:
If retro grooming products are the very last word in beauty chic, they don't come much chicer than the bespoke perfumes from the House of Creed, the preserve of the seriously rich and famous. You're most likely to find the elegant leather atomiser - neatly embossed in gold, with the owner's initials - emerging from the handbag of a royal or Hollywood star. An initial consultation to determine your favourite fragrances, your age, occupation, colouring and lifestyle allows the createur perfumeur to select the ingredients needed for a perfume that you'll like and will suit you. Adding your name to a client list that includes Audrey Hepburn and Sharon Stone is a privilege that doesn't come cheap.Prices start at £1,800 per litre for eau de toilette and £4,000 for eau de parfum. And if you think that's a little on the extravagant side, the minimum order is 10 litres. Do the maths and then contemplate the alternatives. You could opt for a perfume from Creed's Millesime range, which includes Fleurissimo, the fragrance commissioned for Grace Kelly's marriage to Prince Rainier of Monaco (£36 for 30ml).

Call Les Senteurs on 020 7730 2322.

fields.headline: Ooh, Betty
fields.standfirst:
Speaker's retirement shocks MPs
Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: "Order, order!" shouted Betty Boothroyd. Most MPs did not even know that this was one of the last times she will have cleared the tubes with her famous catchphrase.
fields.body:
"Order, order!" shouted Betty Boothroyd. Most MPs did not even know that this was one of the last times she will have cleared the tubes with her famous catchphrase.

What I've always liked is the way that when she is genuinely angry, the genteel voice fades and her Yorkshire accent returns, like a barmaid declaring that she will throw you buggers out if she doesn't get a bit of hush - Sue Lawley turns into Annie Walker.

She then announced that, after eight years, she would retire as Speaker just before the next session begins. It was a tremendous shock. For some Tories, it must have been like hearing that nanny is leaving to get married. They'd pretend to be happy for her, but inside they'd be screaming "what about me?".

Betty then said that she would also resign from her seat in West Bromwich West. A startled "ooh" swept round the chamber, and you can bet there were plenty of MPs who at that point could actually recall her majority when she was last opposed by a Tory (7,830; should be just about safe barring another rise in petrol tax).

But she clearly thought the "ooh" was one of dismay, because she departed from her script and said passionately, "Be happy for me!" - and for the first time I have ever heard, the House of Commons started clapping.

It was an extraordinary sight and an extraordinary sound. Clapping is not what they do. You are simply not supposed to clap, in the same way as you are not meant to throw toilet rolls.

You can go "year, year, year" like a manatee with indigestion. You may shout and jeer and yell. You can wave your order paper in the air. You can even, like Le Petomane, fart Frère Jacques, and you will find nothing to forbid it in Erskine May.

But against all the rules they clapped, wildly, with warmth and gratitude and affection, as if she were Judi Dench at the Oscars, Shirley Bassey on the Des O'Connor Show, or the Williams sisters at Wimbledon.

Or at least the Labour and Liberal benches clapped. Some strange atavistic impulse stopped almost all the Tories from joining in (Michael Ancram and Ann Widdecombe did clap, but in a rather tired, thanks-due-to-our-hon-sec kind of way). Did the rest imagine that on this day of all days the Speaker would reprove them?

Betty does not - how can I put this - have serious problems with her self-esteem, and I suspect she was awfully pleased to find that the announcement of her going was greeted by a total break-down in parliamentary order.

Then Margaret Beckett announced that there would be a full valediction in a fortnight, allowing Betty to represent the house in Ukraine, New York, Scotland and other foreign climes. (In the US I saw, on Saturday Night Live, a take-off of our own prime minister's question time, based on the assumption that viewers would recognise it. That's like Rory Bremner spoofing the Danish parliament and expecting us to get the gags.)

Mrs Beckett added that the election of Speaker will be held when the house returns for autumn, when the father of the house - Ted Heath - will take the chair. So instead of the Speaker saying, "Order, order!" MPs will have to yell "Wakey, wakey!"

MPs filed away to discuss the succession. They love elections for Speaker; they can conspire and wheedle and trade without caring two hoots what their constituents think.

Oh, and thanks to the Tory u-turn on taxes, Tony Blair did much better at question time, which left his troops in a very good mood, with a leader who looks once more like a winner, and 15 blissful weeks of plotting to come.
