fields.headline: They called her madam
fields.standfirst: Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: Beaming more broadly than ever, Betty Boothroyd yesterday told the Commons that she plans to stand down as speaker of the House of Commons when the house breaks up for the summer.
fields.body:
Beaming more broadly than ever, Betty Boothroyd yesterday told the Commons that she plans to stand down as speaker of the House of Commons when the house breaks up for the summer. Brief tributes were immediately paid and warm, even gushing ones will follow on her final day in the chair two weeks from now. Unlike some parliamentary tributes, these will come from the heart.

That she wants to go is hardly surprising. She is 70, and no doubt she wants her life back. The speakership is a famously lonely office: even old friends must be kept at some distance, lest charges be made of partiality. The job drove one of her postwar predecessors, Horace King, to drink and another, Selwyn Lloyd, to distraction. Ms Boothroyd, more than most, is an outgoing person, almost Mowlamesque in her warmth and exuberance, so she must find that hard. She also loves travelling, a life she can now resume as a private person rather than someone stamped with officialdom.

She has been there since April 1992, and it has not always been easy. Sometimes she has been sniped at, cruelly even. There would have been something wrong if she hadn't been. The speaker is put there to defend the rights of the House, which especially means the rights of backbenchers. Once the speaker had to stand up for the House against the monarch; now she still has to do so against an over-mighty executive.

T hat sense of the need to install someone independent of government, a Commons champion, was the main reason why they chose her. John Major's government had been batting for Peter Brooke, who would have done the job well and entertainingly, but fatally he was fresh out of the cabinet. Just as the Commons had earlier defied Margaret Thatcher to pick Bernard Weatherill ahead of her nominee - her friend and loyal lieutenant Humphrey Atkins - so now even Tory members backed Boothroyd, a Labour MP, ahead of Brooke in the first contested election in 40 years.

Before too long complaints about her tenancy were sneakily whispered into complaisant ears. So unhelpful to ministers; so soft on their hecklers; too ready to grant an emergency debate even though the government had let it been known that it would not be welcome. What a shame she could not subordinate her old Labour sympathies, some senior Tories weaselled. Later much the same complaints about unhelpfulness could be heard from Labour ministers too. Her really bad moments were few. The worst was when she tried and failed to silence Michael Mates after he left the Conservative government. Don't persist with that line of argument, she warned, but he did. For a while her famous confidence was visibly shaken.

Some of her pet campaigns were more more successful than others. She writhed as new Labour MPs put endless lickspittle questions, apparently read from cue cards supplied by the whips, to Labour ministers; and again as ministers ate up question time with rambling answers. When rebuked, they amended their ways; but not for long. She had limited success in her fight to make the BBC resuscitate Today in Parliament; even less with her constant moans about initiatives launched on the Today programme when they should have been launched in the House. That persists, for all her strictures; given the way modern politics works, she was always going to fail.

Ms Boothroyd was the first woman speaker. As with Margaret Thatcher as premier 13 years earlier, the surprise that this should happen soon wore off. She redesigned the uniform to make it more female-friendly: asked how she should be addressed she replied "call me madam". Appropriately for one with a showbiz background; no profile of her has ever appeared without some reference to her days as a Tiller Girl.

She is so much a part of the show that it seems incongruous now to write of her in the past tense, but already the names of successors are being discussed. More often than not, the job has alternated between the two biggest parties. This time there will be support for the Liberal Democrat, Menzies Campbell, who should have become party leader when Paddy Ashdown gave up. Though again MPs will say to themselves:he would do the job well, but is he too close to Blair?

July 26, when she goes, will be a great party, with love and no doubt with tears. "Be happy for me," she instructed MPs yesterday; they're used to doing as Betty tells them, so no doubt they will. It is hardly how Mr Speaker Lenthall, Tony Benn's 17th century hero, would have addressed the House, or Arthur Onslow, who served it for 34 years a century later. But it's certainly no worse for that.

What a shame she could not subordinate her old Labour sympathies, some senior Tories weaselled. Later much the same complaints about unhelpfulness could be heard from Labour ministers too. Her really bad moments were few. The worst was when she tried and failed to silence Michael Mates after he left the Conservative government. Don't persist with that line of argument, she warned, but he did. For a while her famous confidence was visibly shaken. Some of her pet campaigns were more more successful than others. She writhed as new Labour MPs put endless lickspittle questions, apparently read from cue cards supplied by the whips, to Labour ministers; and again as ministers ate up question time with rambling answers. When rebuked, they amended their ways; but not for long. She had limited success in her fight to make the BBC resuscitate Today in Parliament; even less with her constant moans about initiatives launched on the Today programme when they should have been launched in the House. That persists, for all her strictures; given the way modern politics works, she was always going to fail. Ms Boothroyd was the first woman speaker. As with Margaret Thatcher as premier 13 years earlier, the surprise that this should happen soon wore off. She redesigned the uniform to make it more female-friendly: asked how she should be addressed she replied "call me madam". Appropriately for one with a showbiz background; no profile of her has ever appeared without some reference to her days as a Tiller Girl. She is so much a part of the show that it seems incongruous now to write of her in the past tense, but already the names of successors are being discussed. More often than not, the job has alternated between the two biggest parties. This time there will be support for the Liberal Democrat, Menzies Campbell, who should have become party leader when Paddy Ashdown gave up. Though again MPs will say to themselves:he would do the job well, but is he too close to Blair? July 26, when she goes, will be a great party, with love and no doubt with tears. "Be happy for me," she instructed MPs yesterday; they're used to doing as Betty tells them, so no doubt they will. It is hardly how Mr Speaker Lenthall, Tony Benn's 17th century hero, would have addressed the House, or Arthur Onslow, who served it for 34 years a century later. But it's certainly no worse for that. david.mckie@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Boothroyd decision takes MPs unawares
fields.standfirst: Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: The Speaker, Betty Boothroyd, drew gasps and sparked an unprecedented burst of applause across the Commons floor and public gallery yesterday when she announced she was standing down as Speaker this autumn after eight turbulent years in the post.
fields.body:
The Speaker, Betty Boothroyd, drew gasps and sparked an unprecedented burst of applause across the Commons floor and public gallery yesterday when she announced she was standing down as Speaker this autumn after eight turbulent years in the post.

She had been expected to continue at least until the election, but she told MPs she wanted to retire earlier, partly so the present crop of MPs could choose her successor.

Her decision will prompt a byelection in her West Bromwich constituency, where Labour party members are keen to select an Asian or black candidate. With many MPs expressing their sadness with sighs and low moans as she made her retirement announcement, she stopped herself and said to laughter: "Be happy for me".

It was announced she would make a valedictory address on July 26 before the summer recess, when she is likely to let loose some of her frustration at the growing dominance of the executive, the gradual decline in importance of the Commons chamber, and the tendency for government ministers to make their announcements outside the Commons. Miss Boothroyd is 70, smokes heavily, and has suffered a minor stomach ailment, but illness did not prompt her retirement decisison. Her successor will be elected when MPs return on October 23, prompting months of discreet electioneering. The vote will be presided over by Sir Edward Heath, father of the house.

The Conservative party will argue it is its turn to take the Speakership, but two Liberal Democrat MPs, Alan Beith and Menzies Campbell, are also being touted.

The television coverage of Commons proceedings has made Miss Boothroyd a national symbol and she is often cited in polls as the public's first choice for president if the country ever became a republic.

Leading an early flood of tributes, Tony Blair said: "She is a really outstanding Speaker, not just because she is sharp and to the point but because she has a marvellous way of using humour and fun to try to deflect really difficult situations. She will be really missed, deeply missed, on all sides of the house."

The Liberal Democrat leader, Charles Kennedy, said: "As the first woman Speaker, her place in the history books is assured. She has been a magnificent ambassador for parliamentary democracy in this country." Former prime minister John Major said Miss Boothroyd had been an "outstanding" Speaker and was a hard act to follow.

Sir Alan Haselhurst, the Deputy Speaker, has been installed as even-money favourite by William Hill to become Miss Boothroyd's successor. The Labour MP John McWilliam (Blaydon) became the first to declare his candidacy for the post, but few rate his chances.

Front runners

Menzies Campbell

Aged 59. Liberal Democrat foreign affairs and defence spokesman. Elegant lawyer, erudite debater and a former sprint record holder, he was once famously described by his wife as "the fastest white man on earth".

Verdict: Seen in the press as the Downing Street favourite

Sir George Young

Aged 58. Admired as shadow leader of the house. Won friends in liberal circles during both Thatcher and Major administrations. Ridiculously tall with dry sense of humour to match wet Tory politics.

Verdict : Not sure if he wants the job.

Sir Alan Haselhurst

Aged 63. The current deputy speaker would be the natural Tory to take the job if the Commons thought he had a dominant enough personality. Widely seen as a fair and knowledgeable deputy, but few think he matches Betty Boothroyd for personality, warmth or style. Unlikely to be excited by modernising chamber.

Verdict: Safe, but maybe too safe

Alan Beith

Aged 57. Deputy leader of Lib Dems is widely liked on all sides and would be more popular with many Labour MPs than Menzies Campbell. A Methodist lay preacher, he has more humour than demeanour suggests.

Verdict: Charisma not his strong suit.

Gwyneth Dunwoody

Aged 69. Fiercely independent Labour backbencher and close friend of Betty Boothroyd. She may have gone too far in attacking government to win mainstream Labour vote.

Verdict: May be too old, but would carry on the tough Boothroyd tradition.

webTitle: Heroes past and present to play for Marshall

fields.headline: Heroes past and present to play for Marshall
fields.standfirst: Have you any cricketing queries? Email asksteven@guardian.co.uk with your question.
fields.trailText: Could you let me have some details of the upcoming charity match in honour of the late Malcolm Marshall? asks Pete Manns
fields.body:
Could you let me have some details of the upcoming charity match in honour of the late Malcolm Marshall? asks Pete Manns

This is a special match at the Honourable Artillery Company ground in the City of London on Thursday July 27, starting at 2pm. An International Bunbury XI, including players like Graham Gooch, Shane Warne, Graham Thorpe, Mike Gatting and Robin Smith, will take on a West Indian XI, captained by Viv Richards and containing many of Marshall's former team-mates in that all-powerful West Indian side of the 1980s. For ticket details, click here. All proceeds will go to a special charitable trust set up to provide for Mali Marshall, Malcolm's young son.

Can you tell me anything about the West Indies Test cricketer Ellis Achong? asks Maryse Achong from Trinidad

Ellis Edgar "Puss" Achong (1904-86) was a left-arm spinner of Chinese extraction who played six Tests for West Indies in the 1930s, taking eight wickets. He is credited with inventing the chinaman delivery - the left-arm wrist-spinner's googly. After he bowled Walter Robins, the Middlesex and England allrounder, in a match at Lord's, Robins is supposed to have returned to the dressing-room and exclaimed "Fancy being bowled by a Chinaman!", whereupon one of his team-mates asked him whether he meant the bowler or the ball. Achong was the subject of a long article by Scyld Berry in Wisden Cricket Monthly in April 1998. This back issue is still available: e-mail wisden@ndirect.co.uk or ring 01483 570358 or for details.

Can you please explain how the County Championship points system works? asks Phil Bowker

The points system has changed a lot over the years - and it has changed again for the current season. The easy part is that the side winning the match gets 12 points, and both sides receive four points in a drawn game (six points each for a tie; no points for losing). The complicated bit is the bonus points, which are only available in the first 130 overs of each side's first innings. You can earn a maximum of five batting bonus points, for passing 200, 250, 300, 350 and 400. And you get bowling points - a maximum of three - for taking three, six and nine wickets. So the maximum number of points a county can score in a game is 20.

What were the first names of Leyland, who played cricket for Yorkshire in the 1930s? asks Norman Brindley

His one and only Christian name was Maurice (it was spelt "Morris" on his birth certificate). He was born in Harrogate on July 20, 1900, and died there on New Year's Day, 1967. Leyland was a fine left-hand batsman, who scored 33,660 runs in first-class cricket between 1920 and 1947, at an average of 40.50, with 80 centuries. He scored 2764 runs (46.06) in 41 Tests. He was also a handy left-arm spinner, who took 466 first-class wickets at 29.31.

I hope to visit England in 2001. Have details of the international matches been released yet? asks Boyd Dempsey

You're in luck: the dates were announced earlier this week. England will play two Tests against Pakistan, at Lord's (May 17-21) and Old Trafford (May 31-June 4), and five against Australia, at Edgbaston (July 5-9), Lord's (July 19-23), Trent Bridge (Aug 2-6), Headingley (Aug 16-20) and The Oval (Aug 23-27). In between the two Test series the three sides will contest a one-day competition. It starts with a floodlit match (England v Pakistan) at Edgbaston on June 7; the final will be at Lord's on June 23.

Who has taken most wickets in one-day internationals? asks Otto Sreedharan

Top of the list is Wasim Akram, who recently took his 400th one-day wicket to go with 400 in Tests as well. He's now got 427, and is well clear of his team-mate Waqar Younis, who's second with 311. Anil Kumble (India) is third with 267. For a list of the leaders click here.

The biggest win in history was by an innings and 851 runs. Do you have any more details of the match? asks Alex Roberts

This was a match in Pakistan's Quaid-e-Azam Trophy at Lahore in 1964-65. Railways piled up 910 for 6 dec against Dera Ismail Khan, who replied with 32 and 27. DIK, as it is known, is a small town which didn't really have enough players to field a proper team - this turned out to be their one and only first-class match.

Can you settle an argument please? I think that Alec Stewart scored the most Test runs during the 1990s. Am I right? asks Mick Collins

Yes you are. Stewart scored more Test runs in the decade (6407) than anyone else. He was just ahead of Mark Waugh (6371), Mark Taylor (6306), Mike Atherton (6277) and Steve Waugh (6213). The decade's top Test wicket-taker was Shane Warne, with 351, ahead of those West Indian wonders Curtly Ambrose (309) and Courtney Walsh (304).

Against which bowler did David Gower score his first Test run? asks Toby Joyce

It was Pakistan's Liaqat Ali, a left-arm medium-pacer, at Edgbaston on June 2, 1978. Liaqat's first ball was a friendly, shortish one on leg stump. Gower, who was two months past his 21st birthday, swivelled and pulled the ball effortlessly to the boundary. He went on to score 58, and made his first Test century against New Zealand later that summer. Gower actually made his full international debut in a one-dayer against Pakistan at Old Trafford in May 1978: he made 33.

Steven Lynch is managing editor of Wisden Cricket Monthly. We regret that not all questions can be answered and that personal correspondence can only sometimes be entered into.

To read last week's Ask Steven, featuring the last man to do the double, Aggers' ball-by-ball baptism and Australia's 41-year-old captain, click here

webTitle: Edinburgh film festival showcases new technologies

fields.headline: Edinburgh film festival showcases new technologies
fields.trailText: The 54th Edinburgh International Film Festival, one of the most important, influential and longest-running in the world, will be held this year between August 13 and 27.
fields.body:
The 54th Edinburgh International Film Festival, one of the most important, influential and longest-running in the world, will be held this year between August 13 and 27.

The programme for the year's festival was announced this morning. Lars Von Trier's already infamous Palme D'Or winner Dancer In The Dark will open proceedings, and Hong Kong director Wong Kar-Wai's exquisite story of unrequited love, In the Mood for Love, has been chosen to close the two-week festival. The director will be present in Edinburgh to give a masterclass - part of the Reel Life series of classes from directors, actors and writers.

Also scheduled to participate in the Reel Life series are Se7en cinematographer Darius Khonji, Swedish director Liv Ullman (whose highly acclaimed film Faithless will be playing), and Basic Instinct and Robocop director Paul Verhoeven, whose The Hollow Man receives its international premiere.

Terence Davies's sumptuous adaptation of Edith Wharton's novel The House of Mirth, starring Gillian Anderson, gets its world premiere, and the likes of Neil LaBute's Nurse Betty (think Doris Day meets David Lynch), Anthony Hopkins in Julie Taymor's bloody Shakespeare adaptation Titus, and the Coen brothers' eagerly anticipated O Brother, Where Art Thou? are sure to attract critical and popular interest.

Digital technology and the endless possibilities of the medium of film are at the forefront of this year's festival. Dancer In The Dark, the opening film, was shot entirely digitally, as was the moving and deeply human drama One Life Stand. Showing as part of the Focus on British Cinema Strand, the latter also boasts the distinction of being the first ever feature film to be shown digitally in the UK. There will also be a special screening of Mike Figgis's Time Code, which was shot digitally, in real time, and will be accompanied by a live sound mix.

The Focus on British Cinema section includes Cannes hits Purely Belter and Billy Elliot (formerly called Dancer); most films are showing for the first time in the UK, if not the world.

Late Night Romps highlights the best of horror and thrillers from around the world; perhaps this year's biggest treat is the Japanese horror series The Ring, which has been a phenomenon in its native Japan. The films, based on the work of Koji Suzuki (Japan's equivalent to Stephen King), are true psycho-horror that descend into unimaginable terror, with scenes of extreme violence and paranormal activity. All three films in the series will be showing.

This year's retrospective looks at the work of master visual stylist Max Ophuls. There is also a selection of family films (look out for David Bowie in a cameo role in Mr Rice's Secret), and, although the festival is non-competitive, six high-profile awards will be given out, including the Guardian New Director's Award and the Michael Powell Award for Best New British Feature.

 To order a programme, call the Hotline on 0907 0131 500 (calls cost £1 to cover post and packaging), or check the website on www.edfilmfest.org.uk.

fields.headline: Blair spells out Labour successes
fields.standfirst:
Economy is stable and more investment to come, prime minister pledges
Read the annual report
fields.trailText: The government has today launched its annual report, with Tony Blair taking personal charge of driving home Labour's pre-election message that the government is indeed delivering on its pledges.
fields.body:
The government has today launched its annual report, with Tony Blair taking personal charge of driving home Labour's pre-election message that the government is indeed delivering on its pledges.

Presenting the report to parliament this afternoon, the prime minister told the Commons that the government's first priority was to get the economic fundamentals right. One million new jobs had been created; real take home pay was up and inflation down. "But none of this has come about without serious, grown-up choices," he said.

"I know that some of these decisions, like the rises in fuel duty, were unpopular. But they were necessary. That stability having been fought for and on course to being won, now we must make the next choice: to invest in the country's future."

The prime minister said Britain was a "chronically under-invested in nation", with transport, health and education starved of resources under the Tories. On the health service, he said there must now be sustained falls in outpatient waiting times.

On transport he said substantial extra investment was needed. "We admit it. The 10-year transport plan to be published shortly will show how it can be done."

And Mr Blair acknowledged that violent crime was on the rise. "We need more police. We will get them. We need new ways to tackle drugs. We will get them. We need tougher action against drug dealers. We are legislating against them."

Mr Blair concluded: "Our purpose is to build a Britain that is strong, modern and fair, under a government which at long last sees economic prosperity and fairness not as opponents but as partners in building the Britain of the future."

The report is the government's third yearly assessment of its performance and activities since its May 1997 election victory. The first two reports were widely mocked as being self-congratulatory, and the Liberal Democrats and Tories made it clear that the latest report faces a similar reception from the government's political opponents.

The Conservative leader, William Hague told the Commons that only a prime minister accused of being "all gloss and gimmicks" would attempt to rebut the charge by publishing a glossy brochure.

The annual report, which is on sale at branches of WH Smith and Tesco, takes the form of an updated assessment by the government on its progress in implementing its election manifesto commitments.

"This is the third annual report," Mr Hague said. "The first was entitled 'So what do you think', the second was called 'So what are we doing', the third one ought to accurately be called 'So what on earth are we going to do now?'" He argued that the report ranged from the "banal" to the "completely untrue".

The Conservative leader, William Hague told the Commons that only a prime minister accused of being "all gloss and gimmicks" would attempt to rebut the charge by publishing a glossy brochure. The annual report, which is on sale at branches of WH Smith and Tesco, takes the form of an updated assessment by the government on its progress in implementing its election manifesto commitments. "This is the third annual report," Mr Hague said. "The first was entitled 'So what do you think', the second was called 'So what are we doing', the third one ought to accurately be called 'So what on earth are we going to do now?'" fields.headline: Fiji coup
fields.standfirst: As the hostage-taking in Fiji ends, Mark Tran and Jo Griffiths explain why the crisis is not over yet
fields.trailText: As the hostage-taking in Fiji ends, Mark Tran and Jo Griffiths explain why the crisis is not over yet.
fields.body:
What is the latest in the crisis?
George Speight, the coup leader in Fiji, has now released the remaining 18 hostages, including deposed prime minister, Mahendra Chaudhry. The release of the hostages ended a two month crisis which has paralysed the country and imperilled the tourist trade. The possibility of the releases came after the army agreed to abolish the countryÕs multiracial constitution, grant the rebels amnesty and remove Mr Chaudhry from office. Mr Speight was finally pushed into delivering the hostages after FujiÕs traditional leaders, the Council of Chiefs, issued a statement saying that no constitutional changes would occur until the hostages were freed. Mr Chaudhry has made an initial statement saying he feels no acrimony towards Mr Speight, and calling for the Fijians to work harmoniously together to secure a prosperous future.

Has Mr Speight been granted all his demands?
Basically, yes, although the role he will play in the new government is as yet undetermined. Mr Speight's main goal was to get rid of Fiji's multiracial constitution and replace it with one which would only permit Fijians to hold the posts of prime minister and president. He also demanded an amnesty for himself and his collaborators. All these key demands have now been met by the military, which declared martial law after the takeover of parliament.

Have there been other incidents of unrest?
Other groups have followed Mr Speight's example. Four tourist resorts were taken over by supporters of Mr Speight, including the exclusive Turtle Island beach resort where the movie The Blue Lagoon was filmed. They briefly held 40 tourists. In other incidents, about 70 people, also wanting to discuss land rights, gathered outside Suva's airport, while the military reported a riot in the maximum security wing of Naboro prison 10 miles outside Suva, the capital.

Who is George Speight?
He is a failed businessman and the son of an opposition MP, Sam Speight. George Speight was chairman of two Fijian firms involved in the country's lucrative $60m mahogany timber trade, but was sacked by Mr Chaudhry after he came to power in last year's landslide victory.

Is there anyone behind Mr Speight?
Mr Speight always seemed a rather implausible coup leader, and there have been reports that the real coup leader is a former special services soldier loyal to former prime minister Rabuka. APF, the French news agency, has reported that the actual leader is Colonel Ilisoni Ligairi, 60, who received training in the UK. He is in charge of the counter revolutionary warfare unit (CRWU) which Mr Speight used to seize Fiji's parliament. The CRWU, considered Fiji's version of the Special Air Service, frequently operates with special forces from Britain, Australia and New Zealand.

Didn't analysts think the coup was going to peter out quickly?
That was the initial thinking. But the longer the coup went on, the more support Mr Speight received from the Fijian population. Fiji's traditional chiefs eventually gave their blessing to the coup, calling for Mr Chaudhry to be replaced by an indigenous Fijian. The chiefs, wield enormous influence, and have now agreed to all of Mr Speight's demands, including a pardon for all those involved in the coup.

What will be the effect on the island's Indian population?
Fiji is bracing itself for a mass Indian emigration similar to that after the 1987 coup. Indians started coming to Fiji as labourers on sugar plantations at the end of the 19th century, when Fiji was a British colony. By 1970, when Fiji became independent, ethnic Indians were in a majority. But after the 1987 coup, many Indians - especially professionals - left the country, and now 51% of the 800,000 population are indigenous Fijians. Indians form 44% of the population.

What is the political background to the crisis?
The Fijian-dominated Alliance Party led by former president Ratu Sir Kamisese Mara (he resigned at the start of the crisis as one of Mr Speight's demands) dominated Fijian politics after independence. But elections in April 1987 saw the Alliance Party supplanted by a multi-racial coalition which divided ministerial jobs evenly between Fijians and Indians, to the consternation of hard-line indigenous nationalists. After colonel Sitiveni Rabuka took power in the 1987 coup, he declared Fiji a republic and the country was expelled from the Commonwealth. Fiji rejoined the Commonwealth in 1997, but it now faces sanctions once again.

fields.headline: Warners pledge British Harry Potter
fields.trailText: Sources at Warner Brothers have moved to head off speculation that the forthcoming Harry Potter picture will have an American hero
fields.body:
Sources at Warner Brothers have moved to head off speculation that the forthcoming Harry Potter picture will have an American hero. The movie is currently in pre-production with American director Christopher Columbus in the chair and American money behind it.

Earlier this week it was rumoured that Columbus was looking outside the UK for a child to play the boy wizard (see our story), but Inside.com quotes an unnamed senior source at Warner Bros as promising that "this will be a British Harry. Not a single person in this film will be anything other than British... Chris is very protective of the integrity of the book."

The concerns over Potter's nationality have been simmering ever since Stephen Spielberg was slated to direct the project. Spielberg allegedly bailed out of the project over creative differences with Rowling, having been set on casting American child star Haley Joel Osment (of The Sixth Sense fame) in the title role. The latest reports suggest, however, that director Columbus is being careful to stay much more faithful to the original books.

webTitle: The hostages are free but Fijian crisis continues

fields.headline: The hostages are free but Fijian crisis continues
fields.standfirst: Without proper democracy, unrest will persist and sanctions could be imposed, writes Guardian foreign affairs specialist Simon Tisdall
fields.trailText: Without proper democracy, unrest will persist and sanctions could be imposed, writes Guardian foreign affairs specialist Simon Tisdall .
fields.body:
The ending of the hostage seizure in Fiji today does not mark the end of the country's political and constitutional crisis. Far from it.

The insurrection led by George Speight, the self-proclaimed leader of Fiji's indigenous population, caused a 56-day standoff between the Fijian army and the rebels holding hostages inside the parliament building in the capital Suva and has done lasting damage.

It brought condemnation from regional countries such as Australia and New Zealand, from the Commonwealth and from the EU, as the elected, ethnic Indian prime minister, Mahendra Chaudhry, and other government members were held captive and stripped of office, and the multiracial constitution was scrapped.

Mr Speight's demands frequently changed, and his promises were just as frequently broken. But to the dismay of those concerned to uphold a democratic system, both the military and the powerful Great Council of tribal chiefs seemed from the first to be sympathetic to his insistence that indigenous Fijians take over the government and that the country's Indians, comprising 44% of the population, be excluded from power.

Mr Speight and his men, already been granted an amnesty, have been celebrating their "success". But the extent of that success is still unfolding.

The decision of the Great Council to appoint a Speight nominee, Ratu Josefa Iloilo, as Fiji's new president is an indication of the power shift that has already taken place. It now remains to be seen whether or not Mr Speight himself will join Fiji's next government, possibly as its prime minister.

Such an outcome would certainly appal neighbours such as Australia. The government of John Howard welcomed the end of the hostage siege, but a statement issued in Canberra said: "The Australian government remains profoundly disturbed at the abrogation of the Fijian constitution and the racially based approach apparently being taken to future constitutional arrangements."

Mr Howard has described Mr Speight's revolt as a "criminal act" and Australia and New Zealand have threatened to impose trade and diplomatic sanctions on Fiji unless democracy is fully restored.

The Commonwealth and the EU, which have eschewed sanctions during the hostage crisis, could well take a tougher line if Mr Speight takes power.

Mr Chaudhry, the deposed prime minister, demonstrated impressive cool after his release, saying he did not harbour a grudge against the captors who beat him up early on in the crisis.

Mr Chaudhry, unlike his opponents, is an experienced and well-connected politician. Now that he has been freed, he may become the focus of international efforts to restore a credible democracy.

The Indian minority population, which largely kept its collective head down during the siege, may also begin to make its feelings heard now the captives are free.

This could bring the Indian community into conflict with Speight supporters and with groups of indigenous Fijians who have carried out a series of ad hoc occupations and property seizures in recent weeks, including foreign-owned tourist resorts. With the military's position compromised, the immediate situation seems highly hazardous.

In other words, the end of the hostage siege may just be the beginning of a new and even more troubling chapter in Fiji.

webTitle: Graham: we're on the right track

fields.headline: Graham: we're on the right track
fields.standfirst: The Spurs manager talks to Sean Ingle about his summer signings, and how he hopes to meet  supporters' high expectations
fields.trailText: Spurs manager George Graham has warned fans not to expect the glory days to return to White Hart Lane just yet - despite the recent signings of Sergei Rebrov, Neil Sullivan and Ben Thatcher.
fields.body:
Spurs manager George Graham has warned fans not to expect the glory days to return to White Hart Lane just yet - despite the recent signings of Sergei Rebrov, Neil Sullivan and Ben Thatcher.

"We've still got some work to do," Graham admitted in an exclusive interview with Football Unlimited. "Spurs have always been a big club, but the problem is they haven't really achieved.

"I don't think there's any question of that: it's 40 years since they won the championship. Really they should have been challenging for the championship on a regular basis."

Graham has targeted a top six place and a trophy for the forthcoming season, and insists the club is heading in the right direction. "Do I share the fans' buoyancy? Of course I do," he said. "We've spent a lot of during the last few weeks and if there's one thing I'd like to give to the Spurs fans it is expectation.

"If we can get some more players here and get a big enough squad we will start challenging the big boys and then I expect the fans' expectation to rise further," he added.

Graham's guarded optimism was backed up by director of football, David Pleat. When asked by Football Unlimited whether the recent £16m outlay on new players meant that Spurs were now back with the Premiership big boys, he was quick to dampen expectations.

"No, we're not a big club yet," he said. "The results have to prove that. We have to do well on the field. But the recent signings do show an ambition that some people suggested we are lacking."

But Pleat is optimistic about the future, and says the five U-21 internationals at the club all have an excellent chance of becoming first team regulars.

"Everyone talks about our big name signings, but don't forget that some of the younger players are doing very well too. There are at least five boys under 21s, who aren't regular first team players: Doherty, Gardner, Young, Davies and Etherington coming through," he said. "And Sol Campbell is staying, which means our squad will be a lot stronger than this time last year."

"But we're not there yet. We just feel it takes a lot of thinking and a lot of patience, but we do believe we can turn it round. The way to do that though is to start winning matches."

fields.headline: Perfectly executed
fields.standfirst: Derek Malcolm’s 100 greatest movies. This week, number 76: Jean-Pierre Melville’s Le Samourai
fields.trailText: It is difficult to see how this story could be better accomplished. It has all the best virtues of American film noir but with a European sensibility that could have seemed melodramatic or pretentious in a Hollywood film
fields.body:
In France, there are few more admired directors than Jean-Pierre Melville. He changed his name from Grumbach after he read Moby Dick and used to wear a stetson and dark glasses, as if to prove his allegiance to American style. But though Hollywood films, especially of the pre-war variety, were his model, his work remained unmistakably French. In fact, many thought Melville was as much influenced by Bresson as by films such as Huston's Asphalt Jungle. But he would usually reply that, on the contrary, Bresson was influenced by him. Melville was the true ancestor of the French New Wave.

Certainly, he made a series of films that were unlike anyone else's, and Le Samourai, one of the best of them, could be regarded as one of the greatest psychological thrillers, addressing questions of honour, loyalty and betrayal.

It gave Alain Delon his best part. Filmed on the wide screen and in wonderfully muted colour to add atmosphere - the great Henri Decaë was Melville's cinematographer - it has Delon as a ruthless hired killer living alone in a dingy apartment with a bullfinch as his sole companion. The girl who loves him (Nathalie Delon, Alain's wife) lives in greater luxury elsewhere at another man's expense and is prepared to give him a perfect alibi after his next contract. He executes it with chilling skill in a nightclub and successfully avoids a hood sent to kill him and a posse of police on his trail.

He is, however, doomed from the first, or, as Melville puts it, "laid out in death". He is tempted by a girl he saw in a corridor of the nightclub and should have killed as a witness; thus he breaks the first rule of his trade, which is not to get emotionally involved. It's a bad mistake and honour demands that she has to be his next contract. But, almost masochistically, he deliberately uses an empty gun and is shot down by the police. He has virtually committed hari-kiri.

It is difficult to see how this story could be better accomplished. It has all the best virtues of American film noir but with a European sensibility that could have seemed melodramatic or pretentious in a Hollywood film. Paris becomes a city of shadows. In the first scene, where Delon lies stretched out on his bed in the half-light, a sense of acute foreboding is created. This is rigorously maintained throughout, with very little dialogue to disturb it.

Le Samourai is as efficient a piece of cinema as it is darkly romantic. Melville shows us his lone killer's methodical precision with great flair, and the police manhunt through the Métro is as good an action sequence as any.

The film opens with a purported line from the Book of Bushido - the source of the Japanese warrior class's knowledge: "There is no greater solitude than that of the samurai, unless perhaps it be that of the tiger in the jungle." After the film was shown in Japan, Melville admitted he wrote the quotation himself. But Delon expresses this perfectly with his deliberately impassive performance.

It wasn't for nothing that Godard gave Melville a bit part in A Bout de Souffle. He and other New Wavers acknowledged his mastery freely while understanding that he was an individualist who would never subscribe to any movement.

fields.headline: Badgers
fields.standfirst: All you need to know about Britain's favourite cuddly mammal, and why some farmers want them killed
fields.trailText: All you need to know about Britain's favourite cuddly mammal, and why some farmers want them killed
fields.body:
1. The Ministry of Agriculture has released the latest figures on the spread of bovine tuberculosis, showing a 6% rise over the past year. Many farmers believe that badgers are responsible for spreading the disease.

2. Wildlife lobbyists point out that myobacterium bovis, the bug responsible for bovine TB, affects less than 0.1% of British cattle, compared with 40% before the second world war. The alleged link with badgers was first postulated only in the early 1970s.

3. The Ministry is keen to stamp out bovine TB, not least because all infected cattle must be slaughtered and their owners compensated at market rates.

4. MAFF and its independent advisers are working on a five-point programme, including a detailed study of whether badgers can transmit the disease to cattle.

5. The study will involve the shooting of some 12,500 badgers - about 3% of the estimated population. Conservation groups like Brockwatch and the National Federation of Badger Groups say the cull is unscientific, inhumane, and unnecessary.

6. They also accuse the government of making a sharp U-turn on its pre-election pledge to stop the cull, which was recommended in a report by Professor John Krebs at the end of 1997. Maff has acknowledged, as recently as May, that the badger-factor is as yet unproved, but insists that it must be investigated thoroughly.

7. The National Farmers' Union also has doubts, but insists that the cull must go on. The NFU is also keen to promote its members as wildlife custodians, but makes no mention of badgers on its attractive countryside web pages.

8. Badgers and their setts are protected by law - but not from Maff. fields.headline: Chemistry in motion
fields.standfirst: The US government wants Hollywood to spread an anti-drugs message to the masses. Just what are the politicians on? More than a few classic movies owe their existence to some illegal assistance. By  Clark Collis
fields.trailText: The US government wants Hollywood to spread an anti-drugs message to the masses. Just what are the politicians on? More than a few classic movies owe their existence to some illegal assistance. By Clark Collis
fields.body:
There's a scene in Warren Beatty's political satire Bulworth where his senatorial candidate addresses a roomful of Hollywood executives. "The funny thing is how lousy most of your stuff is," announces Beatty, who, having taken out a contract on himself, no longer feels obliged to lie. "You make violent films and you make dirty films and you make family films... but most of them are just not very good, are they?"

Given that the senator has turned the accepted way of doing things upside down, the depiction could not be more on the money. American politicians have traditionally been wary of speaking their mind about Tinseltown's product so as not to alienate people who are among their greatest backers - both in terms of money and more importantly star endorsements. Yet, while most satires date rapidly, Bulworth appears to be increasingly relevant. For it was announced on Monday that the Clinton government no longer intends to stand by and let Hollywood do what it wants, at least with regard to the on-screen depiction of drug abuse.

In fact, White House drugs "tsar" General Barry McCaffrey confirmed that a portion of his $1bn budget will be used "leveraging popular movies and videos" to promote the campaign against narcotic use by teenagers. McCaffrey's announcement follows what is perceived by the Clinton administration to be a successful initiative whereby TV companies are let off their requirement to screen drugs awareness messages - at half or less the market price - in return for promoting "accurate depictions of drug- use issues". As a result, prime-time hits like ER, Chicago Hope and Beverly Hills 90210 have all had their scripts amended to satisfy White House policy.

Now, bearing in mind that few characters on American TV shows were buying heroin ("Wanna go score some skag, Chandler?") or rolling joints ("Smooth smoke, Dr Ross!") in the first place, this does seem rather a waste of money. Movies, however, are another matter. Indeed, recent years have seen Hollywood increasingly showing drug use in a positive, or at least less than disastrous light, from the stoned babblings of Cheech And Chong to Bulworth itself, where the senator's dope-smoking has little adverse effect other than turning him into the world's worst - and worst-dressed - rapper.

In short, anti-drugs conspiracy theorists would have us believe that if The Sound Of Music were remade today then the hills would be alive not with the sound of music but with rustling fields of marijuana. ("Dope - a drug, a neat kind of drug. Ray - the guy we score off down the pub..." etc.)

Yet, while there's no doubt that the increasing use of hard drugs is an enormous social problem, both in the States and here, it's difficult to see quite how successful McCaffrey's crusade can be. After all, the world's not exactly short of armed conflict, despite a relatively small amount of recent movies suggesting that wars are an absolute hoot and that we should really have more of them.

And one wonders how many film stars we might have lost if their off-duty drug use had prevented them from getting work. You can forget Robert Mitchum, Richard Dreyfuss, Carrie Fisher and Dan Aykroyd for starters, while Dennis Hopper would also doubtless find his on-lot parking privileges revoked - although bearing in mind much of the actor-director's behaviour during the drug-drenched 70s, this might have been something of a boon all round.

Then there are the movies themselves, both those which were created, at least in part, by drug users (Jaws, Apocalypse Now, Animal House), and those which would be fundamentally different without their relatively positive narcotic depictions. Anyone who's ever seen the golf comedy Caddyshack, for example, will know that the most hilarious scene involves deranged groundskeeper Bill Murray showing fairway nut Chevy Chase his newly developed type of turf ("This is a hybrid of Kentucky bluegrass and Northern sensemillia. The amazing thing about this stuff is - you can play 26 holes on it in the afternoon, take it home and get stoned.")

Moreover, who is to say what constitutes a postive drug movie? Certainly, on paper 2001: A Space Odyssey is a drug-free zone, but that didn't stop hordes of cinema-goers using it to enhance their acid trips.

Then again, if he sticks rigidly to his own wording, McCaffrey may just be onto something. After all, as anyone who's been to Glastonbury can testify, an "accurate depiction of drug use" usually involves people talking a good deal of arrant nonsense while completely failing to understand the complex technology of chocolate bar wrappers - a vision of hell that would probably put most kids off drugs for life. One can only hope that, for his sake, Bruce Willis likes Kit-Kats.

fields.headline: Calling all beach cricketers
fields.trailText: Six into the sea ... not out first ball ... tip and run ... Wisden Cricket Monthly is turning its attention to a vital and neglected form of the game: beach cricket.
fields.body:
Six into the sea ... not out first ball ... tip and run ... Wisden Cricket Monthly is turning its attention to a vital and neglected form of the game: beach cricket.

We are looking for three or four families or other groups that will be sinking their stumps into the sand during July and are willing to be immortalised in the September issue of WCM.

And even if you are stuck in an office, we still want to hear from you if you know any anecdotes, secrets or even the definitive rules of beach cricket. (One hand one bounce? Half out or not? And at what score do you have to retire?)

The editor of WCM has already confessed that in Brittany in 1972, he kept his batting average in his head. If you have equally shocking revelations, or anything at all to say on the subject, email us at wisden@johnbrown.co.uk.

webTitle: So perhaps the Pope is really gay

fields.headline: So perhaps the Pope is really gay
fields.standfirst: What other explanation is there for his bizarre hate campaign?
fields.trailText: What other explanation is there for his bizarre hate campaign?
fields.body:
"What a man believes upon grossly insufficient evidence," Bertrand Russell wrote, "is an index to his desires - desires of which he himself is often unconscious." The Vatican's current obsession with homosexuality suggests that something interesting might be going on. Are some of the Catholic church's most powerful cardinals struggling with their sexuality? Could the Pope himself be gay?

On Sunday, the Holy Father launched his fiercest attack on gays, insisting that the World Pride festival in Rome was "an offence to the Christian values" of the city. Homosexuality, he maintained, is "objectively disordered" and "contrary to natural law".

Last year, the Congregation for the Doctrine of the Faith (CDF), the church's sinister enforcement agency, forbade a priest and a nun from ministering to gays in the United States, after they refused to sign a statement testifying that "homosexual acts are always objectively evil". Gays, the Vatican believes, bring their misfortunes upon themselves. "When civil legislation is introduced to protect behaviour to which no one has any conceivable right," the CDF asserts, "neither the church nor society at large should be surprised when . . . violent reactions increase." Gay rights campaigners maintain that between 150 and 200 gay men are murdered in Italy every year.

For this reason, if for no other, we should take this papal bull seriously. So let us examine the two main themes of the Vatican's edicts: homosexuality, it maintains, is both immoral and unnatural.

Morality is surely meaningless unless it refers to the impact we have on other people. Interestingly, even the Vatican appears unable to point to any ill-effects of safe sex between consenting gay adults, other than to suggest that its acceptance might "deprave" or "corrupt" other people. What this appears to mean is that they might be led away from the teachings of the church. Heterosexuality is quite another matter. Reproduction among prosperous people has a demonstrable impact on the welfare of others: thanks to the depletion of resources and the effects of climate change, every child born to the rich deprives children elsewhere of the means of survival. In a world of diminishing assets, being gay is arguably more moral than being straight.

The claim that homosexuality is "unnatural" is more interesting. This could mean one of two things. Perhaps the Pope is suggesting that it lies beyond the scope of "normal" human behaviour. If so, this has uncomfortable implications for an associa tion of old men who wear dresses, hear voices and practise ritual cannibalism.

Alternatively, he might be suggesting that homosexual behaviour is at variance with that of the non-human world. Here too, however, the church has a problem. Biological Exuberance, a book by the science writer Bruce Bagemihl, documents homosexuality in no fewer than 470 animal species. He shows how groups of manatees carouse in gay orgies; how male giraffes start "necking" and end up fornicating; how female Japanese macaques will pair off for weeks at a time, fondling each other and having sex.

As New Scientist magazine records, at the beginning of the last century the embarrassed keepers of Edinburgh Zoo had repeatedly to rename their penguins, after they found that the loving couples they observed were not all that they seemed. Female roseate terns sometimes mate with each other for life, allowing themselves to be fertilised by males, but making nests and bringing up their young together. I would hesitate to describe what pygmy chimpanzees, orang-utans or long-eared hedgehogs get up to, even in a liberal newspaper.

The world's wildlife, in other words, is depraved. But we would be hard put to call it unnatural. Self-enforced celibacy, by contrast, is all but unknown among other animal species. If any sexual behaviour is out of tune with the natural world, it is surely that of the priesthood.

My guess is that the Pope is not gay, but that he has found in homosexuals a necessary enemy, an external threat which allows the Holy See to justify its iron grip on the lives of the faithful. Though some brave priests and bishops have sought to resist its excesses, for centuries the Vatican has picked on the victims of existing prejudice and persecution. It is no longer allowed to burn heretics and witches at the stake, so now it preys instead upon homosexuals and pregnant women, exposing gays to violent abuse, campaigning against the use of condoms and seeking to prevent even the rape victims of Kosovo from taking the morning-after pill.

Homosexuality is surely both natural and moral. Can the same be said of the Pope?

fields.headline: Swiss toll
fields.standfirst: In our second extract from his controversial new book,  Norman Finkelstein  argues that the campaign to reclaim Jewish assets from Swiss banks smacks of hypocrisy and double standards
fields.trailText: In our second extract from his controversial new book, Norman Finkelstein argues that the campaign to reclaim Jewish assets from Swiss banks smacks of hypocrisy and double standards
fields.body:
In May 1995, commemorating the 50th anniversary of the end of the second world war, Switzerland's president formally apologised for denying Jews refuge during the Nazi Holocaust. Discussion reopened on the question of Jewish assets deposited in Swiss accounts before and during the war.

Swiss bankers declared that they could locate only 775 unclaimed dormant accounts, worth a total of $32m. They offered this sum as a basis for negotiations with the World Jewish Congress, which refused it as inadequate.

The WJC, working with institutions including the US Holocaust Memorial Museum and the Simon Wiesenthal Centre, mobilised the US political establishment. Using the House and Senate banking committees as a springboard, the Holocaust industry orchestrated a shameless campaign of vilification.

The campaign rapidly degenerated into a libel of the Swiss people. Tom Bower, in a study supported by the Simon Wiesenthal Centre [Nazi Gold], reports that they had "knowingly profited from blood money"; "committed an unprecedented theft"; that "Swiss greed was unique"; that the "Swiss character" combined "simplicity and duplicity"; that the Swiss were "not just a peculiarly charmless people who had produced no artists, no heroes since William Tell and no statesmen, but were dishonest Nazi collaborators who had profited from genocide", and so on.

The Holocaust industry first alleged that Swiss banks had systematically denied legitimate heirs of Holocaust victims access to dormant accounts worth between $7bn and $20bn.

In late 1996 a parade of elderly Jewish women and one man delivered moving testimony before the Congressional banking committees on the malfeasance of the Swiss bankers. Yet almost none of these witnesses, according to Itamar Levin, an editor of Israel's main business newspaper, "had real proof of the existence of assets in Swiss banks".

In 1997 the Swiss reportedly spent $500m to fend off the Holocaust industry attacks. In April 1998 they started buckling under pressure. In June the banks made a "final offer" of $600m. The next month stiff US sanctions were threatened. The Swiss caved in and agreed to pay $1.25bn.

The settlement covered three classes: claimants to dormant Swiss accounts; refugees denied Swiss asylum; and victims of slave labour which the Swiss benefited from. For all the righteous indignation about the "perfidious Swiss", however, the comparable American record is, on all these counts, just as bad, if not worse.

Like Switzerland, the US denied entry to Jewish refugees fleeing Nazism before and during the second world war. Yet the US government hasn't seen fit to compensate them. And, although dwarfed in size and resources by the US, Switzerland admitted just as many Jewish refugees as America (approximately 20,000) during the Nazi Holocaust.

Prior to the first Senate hearing on the dormant accounts in April 1996, the Swiss banks had agreed to establish an investigative committee and abide by its findings. It comprised of six members, three each from the World Jewish Restitution Organisation and the Swiss Bankers Association, and headed by Paul Volcker, former chairman of the US Federal Reserve Bank.

In December 1999 the committee issued its report on Dormant Accounts of Victims of Nazi Persecution in Swiss Banks. The exhaustive audit had lasted three years and cost no less than $500m. Its central finding merits extended quotation:

"For victims of Nazi persecution there was no evidence of systematic discrimination, obstruction of access, misappropriation, or violation of document retention requirements of Swiss law. However, the Report also criticises the actions of some banks in their treatment of the accounts of victims of Nazi persecution.

"The word 'some' in the preceding sentence needs to be emphasised since the criticised actions refer mainly to those of specific banks in their handling of individual accounts of victims of Nazi persecution in the context of an investigation of 254 banks covering a period of about 60 years. For the criticised actions, the Report also recognises that there were mitigating circumstances for the conduct of the banks involved in these activities.

"The Report acknowledges, moreover, that there is ample evidence of many cases in which banks actively sought out missing account holders or their heirs ... and paid account balances of dormant accounts to the proper parties."

The most explosive finding of the Volcker committee went unreported in the American media. Alongside Switzerland, the committee observed, the US was also a primary safe haven for transferable Jewish assets in Europe. The question is, what happened to the dormant Holocaust-era accounts in American banks?

The House Banking Committee did call one expert witness to testify on this issue. Professor Seymour Rubin served as deputy chief of the US delegation in the Swiss negotiations after the second world war. Under the auspices of American Jewish organisations, Rubin also worked during the 1950s with a "group of experts on Jewish communal life in Europe" to identify dormant Holocaust-era accounts in US banks.

In his House testimony Rubin stated that, after a most superficial and rudimentary audit of banks in just New York, the value of these accounts was put at $6m. Jewish organisations requested this sum for "needy survivors" from Congress (abandoned dormant accounts in the US are transferred to the state).

"The United States," Rubin concluded, "took only very limited measures to identify heirless assets in the United States, and made available a mere $500,000, in contrast to the $32m acknowledged by Swiss banks even prior to the Volcker inquiry." In other words, the US record is much worse than the Swiss record.

European Jews had also purchased plots of land and opened bank accounts in Palestine during the British Mandate [1920-1948] to support the Zionist enterprise or prepare for future immigration. Recently the Financial Times reported that "unlike countries in Europe, Israel's banks and Zionist organisations are resisting pressure to set up independent commissions to establish how much property and how many dormant accounts were held by Holocaust survivors, and how the owners can be located".

In October 1998, an Israeli newspaper stated that the WJC and the WJRO decided "to refrain from dealing with the subject of assets in Israel of Holocaust victims on the ground that responsibility for this lay with the Israeli government". The writ of these Jewish organisations thus runs to Switzerland but not to the Jewish state. The most sensational charge levelled against the Swiss banks was that they required death certificates from the heirs of Nazi holocaust victims. Israeli banks have also demanded such documentation. One searches in vain, however, for denunciations of the "perfidious Israelis".

In an address to the Swiss parliament, US Secretary of State Madeleine Albright explained that the economic benefits accruing to the Swiss from withheld Jewish accounts "were passed along to subsequent generations and that is why the world now looks to the people of Switzerland . . . to be generous in doing what can be done at this point to right past wrongs." Noble sentiments all, but nowhere to be heard - unless they are being ridiculed - when it comes to African-American compensation for slavery.

Alongside Switzerland, the committee observed, the US was also a primary safe haven for transferable Jewish assets in Europe. The question is, what happened to the dormant Holocaust-era accounts in American banks? The House Banking Committee did call one expert witness to testify on this issue. Professor Seymour Rubin served as deputy chief of the US delegation in the Swiss negotiations after the second world war. Under the auspices of American Jewish organisations, Rubin also worked during the 1950s with a "group of experts on Jewish communal life in Europe" to identify dormant Holocaust-era accounts in US banks. In his House testimony Rubin stated that, after a most superficial and rudimentary audit of banks in just New York, the value of these accounts was put at $6m. Jewish organisations requested this sum for "needy survivors" from Congress (abandoned dormant accounts in the US are transferred to the state). "The United States," Rubin concluded, "took only very limited measures to identify heirless assets in the United States, and made available a mere $500,000, in contrast to the $32m acknowledged by Swiss banks even prior to the Volcker inquiry." In other words, the US record is much worse than the Swiss record. European Jews had also purchased plots of land and opened bank accounts in Palestine during the British Mandate [1920-1948] to support the Zionist enterprise or prepare for future immigration. Recently the Financial Times reported that "unlike countries in Europe, Israel's banks and Zionist organisations are resisting pressure to set up independent commissions to establish how much property and how many dormant accounts were held by Holocaust survivors, and how the owners can be located". The writ of these Jewish organisations thus runs to Switzerland but not to the Jewish state. The most sensational charge levelled against the Swiss banks was that they required death certificates from the heirs of Nazi holocaust victims. Israeli banks have also demanded such documentation. One searches in vain, however, for denunciations of the "perfidious Israelis". In an address to the Swiss parliament, US Secretary of State Madeleine Albright explained that the economic benefits accruing to the Swiss from withheld Jewish accounts "were passed along to subsequent generations and that is why the world now looks to the people of Switzerland . . . to be generous in doing what can be done at this point to right past wrongs." Noble sentiments all, but nowhere to be heard - unless they are being ridiculed - when it comes to African-American compensation for slavery.

fields.headline: Spine tingler
fields.standfirst: House of Leaves is a horror novel with a difference - even its pages look creepy. Mark Danielewski tells  Brian Logan about his frightening footnotes
fields.trailText: House of Leaves is a horror novel with a difference - even its pages look creepy. Mark Danielewski tells Brian Logan about his frightening footnotes
fields.body:
"We haven't begun to push the boundaries on books yet," says America's literary sensation of the year, Mark Z Danielewski. "Scholars want to tell you that it doesn't matter what language looks like, but it's not true." Danielewski's assault on that orthodoxy arrives in the UK this week in the 700-page shape of House of Leaves, a novel about the footnotes in a treatise about a film about a haunted house that's one quarter inch bigger inside than out. Lost? That's the point. Danielewski's trick is to reflect the disorientation at his story's core with a series of mind-bending narrative and visual devices, which at their most extreme would have ee cummings reaching for the smelling salts.

Navigating the book, it's easy to understand why House of Leaves has taken its 33-year-old author 10 years to complete. It takes the form of a series of essays about a supposedly famous home video in which a Pulitzer prize-winning photojournalist records his family's adventures in their spooky new house. Danielewski filters those essays - which both relate and deconstruct the horror story in a series of breathtakingly erudite foot notes - through the increasingly freaked-out commentary of the drop-out tattooist who wishes he'd never discovered them in a trunk next to claw-marks on a dead man's floor.

American reviewers duly paid tribute to Danielewski's admirable achievement: "The most impressive literary debut since Thomas Pynchon's V 40 years ago," cooed the San Diego Tribune, while Newsweek called House of Leaves "the most ambitious, complicated and eagerly awaited debut of the year."

The public responded: published in the US in March, House of Leaves is now into its second print run. Suddenly, Danielewski's face, crowned by a crop of blue hair, is everywhere. Later this summer, he and his songwriter sister Poe release a House of Leaves-inspired CD.

"It's easy to see the final product and convince yourself that it was predestined," he tells me. "But the book could easily have been a heap of paper burning in some barrel right now, and I could look back and say, 'Well, that was 10 years of wasted life'." Wasted? Danielewski has toiled these 10 years in occupations as diverse as film student, plumber, waiter and teacher to fund the development of what began as nothing more than "this sense that I was going to write something large".

House of Leaves began to coalesce when its author penned a series of essays "about how text could be used in cinematic ways". Heritage was at work here: Danielewski's father, Tad, was an avant-garde film-maker. "There's a long history in film," says the son, "of intensifying and controlling the viewer's experience by using long shots, close-ups, rhythmic patterns, colour. I began to wonder how that could be applied in a textual way." When he later conceived the idea of a house whose interior dimensions kept morphing he cottoned on that, "the theoretical ideas I'd been working on were represented by that space".

So when the novel's protagonist, Will Navidson, explores his house's subterranean labyrinth, Danielewski's text becomes labyrinthine. The act of reading, slowed down by the need to decipher backwards text or rotate the page full circle, reflects the act of exploration. When Navidson escapes the maze, the reader speeds through pages with only a handful of words on each. Some will find the devices gimmicky and will be thrown, predicts Danielewski, "into a murderous rage", but it's hard to deny that they generate something of the disquiet at which their author aims. The novel's other quirk is its frame of fabricated footnotes and appendices, in which Greek myth, Camille Paglia and Jung, among others, substantiate the essays' critique of Navidson's film.

Danielewski studied at Yale, where he was rejected by every writing course for which he applied, and his book pokes fun at the academic world's arcane debates. But the footnotes serve other than satirical purposes. They heighten the tension (frustratingly) by interrupting the moments of suspense. "It's very theatrical," says Danielewski. "I've always had a fondness for the way the page, when wrapped in footnotes and marginalia, seemed to come to life. It was like some strange, two-dimensional stage. Our words and phrases have all been influenced by the writers that came before us. I thought this was a more honest way of relating how stories are told."

The miracle was that his American publisher, Pantheon Books, was receptive to this outbreak of honesty. They released House of Leaves in precise accordance with Danielewski's strictures - the labyrinth chapter took its writer nine months to lay out. "I think that was one of the glories of living in LA," he reflects. "There is no publishing industry here, so I wrote this book in my own bubble. If I'd lived in New York, I would have become aware of the rules, and everyone would have said, 'Are you kidding? For your first novel?'."

Pantheon also co-operated with Danieleweski on the novel's online serialisation, a first in the American book world and apt for a novel which seems to parallel the development of the web. One medium via which you won't be receiving House of Leaves, however, is film. Despite his novel's cinematic inspiration, Danielewski refuses to sell the movie rights. "Have you seen [the new George Clooney vehicle] The Perfect Storm?" he asks. "It's an awful movie. Yet the book has some marvellous sequences."

It's the ultimate proof of his radicalism: he lives in LA and cares neither for movies nor for the money they're offering him. "In this day and age people feel that their life isn't ratified unless they've had a TV movie made about them." He thinks he "can set an important example".

House of Leaves' success should guarantee him a plumbing-free run at his next novel, on which, however, he won't promise to continue his test of the limits of textual possibility. "I'll only explore insofar as it benefits the reader and complements the story. If I decide to tell a story about a wheelbarrow sitting by itself in the middle of the street, I don't know if all these dynamics would be appropriate".

After reading House of Leaves, you'll believe that if anyone can twist text to lay bare that dormant wheelbarrow experience, it's Danielewski.

Mark Danielewski's House of Leaves (www.houseofleaves.co.uk) is published tomorrow by Anchor, priced £13
