fields.headline: The infinity of desire
fields.trailText: It seems to me one looks at paintings hoping to find some secret. A secret not about art, but about life. And if one finds one, it remains a secret, because, finally, it is untranslatable into words. With words one can only, sometimes, make a clumsy map, hand-drawn, to show where the secret was found.
fields.body:
A letter opened has been placed on the window sill in the corner of a kitchen. On the wall of white tiles behind is a poster of a donkey. Near the envelope stand a jar of paint brushes and an empty vase. Through the window I see trees.

Why do people go to galleries and look at paintings? This question probably has as many answers as people. Another naive question: after they've really looked at a painting, where do they keep it in their memory? With their memories of places? With their memories of other spectacular sights? Or somewhere quite different? You would know, Marisa, but you're not saying.

It seems to me one looks at paintings hoping to find some secret. A secret not about art, but about life. And if one finds one, it remains a secret, because, finally, it is untranslatable into words. With words one can only, sometimes, make a clumsy map, hand-drawn, to show where the secret was found.

I'm trying to make a map. The starting point is the category of paintings called still lifes in English, natures mortes in French and bodegones in Spanish (which could mean coming-from-a-cool-cellar). The difference in these names is already promising and confusing.

I'll begin by drawing a line, a list of names: Zurbaran, Chardin, Cézanne, Morandi, Barcelo. When it gets dark, I'll use my list as a cord.

As in every genre, masters were rare. Masters were those who met the public demand yet pushed their art beyond it. Yet whether one is thinking of masters or modest artisans, the genre has its own logic, its own metaphysics, which tends to push its practitioners in a certain direction.

Still lifes - even before they begin to be painted - have been deliberately assembled: objects which the painter finds intriguing or touching have been arranged as compositions on the table or shelf. Still life is a sedentary art, connected with the activity of keeping house. A home may be tidy or informal but there is always a certain welcoming order to it. Which is why Rembrandt's Slaughtered Ox, or certain canvases of carcasses by Soutine, are not still lifes but dramatic works, whereas Goya's heartbreaking Dead Pheasant is nevertheless a still life.

The drama in a still life is the drama found in a juxtaposition, a placing, an encounter, within a protected space. Every still life is about safety, just as every landscape is about risk and adventure. Still lifes tell about how certain things have come together and, despite their evident ephemerality, will stay together. They are images of residence, in every sense of the term. And so the painter is forced to study the neighbourliness of the things in front of him, how they adjust and live together, how they intersect, overlap and keep separate, and how they converse.

An oyster speaks to a loaf of bread, an apple to a piece of cloth, a carnation to a clock. They converse through colour, texture, shadow, luminosity, shape, and what they talk about is prompted by their juxtaposition. In the safety zone and silence of still lifes the visibility of objects becomes eloquent.

The portraitist contests the mortality of his sitter. The landscape painter contests the ceaseless movement of nature; the history painter the forgetting of history; and the still-life painter the dispersal of objects. His antagonists are decay, the bailiff and the junk merchant.

I hold on to the cord - it is getting dark - and I begin with Zurbaran, who was more or less contemporary with some of the first Dutch or Flemish still-life painters. Therefore, I'll place among the early still lifes Zurbaran's paintings of the Holy Face of St Veronica's Veil. He made at least six or seven versions of this subject, of which the most remarkable is in Stockholm.

A whitish, pinkish cotton or linen scarf is pinned to a dark wall, filling the canvas. The folds and the pins are painted in a style which borders on trompe l'oeil. They are very tangible, in contrast to the image of Christ's face printed on the cloth as a fading ochre stain. This is, of course, in keeping with the story of how Veronica used her scarf to wipe the sweat from Christ's face, as he was carrying the cross to Golgotha. But does it also hint at the secret of still lifes?

Another Zurbaran painting shows just four pots and two pewter plates on a shelf. A modest still life. Behind them there is darkness. They are strongly lit, with evident volume. At first one believes in both their presence and their materiality. They are without question there, more there than many painted objects, because they are precisely lit and tangibly solid before a curtain of darkness.

Yet, after a while, one begins to question whether this impression isn't an illusion. What is there, so strongly lit, is only the "appearance" of each object. The six "appearances" on the shelf have been newly laundered, ironed and put on hangers, awaiting a wearer. No wearer has come forward. There is nothing inside or behind the freshly laundered appearances. The empty pots are doubly empty. The true subject of this painting is the darkness behind, the darkness in which everything is invisible. The vessels on the shelf are there, not for their own material sake but to show that the darkness is - not a curtain - an infinity; just as the cloth with all its folds and woven texture is there, in the painting of St Veronica's Veil, to insinuate the eternity of the immaterial Holy Face. I use the verb insinuate (to bring-in-with-a-curve) in a positive sense: to suggest rather than to enforce. It is a key word and I like it; we can use it.

Zurbaran, at the height of the Counter Reformation, was painting mostly for the monasteries. Chardin was born a century later and worked for the emerging French bourgeoisie of the Enlightenment. He was a friend of Diderot, who wrote with enthusiasm about his art. It is difficult to imagine two painters working for two more opposed or different publics. Yet, as still-life painters, both of them found themselves facing the same persistent question before each object: how is it there?

Chardin was secretive about his working methods - do you know any painter who isn't? It seems that he first applied everywhere on the canvas a kind of paste, with an uneven, rough surface, which he built up slowly, and which, at a certain moment, he coloured with lead white and some reddish brown. The stuff of this surface was both luminous and earthy. He did not apply it mechanically or uniformly; he worked on it and in it with much patience, until it took on the air of being the ground for all substantiality, until he could see in it the unspecified material of the whole world, with its infinitude of possibilities. "Corporeal substance," said Spinoza, "can only be conceived as infinite, unique and indivisible."

He waited until the objects began to glance at him, until their glances came towards him through the act of painting, intimate, furtive glances which became his broken, correcting, crumbling brush-strokes, or sometimes finger smears. The wiggles of a walnut, the mat white shells of newly laid eggs, the black redness of wine in a glass, the fire in dented copper: each of them glanced at him in a breathtakingly distinct and particular way, yet all of them belonged to the indivisible substantial world and the single mystery of its existence.

Like Zurbaran, Chardin in his still lifes confronted the infinite. For the Spaniard it was the infinity of darkness; for the Frenchman the infinity of substantiality.

About 130 years later, between 1900 and 1906, Cézanne was painting his late watercolours. As a young man he had made no secret of his admiration for "the cunning fellow" Chardin. I believe that every time Cézanne laid a knife on his still-life table, a knife pointing diagonally into the picture, he did it as a homage to the old cunning master.

Gradually, still lifes became Cézanne's favourite genre because, as he said, they meant "grappling directly with objects". What happened during this grappling? In his late watercolours there is, it seems to me, a light which hadn't been seen before in European painting. When he applied the colours - blue, green, ochre, red - they all referred to this white in deference. They never referred directly to each other, as in earlier paintings, they referred to each other by way of the white. And the white arranged each of them, according to its wave-length, somewhere between surface and void. The sum of all these exchanges constitutes the new light.

This light enters between things to reveal that every point has its tangent, that everything is touching, and that all the existing distances and spaces which separate objects are no more than clefts or folds. It is a light which, as it travels, bestows continuity, a light which does not allow separation.

I look at the palm of my hand. Now I begin to close my fingers slowly, and watch the creases forming between the phalanges of each finger. Within these paintings, the edges of the apples on the table, or the edges of the casserole dish or of the jar, are like those creases, because they mark both an apparent separation and a real continuity. If I open my fingers a little, the creases will disappear, just as the contours of the objects on the table will disappear if, instead of looking at them, I feel my way either by touch or philosophy from one to the other.

When Cézanne spoke about being faithful to the "motif", faithful to nature, what he had in mind, I think, was the fidelity of an unbroken embrace between his perception and the continuous, infinite extension of everything in front of him.

Giorgio Morandi was probably the most austere still-life painter of all time. Repeatedly during his long life he painted the same dozen or so objects: his bottles, whose glass he painted white or red before painting them on the canvas, his coffee pot, his two jugs, his carafe, his dried flowers, his seashells.

His art divides itself into three periods. From the 1920s until 1940, he painted in order to approach the objects being painted. He goes closer and closer. The final closeness has nothing to do with detail or photographic precision. It is a question of the presence of the object; almost its body temperature being felt. In Morandi's second period, between 1940 and 1950, one has the impression that he stayed still while the objects approached the canvas. He waited and they arrived. In the last period, from 1951 until his death in 1964, the objects seem to be on the point of disappearing. Not that they are faint or faraway. Rather they are weightless, in flux, on the frontier of existence.

If this is a progression - if his mastery increased as he grew older - one has to ask: what was he trying to do? The answer often given - that Morandi was the poet of the ephemeral - doesn't convince me. The energy of his work is neither nostalgic nor - in any personal sense - intimate. In his life he may have shut himself away. And his odious fascist politics suggest panic. Yet his art is strangely affirmative. Of what?

What interests him is the process of the visible first becoming visible, before the thing seen has been given a name or acquired a value. The visible begins with light. And as soon as there is light there is shade. All drawing is a shadow around light. Slowly the eye registers and reads the space which the coffee pot and the jug are going to occupy. In other words, the objects Morandi paints can be bought in no flea market. They are not objects. They are places, places where some little thing is about to come into being. The infinity of becoming.

Morandi's vision depended upon a certain quiet; around it was the afternoon throbbing of cicadas and the silence of the siesta. Within 30 years of Morandi's death, life radically changed and the world was filled with a new kind of noise: the din of commodities. In 1994, Miquel Barcelo painted a series of very large still lifes entitled In Extremis. And at that time he wrote: "To paint a flayed ox has become important_ one has to take things, one after another, from the stickiness of Berlusconi and make them anew, fresh and clean, show them palpitating, or with their own sweet rottenness."

Barcelo paints on the ground, as if with a stick in the dust. In his still lifes there is no affluence and little security - enough maybe for the next 24 hours. And this is where they differ from their predecessors and why they belong specifically to the end of our millennium.

His fruit, carcasses and fish offer no illusion of permanence. What he is painting with each thing that he handles is a moment, a phase, in a repeated cycle of seeding, flowering, fading, dying. The paintings make this clear. They do not celebrate what things look like. What they celebrate, accidents notwithstanding, is recurrence, and the secret of recurrence is mortality. Barcelo's still lifes oppose the crass promises of consumerism with the insinuation of death and the respect which death demands.

In their own way, these paintings are images of paradise. A paradise which has nothing to do with perfection, for perfection is unlovable, and if there's no love in paradise, what is it? Barcelo's is a paradise painted on the reverse side of pain, following the same contours. The infinity he confronts is that of desire.

You are right, Marisa, I'm trying to make a still life with words! My favourite flower is lilac, either white or mauve. Sprigs of lilac always come in pairs. So there is a couple against a green curtain of leaves. And I place them in the empty vase beside the jar with brushes. And their minutely small white petals resemble the white letters in all the words I've written down.

This is an edited extract of the Peter Fuller Memorial Lecture, given by John Berger at Tate Modern on Saturday.

But does it also hint at the secret of still lifes? Another Zurbaran painting shows just four pots and two pewter plates on a shelf. A modest still life. Behind them there is darkness. They are strongly lit, with evident volume. At first one believes in both their presence and their materiality. They are without question there, more there than many painted objects, because they are precisely lit and tangibly solid before a curtain of darkness. Yet, after a while, one begins to question whether this impression isn't an illusion. What is there, so strongly lit, is only the "appearance" of each object. The six "appearances" on the shelf have been newly laundered, ironed and put on hangers, awaiting a wearer. No wearer has come forward. There is nothing inside or behind the freshly laundered appearances. The empty pots are doubly empty. The true subject of this painting is the darkness behind, the darkness in which everything is invisible. The vessels on the shelf are there, not for their own material sake but to show that the darkness is - not a curtain - an infinity; just as the cloth with all its folds and woven texture is there, in the painting of St Veronica's Veil, to insinuate the eternity of the immaterial Holy Face. I use the verb insinuate (to bring-in-with-a-curve) in a positive sense: to suggest rather than to enforce. It is a key word and I like it; we can use it. Zurbaran, at the height of the Counter Reformation, was painting mostly for the monasteries. Chardin was born a century later and worked for the emerging French bourgeoisie of the Enlightenment. He was a friend of Diderot, who wrote with enthusiasm about his art. It is difficult to imagine two painters working for two more opposed or different publics. Yet, as still-life painters, both of them found themselves facing the same persistent question before each object: how is it there? Chardin was secretive about his working methods - do you know any painter who isn't? It seems that he first applied everywhere on the canvas a kind of paste, with an uneven, rough surface, which he built up slowly, and which, at a certain moment, he coloured with lead white and some reddish brown. The stuff of this surface was both luminous and earthy. He did not apply it mechanically or uniformly; he worked on it and in it with much patience, until it took on the air of being the ground for all substantiality, until he could see in it the unspecified material of the whole world, with its infinitude of possibilities. "Corporeal substance," said Spinoza, "can only be conceived as infinite, unique and indivisible." He waited until the objects began to glance at him, until their glances came towards him through the act of painting, intimate, furtive glances which became his broken, correcting, crumbling brush-strokes, or sometimes finger smears. The wiggles of a walnut, the mat white shells of newly laid eggs, the black redness of wine in a glass, the fire in dented copper: each of them glanced at him in a breathtakingly distinct and particular way, yet all of them belonged to the indivisible substantial world and the single mystery of its existence. Like Zurbaran, Chardin in his still lifes confronted the infinite. For the Spaniard it was the infinity of darkness; for the Frenchman the infinity of substantiality. About 130 years later, between 1900 and 1906, Cézanne was painting his late watercolours. As a young man he had made no secret of his admiration for "the cunning fellow" Chardin. I believe that every time Cézanne laid a knife on his still-life table, a knife pointing diagonally into the picture, he did it as a homage to the old cunning master. Gradually, still lifes became Cézanne's favourite genre because, as he said, they meant "grappling directly with objects". What happened during this grappling? In his late watercolours there is, it seems to me, a light which hadn't been seen before in European painting. When he applied the colours - blue, green, ochre, red - they all referred to this white in deference. They never referred directly to each other, as in earlier paintings, they referred to each other by way of the white. And the white arranged each of them, according to its wave-length, somewhere between surface and void. The sum of all these exchanges constitutes the new light. This light enters between things to reveal that every point has its tangent, that everything is touching, and that all the existing distances and spaces which separate objects are no more than clefts or folds. It is a light which, as it travels, bestows continuity, a light which does not allow separation. I look at the palm of my hand. Now I begin to close my fingers slowly, and watch the creases forming between the phalanges of each finger. Within these paintings, the edges of the apples on the table, or the edges of the casserole dish or of the jar, are like those creases, because they mark both an apparent separation and a real continuity. If I open my fingers a little, the creases will disappear, just as the contours of the objects on the table will disappear if, instead of looking at them, I feel my way either by touch or philosophy from one to the other. When Cézanne spoke about being faithful to the "motif", faithful to nature, what he had in mind, I think, was the fidelity of an unbroken embrace between his perception and the continuous, infinite extension of everything in front of him. Giorgio Morandi was probably the most austere still-life painter of all time. Repeatedly during his long life he painted the same dozen or so objects: his bottles, whose glass he painted white or red before painting them on the canvas, his coffee pot, his two jugs, his carafe, his dried flowers, his seashells. His art divides itself into three periods. From the 1920s until 1940, he painted in order to approach the objects being painted. He goes closer and closer. The final closeness has nothing to do with detail or photographic precision. It is a question of the presence of the object; almost its body temperature being felt. In Morandi's second period, between 1940 and 1950, one has the impression that he stayed still while the objects approached the canvas. He waited and they arrived. In the last period, from 1951 until his death in 1964, the objects seem to be on the point of disappearing. Not that they are faint or faraway. Rather they are weightless, in flux, on the frontier of existence. If this is a progression - if his mastery increased as he grew older - one has to ask: what was he trying to do? The answer often given - that Morandi was the poet of the ephemeral - doesn't convince me. The energy of his work is neither nostalgic nor - in any personal sense - intimate. In his life he may have shut himself away. And his odious fascist politics suggest panic. Yet his art is strangely affirmative. Of what? What interests him is the process of the visible first becoming visible, before the thing seen has been given a name or acquired a value. The visible begins with light. And as soon as there is light there is shade. All drawing is a shadow around light. Slowly the eye registers and reads the space which the coffee pot and the jug are going to occupy. In other words, the objects Morandi paints can be bought in no flea market. They are not objects. They are places, places where some little thing is about to come into being. The infinity of becoming. Morandi's vision depended upon a certain quiet; around it was the afternoon throbbing of cicadas and the silence of the siesta. Within 30 years of Morandi's death, life radically changed and the world was filled with a new kind of noise: the din of commodities. In 1994, Miquel Barcelo painted a series of very large still lifes entitled In Extremis. And at that time he wrote: "To paint a flayed ox has become important_ one has to take things, one after another, from the stickiness of Berlusconi and make them anew, fresh and clean, show them palpitating, or with their own sweet rottenness." Barcelo paints on the ground, as if with a stick in the dust. In his still lifes there is no affluence and little security - enough maybe for the next 24 hours. And this is where they differ from their predecessors and why they belong specifically to the end of our millennium. His fruit, carcasses and fish offer no illusion of permanence. What he is painting with each thing that he handles is a moment, a phase, in a repeated cycle of seeding, flowering, fading, dying. The paintings make this clear. They do not celebrate what things look like. What they celebrate, accidents notwithstanding, is recurrence, and the secret of recurrence is mortality. Barcelo's still lifes oppose the crass promises of consumerism with the insinuation of death and the respect which death demands. In their own way, these paintings are images of paradise. A paradise which has nothing to do with perfection, for perfection is unlovable, and if there's no love in paradise, what is it? Barcelo's is a paradise painted on the reverse side of pain, following the same contours. The infinity he confronts is that of desire. You are right, Marisa, I'm trying to make a still life with words! My favourite flower is lilac, either white or mauve. Sprigs of lilac always come in pairs. So there is a couple against a green curtain of leaves. And I place them in the empty vase beside the jar with brushes. And their minutely small white petals resemble the white letters in all the words I've written down. This is an edited extract of the Peter Fuller Memorial Lecture, given by John Berger at Tate Modern on Saturday.

webTitle: July 13: In brief and casting news

fields.headline: July 13: In brief and casting news
fields.trailText: Afro-American film-makers break out of niche market, Drew Barrymore to wed, Ryan and Quaid file for divorce, and, on the casting couch, Jimmy Smits, Matt LeBlanc and Cameron Diaz
fields.body:
 Afro-American film-makers are being hailed as 2000's biggest success story after the runaway Stateside performance of a series of movies by black directors. Following Ice Cube's number-one hit comedy Next Friday, the Hollywood Reporter today suggests that John Singleton's Shaft remake and Keenan Ivory Wayans' horror-spoof Scary Movie look set to become two of the summer's biggest blockbusters. Scary Movie, in particular, set a record last week for the most successful opening-weekend for a film by a black director (see our story), and has become the second highest-grossing opener of the year (behind Mission: Impossible 2). All told, the figures suggest that movies by Afro-American directors are starting to break out of their niche markets in the urban centres and play well with white audiences across America. "I think this year alone, mainstream America has really started to come out and support black films and film-makers," said Wayans.

 Drew Barrymore (pictured) has announced that she is to marry MTV prankster Tom Green, her boyfriend for the last year. It will be Barrymore's second wedding, following a brief marriage to Welsh actor Jeremy Thomas when she was still a wild-child teenager. Earlier this year, Barrymore nursed Green through a struggle against testicular cancer.

 And as one Hollywood marriage flares up, another burns out. Having announced his separation from Meg Ryan two weeks ago, actor Dennis Quaid has now officially filed for divorce citing "irreconcilable differences". The 46-year-old actor (who can currently be seen in the paranormal thriller Frequency) is seeking joint custody of the couple's 8-year-old son Jack. Ryan and Quaid first met while making the 1987 movie Innerspace and married on Valentine's Day 1991.

 Former NYPD Blue and LA Law star Jimmy Smits is the latest name to join the new Star Wars movie, currently in production in Australia. Smits will play Senator Bail Organa, the foster father of Princess Leia. He joins new recruits Christopher Lee (as a rotten politician), Hayden Christensen (the teenage Anakin), and old hands Ewan McGregor, Natalie Portman and Samuel L Jackson on the set with George Lucas.

 Friends favourite Matt LeBlanc has signed on to play a military leader in the second world war indie comedy All the Queen's Men. LeBlanc, better known as the lunkish Joey, will star as a soldier charged with infiltrating an all-female factory in Nazi Germany in order to get his mitts on a decoding device.

 Cameron Diaz is in sight of a career-best $15m paycheque if attempts to sign the actress up to the Columbia comedy The Untitled Nancy Pimental Project are successful. Diaz is reported to be in final negotiations to star in the film once work is completed on Martin Scorsese's movie The Gangs of New York. The Untitled Nancy Pimental Project is scheduled to begin shooting next March with Roger (Cruel Intentions) Kumble in the director's chair.

fields.headline: Dear Anna
fields.standfirst: The Guardian's consumer champion fights your corner
fields.trailText: The Guardian's consumer champion fights your corner
fields.body:
Cold facts

This month a frustrated housewife held a Servis technician hostage in her home after waiting weeks for spare parts to arrive for her washing machine. Jan Brown, who has endured similar suspense with her fridge freezer, preferred to appeal to Consumer. The gadget broke down in mid-June but luckily Brown had invested in a £149.99 "supercover warranty" from the retailer Comet. This, the salesman had assured her, promised a repair within 24 hours should the need arise.

An engineer duly arrived the next day and managed to crack a panel while discovering that a broken plastic fan was the cause of the mischief. The replacement parts, he told an incredulous Brown, would have to be ordered from Turkey. Three weeks on she is still waiting. "We're living out of a cool bag and having to chuck large quantities of food out daily," she says. "We've both had bouts of stomach trouble caused by unhygienic food and even the cat has had diarrhoea." The insurer claims it was not its problem and Comet has failed to keep three promises to call back. "They haven't even offered us the loan of a table-top fridge," says Brown.

"We are so pleased that you are allowing us the opportunity to make amends," simpers Comet, after Consumer gets in touch. It's a privilege the Browns have been attempting to allow the retailer for three weeks, but no matter. The happy upshot is that the family now gets to choose a new fridge to the value of £530, which was the original cost of the appliance and the cost of the extended warranty.

Steve Mills recalls how he was also left freezerless thanks to Comet's bizarre sense of geography. He'd ordered a new machine from the Stoke-on-Trent branch, took a day off to await delivery, then received a call from the delivery man claiming that no one was answering the doorbell. "He was at the right address but the wrong county," says Mills. "He was in Walton, Surrey, and I was in Walton, Staffordshire." The story has a coda: two years after the freezer arrived, Mills received a demand from a debt collection agency. The sum was for a freezer delivered to "his" Surrey address.

No Virgin tickets to ride

Anyone who has spent a lifetime waiting on Virgin Train's booking line will see the advantage of thetrainline.com. Just get online, choose your trains, key in your payment details and wait for your tickets to come.

The involvement of Virgin, which set up the site with Stagecoach, should be a warning, though. Virgin, notoriously incapable of running its trains on time, appears to be having equal difficulty with its postal service. "Fifty per cent of the time the tickets don't turn up and it's almost impossible to get hold of anyone who can help," says Valerie Fairbrass. Ron Guariento was dismayed to be told after confirming his booking that, while tickets booked over the phone usually arrive the next day, those ordered online don't come until the day before departure, even if it is weeks ahead. Moreover, customers were told to call customer services only if the tickets failed to show on the last day, by which time, of course, it would be too late. Alan Burkitt-Gray discovered this for himself when he booked five returns on May 9. He was promised that they would be posted within 24 hours; in fact they turned up nine days later.

Thetrainline.com admits that there have been problems and says it is reviewing its procedures. The target is delivery within two days and customers can now track the progress of their reservation on the website. Those that are delayed will now be sent special delivery to the customer's local station if time is short.

As for the warning that tickets would arrive the day before departure, thetrainline.com admits that "the wording does not put confidence in the mind of the customer" and that it's "unacceptable" to tell customers to wait until the day before departure to complain. Travellers are now to be told to ring customer services if their tickets don't show after three to five days.

Homes with baggage

Sensible people who buy a property will check out the idiosyncrasies of their new neighbours before committing themselves. The character of the vendor or purchaser can be even more crucial, however. Mr and Mrs Yong bought themselves a London base from a couple who moved out leaving numerous unpaid bills. Despite the fact that they were unable to use any gas because the boiler was broken, bills based on an outdated meter reading and addressed to the Yongs began arriving thick and fast from British Gas.

No effort on the part of the Yongs' son-in-law, Jonathan Points, could stem the flow, despite promises from BG that the records would be amended. Finally, the Yongs received a letter warning that their gas supply would be cut off unless they paid the sum owed by their predecessors.

The bills soon dried up under the hot breath of Consumer. British Gas blames an "unfortunate administrative error in processing the change of tenancy" and has apologised.

Staying with the subject of house-moving headaches, Sandy Adirondack's problem stemmed from unscrupulous purchasers of her property. Last month we published the tale of a reader who was refused credit because of a bad debt at an address she'd left seven years ago. Companies are forbidden by law to hold information relevant to an address vacated more than six years ago, but Adirondack reckons that her tale shows how things can go wrong.

After she'd moved house more than seven years ago her former bank wrote to her old address inviting her to apply for a visa card. The letter never reached her; instead the new householders applied for the card in her name and, having secured it, set about applying for a variety of other bank cards.

Adirondack only found out when she asked to check her credit rating. Soon afterwards she was rung by a debt collection agency seeking recovery of £10,000 run up in her name. "The police said they could do nothing because I hadn't lost anything (apart from my reputation)," says Adirondack, "but I gave all the information to the agency and didn't hear from them again."

The ghost of Cable & Wireless

The curse of Cable & Wireless continues to afflict its new owner, ntl. Sylvia Trench, Kevin Archbould and Jon Dean are among the numerous readers still waiting for their free internet disc, promised by the end of April. Ntl blames overwhelming demand and last month told Consumer that it had already stopped advertising the offer. Not so, according to one reader who says he saw an ad on Carlton Central TV the very same day.

Write to us at119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, phone us on 020-7713 4731, send a fax on 020-7239 9933 or email us at consumer@theguardian.com

webTitle: His last bow?  Plenty of frills from Saint Laurent

fields.headline: His last bow?  Plenty of frills from Saint Laurent
fields.trailText: The drama of Yves Saint Laurent's haute couture show in Paris yesterday was heightened by speculation that it may have been his last.
fields.body:
The drama of Yves Saint Laurent's haute couture show in Paris yesterday was heightened by speculation that it may have been his last.

At 64, Saint Laurent is by no means the oldest fashion designer working in Paris, but his health is said to be failing.

In November last year, the ready-to-wear branch of the label was sold to the Gucci group, whose creative director, Tom Ford, will present his first collection for the house in October. At the time of the sale, Saint Laurent's long-term business partner, Pierre Berge, insisted that "the heart and soul of the maison, the haute couture collection, will remain in French hands", but this failed to curb rumours that the designer will bow out.

Saint Laurent is rightly known as one of fashion's greatest innovators, but this collection had little of the forward-thinking spirit of his youth.

Straight-brimmed hats echoed the clean horizontal line of sharp-shouldered jackets, emphasising the breadth of the torso. High-waisted trousers were worn matador style with tiny bolero jackets.

Suits came in three styles: a flippy circular skirt with a curvy jacket resting on the hipbone, a straight knee length skirt with a simple blazer, or trousers with a cropped boxy jacket.

By contrast, evening wear was exaggeratedly feminine, with an abundance of satin sashes, velvet bows and taffeta frills. The evening coats stole the show, however: what dress could compete with a black velvet parka with a white fur hood, an Icarus-esque cape of silver-black feathers, or a pink satin coat scattered with gold stars?

There were perhaps too few ideas to sustain a collection of 92 outfits but Saint Laurent has clearly not heard the adage that one should leave one's audience wanting more.

A full report on the Paris haute couture collections will appear in G2 tomorrow

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: All today's rumours served with a garlic-infused extra virgin olive oil dip
fields.trailText: AC Milan president Silvio Berlusconi has admitted he's still after David Beckham. "I like the Manchester United midfielder a lot," the media magnate said. "I am Milan's biggest supporter and my promise to other Milan supporters is that there will be an important arrival."
fields.body:
AC Milan president Silvio Berlusconi has admitted he's still after David Beckham. "I like the Manchester United midfielder a lot," the media magnate said. "I am Milan's biggest supporter and my promise to other Milan supporters is that there will be an important arrival."

Nick Barmby will move to Liverpool next week according to speculation in the Daily Mail. They claim that Gerald Houllier's "first act on returning from holiday" next Tuesday will be to contact Walter Smith with an improved bid of £4.5m. Everton will refuse it, but by the end of next week the two clubs will have compromised on a £5m fee. Spooky.

Meanwhile Walter Smith is demanding defender Chris Coleman rather than cash in a deal that looks likely to take John Collins to Fulham.

webTitle: England's heavyweights give Zims a thumping

fields.headline: England's heavyweights give Zims a thumping
fields.trailText: You might say that normal service has been resumed. England thumped Zimbabwe at Old Trafford so quickly that the ECB's electric bill will be smaller than expected, as the floodlights weren't really needed at all.
fields.body:
You might say that normal service has been resumed. England thumped Zimbabwe at Old Trafford so quickly that the ECB's electric bill will be smaller than expected, as the floodlights weren't really needed at all.

What will have made this win doubly satisfying is the fact that England have usually struggled to bury Zimbabwe in one-dayers. This was the 14th meeting between the two sides, and it's now seven-all (the tiebreaker's on Tuesday at Edgbaston). Alec Stewart has been involved in all of those embarrassing defeats, but he couldn't have done much more to help win this one: six catches, to equal Adam Gilchrist's one-day record, and a few runs before looking a little unlucky to get an afterthought lbw from John Holder, one of county cricket's most renowned finger-raisers.

Stewart resisted the temptation to whip them both off (it's an overused tactic that rarely works, anyway), and gave Mullally eight overs and Ealham his full ten. Then White nipped in with a couple of morale-boosting wickets. So did Trescothick, who's rapidly becoming England's good-luck charm. He batted well again, before he also received a marginal leg-before decision, and even managed a slick run-out.

England's batting was solid, to say the least. Trescothick, Flintoff, Hick ... all cruiserweights, with the odd heavyweight thrown in. In comparison Maynard, sitting expectantly on the dressing-room balcony, looked like the team's cox. But the big three did the business, although Flintoff lived dangerously at times, teasing the fielders with some uppish miscues.

Now the pressure's on West Indies, still pointless after all these matches. Chances are that Courtney, who'd hoped to rest during the qualifiers, will be easing those big bowling boots back on up at Chester-le-Street.

Steven Lynch is managing editor of Wisden Cricket Monthly

webTitle: Gibraltar protests at nuclear sub repair

fields.headline: Gibraltar protests at nuclear sub repair
fields.trailText: Hundreds of people marched to the governor's residence in Gibraltar yesterday in protest at the presence of a nuclear submarine awaiting repair.
fields.body:
Hundreds of people marched to the governor's residence in Gibraltar yesterday in protest at the presence of a nuclear submarine awaiting repair.

Hundreds more held a simultaneous march in La Linea, on the Spanish side of the border. Local media put the number of marchers on both sides of the border at between 1,500 and 2,000.

HMS Tireless has been in Gibraltar since May 19, towed in when a coolant leak was found in its propulsion system while it was cruising between Sicily and North Africa.

The authorities say there is no danger of a radiation spill from its nuclear-powered engines.

But Gibraltarians, fearing a threat to health and the environment, want the boat returned to Britain for the repairs.

When the Tireless was brought in, the Ministry of Defence said that this might be done, but no action has been taken. The boat remains half submerged, with its reactor shut down, guarded by a police launch.

The protesters on the Rock delivered a letter to the governor, David Durie.

Paco Olivia, a local resident, said it was the first time Gibraltarians had protested at something that had nothing to do politics or the troubled relations with Spain.

Tireless is one of the Royal Navy's 12 hunter-killer nuclear submarines.

webTitle: Kids star found dead in Vegas hotel

fields.headline: Kids star found dead in Vegas hotel
fields.trailText: Justin Pierce, who rose to notoriety as a skateboarding delinquent in the 1995 film Kids, was found hanged in a Las Vegas hotel room late on Monday night
fields.body:
Justin Pierce, who rose to notoriety as a skateboarding delinquent in the 1995 film Kids, was found hanged in a Las Vegas hotel room late on Monday night. Authorities said that they had found two suicide notes near the actor's body, and Clark county coroner Ron Flud confirmed that "hanging is the cause of death and the manner of death is suicide."

New Yorker Pierce, 25, was plucked out of obscurity by director Larry Clark, who cast him alongside Leo Fitzpatrick as one of a pair of hedonistic, juvenile tearaways in his controversial debut, Kids. The film was damned and praised in equal measure for its no-holds-barred look at teenage sex and violence and provided an attention-grabbing calling card for its two stars, young writer Harmony Korine and supporting actress Chloe Sevigny.

At the time of Kids' release it appeared that Pierce was the actor best placed for a successful follow-on career. But while Korine went on to become the enfant-terrible of indie film-making with his directoral debut Gummo, and Sevigny gained an Oscar-nomination this year for her role in the acclaimed Boys Don't Cry, Pierce's career never quite took off. At one stage during the making of Kids, Sevigny dated Pierce before moving on to Korine, who remains her regular off-screen partner.

Pierce, who was staying at the Bellagio resort, was in Las Vegas to work on a fashion shoot. He recently acted in the hit film Next Friday and the comedy Pigeonholed, opposite Rosanna Arquette.

fields.headline: Philadelphia police filmed beating suspect
fields.standfirst: Watch the video from Philadelphia Channel 6
fields.trailText:
Philadelphia police have been videotaped kicking and beating a suspect who had been involved in a shootout with police minutes earlier.
Watch the video from Philadelphia Channel 6
fields.body:
Philadelphia police have been videotaped kicking and beating a suspect who had been involved in a shootout with police minutes earlier.

Philadelphia mayor John Street promised "a proper and fair investigation."

"While it would be easy to be inflamed by the videotape, we have to determine all the facts," Street said late last night.

He said that "as inflammatory as this tape might be," police had been trying to apprehend the man, who had resisted arrest and had shot an officer.

The man, Thomas Jones, 30, is accused of leading police on a chase in a stolen patrol car after firing at them and wounding one with an officer's gun. He was dragged from the police car and kicked and beaten by police for about 30 seconds while a television news helicopter hovered overhead.

Jones, who appeared to resist officers as he was led away in a chokehold and handcuffs, was in serious condition with injuries to his abdomen and arms, said hospital spokeswoman Vivica Aycox.

Witnesses said he and police traded numerous gunshots before he leaped into one of their cruisers and fled. Police said the man was shot by officers two or three times.

Police commissioner John Timoney said questions about police brutality were premature. "The guy obviously doesn't want to get arrested," Timoney said. "When somebody doesn't want to get arrested, there really isn't a very easy way of doing it. So let's not jump to any conclusions; let's wait and see what happens."

The incident began when officers saw a car driving erratically and determined it was reported stolen on 1 July, Timoney said. Two officers stopped the car and there was a confrontation.

Bertha Jones, 40, was sitting on her porch when she saw police and the suspect exchange gunfire. The suspect led police on a foot chase around a building across the street and then jumped an iron gate with his hands in the air, as if to surrender, she said.

"The cops ran over and start beating on him," she said. "They was beating on the man. He got one of their guns, started shooting, and by then I ran in the house."

"He fired his shots off. They fired," she said.

An officer was shot in the thumb and was in stable condition. Another officer was treated for a bite wound inflicted by the suspect, police said.

The suspect jumped into the police car and fled before the car was stopped by other officers. The suspect was dragged from the cruiser.

Video from a TV helicopter showed a dozen men, some in uniform and some in civilian clothes, surrounding the suspect on the ground, beating and kicking him for about 30 seconds. He was then led away.

Philadelphia Inquirer

fields.headline: Fiji hostage crisis ends
fields.trailText:
Coup leaders in Fiji today released their remaining 18 captives, ending a two-month-old parliamentary hostage crisis
that has spawned increasing unrest, including the seizure of at least four tourist resorts.
fields.body:
Coup leaders in Fiji today released their remaining 18 captives, ending a two-month-old parliamentary hostage crisis that has spawned increasing unrest, including the seizure of at least four tourist resorts.

The hostage-takers held a traditional ceremony seeking forgiveness, then rebel leader George Speight shook hands with and embraced the deposed prime minister Mahendra Chaudhry before allowing him and the other freed hostages to be loaded on to two lorries. "They're all out," said military spokesman Major Howard Politini.

About 150 Speight supporters cheered as the hostages left. The hostages later arrived to applause at the Fiji Red Cross Society building, where they underwent medical checks.

Today's releases followed a deal on Sunday, when the armed forces agreed to scrap the country's multiracial constitution, depose Mr Chaudhry - Fiji's first prime minister of ethnic Indian descent - and grant amnesty to Mr Speight and his supporters. Eight hostages were released on Wednesday.

The military seized control on May 29 to try to curb violence and looting that erupted 10 days earlier when Mr Speight's gang raided the parliament building in the capital Suva. Elsewhere in Fiji, protesters seized two more tourists resorts today, bringing the number held to four, the military said. The seizures of the Buca Bay and Rukuruku resorts, which appeared peaceful, came hours after the takeover of the upmarket aucala Island resort and a day after the occupation of the Turtle Island Resort where The Blue Lagoon was filmed.

It was unclear if the takeovers were part of Mr Speight's efforts to put pressure on the Great Council of Chiefs, Fiji's traditional power, to endorse his proposed cabinet for an interim government or if his campaign was spiralling out of control.

The chiefs began meeting this morning to choose a new president and vice president in line with the agreement signed on Sunday and in the hope of freeing the 18 remaining hostages in parliament.

Incidents of unrest have increased in recent days. Most have been peaceful, although five police officers were injured in the takeover of a police station yesterday at Labasa, which has turned into a hotbed of Speight support.

There were growing concerns that the takeovers could spread, possibly to Fiji's international airport near Nadi. The road from Nadi to Suva has been blockaded, so disruption at the airport would isolate the capital.

The United States today urged Americans in Fiji to leave the country, and last week, Washington recalled the US ambassador for consultations. Australia and New Zealand have also advised their citizens to leave Fiji.

Mr Speight has said the protesters are acting independently, but in support of what he says is his cause - indigenous Fijian rights. His rebels are ethnic Fijians who say the Indian minority has too much power. Indo-Fijians, whose ancestors were brought to the islands by British colonialists over a century ago to work in the rich sugar cane fields, make up 44% of Fiji's 812,000 people. Many indigenous Fijians, who make up 51% of the population, resent the Indo-Fijians' economic and political clout.

fields.headline: Reshaping the landscape
fields.standfirst: Bigger farms but poor farmers
fields.trailText: Rioting farmers storming the local mairie, routes to Channel ports blocked by burning straw: the French farmer in revolt can still violently reshape the political landscape.
fields.body:
Rioting farmers storming the local mairie, routes to Channel ports blocked by burning straw: the French farmer in revolt can still violently reshape the political landscape.

But stereotypes of a countryside kept going by EU subsidies and fixed in the tough but joyous culture immortalised by Marcel Pagnols Jean de Florette are false.

A century ago half the population worked on the land and even in 1946 three in 10 did so. Today just over 3% are in agriculture. It employed 3.8m in 1962; now it gives work to fewer than 900,000 - of whom only 350,000 work full-time.

Drive towards the Paris basin from Calais and youll pass hedgeless fields of cereals, industrial piggeries, beef farms and acres of sugar beet.

France is the worlds second biggest food exporter and largest food producer, accounting for 21.5% of EU farm output.

But discontent remains. Daniel Levesque, who produces wheat, barley and potatoes (for McCains frozen chips) on some 400 hectares (1,000 acres) west of Chalons-sur-Marne, reckons his income has fallen 20% in seven years.

He blames bureaucracy and the malign role of subsidies. But, with four full-time and one seasonal worker, he rails against social charges - and the 35-hour week.

The son of Norman farmers, he abandoned civil engineering to take over the family busines. Now he employs a manager to run the farm while he spends most of his time seeking new markets - including renewable energy and extracting proteins from crops such as alfalfa.

His near-neighbour at Vitry-le-Francois, Michel Delaunoy, is much happier. He employs 18 on his 580 hectares, and sees a profitable future as technology enables farmers to switch to renewable energy, industrial alcohol or maybe organic products.

Theres still a place for the small farmer, he says, provided he does something else like running a gite for tourists. For many of my smaller neighbours the pot would be empty of food if their wives didnt go out to work.

Mr Levesque has a warning for ministers basking in the dynamism of French agriculture: There will be big demos this autumn in protest at four years of heavy burdens. Its the wholesale merchants and supermarkets which get all the value-added of our work; we just get the crumbs.

webTitle: Brown announces more money for public services

fields.headline: Brown announces more money for public services
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: Special report
fields.trailText: Labour today stepped up its fightback against the Tories as the chancellor Gordon Brown announced an extra £3bn for public services.
fields.body:
Labour today stepped up its fightback against the Tories as the chancellor Gordon Brown announced an extra £3bn for public services.

The windfall stems from the bonanza from April's mobile phone licence auction, and lower than expected unemployment and welfare spending. Mr Brown, speaking to the Royal Economic Society conference in St Andrews, held out the prospect of more public money in anticipation of another successful auction of radio frequencies in the autumn.

The April auction raised an extra £22bn for the Treasury. Mr Brown, in keeping with his reputation for prudence, confirmed that the money is to be used to reduce the national debt of £330bn, which will save the government just over £1bn in interest payments by 2003/4.

"By cutting debt, we cut debt interest payments," Mr Brown said. "By the end of this spending period, the first spectrum sale alone will lower debt interest payments by a billion pounds a year. Together with further savings from cutting unemployment and tackling benefit fraud, this allows us to release more than expected for the country's priorities - education, health, transport and policing - extra public spending which comes not at the expense of prudence but because of prudence."

Mr Brown's promise of more money for health, education, transport and policing - while public borrowing within narrow limits - is a trump card that the Tories will find it hard to counter in the run-up to the general election, expected to be called early next year.

In his annual budget in March, Mr Brown said overall current spending would rise by 2.5% a year in real terms, or roughly £40bn in total, between 2001 and 2004 - the three years covered by the next comprehensive spending review he will present to parliament next Tuesday. Today's announcement adds £3bn to the government's spending plans.

While party activists have criticised Labour for neglecting its heartlands, Mr Brown has dispelled Labour's traditional reputation for economic mismanagement. A tight grip on public spending and some tax rises over the first three years in power has turned a £28bn public deficit into a £15bn surplus. Another success the government can trumpet is record levels of employment with 28m people in work and the lowest jobless total since 1980 - 1,098,000.

Now, with an election probably only a year away, the government can open the purse strings to deliver on manifesto promises made at the time of the 1997 general election. Mr Brown has already said health spending will rise by over 6% above inflation annually in the next few years and that education and transport will also be big beneficiaries of government largesse.

But Mr Brown stressed that he will not abandon the fiscal rectitude which has earned him respect in the City, which has traditionally been highly suspicious of Labour governments.

"The same toughness and discipline that we have shown over the last three years will continue in the coming years," Mr Brown said. "We will meet our fiscal rules over the cycle, indeed, even in the most cautious case. We will stick to the envelope we announced in the budget for public spending."

Earlier in the day, the government released its annual report, its third yearly assessment of its performance since it came to power. As in previous reports, the government claimed it was delivering on its election pledges. Liberal Democrat leader Charles Kennedy said the government was acting as "judge and jury" on its own manifesto commitments.

"The prime minister says he is doing well in most subjects, could do better in a few others and probably will," Mr Kennedy said. "But if we all wrote our own end-of-term reports, we'd all give ourselves top marks."

Mr Brown, in keeping with his reputation for prudence, confirmed that the money is to be used to reduce the national debt of £330bn, which will save the government just over £1bn in interest payments by 2003/4. "By cutting debt, we cut debt interest payments," Mr Brown said. "By the end of this spending period, the first spectrum sale alone will lower debt interest payments by a billion pounds a year. Together with further savings from cutting unemployment and tackling benefit fraud, this allows us to release more than expected for the country's priorities - education, health, transport and policing - extra public spending which comes not at the expense of prudence but because of prudence." Mr Brown's promise of more money for health, education, transport and policing - while public borrowing within narrow limits - is a trump card that the Tories will find it hard to counter in the run-up to the general election, expected to be called early next year. In his annual budget in March, Mr Brown said overall current spending would rise by 2.5% a year in real terms, or roughly £40bn in total, between 2001 and 2004 - the three years covered by the next comprehensive spending review he will present to parliament next Tuesday. Today's announcement adds £3bn to the government's spending plans. While party activists have criticised Labour for neglecting its heartlands, Mr Brown has dispelled Labour's traditional reputation for economic mismanagement. A tight grip on public spending and some tax rises over the first three years in power has turned a £28bn public deficit into a £15bn surplus. Another success the government can trumpet is record levels of employment with 28m people in work and the lowest jobless total since 1980 - 1,098,000. Now, with an election probably only a year away, the government can open the purse strings to deliver on manifesto promises made at the time of the 1997 general election. Mr Brown has already said health spending will rise by over 6% above inflation annually in the next few years and that education and transport will also be big beneficiaries of government largesse. But Mr Brown stressed that he will not abandon the fiscal rectitude which has earned him respect in the City, which has traditionally been highly suspicious of Labour governments. "The same toughness and discipline that we have shown over the last three years will continue in the coming years," Mr Brown said. "We will meet our fiscal rules over the cycle, indeed, even in the most cautious case. We will stick to the envelope we announced in the budget for public spending." Earlier in the day, the government released its annual report, its third yearly assessment of its performance since it came to power. As in previous reports, the government claimed it was delivering on its election pledges. Liberal Democrat leader Charles Kennedy said the government was acting as "judge and jury" on its own manifesto commitments. "The prime minister says he is doing well in most subjects, could do better in a few others and probably will," Mr Kennedy said. "But if we all wrote our own end-of-term reports, we'd all give ourselves top marks."

fields.headline: Anger at peace talks 'meddling'
fields.standfirst:
Political scandal in US as Bush advisers tell Israelis to be ready to walk out of Camp David negotiations

Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: Political scandal in US as Bush advisers tell Israelis to be ready to walk out of Camp David negotiations
fields.body:
The Middle East peace talks at Camp David became the subject of a political scandal in the US last night when reports emerged that one of George W Bush's foreign policy advisers had warned the Israeli delegation to be prepared to walk out of negotiations.

Richard Perle, a veteran cold war warrior and former assistant secretary of state, urged the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, not to agree to any settlement which left the future status of Jerusalem unresolved, according to the New York Post website.

The website quoted a message received by Mr Barak yesterday from two of his emissaries, Yoram Ben-Ze'ev and Yossi Alpher. The two men said Mr Perle "asked us to send a clear message" to Mr Barak that it would be a "catastrophe" if the Jerusalem question was not dealt with, and urged him "to walk away" from the Camp David negotiations if faced with that outcome.

Mr Bush's office had no comment on the report yesterday. Mr Ben-Ze'ev, contacted by mobile phone, said he was in Houston, Texas - Governor Bush's home state - but would not explain the purpose of his visit and also refused to comment on the newspaper report.

Democrats responded angrily to what they portrayed as Republican meddling in the delicate negotiations currently under way at the presidential retreat at Camp David, Maryland, aimed at reaching a final settlement in the 52-year Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

"While I and all Americans are hoping and praying that the critical meeting at Camp David will be the beginning of a new era of peace for the Middle East, some are playing politics with this historic opportunity," said Sam Gejdenson, the ranking Democratic mem ber of the house committee on international relations.

Mr Gejdenson described Mr Perle's alleged intervention as "an outrage" and urged Mr Bush to disown his advisers' remarks. "In matters of life and death there is no room for politics and ego," he said.

In a further complication to the talks, entering their third day today, sources close to Yasser Arafat said he intended to summon Palestinian politicians to Camp David to discuss the next step.

Joe Lockhart, the White House spokesman, said the US mediators had not been informed of Mr Arafat's inten tions and said there was no provision in the Camp David ground rules for delegation members to come and go.

Mr Barak meanwhile offered his hosts a gift, promising to scrap the planned sale of a sophisticated airborne radar system to China. This would remove a longstanding irritant to US-Israel relations and lift a potential obstacle to increased US financial aid.

"They took into account our security concerns. We appreciate that and we welcome the decision," Mr Lockhart said.

Gadi Baltiansky, the chief Israeli spokesman at the talks, said Mr Barak had agreed to cancel the sale of the Phalcon early warning system to China at a Tuesday night meeting with President Clinton. The decision, Mr Baltiansky said, was aimed at improving the country's "intimate relations" with the US.

"Israel is right now together with the United States in the midst of an effort to achieve historic decisions relating to her vital interests," Mr Baltiansky said, explaining the background to the announcement. He said Mr Barak had "expressed sorrow" over the deal's cancellation in a letter to the Chinese president, Jiang Zemin.

webTitle: Putin steps up battle against the oligarchs

fields.headline: Putin steps up battle against the oligarchs
fields.standfirst: Russia: special report
fields.trailText: The Kremlin's crackdown on Russia's leading business tycoons intensified yesterday, when a criminal tax-evasion case was launched against its largest car manufacturer, Avtovaz.
fields.body:
The Kremlin's crackdown on Russia's leading business tycoons intensified yesterday, when a criminal tax-evasion case was launched against its largest car manufacturer, Avtovaz.

Announcing the latest in a stream of criminal investigations against the country's business elite, the head of Russia's tax police declared that the car-manufacturing giant - which is reportedly associated with the country's most influential tycoon, Boris Berezovsky - had "concealed huge sums" from the state.

In televised interviews, which appeared designed to spread unease throughout Moscow's corporate elite, senior tax officials warned that a criminal investigation against another massive Russian business would be launched today.

The Russian president, Vladimir Putin, also hinted that the country's oligarchs - the small group of businessmen who used their political contacts to amass vast fortunes when Soviet state monopolies were privatised in the early 1990s - were in for a difficult time.

This unexpected wave of high-level, anti-oligarch activity began on Tuesday when another tax-evasion case was opened against the chairman of Lukoil, Vagit Alekperov.

Lukoil, Russia's largest oil company, denied the charges, with officials pointing out that it had received last year's "honest tax-payer of the year" award.

At the same time, Vladimir Potanin, who heads the group controlling one of the world's largest nickel producers, Norilsk Nickel, came under separate attack. He was asked by the state prosecutors' office to make a voluntary payment of $140m (£92m) to the government in compensation for the amount it claims he underpaid for a large stake in Norilsk when it was privatised in the mid-1990s.

Meanwhile, criminal action against the press baron, Vladimir Gusinsky - the head of the independent media company, MediaMost - was stepped up, with new searches of its headquarters in Moscow by officials from the FSB, the successor to the KGB. Prosecutors this week widened their investigation to include the links between Mr Gusinsky's company and the natural gas monopoly, Gazprom, from whose head offices documents were also seized on Tuesday.

In his pre-election campaigning, Mr Putin courted popular approval by promising to act against the widely despised oligarchs, pledging that, under his rule, they would "cease to exist as a class". However, until this week, he had moved only against Mr Gusinsky, whose media holdings have been conspicuously critical of the Kremlin since Mr Putin's arrival in power last summer.

The move against Avtovaz was particularly unexpected, given its links with Mr Berezovsky, who was hugely influential in orchestrating Mr Putin's rapid rise to power.

There was speculation last night that the case was simply a flexing of muscles - an attempt by Mr Putin to see how much independence he is able to leverage from the powerful business figures who wielded so much influence over his predecessor Boris Yeltsin.

"Putin needs to show that he is in charge. These moves are more political than criminal," said Yevgeny Volk, a political analyst with the Heritage Foundation.

Within the Byzantine world of backroom Kremlin politics, ambiguity remained last night about whether the prosecutions were merely a display of strength for public consumption or whether Mr Putin truly intends to pursue this campaign to its conclusion.

fields.headline: No: 1376
fields.standfirst: Tiggy Pettifer
fields.trailText: Tiggy Pettifer
fields.body:
Name: Tiggy Pettifer, née Legge-Bourke.

Age: 34.

Status: Former nanny to Princes William and Harry.

Appearance: In the red.

As in embarrassed, or as in a problem debtor? Actually, a bit of both. The classy childminder caused a bit of a hoo-hah when she stopped for petrol at an M4 service station with Harry, then drove away without paying.

Hurrah! Another champion of the "Get It Down, Brown" petrol tax campaign. That's one way to dodge it. Don't be so crass, it was all just a terrible mistake. She assumed that the bodyguard who paid for the prince's sweets had also forked out for the fuel. And he thought that she was coughing up.

So what did the petrol station staff do? Hastily deploy their CCTV cameras and alert the police to the perpetrator's licence plate number? A little discretion, if you please. They chose the more delicate procedure of notifying Buckingham Palace of the oversight.

Don't tell me. The Queen Mum delved into her official birthday money to cover the cost of the gaffe. Not exactly, but St James's Palace did send a £40 cheque to BP to cover Mrs Pettifer's inattention.

So what did the staff make of it all? Garage manager David Haskell says: "There must have been a mix-up somewhere along the line. It all seems to be a genuine mistake and Tiggy has been in contact with us and has apologised."

He seems a forgiving chap. Yes, and on first-name terms with the Tigster, you'll notice. He adds: "Tiggy is a regular customer here. She is lovely and friendly with all the staff."

Do say: "Tiggy Pettifer - the people's nanny!"

Don't say: "Tiggy Pettifer - the people's petrol thief!"

Not to be confused with: Twiggy, Tricky, the Artful Dodger.

webTitle: Sharp rise in deaths raises alarm over human BSE

fields.headline: Sharp rise in deaths raises alarm over human BSE
fields.standfirst: What's wrong with our food? - special report
fields.trailText: A sharp rise in the death toll from the human form of BSE is being investigated by the government's scientific advisers with 67 people in Britain now thought to have been poisoned by infected beef.
fields.body:
A sharp rise in the death toll from the human form of BSE is being investigated by the government's scientific advisers with 67 people in Britain now thought to have been poisoned by infected beef.

The figure is 25 more than a year ago and seven up on those for the beginning of June although comparisons are difficult because of changes in the way the inevitably fatal condition is diagnosed and confirmed.

Seven more people are also believed to be suffering the condition following either brain scans or tonsil tests, statistics that will at the very least ensure there is no political complacency that either BSE or its human equivalent, vCJD, is under control.

The advisers will consider the latest figures at a meeting on Monday but it will be another two weeks before they announce whether there is cause for further public concern.

Also next week the food standards agency continues its review on whether it would be safe to reduce some anti-BSE controls introduced over the past 12 years, but widely flouted. Confidence was recently dented by the announcement that a cow born after extra controls were introduced on Europe's orders in March 1996 had contracted BSE, which had in the past few years only been killing older dairy cows that had not been culled as they were not destined for food.

This autumn, Lord Phillips, head of the BSE inquiry, will also deliver his verdict on the Conservative government's handling of the crisis up to 1996.

The Department of Health said yesterday the latest vCJD figure was "higher than we have seen of late, but we should be cautious about drawing too many conclusions from one set of monthly statistics. It is the underlying trend that is more important and the spongiform encephalopathy advisory com mittee will, as usual, be studying the latest data at their meeting this month. It is too early to predict the ultimate size of the vCJD epidemic."

Since April, the CJD surveillance unit has been adding figures of people still alive, but thought to have vCJD, to the monthly figures and there have been other changes to its monitoring. These have included increasing the recorded death toll for 1998 and 1999. The monthly figures often do not reflect when people died but when cause of death was established.

Even estimating the pattern of the disease from the date friends, relatives and GPs first identified symptoms to when people might die is difficult because so far this has varied from seven to 38 months, with an average of 14 months. In addition scientists do not know how long victims might have had the condition before it became apparent through depression and mood swings at first to problems with balance and other coordination later.

Three people are thought to have died in 1995, 10 in 1996, the year the probable human link to beef was first accepted by ministers, 10 in 1997, 18 in 1998 and 14 last year. A dozen more people are thought to have died in the first six months of this year, although in three cases, postmortem confirmation is still awaited.

fields.headline: Scandal that rocked Tories
fields.standfirst:
Turkish dam funding condemned
Villagers left high and dry by tide of progress
Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: The row over the Ilisu dam echoes the scandal over the £417m Pergau dam in Malaysia seven years ago, which rocked the Thatcher and Major governments and exposed the misuse of aid to get military orders and back British companies, regardless of environmental damage.
fields.body:
The row over the Ilisu dam echoes the scandal over the £417m Pergau dam in Malaysia seven years ago, which rocked the Thatcher and Major governments and exposed the misuse of aid to get military orders and back British companies, regardless of environmental damage.

The dam, now being built -also by Balfour Beatty - is destroying rainforest, displacing people and risking the spread of disease.

The scandal erupted when Sir Tim Lankester, then permanent secretary at the Foreign Office, refused to pay a £234m aid package because he believed it was "inconsistent with the spending of taxpayers' money in a prudent and economic manner". He was overruled by Douglas Hurd, then foreign secretary.

Then followed the most damaging revelation - the leak of a secret memoran dum of understanding between Britain and Malaysia - negotiated when Lady Thatcher was prime minister. This revealed that Britain and Malaysia had linked aid for the Malaysian dam - to be paid under the government's aid and trade provision - to defence orders for fighter aircraft. This was illegal and Whitehall tried to cover its tracks by saying that there had been drafting mistakes.

The scandal was big enough for Clare Short, the international development secretary, and Margaret Beckett, then trade secretary, to abolish the aid and trade programme after Labour won the election. The problem is resurfacing under the exports credit guarantee department, which provides credit cover for British projects overseas.

David Hencke

fields.headline: Turkish dam funding condemned
fields.standfirst:
Villagers left high and dry by tide of progress
Scandal that rocked Tories
Labour's ethical foreign policy: special report
fields.trailText: The government's credibility was dealt a stinging and highly embarrassing blow yesterday as MPs from all parties demanded that the proposed underwriting of a hydro-electric dam project in Turkey should be withdrawn immediately because it infringes human rights, threatens peace in the region and contravenes international standards.
fields.body:
The government's credibility was dealt a stinging and highly embarrassing blow yesterday as MPs from all parties demanded that the proposed underwriting of a hydro-electric dam project in Turkey should be withdrawn immediately because it infringes human rights, threatens peace in the region and contravenes international standards.

The international development committee of MPs expressed astonishment at the conduct of the Foreign Office over plans to give £200m support for the Ilisu dam and castigated the Department of Trade and Industry for putting profit for British companies above human rights and the prospects for peace in the Middle East. The dam project "is the worst form of export credit practice," the report said.

The condemnation is an embarrassment for Tony Blair, who in December overruled cabinet colleagues' scruples on the dam and asked Stephen Byers, the trade secretary, to announce on Christmas Eve that Britain "is minded" to back the project.

The report provides ammunition for environment groups which are planning to take the government to court for breaches of international law if it provides Balfour Beatty with export credit guarantees for the £1.25bn Ilisu project.

Yesterday, Patricia Hewitt, trade and industry minister, insisted that the government's involvement would help human rights. "What people do need to understand about this is that this dam is going to be built anyway. It is a very good argument for us to be involved in order to do everything we can to ensure that human rights and ethical standards are met."

The report refutes this idea: "The Ilisu dam was from the outset conceived and planned in contravention of international standards and it still does not comply. For that reason cover should not be given." MPs were particularly concerned about the plight of the Kurds and the destruction of the their city of Hasankeyf and its archaeological heritage.

"The project fails almost every internationally agreed test in terms of both con sultation and planning for social and environmental and social impact." MPs say the region has been "troubled by severe conflict." Human rights abuses among the minority Kurdish community and the prospect of tension between Turkey, Iraq and Syria over the cross-border flow of water from the river Tigris were well documented.

Despite this, the report said: "We have no sense the government have at any point seriously considered what repercussions the construction of the dam will have on the prospects for peace and the rights of the marginalised in this region of Turkey.

"We are astonished that the Foreign Office did not raise any questions about the proposed Ilisu dam and its effect on the human rights of those living in the region. The large scale resettlement of a population, many of whom may well question the very legitimacy of the government which moves them from their homes, must surely demand some detailed analysis from the Foreign Office."

The export credit guarantee department (ECGD) is having its rules for backing overseas projects with taxpayers' money revised. The committee says the ECGD should not provide cover for any project which infringes the human rights of workers or local populations

In a reference to the fact that Balfour Beatty is among a consortium of dam companies being prosecuted in a £2m bribes scandal in Africa and on June 7 was raided by the FBI in Boston over a £350m high-speed train project, the committee says any company found guilty of corruption or bribery should have export credit declared void.

The Foreign Office, in an attempt to deflect criticism, insisted yesterday that it had voiced its fears for the Kurds and peace in the Middle East if the dam was built to Brian Wilson, then trade minister. Richard Caborn, his successor, was clearly not aware of this when he gave evidence to the committee that no warnings had been given.

Tony Juniper, policy and campaigns director at Friends of the Earth, said: "This report vindicates every criticism we have made of this miserable project which the UK only supports because of the intervention of Tony Blair.

"He was told in a briefing it would be good for business because Balfour Beatty was in line for reconstruction contracts after the Turkish earthquakes. But now the prime minister's own MPs are telling him what we have known all along: the Ilisu dam is an environmental disaster, a human rights scandal and a threat to peace."

The director of the World Development Movement, Barry Coates, said: "This report should deliver the fatal blow to the disastrous dam. The ECGD has a long record of providing public funds, in the form of guarantees, for projects that have been involved in massive social and environmental damage. The current situation is a corporate welfare scandal."
