Shareholders have achieved the concession of upfront communication in public and been assured that in future payments will not be linked to deals. Mr Gent, though, still has his £10m of cash and shares. It is now up to the chief executive and his colleagues to show they were worth it all along. It's good to talk On the subject of big, modern companies communicating with their shareholders, employees and customers (yes, we are talking stakeholders here), a survey has just been published on how global businesses might survive what is termed the "Age of Accountability". According to a corporate marketing consultancy called Addison, the key findings "deliver a warning to the boards of the world's biggest companies who have demonstrated that they are ill-equipped to deal with the dramatic changes that have been brought about by the electronic information revolution." Companies, we are told, must start to prepare communication strategies that are specifically targeted to all their key stakeholder groups, including non-governmental organisations, environmental groups, as well as customers and both retail and institutional shareholders. Apparently, directors of global companies are really quite naive when assessing the power of stakeholder groups. They do not understand how the communicative power of the internet has changed the game, shifting power away from the company itself and at the same time raising the expectations amongst all sorts of audiences in terms of facts and disclosure. And who owns this lefty, opinionated Addison outfit, anyway? Step forward WPP, the advertising group run by Sir Martin Sorrell - a man who really does know a thing or two about fat-fat pay packets and justifying their existence.

webTitle: Primate who discarded Anglican image as Tory party at prayer

fields.headline: Primate who discarded Anglican image as Tory party at prayer
fields.standfirst:
Archbishop antagonised politicians by refusing to temper his innate beliefs
Religion in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: The prime minister, church leaders from all main denominations, and even old foes including Lady Thatcher and Lord Tebbit, joined to pay tribute to Lord Runcie, former archbishop of Canterbury, who died yesterday, and who in his lifetime suffered more denigration and abuse than perhaps any holder of the office for 300 years.
fields.body:
The prime minister, church leaders from all main denominations, and even old foes including Lady Thatcher and Lord Tebbit, joined to pay tribute to Lord Runcie, former archbishop of Canterbury, who died yesterday, and who in his lifetime suffered more denigration and abuse than perhaps any holder of the office for 300 years.

The tributes praised the moral courage and integrity of the former archbishop, who died at the age of 78 following a six-year struggle against prostate cancer.

Tony Blair said Lord Runcie had been a man of great faith and moral courage who had carried the Church of England united through momentous and historic times. "He was also a spiritual man of humility and modesty who will be missed by millions of ordinary people who saw him as their friend," he said.

Lady Thatcher admitted she had had her differences with the archbishop but added: "Robert Runcie was a warm, good, brave man... a friend for more than 50 years. I shall miss him."

George Carey, the present archbishop, spoke of Lord Runcie's deep Christian faith. "I mourn the passing of a friend and brother bishop whose attitude to death as to life was rooted in a firm conviction of God ever present."

There were heartfelt words, too, from other Anglican bishops, Catholic leaders, Methodists, the Church of Scotland, and the chief rabbi, Jonathan Sacks, who praised him as a warm and gentle leader, undervalued in an abrasive age.

During Dr Runcie's 11 years as archbishop from 1980 to 1991, he was much criticised by politicians for his pointed and sometimes inconvenient reminder of non-partisan, spiritual values, and sometimes by his fellow churchmen for his determination to represent the whole communion rather than factions within it.

There were historic occasions such as the visit to Britain of Pope John Paul II in 1982, when the two men prayed together at Canterbury Cathedral, the first visit ever by a serving pontiff and an event inconceivable only a few years earlier. And there were state occasions, too, such as the wedding of the Prince of Wales to Princess Diana - an event Lord Runcie later said he had known to be an arranged marriage between an ill-matched couple.

Military Cross

But he is probably likely primarily to be remembered as the leader of the Church of England at a time when it fell out with the Conservative government and ceased to be regarded as the Tory party at prayer.

A patrician and avuncular figure, he antagonised Margaret Thatcher by preaching a conciliatory sermon at the service in St. Paul's to celebrate the end of the Falklands war, asking for prayers for the relatives of those who had died on both sides.

It was something he could do with some authority, much exacerbating the government's aggravation, having been awarded the Military Cross while a tank commander in the Scots Guards during the second world war.

The medal, awarded to him during the invasion of Normandy in 1944 for drawing fire away from other tanks, aptly prefigured his subsequent career, where attacks on the church honed in on him. He was the first modern archbishop to be pilloried in the media - attacks which he generally took with geniality. "It would be difficult to be an archbishop without people gunning for you," he said in 1985.

Lord Runcie drew fire when he presided over the Church of England's report Faith in the City in 1985, a report which criticised the government's policies over urban poverty and deprivation, and was denounced by Norman Tebbit and other ministers, even ahead of publication, as a Marxist document.

Lord Tebbit said yesterday: "I found him a very warm and human man, very unstuffy. I never doubted his conviction. But, you know, being an archbishop doesn't necessarily make you any more right than being a cabinet minister."

Generally Lord Runcie's stature con trasted with the calibre of those who attacked him, like Jeffrey Archer and Neil Hamilton.

They did not like it when he urged sympathy for beleaguered mining communities during the miners' strike, or pointed out, in relation to the inner cities: "We don't have to look as far as Ethiopia to find the darkness of disease, death and disaster. It is here on our doorstep."

Lord Runcie, whose recreations in Who's Who were given as opera, reading history and novels, and owning Berkshire pigs, was a more substantial figure than his opponents, both in government and within the church, credited. For many he was one of the most distinguished archbishops of the 20th century.

An urbane intellectual, with an Oxford first class degree and 10 years as head of a theological college, he succeeded in holding the Anglican communion together, while paving the way for convulsions such as ordination of women, an initiative to which he was initially opposed.

Within the Church of England he was renowned for his emollience and ability in conciliation, but also for his irreverent wit and a phenomenal memory which enabled him to remember, even decades later, the identities of those he had met in the past.

He was instinctively and intellectually hostile to the fervour, bordering on fanaticism, of some in the church. "There is a sort of feeling that the religion that counts is one that is definite and uncompromising. We liberals have got to keep our head," he said last year.

His diplomatic skills led nonetheless to conflict when one of his friends, the embittered Oxford college chaplain Gary Bennett, passed over for a bishopric, committed suicide after being identified as the anonymous author of a vitriolic attack on Lord Runcie in the 1987 Crockford's clerical directory. Among the archbishop's other troublesome advisers was Terry Waite, who disobeyed advice by retuning to the Lebanon on a doomed mission to negotiate the release of hostages and was himself incarcerated for five years. Robert Runcie was the first archbishop of recent times to step up to the primacy from a mere bishopric, St Albans, and after only 10 years as a bishop. The son of an engineer working for Tate and Lyle in Liverpool, he was ordained in 1950, becoming principal of Cuddesdon theological college, near Oxford, 10 years later.

Lord Runcie, who received a life peerage after his retirement in 1991, leaves a wife Rosalind (Lindy), and a son and daughter.

In retirement controversy continued to dog him after remarks he made for background purposes to his biographer Humphrey Carpenter were quoted verbatim when the book was published in 1996. He was rebuked by Dr Carey for inadvertently letting slip that he thought Princess Diana an actress and schemer.

Characteristically, the former archbishop confined himself to a restrained letter of complaint to Carpenter: "I have done my best to die before this book is published ... it is yet another investigation heavily dependent on the skillfully edited tape recorder. Burbling into it for background, I find it reproduced for substance.

"It is not only the syntax that makes me wince. There is much that I never imagined I would see in print ... Meanwhile I shall try to keep my sense of humour and the perspective of eternity."

Times of strife

March 1980 Enthroned as 102nd archbishop of Canterbury

July 1981 Marriage of Prince Charles and Princess Diana

May 1982 Visit of Pope John Paul II to Britain

July 1982 Falklands memorial service. Annoys government with prayers for Argentinian and British dead

September 1984 Says government should stop treating its opponents as "scum"

October 1984 Expresses concern at government economic policies: "How long can we wait for jam tomorrow?"

December 1985 Faith in the City report described as Marxist by government ministers

January 1987 Terry Waite kidnapped in Beirut

December 1987 Crockford's preface accuses Runcie of being weak and indecisive. Author commits suicide when unmasked as embittered Oxford don

March 1988 Says homosexual priests could live together if they are not in a sexual relationship

November 1989 Votes for ordination of women

January 1991 Resigns as archbishop

November 1991 Terry Waite released

September 1996 Criticised for making indiscreet remarks in biography by Humphrey Carpenter

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Home Office selects ICL
fields.body:
Home Office selects ICL

ICL has won a 10-year, £350m contract to modernise IT at the Home Office. The Sirius consortium, led by ICL, also includes PriceWaterhouseCoopers and Global Crossing and replaces the Home Office's current IT provider, Sema Group. The consortium will provide telephony, e-business consultancy, secure e-mail, internet and extranet technologies.

Ultimatum for Railtrack

Virgin Trains has issued an ultimatum to Railtrack: cut delays on the west coast main line in 28 days or we'll see you in court. The train operator postponed the threat of immediate legal action after studying a 30-point plan from Railtrack to deal with the worst delays.

Services on the route have suffered delays of up to four hours since the start of the £5.8bn track and signalling upgrade. Work will not be finished until 2005. Railtrack said performance had been "disappointing" but it had been working hard to tackle the problems.

SFO poaches Howse The serious fraud office yesterday poached Tricia Howse, a well known financial crime buster, from the City regulator, the financial services authority.

The departure of Ms Howse, who will be an assistant director at the SFO, was regarded as a blow for the FSA where she was head of statutory investigations and prosecutions. She leaves the FSA just as the regulator gains new powers to tackle "market abuse". She is expected to join the SFO in October.

UN turns up heat on G7

UN secretary general Kofi Annan has added to pressure on leaders of the world's seven richest industrialised nations by calling for urgent action to accelerate third world debt relief. South African president Thabo Mbeki will lobby the G7 meeting in Okinawa next week along with Nigeria's president, Olusegun Obasanjo, and other leaders from developing nations, who will reinforce Kofi Annan's message.

Nexium wins EU approval

The ulcer drug Nexium, seen as the replacement for the top-selling Losec, won approval to go on sale in Europe. AstraZeneca, its maker, says Nexium will be even more successful, and the shares hit a record high of £31.92 yesterday.

IMF warns on US inflation

The IMF said "decisive policy action" from the Federal Reserve was needed to keep the US economy from overheating. In its annual review of the US economy, the IMF said further tightening of monetary policy was needed to keep inflation under control. The IMF also warned against large tax cuts or new spending.

£500,000 bail for a holiday

Andrew Regan, the entrepreneur who tried to takeover the CWS and now faces charges of stealing £2.4m, was permitted by magistrates yesterday to take a holiday in St Tropez, provided he added a further £500,000 to his £1m bail. He is due to appear at Snaresbrook crown court in September.

fields.headline: £300m facelift for Regent Street
fields.trailText: The Crown Estate is planning to spend £300m over the next 10 years in a massive upgrade of Regent Street in London. But it has run into a roadblock with Westminster city council over traffic-calming measures for the area.
fields.body:
The Crown Estate is planning to spend £300m over the next 10 years in a massive upgrade of Regent Street in London. But it has run into a roadblock with Westminster city council over traffic-calming measures for the area.

The planned investment is expected to bring in an extra £75m a year of revenue. Talks are under way with several developers about a joint venture.

The historic facade of Regent Street properties will be retained. But extensive modernisation will take place inside many of the 125 offices and retail outlets owned by the public sector organisation.

Twenty-five of the long leases in Regent Street expire over the next 10 years and the Crown Estate is keen to change the economics of the buildings. It makes only £500,000 a year in revenues from £130m worth of property.

The Crown Estate, directly answerable to the House of Commons, yesterday announced it had produced profits of £133m in 1999, a 5.6% increase on 12 months earlier.

The capital value of its entire portfolio of properties, which takes in 850 farms and Windsor Great Park, increased in value almost 10% to £3.6bn.

The at Regent Street development would not be affected by the impasse at street level, said the Crown Estate's chief executive, Chris Howes, who hopes for an amicable agreement with the local authority.

fields.headline: Capital Radio feels the £34m Beat
fields.standfirst: Capital corporate site
fields.trailText: Capital Radio, Britain's largest commercial radio group, yesterday snapped up one of Scotland's fastest growing young stations for £33.75m, making millionaires of three local celebrities in the process.
fields.body:
Capital Radio, Britain's largest commercial radio group, yesterday snapped up one of Scotland's fastest growing young stations for £33.75m, making millionaires of three local celebrities in the process.

Former footballer Ally McCoist, television presenter Carol Smillie and Texas lead singer Sharleen Spiteri are understood to have received around £1m each for their stakes in Beat 106, which started broadcasting just nine weeks ago.

Nightclub impresario Ron McCullough, whose Big Beat Holdings owns Leicester Square superclub Home, is the largest individual shareholder and receives around £10m. Analysts say values within the radio sector have been inflated by the rapid pace of consolidation among analogue broadcasters. Capital's latest deal follows hot on the heels of its £151m takeover of Border Television's Century radio assets and the enlarged group will have the potential to broadcast to 58% of Britain's adult population, said operations director Paul Davies.

"We've been looking to achieve a bigger national platform and we still have headroom to make more acquisitions or acquire more licenses," he added.

The deal will be financed through the issue of new shares equivalent to 5.6% of Capital's issued share capital at £15 each, providing the group with £30m to help fund further expansion.

Capital claimed the Beat 106 acquisition will prove attractive to advertisers, increase its reach by 3.9% and potential audience by 10%.

Beat 106 broadcasts a mixture of new rock and dance music and targets 15- to 39-year-olds in the Glasgow and Edinburgh region. Its total transition area extends to 60% of the Scottish population.

Simultaneously Capital's interactive division announced plans to increase its offering of web-based radio stations, which can broadcast to global audiences across the internet. It plans to launch three narrowcast stations aimed at niche audiences.

Rage will be aimed at a young male market, Diva at working women and Urban Groove at 20-somethings. EMI, Universal and BMG music companies have agreed that the stations can use their material online and partnerships with websites such as Handbag.com and Sports.com will be used to give the broadcasts as wide an audience as possible.

Capital's shares slipped 12.5p to £15.75p.

fields.headline: Shopping list regular
fields.trailText: PaineWebber, one of the oldest securities firms in America, has been on the shopping list of almost every financial services group looking to buy a piece of Wall Street for years.
fields.body:
PaineWebber, one of the oldest securities firms in America, has been on the shopping list of almost every financial services group looking to buy a piece of Wall Street for years.

Don Marron, appointed group chief executive in 1980, has repeatedly rejected overtures from companies including Goldman Sachs and Dresdner Bank . In approaching his 65th birthday, however, Mr Marron is understood to have succumbed to UBS because of the increasing difficulty in competing against bigger operations such as Merrill Lynch and online operator Charles Schwab .

The decision to sell out to the Swiss group ends 120 years of independence at a firm started by two Boston bank clerks, William Paine and Wallace Webber, in 1879. The firm joined the New York stock exchange in 1890. It moved to New York in 1963.

Although it expanded through acquisitions, the bank largely missed out on the takeover craze of the 1980s. After the 1987 stock market crash, Yasuda , the Japanese insurance company, bought an equity stake of about 8% of the firm.

PaineWebber was hit hard by the bond market crash in 1994, reporting an 87% decline in earnings. The bank cut jobs after it paid General Electric more than $670m (£418m) for Kidder, Peabody , the troubled investment bank involved in the share trading scandals of the 1980s. In 1996 it bounced back with record earnings.

webTitle: BT faces lawsuits over local loop

fields.headline: BT faces lawsuits over local loop
fields.trailText: British Telecom's refusal to open up its entire network to competition this year leaves the company open to a rash of lawsuits from rivals and legal action from the European commission, it emerged yesterday.
fields.byline: Andrew Osborn in Brussels and  Helen Carter
fields.body:
British Telecom's refusal to open up its entire network to competition this year leaves the company open to a rash of lawsuits from rivals and legal action from the European commission, it emerged yesterday.

A regulation approved by the commission yesterday stipulates that BT will be legally obliged to open up the local loop - the crucial final stretch of cable leading to a consumer's home - by the end of this year.

Oftel admitted yesterday that Britain would not be in a position to comply with the regulation until July of next year, some seven months late, exposing BT to potentially punitive compensation claims.

The move came as a double blow for BT's chairman, Sir Iain Vallance, who came under pressure yesterday at the company's annual meeting in Manchester from shareholders worried about the plunging share price.

Shareholders sought assurances that every effort was being made by the board to prevent further falls in the company's value, which is at an 18-month low of 815p a share.

The commission said ending telecoms monopolies was a crucial step in the race to offer consumers a choice of unlimited high-speed internet deals at fixed prices, viewed as one of the best ways of getting more people on to the net.

Oftel yesterday did its best to argue that Britain would be able to comply with the regulation because the legal frame work for liberalisation would be in place before 2001 and BT would be taking orders for access to its network from this September.

The regulator did acknowledge, however, that the local loop would not be open to all of BT's competitors until next July.

Oftel's interpretation of what must be done to meet the regulation's conditions falls far short of what the company expects and was immediately slapped down in Brussels.

"The regulation is clear and requires incumbents to give full physical access to new market entrants by January 1, 2001," one commission official said. "If a company is unhappy with BT they can take it to court once this becomes law. The regulation is supreme and that is law."

The regulation must still be approved by European Union telecoms ministers and the European parliament before it can become law, and Oftel remains adamant that its own interpretation of what BT must do to comply will avoid any legal action.

"It's not something that can happen overnight but it is going to be rolled out. It takes a lot of work and technical knowhow and we do not want any mismatches of equipment," on Oftel spokeswoman said.

"We believe we would be compliant with the regulation's terms and conditions," she added, saying that the question of whether BT had to physically offer the service by the end of the year rather than simply take orders for it was "a matter of opinion".

webTitle: Football fan curbs will have time limit

fields.headline: Football fan curbs will have time limit
fields.standfirst: Football Violence special report
fields.trailText: The emergency legislation to tackle football hooliganism being rushed through parliament this month is only to be a temporary addition to the statute book, Jack Straw announced last night.
fields.body:
The emergency legislation to tackle football hooliganism being rushed through parliament this month is only to be a temporary addition to the statute book, Jack Straw announced last night.

The details of the bill published last night show that the most sensitive parts of the legislation, including on-the-spot bans on suspected hooligans travelling abroad, will have to be reviewed after 12 months by both houses of parliament and will lapse completely after five years.

The home secretary, who faces an uphill struggle to get his emergency legislation through parliament by the end of this month, has also conceded that the police must give their reasons in writing when they detain somebody at an airport or rail station under their powers in the bill. The need to review the powers after their first year in operation and the decision to let them lapse after five years will also apply to the new power for the courts to issue football banning orders on suspected hooligans against whom the evidence falls short of a conviction.

The national criminal intelligence service is also to get the power to share its information on football hooligans with certain other organisations, such as the Football Association, so they can purge their supporters' organisations of known hooligans and racists.

Mr Straw proposed the amendments to his original proposals after meeting peers and MPs earlier this week. The Conservative peer and chairman of Justice, the all-party law reform group, Lord Alexander of Weedon, had suggested the bill should have a "sunset clause" which would enable it to reach the statute book for England's World Cup qualifying games in September and October but its powers would then lapse.

Last night the Conservative MP Simon Burns, who took his Football (Offences and Disorder) Act into law last year with government support, said the renewal plan was not ideal but may be necessary to ensure the safe passage of Mr Straw's bill.

"We must have proper scrutiny in parliament. If one way of allaying fears about it is to have an arrangement similar to the Prevention of Terrorism Act where parliament has to reappraise the legislation, then I think that's probably a sensible way out."

Ministers also moved yesterday to reassure MPs that the powers in the bill, particularly to prevent hooligans travelling abroad, did comply with the European convention on human rights.

Mr Straw yesterday signed the commencement order which will mean that human rights cases can be brought in British courts from October 2. Home Office ministers made clear the powers in the bill did not contravene the right to travel as the convention gave governments the power to limit free movement on the grounds of public order.

webTitle: Opera stars hit high notes without cruellest cut of all

fields.headline: Opera stars hit high notes without cruellest cut of all
fields.trailText: Even 10 years ago, audiences laughed at them as silly men with squeaky voices. But now a new breed of operatic superstar is taking music written for the almost mythical castrati back to the masses.
fields.body:
Even 10 years ago, audiences laughed at them as silly men with squeaky voices. But now a new breed of operatic superstar is taking music written for the almost mythical castrati back to the masses.

The resurgence in popularity of the counter tenor - for long dismissed as an operatic oddity - is now so strong that many in classical music are predicting their appeal will eclipse the great stadium-filling tenors like Pavarotti, Domingo and Carreras.

Handel's greatest arias once required the ultimate sacrifice from a male singer. With few takers willing to undergo the knife, female contraltos and mezzo sopranos were hired to play those key male roles in baroque opera modern listeners found so strange and haunting.

Now the sublime voices of counter tenors like the charismatic David Daniels and Andreas Scholl, who can sing the high notes required by Bach and Handel without recourse to drastic surgery, have built a huge international following for a once forgotten oeuvre of early music.

Recordings by both men have recently topped the classical music charts, and their performances sell months in advance.

Unlike their 18th century counterparts like Farinelli, who were castrated in childhood so their voices would never break, modern counter tenors need not compromise their manhood for their art. Instead the falsetto (false voice) of which most men are capable - and which made Barry Gibb of the Bee Gees rich - can be honed to reach the higher registers.

Even so, a little of the prejudice under which the castrati laboured lingers on. Not even the German-born Scholl, who created a sensation last year at Glyndebourne with his Bertarido in Handel's Rode-linda, has been immune from the sniggers. Though well over 6ft, and with the dashing looks which have earned him the soubriquet of Superman, he too has been laughed at. "I have sung in Nuremberg, and some of the audience laughed because they thought it was funny that a man sings that high - even though they hear it every day on the radio. Male pop singers sing higher than counter tenors, screaming their heads off, and nobody worries about that."

But that has not put off the hundreds of hopefuls who Daniels claims want to train as counter tenors in the United States.

"When I started no one was interested. Now huge numbers of young men are training. There are hundreds at college auditions."

Daniels and Scholl are arguably the two greatest male singers in the world, according to Andrew Clements, the Guardian's classical music critic, a happy coincidence which has combined with the new interest in early music to cement the trend.

It is Britain which has done most to save the style from slipping into oblivion. The tradition of the counter tenor - or male alto as it was called here - never really died out and it was the post-war singer Alfred Deller who awakened its potential in contemporary composers like Tippett and Britten.

Margaret Cable, professor of singing at the Royal College of Music in London, is convinced the new wave of counter tenors will give Pavarotti, Domingo and Carreras a run for their money. "I wouldn't be in the slightest bit surprised if we get three counter tenors doing the same thing. Why not ... they are very, very popular."

webTitle: UVF man shot as loyalists fall out

fields.headline: UVF man shot as loyalists fall out
fields.standfirst:
Violence mars Protestants' big night as bitter divisions and murderous disputes ravage community
Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: He died beneath a lamp post, painted red, white and blue, and from it fluttered the purple standard of his paramilitary organisation, the Ulster Volunteer Force. The grass was still stained with his blood, and, next to the swings and roundabout, firemen were dousing the embers of the once roaring bonfire.
fields.body:
He died beneath a lamp post, painted red, white and blue, and from it fluttered the purple standard of his paramilitary organisation, the Ulster Volunteer Force. The grass was still stained with his blood, and, next to the swings and roundabout, firemen were dousing the embers of the once roaring bonfire.

Andrew Cairns, 22, was killed early yesterday from a single gunshot to the back of his head. Hundreds of people were on the Old Glenarm Road in Larne, Co Antrim, when he was executed after 12 men, all fellow loyalists, had chased him and meted out a savage beating.

Like tens of thousands of Protestants throughout Northern Ireland, the residents had been celebrating 11th night, the eve of July 12, the high point in the Orange Order's marching season, with a huge fire.

They were marking King William of Orange's victory over the Catholic forces of King James II at the Battle of the Boyne on that date in 1690, so setting Protestants on course for centuries of supremacy. Bonfires were lit to alert his supporters when he set ashore in nearby Carrickfergus the previous month.

Detective Inspector George Montgomery was spending the public holiday piecing together the motive. Drink played an important part, but he was looking at whether a loyalist feud was to blame.

Had Protestants murdered a Catholic it would have fearsomely exacerbated the crisis over the ban on Orange Order's march at Drumcree, just outside Portadown, Co Armagh, just as it was dying out. So perhaps some of the relief across Northern Ireland yes terday at the feud theory was understandable.

Security sources believe Drumcree had nothing much to do with Mr Cairns's murder, just as it was unconnected to the non-fatal stabbing of a loyalist at a bonfire in east Belfast. They said Cairns was, in a euphemism much favoured here, well known to police, and indicated he may have died anyway.

Initial speculation was that Ulster Freedom Fighters were behind the killing. They have an alliance in some areas with the hardline Loyalist Volunteer Force, at murderous loggerheads with the UVF, particularly in Portadown. But it was later suggested fellow UVF members were responsible.

No matter. His assassination, in such a public manner, highlighted the mess the Protestant community is in after 11 days of the Drumcree dispute. Whether they would choose to be defined as Orangemen, unionists or loyalists, Protestants are confused, and irrevocably split.

They cannot even agree what they are protesting against. Some cite the civil and religious liberties of the Portadown district, banned from the nationalist Garvaghy Road for the third year running. Others are unhappy with the Good Friday agreement, particularly with Sinn Fein members in government, and many find their sectarian bile hard to swallow at this time of year.

Some are alienated, with deprivation more a cause than politics or religion. Others enjoy the violence. And for many, there is an abstract sense that they are losing in the new Northern Ireland.

So they are unable to agree on tactics. Because there is a lack of leadership among the constituent parts, and with even hardline unionist politicians avoiding involvement for the first time in six years of the saga, the protests are a rudderless disaster. Loyalists, long key in supporting reasoned change, are the bad guys again, and the 205-year-old Orange Order is in disarray.

David Ervine, assembly member of the Progressive Unionist Party, linked to the UVF, said: "Many of us perceive our culture to be under threat from outside. I am inclined to wonder just how much it is under threat from inside. We in the unionist community are doing terrible, terrible damage to ourselves, and I can hear the laughter of the republican community."

Jack McKee, a Larne councillor for the Democratic Unionist party, at the bonfire when Mr Cairns was murdered, said: "I am shocked and numbed. Protestant is now turning gun on Protestant, and it is an absolute disgrace."

Masked UFF volunteers appeared at bonfires on the Sandy Row and on the Shankill Road in Belfast yesterday. They fired wildly into the air, to rousing cheers.

It was ugly too at Drumcree, with 21 RUC officers hurt, bringing to more than 80 the total of security force casualties.

Protesters burned an effigy of an RUC man in riot gear on their bonfire in the nearby loyalist Corcrain estate. They did so as unionists in the Commons were again trying to save the 78-year-old force's name.

There were scores more incidents. Ambulance crew were attacked in west Belfast. Many Orangemen are distraught.

William Brown, a deputy grand master of Ireland, said: "When I see people blocking traffic with pints of beer in their hands, that was not the organisation I joined. Good people have only to do nothing to let bad men succeed. We need new leadership."

But Orangemen Jim Rodgers, an Ulster Unionist councillor, was heckled at yesterday's mass meeting of Orangemen in Belfast.

Robert Saulters, head of the Orange Order, sounded a defiant note in Killyleagh, Co Armagh, as he blamed one or two Orangemen for feeding stories to the media. He then attacked politicians who had gone into government with Sinn Fein.

The fear of change in Northern Ireland is deep these days.

webTitle: Beatles head list of greatest songs

fields.headline: Beatles head list of greatest songs
fields.trailText: Some of the world's finest songwriters have collaborated to compile a list of what they consider to be the greatest songs of all time, and topping the list are songs from two of the country's most famous bands.
fields.body:
Some of the world's finest songwriters have collaborated to compile a list of what they consider to be the greatest songs of all time, and topping the list are songs from two of the country's most famous bands.

The Beatles' In My Life, an autobiographical tune written by John Lennon about his home town of Liverpool, pipped the Rolling Stones' Satisfaction for first place in a list that included Over The Rainbow, Tracks Of My Tears and You've Lost That Lovin' Feelin'.

However, the list lacks a strong modern influence with most of the songs coming from the 1960s and 1970s. Recent pop songs are the exception rather than the rule, with only 10 of the top 100 songs composed after 1980.

Beatles songs figured prominently throughout the list, along with other celebrated songwriters like Bob Dylan, Billie Holiday and Simon and Garfunkel.

And while normally it is their songs that feature on such lists songwriters including Paul McCartney, Hal David, the Beach Boys' Brian Wilson, Cynthia Weil who wrote You've Lost That Lovin' Feelin' and Motown's Lamont Dozier each nominated 20 favourite songs to help compile the poll which appears in next month's issue of the music magazine Mojo.

While the top 100 is loaded with classic songs, there are some unexpected placings, with Britney Spears's Baby One More Time ranked higher than The Buzzcocks' Ever Fallen In Love, and Desperado by The Eagles.

Jim Irvin, senior editor of Mojo, said the appearance of pop's teen sensation should not be that surprising. "It might look odd, but there are a lot of people I know who feel that it's a genius piece of songwriting."

The Beatles' In My Life, an autobiographical tune written by John Lennon about his home town of Liverpool, pipped the Rolling Stones' Satisfaction for first place in a list that included Over The Rainbow, Tracks Of My Tears and You've Lost That Lovin' Feelin'. However, the list lacks a strong modern influence with most of the songs coming from the 1960s and 1970s. Recent pop songs are the exception rather than the rule, with only 10 of the top 100 songs composed after 1980. Beatles songs figured prominently throughout the list, along with other celebrated songwriters like Bob Dylan, Billie Holiday and Simon and Garfunkel. And while normally it is their songs that feature on such lists songwriters including Paul McCartney, Hal David, the Beach Boys' Brian Wilson, Cynthia Weil who wrote You've Lost That Lovin' Feelin' and Motown's Lamont Dozier each nominated 20 favourite songs to help compile the poll which appears in next month's issue of the music magazine Mojo. While the top 100 is loaded with classic songs, there are some unexpected placings, with Britney Spears's Baby One More Time ranked higher than The Buzzcocks' Ever Fallen In Love, and Desperado by The Eagles. Jim Irvin, senior editor of Mojo, said the appearance of pop's teen sensation should not be that surprising. "It might look odd, but there are a lot of people I know who feel that it's a genius piece of songwriting." webTitle: Bored husband 'asked friend to kill wife'

fields.headline: Bored husband 'asked friend to kill wife'
fields.standfirst: Court hears of £20,000 offer for murder at luxury home
fields.trailText: A wealthy book dealer contracted a friend to murder his wife and dump her body in the couple's swimming pool because he was bored with her, a court heard yesterday.
fields.body:
A wealthy book dealer contracted a friend to murder his wife and dump her body in the couple's swimming pool because he was bored with her, a court heard yesterday.

Colin Harrold, 35, allegedly offered Darren Lake, his best man from a previous marriage, £20,000 to make it look as if his wife Diane, 36, had fallen into the pool at the couple's luxury home in Uffington, Lincolnshire, in October last year.

Nottingham crown court heard that Harrold also paid Lake to drown the family cat so it would appear that Mrs Harrold had tripped over a broken slab and drowned while looking for it.

James Hunt QC, prosecuting, told the jury that the staged accident had gone wrong. Lake, 31, from Peterborough, had used a 3ft wooden post to stun Mrs Harrold, fracturing her nose and leaving bloody footprints in the house and a fingerprint on a Tesco bag full of cash.

Lake has already pleaded guilty to murdering Mrs Harrold and is due to give evidence for the prosecution. Mr Hunt said: "This is not a case of whodunnit. We know - he has admitted it. It is a question of who got him to do it. We say it is plainly Colin Harrold,"

Harrold denies murder and conspiring to murder his wife.

He met her in February 1994 after placing a lonely hearts ad in a local paper, the court heard. "She was his second wife. She wanted children. He did not," said Mr Hunt. "Moreover he had become tired of and disinterested in her and was playing with another woman. He had made a lot of money and lived a lavish lifestyle. It would have been expensive to divorce his second wife and she would know too much of his shady business to be bought off cheaply."

Mr Hunt said Harrold had therefore arranged for Lake to kill his wife at their £335,000 home while he established his alibi on a business trip to the south-east of England and Amsterdam.

Mrs Harrold was killed on the night of October 19, 1999, Mr Hunt said. The following day Harrold and Jo Azzopardi, his employee and friend, flew to Amsterdam.

Mr Azzopardi, giving evidence, said the two men had "gone to see the totty" in Amsterdam's red light district. He said Harrold liked women but had not said anything about an extramarital affair. "Yes he liked women but so do I - that does not make him a murderer," said Mr Azzopardi.

Harrold claims he raised the alarm after getting no reply when he telephoned home while in Amsterdam, and then asked his brother, Neil, to check everything was fine, the court heard.

Mrs Harrold's body was found face down in the deep end of the swimming pool, there were blood stains in the laundry room, kitchen and on a wall near the back door of the house.

Lake was arrested but denied Colin Harrold had had any part in the murder. But police found letters at Lake's house which he had written to his father and to himself. One of the letters was to be sent to police in the event of his suspicious death.

It said the most likely reason for his death was that "Colin Harrold had paid for a hit or killed me himself, possibly a boat accident, car accident or whilst on holiday with him."

In the letter, which was read out in court, he said he had been a fool with money "which has led me to do this thing I am going to tell you."

It went on: "Colin Harrold knows I have huge debts and has offered me £20,000 to kill Diane, his wife, in the pool and the cat ... thus freeing him to have a playboy life, freedom to see Tania [a woman he supposedly was having an affair with] and others, boat in Malta, his house paid for, less expense as she spends lots."

Mr Hunt said Harrold told a woman he met in a cafe who asked him if he was married, "Yes for two years, two years too bloody long".

He allegedly told her that "money is changing hands as we speak, I'm doing something about it now."

The Harrolds' housekeeper, Michelle Cook, told the court Mr Harrold had told her Mrs Harrold was not as attractive as his first wife and that he was not 100% happy in the relationship.

The trial continues tomorrow.

webTitle: Corrupt police framed three for robbery

fields.headline: Corrupt police framed three for robbery
fields.standfirst: Ten year jail sentences quashed by court of appeal after allegations that crucial evidence was planted by flying squad officers
fields.trailText: Three men who were serving 10 years for armed robbery had their convictions quashed at the court of appeal yesterday following allegations that corrupt Scotland Yard detectives planted crucial evidence and bragged they "stitched up guys like you all day long."
fields.body:
Three men who were serving 10 years for armed robbery had their convictions quashed at the court of appeal yesterday following allegations that corrupt Scotland Yard detectives planted crucial evidence and bragged they "stitched up guys like you all day long."

Michael Brown, 27, Anthony Taylor, 29 and Kevin Martin, 30, repeatedly denied raiding a jeweller's shop in Edmonton, north London, and stealing gems worth £6,000 after immobilising the owner with a stun gun.

They were convicted in July 1995 after a jury heard that officers from the flying squad found a stun gun in Mr Martin's London flat, and had matched his palm print to one found on the glass counter of the shop.

The case against the three men began to crumble two years ago when a police complaints inquiry into the flying squad uncovered a web of corruption.

Two officers who were instrumental in the jewellery shop investigation, detective constables Terry McGuinness and Kevin Garner, have since been convicted of a series of offences, including aggravated burglary and conspiracy to steal 80kg of cannabis.

McGuinness was jailed for nine years. Garner is awaiting sentence.

The court of appeal heard Garner was the officer who claimed to have found the stun gun in Mr Martin's flat. McGuinness was also there during the search, which took place nine months after the robbery.

Three other officers involved in the investigation are awaiting trial on corruption charges and cannot be named for legal reasons.

When Mr Martin was arrested, he insisted officers had planted the stun gun under a cushion on his sofa. Mr Martin said one of the officers turned to him and boasted he "had stitched up guys like you all day long."

Quashing the convictions, Lord Justice Henry, Mrs Justice Bracewell and Mr Justice Richards, said: "It would be curious if so incriminating an item were to be found so ill concealed by a surprise raid nine months after the alleged use of that weapon."

They noted there was no forensic evidence linking the stun gun to the one used in the robbery.

"In the light of what is now known, the crown prosecution service accepts that the evidence given at the trial, of the search for and discovery of the gun cannot be relied on," their judgment said.

The justices also referred to the "surprising" way detectives managed to match Mr Martin's palm print to one found on the glass counter seven months after the robbery, even though Mr Martin, who lives in south London, had been a suspect for more than six months and his prints were already on police files.

McGuinness, 42, is also alleged to have shown photographs of Mr Taylor, who lives in Hackney, north London, to a witness shortly before an identity parade in April, 1994.

The defendants had a first appeal dismissed in June 1996. But their case was referred back to justices in October last year by the criminal cases review commission following revelations about widespread corruption in the flying squad uncovered in a secret Scotland Yard investigation, codenamed Operation Spain.

McGuinness confessed to a series of charges after a "sting" set up by the Met's anti-corruption branch, CIB3, in December 1997.

CIB officers planted 80 bars of cannabis inside a bathroom cabinet in an east London flat.

After leaking information about the whereabouts of the haul, McGuinness and Garner were filmed stealing the drugs and were arrested. Both men became supergrasses.

webTitle: 'No judge or jury will ever believe those officers fitted you up. You've just got to serve your sentence'

fields.headline: 'No judge or jury will ever believe those officers fitted you up. You've just got to serve your sentence'
fields.body:
'No judge or jury will ever believe those officers fitted you up. You've just got to serve your sentence'

"What's this we've got here?" said Detective Constable Garner, holding up a long black weapon that he appeared to have found on Kevin Martin's sofabed.

"It looks like a stun gun to me," replied DC McGuinness.

"I've never seen that before in my life", yelled Martin. "You're stitching me up."

As a 19-year-old, Martin had carried out a raid on a jeweller's in Dalston, for which he served two years in prison. In the eyes of the police, the conviction made him a significant suspect in the "stun gun" robbery in Edmonton in 1993.

On November 2, he and his girlfriend were woken at 7.30am by bangs, crashes and raised voices. The police had broken down his neighbour's door - they had the wrong flat. Realising the mistake, officers poured into Martin's flat.

His girlfriend screamed that she was seven months pregnant. Martin saw armed officers outside and was warned to keep away from the window. "I turned round, and they were in the bedroom," Martin said.

"Four or five, with others coming in behind. I was very frightened. Then one of them hit me on the face with a blunt object, I never found out what.

"Suddenly, they were raining blows on me. They were telling me to keep calm and hitting me at the same time."

"It was one mad minute that led to seven years of pain for me and my family."

Martin believes the police planted the stun gun while he was being assaulted.

He was handcuffed, his feet were shackled, and he was bundled into a police van. There were two main pieces of evidence against Martin: the stun gun and a palm print from the shop counter that supposedly matched his.

This evidence, only produced seven months after the crime, was suspicious. The first two occasions the prints were sent for analysis the result was negative - it did not match Martin's.

"No one, not the criminal cases review commission, not the court of appeal, has ever been given a satisfactory answer as to why that print finally matched," said Martin.

There was no identification evidence against him. He was never put on an identity parade.

In prison, Martin immediately made a complaint about the police and the following month was visited in Belmarsh, south-east London, by an investigating officer.

"He said to me, 'No judge or jury will ever believe that those officers fitted you up. You've just got to serve your sentence'."

Seven months into Martin's sentence, his younger brother, Jason, committed suicide. The brothers had been close, and Jason had had a breakdown after Kevin's conviction.

In August last year, an officer from CIB3, the anti-corruption branch, told Martin his case was being reinvestigated as part of an inquiry into allegations against the flying squad. He was released on bail, pending appeal, in November last year.

"There's a lot of other guys in prison going through all this who have been fitted up, and no one's listening. I just want this to give all those people hope."

webTitle: Police receive 4,000 calls on missing Sarah

fields.headline: Police receive 4,000 calls on missing Sarah
fields.trailText: Detectives leading the hunt for missing schoolgirl Sarah Payne yesterday received 1,500 calls in two hours as the public response to their request for help reached overwhelming proportions.
fields.body:
Detectives leading the hunt for missing schoolgirl Sarah Payne yesterday received 1,500 calls in two hours as the public response to their request for help reached overwhelming proportions.

As the search for the eight-year-old entered its 12th day, the investigation team of around 300 officers was stretched to the limit as it sifted through the mass of information which flooded into its headquarters in Littlehampton, West Sussex.

Nigel Yeo, assistant chief constable of Sussex, said around 10,000 calls had been received since Sarah vanished from a country lane near her grandparents' house in Kingston, West Sussex, on July 1 - the biggest public response he had seen in his career.

He said 1,500 calls had been received between 7.45am and 9.45am yesterday after a television appearance by the youngster's parents, Sarah and Michael. By the end of the day, more than 4,000 calls had been made.

Mrs Payne, 31, told GMTV the family was trying to cope with the strain by sticking together and holding on to normality as best they could.

The mother of four said: "If any good can come out of something so devastating, it has made us an even stronger family for Sarah to come back to."

Mr and Mrs Payne also appealed to the man seen with a girl at a motorway service station in Cheshire nine hours after their child vanished to come forward.

An e-fit of the man who was seen at the Knutsford service station at 5am on July 2, with a girl called Sarah who fitted the missing youngster's description, prompted hundreds of calls after its release on Tuesday.

Mr Yeo confirmed that 2,864 calls had come in during the 12 hours after distribution of the picture which was described as 90% accurate by the witness involved.

But he added that despite a deluge of calls, double the amount received in the equivalent 12-hour period last week, police had come no further in their endeavours to track down the mystery man.

He said: "At the moment the Knutsford sighting remains the best, the most significant, and that's why we are still working on it.

"The hope has always been, and remains, that if that person is completely coincidental and if that sighting at the motorway service station is not related to this, the person can come forward."

But he added: "The fact that this has not yet happened leads one to draw inferences, but they are only inferences, not concrete evidence."

He made a further appeal for help in tracing the white van seen by Sarah's brother, Lee, 13, just after she disappeared.

webTitle: An era swoons away as Mills and Boon goes photographic

fields.headline: An era swoons away as Mills and Boon goes photographic
fields.trailText: It is curtains - crimson velvet swagged curtains with gold rope tie backs - for the jutting chin and the dimpled cheek.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy,  arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
It is curtains - crimson velvet swagged curtains with gold rope tie backs - for the jutting chin and the dimpled cheek.

The most shattering literary news of the new millennium broke yesterday, the announcement that Mills and Boon is to abandon its cover drawings in favour of "modern imagery which shows empowered women" - ie, cover photographs.

The publishers are ruthlessly turning their backs on a half century in which every conceivable combination was rung on tall, petite, dark, rugged, nubile, slender, gleaming blonde, sultry redhead, silver templed, tousle-headed, broad shouldered and fragile hero and heroine.

The covers promised the happy endings, with the lovers locked in one another's arms - denouements which the reader reached only after tumultuous encounters with spiteful rivals, open heart surgery, tyrannical employers, lost letters or disastrously misinterpreted overheard conversations. Their passion raged, obeying only the rules that moustaches are for villains, beards for deranged artists, women have no body hair except on their heads, and heroes always tower head and shoulders above heroines.

Jo Oliver, spokeswoman for Mills and Boon, said yesterday that the decision was taken afer extensive market research among its women readers, aged between 25 and 60, from all over the UK.

webTitle: Father lands in Tokyo to boost search for daughter

fields.headline: Father lands in Tokyo to boost search for daughter
fields.trailText: The father of Lucie Blackman, the British woman who has been missing in Tokyo for 13 days, flew into Japan yesterday to try to inject fresh life into a search that police acknowledge is making little progress.
fields.body:
The father of Lucie Blackman, the British woman who has been missing in Tokyo for 13 days, flew into Japan yesterday to try to inject fresh life into a search that police acknowledge is making little progress.

"I've come to make sure that everything is being done to find Lucie," Timothy Blackman said on his arrival at Narita airport, Tokyo.

His 21-year-old daughter, from Sevenoaks, Kent, went missing on July 1. According to a friend, she disappeared after going on a date with a customer at the hostess bar where she worked. There have also been reports that she may have been abducted by a religious cult.

The police had adopted a softly-softly approach in their investigation, but Mr Blackman's arrival brought an immediate change of tack.

After a long meeting between the two sides, detectives last night gave their first press conference to the domestic media and began distributing 40,000 leaflets appealing for information. As a result, prime time news stations reported on Ms Blackman's disappearance for the first time.

Police and British consular authorities had earlier advised the Blackman family not to go public for fear that an outcry might prompt an abductor to kill the former British Airways stewardess.

"Usually we prefer not to release information but, taking into account the wishes of the father and other factors, we have decided that it is appropriate on this occasion to open up about the case," said Toshihiko Mii, deputy superintendent of the Azabu police station.

Extra pressure has been put on the police by the presence in Japan of British foreign secretary, Robin Cook, who flew in yesterday for a meeting of diplomats from the group of eight nations.

"We are aware that the disappearance of Miss Blackman will be a subject for discussion at the G8 meeting," Mr Mii said.

"We have got little to go on, but I stress that we are doing all we can to find Lucie." He was unwilling to say how many officers were on the case.

Relations between the Blackman family and the Japanese police have been strained since Sophie Blackman, the 19-year-old younger sister of the missing woman, flew into Japan last week to co-ordinate the search.

Police have complained that Sophie is refusing to answer their questions, while Sophie has expressed frustration at the slow pace of the investigation.

Yesterday's leaflet campaign suggested that Mr Blackman's arrival may have helped mediate a compromise. It will also raise concerns in Tokyo's Roppongi entertainment district, where Miss Blackman was working.

As speculation spreads that she may have been abducted during a date with a client, other bars have issued warnings to their female employees. "I've worked in bars in a lot of countries and always thought that Japan has one of the safest, but now I wonder," said one hostess from the US.

There was also a recognition that double standards were at work in pushing Miss Blackman's case. "I bet lots of bar girls from Thailand and the Philippines are abducted here in Japan, but nobody ever reports those cases," said a hostess from New Zealand.

fields.headline: ETA bombs Madrid
fields.standfirst:
Eight hurt in early morning blast

Bombs in Madrid: special report
fields.trailText: A huge car bomb exploded yesterday in the heart of Madrid's main shopping district, an act that was calculated by the Basque separatist group ETA to show that it has the capacity to cause massive carnage.
fields.body:
A huge car bomb exploded yesterday in the heart of Madrid's main shopping district, an act that was calculated by the Basque separatist group ETA to show that it has the capacity to cause massive carnage.

Because the blast was set off at 6.30am, casualties were restricted to eight injured. But a few hours later, this area would have been packed with local shoppers and tourists.

"ETA knows what it's doing," a police spokesman said. "This was carefully planned and look who the victims have been - some poor down and outs." Two beggars, a policeman and a delivery man were among those hurt.

The explosion was also timed to deliver a political message: the government in Madrid and the Basque regional administration - run by the Basque Nationalist party (PNV), the largest in the region - are working to repair their damaged relations and have announced that they will work more closely to share information on ETA.

The bomb car was parked outside Madrid's emblema tic Puerta del Sol, the equivalent of Piccadilly Circus in London. Metal, glass and debris from adjacent buildings showered through the air.

The police - who got a telephone warning 20 minutes earlier from an anonymous caller claiming to represent ETA - estimate that up to 15kg of explosive was used.

Yesterday's attack took place on the anniversary of a particularly cold-blooded ETA murder in 1997 of a young local councillor representing the government's centre-right People's party in the Basque country. He was kidnapped then killed. The death brought millions of Spaniards on to the streets demanding an end to terror.

Seeing itself so disdained, ETA made an alliance with the non-violent PNV.

But the initiative was short-lived. ETA has killed five people so far this year and stepped up threats and extortion against Basque businessmen, put bombs outside newspaper offices and sent several in parcels to journalists.

webTitle: Israel jails hero of poor for bribery

fields.headline: Israel jails hero of poor for bribery
fields.standfirst: Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: Amid blasts from a long, curving ram's horn, and screams of anguish from hundreds of black-clad protesters, the Israeli supreme court yesterday jailed for three years a charismatic rabbi who rose like a rocket through Israeli politics.
fields.body:
Amid blasts from a long, curving ram's horn, and screams of anguish from hundreds of black-clad protesters, the Israeli supreme court yesterday jailed for three years a charismatic rabbi who rose like a rocket through Israeli politics.

The decision to uphold the bribery conviction of the former interior minister Arieh Deri, seen as a demi-god by supporters of Shas, the Jews of Middle Eastern origin who are the have-nots of Israeli society, was immediately denounced as racist by supporters besieging the court.

Deri will go to jail on August 13 for bribery and fraud. However, the court did reduce his original jail term by a year, finding the bearded talmudic scholar had embezzled less money than previously thought; it ruled he had taken $60,000 (£40,000) in bribes, pocketing some of the money and diverting the rest towards local Shas projects.

Although Deri has been under a shadow for 10 years, when investigations into his tenure at the ministry began, that has not dented his reputation among Shas followers. While they were forced yesterday to concede his guilt, they said he was too great a man to be sent to prison.

"There is no justice in the state of Israel," Deri's brother, Yehuda, told anguished supporters on the steps of the courthouse. "We do not accept this verdict, it is simply hot air."

But Deri, who is also banned from politics for 10 years after his release, said he accepted the court's decision - with love - and that he saw it as a trial from the almighty. "God willing, my mission is to go to jail. I will go and I will do so happily."

Until Deri's original conviction 15 months ago, he was the leader of the Shas party, the second largest in the coalition government of Prime Minister Ehud Barak, until it quit last week. Deri's supporters, who scuffled with police before pouring out into the streets in angry tears, claim the verdict was meant to clip Shas's wings, and is another sign of the discrimination they suffer at the hands of Israel's largely European elite.

fields.headline: The price is right
fields.standfirst: Which of these pop stars will have a top 10 hit in 2010?
fields.trailText: Which of these pop stars will have a top 10 hit in 2010?
fields.body:
Geri Halliwell 3/1

Radiohead 4/1

Kylie Minogue 20/1

An Elvis impersonator 33/1

"Pop is supposed to be fickle," says Ed Nicholson, Ladbrokes' entertainment odds compiler, "but pop stars of today seem to have more longevity than ever before."

Who would have thought that Bruce Springsteen - old in the 80s - would be wrapping up another mammoth 14-month world tour? Or that Tina Turner would eventually retire after 44 years in the business. Whether rolling into rehab like Ronnie Wood or enjoying a new career, like Joni Mitchell opening an art show, it just goes to show that a shooting star doesn't always have to fall.

But in the current army of trend-setters, which ones will last the distance? "Geri Halliwell could become the 21st-century answer to Madonna," says Ed. "She's already changed her image to get the hits, and you can see her being around for a long, long time. She craves attention like a fish needs water."

Since being dumped by her record label, Kylie Minogue has made a fantastic comeback, achieving her first number one in a decade with Spinning Around. "She's back on the up, but can she last another 10 years in the dog-eat-dog world of pop?" Ed asks. "I think it's more likely she'll be writing an entertainment piece for a tabloid newspaper - you know what they say, better the devil you know!"

And at the other end of the scale, darkly popular band Radiohead is heading towards that tricky third album. But with early reports being positive, Ed reckons the Oxford boys are in with a good chance. "They're close school buddies, always a good sign. And each of their albums has developed a new sound, which keeps the band fresh.

"They say there are no certainties in life, but I think I've found one. Elvis impersonators will be around in 2010 without a shadow of a doubt," says Ed. After all, the Naked Chef just had one at his wedding. "But I doubt that one will have a top 10 hit."

fields.headline: Smoke rings can kill
fields.standfirst: David Hambling  on a natural phenomenon with potentially devastating power
fields.trailText: David Hambling on a natural phenomenon with potentially devastating power
fields.body:
A white disc rose into the Sicilian sky, leaving a faint vapour trail. It took me a minute to realise that this strange object was a puff of steam from Mount Etna.

But while the rest of the volcano's exhaust was blown away on the wind, how did it retain its shape and carry on along the same course? Through binoculars I saw the disc was a gigantic smoke ring more than 100 metres in diameter. Etna has been known to emit 50 of them a day from a crater called Bocca Nuova, forming what physicists call a vortex ring. They occur in many places in nature and have some curious properties, which scientists are finding ways to exploit.

The principle of a vortex ring is simple enough. A vortex is a swirling motion, like a tornado or a whirlpool. Curve it around so that the top and bottom meet in a doughnut shape and you have a vortex ring. They can be formed by turbulent flow in liquids and gases. Miniature vortex rings occur in blood in the chambers of the pumping heart; huge ones occur in the atmosphere as thermals, where masses of warm air rise and cooler air is sucked in below. Baby dolphins project vortex rings from their blowholes for fun, nudging them around like toy haloes.

The rings of gas and steam of Mount Etna last for up to 10 minutes, rising thousands of feet into the air. This stability is partly because of momentum (once something starts spinning, it tends to continue), and partly because of density. Centrifugal force will tend to pull the ring apart, but a ring which is less dense than its surroundings, such as a ring of warm smoke in air, will stay together. A vortex ring will even survive an impact with a hard surface, bouncing off like a rubber ball and keeping its coherence. This stability has attracted researchers at the Naval Air Station, Point Mugu, in California, who have patented some ingenious inventions for civilian life.

One of the simplest ideas is for an inhaler. Instead of spraying the vaporised medicine into the mouth, where there is the risk that it will get no further than the trachea, a dispenser will blow a series of tiny vapour rings. These ricochet down through the airways and find their way into the lungs where they deliver the medicated vapour to where it is most effective.

A similar principle is applied in the patent for a device for firefighting in confined spaces. A large projector will fire rings of carbon dioxide or halon gas through air ducts to douse the fire.

A more imaginative, though perhaps less plausible, vortex ring projector is intended for law enforcement. The device would be mounted on a police helicopter which would swoop down on cars in high speed chases. The projector launches rings of carbon dioxide at the fleeing car, upsetting the air/fuel mixture ratio in the engine, causing it to lose power and come to a gradual halt. Whether this could be made to work in practice has yet to be proved.

Vortex rings have other aerodynamic quirks. A faster smoke ring will overtake a slower one by going through the middle, leaving both intact. If several vortex rings are moving one after the other at the same speed, they interact, moving together as a train faster than one ring alone. Under normal conditions this is hardly noticeable, but at high speeds it can make a big difference. The exhaust from a jet engine will be faster if it takes the form of a series of vortex rings; and a faster exhaust means greater thrust.

There are signs that a top-secret, supersonic aircraft using this technology may already be flying. Residents of different parts of the US have reported hearing a series of pulsing booms from an aircraft which left a distinctive contrail described as "doughnuts on a rope".

In the 1940s there were toy "air ray pistols" which could launch an air ring to knock over a paper target at a range of several feet. Water is a thousand times more dense than air, and a ring vortex in water could carry that much more force. This has led to a US Navy proposal for a "directed energy obstacle clearing device utilising cavitating vortex rings".

This giant underwater version of the air ray pistol, which sends an explosively formed vortex ring barrelling through the sea, tearing apart everything in its path with the full force of the explosion, leaving a trail of shredded seaweed and stunned fish.

It may sound like an unlikely B-movie creation - The Killer Doughnut From 20,000 Fathoms. But although we may be used to thinking of smoke rings as indoor toys, the pictures from Mount Etna shows that they can grow into monsters.

webTitle: You've got a lot to answer for, Charlie Darwin

fields.headline: You've got a lot to answer for, Charlie Darwin
fields.standfirst: Is psychology frozen in the Pleistocene era?  Hilary  and  Steven Rose  are sure it must have evolved since then
fields.trailText: Is psychology frozen in the Pleistocene era? Hilary and Steven Rose are sure it must have evolved since then
fields.body:
In the spring of last year, several contributors to our new book, Alas, Poor Darwin, hired a boat, appropriately called the Beagle, and took off round the Pacific islands Darwin made famous: the Galapagos.

The richness and diversity of the plant, animal and bird life on these volcanic outcrops fascinated him, and he was later able to identify among his collection 12 distinct species of finches, each with slightly different beaks and feeding habits, from cactus eaters to insectivores.

They must, he argued, have been derived from a common ancestor blown over from the mainland, and the different forms later diverged on their separate islands. Hence the evolution of species.

On the boat we debated the mechanisms and processes involved, informed by modern studies of the changing distribution of beak sizes as finch populations responded to years of drought or downpour.

Yet superb as such microevolutionary studies of Darwin's finches are, we chewed over how far they could cast light on major evolutionary transitions. The gap between evidence and theory on geological time scales is hard to bridge. Could the study of three decades of finch beaks inevitably lead to a theory of evolution as gradualist and continuous?

How different such meticulous research was, we reflected, from the speculations of those self-styled Darwinians who have grouped themselves under the banner of evolutionary psychology (EP) and whose claims our book is intended to counter.

EP's central thesis, stated in a score of popular books, newspaper articles and television spectaculars is that there is a "universal human nature" which "we" all recognise when "we" see it. That there is immense diversity as well as commonality in what another "we" sees is brushed to one side. This "nature", they argue, was established by evolution and natural selection during the Pleistocene epoch and has remained unchanged ever since, despite dramatic changes in the organisation of human society and lives - to say nothing of climate.

But if birds' beaks can change within 30 years across a few generations, why not humans over the 100-600,000 years since the Pleistocene? Evolutionary psychology persists in misreading Darwin's central project, that was to explain the transmutation of species, and hence change over time. Its followers are preoccupied with stasis.

There are, they say, universal mental "modules" for cheat detection, recognition and the sexual preferences of older men for younger women and young women for rich old men which persist as adaptations to the Pleistocene ecological niche - their so- called Environment of Evolutionary Adaptation. The fact that even their own texts report contradictory evidence - for example, research indicating that where women have independent access to resources, they no longer go for rich old men - does not dismay them.

Here EP is much closer to Herbert Spencer's social Darwinism - the insistence on the natural "struggle red in tooth and claw" as providing an explanation of the social hierarchy of the Victorian Empire. Neither Spencer nor the EPers have change over time at the core of their theory. This omission ensures that EP fails to address the important task it sets itself.

Take the claims that the expression of the emotions - of anger, happiness or misery - are the same the world over. Darwin's original evidence in his book The Expressions Of The Emotions In Animal And Man was based on his finding that photographs of ham actors expressing these emotions were accurately identified by many people in different countries.

EPers build this speculation into a case of biologically fixed human universals. Potential facial manoeuvres are constrained by muscle, bone and nerve. So a smile is a smile is a smile - or is it merely an actor's rictus? What exactly is expressed by those photos in Hello! magazine of society beauties with their fixed smiles showing flawless teeth - but often ice-cold eyes? Genuine happiness? Posing for the photographer? The power of wealth?

And what are the many meanings read into those smiles by us, the knowing viewers? These are not innocent expressions of pure biology, but the contruction of meaning out of the complexity of our biosocial existence.

How about the poker faces of those who will not smile, or the sycophantic smiles of inferiors at superiors' jokes? And of course social scientists have been telling us for years about smiling as compulsory gender performance - notably by air stewardesses.

Bringing gender analyses from the social sciences together with meticulous biological observation and experimentation is mutually enriching. Each discourse challenges and informs the other.

As a sociologist and biologist living and working together we have enjoyed many hours of such debate. Yet this truly interdisciplinary research is precisely what EP denies in its insistence on the subordinate and colonised status of the social sciences. Both evolutionary theory and human psychology have been hijacked.

Alas, Poor Darwin, the product of discussions between 15 philosophers, cultural critics, social scientists, ethologists and molecular biologists, is a step towards rescuing this interdisciplinary goal from the populist claims of biology as destiny. It will not get an easy ride, for EP is vociferous and well entrenched, and its claims are glib and attractive. Ultimately the only way to drive out bad theory is to replace it with better. This is the task we have set ourselves.

 Alas, Poor Darwin: Arguments Against Evolutionary Psychology, ed. Hilary & Steven Rose, is published by Cape.

fields.headline: Waiting for God
fields.standfirst: Last night's TV:  Nancy Banks-Smith
fields.trailText: Cons/ Coronation Street/Emmerdale
fields.body:
When a man who is going to the electric chair talks to you for an hour wearing a baseball cap with Job 13:15 on it, it gnaws away at the back of your brain.

Job. Job. How are you on Job?

Cons (Sky 1), produced and directed by Douglas Chirnside, was a strikingly good and goose-pimpling documentary. I suspect it was made on a quarter of a BBC budget - which sometimes leads, as it did here, to a bleak, bare beauty.

The dark star of the first programme was Philip Workman, who has been on death row for 19 years and, all appeals exhausted, was to go to the electric chair.

"This chair was refurbished when we opened in 1989", said Pam Ryan, composedly strapping herself in. She is a prison administration assistant; I never met a more down-to-earth young woman in my life. Her self-possession was so absolute, I found myself hypnotised by the false fingernails clicking home the buckles, as if they might offer some clue to such composure.

She demonstrated the cable which bubbles the brain ("This will hook to the headgear and carry the current.") She explained the perforated seat ("When they pass, they lose control of their body functions. ... There'll be a tray under here so there'll not be a lot of mess to clean up afterwards.") She pulled the lever on the control board with its bizarre safety warnings ("Never work when alone or tired.") She put her long, white, ghostly nail on the button ("It goes in two cycles, 15 seconds and another 15 seconds. But it does it automatically, you just push the button once.")

There are, in fact, two buttons. If two people push together, only the computer knows which one killed the man in the electric chair.

Workman called it the most premeditated form of murder there is. He kept remembering the Beatles song "Help! I need somebody", and laughed a little. Riverbend Maximum Security Institution is near Nashville; you feel there should be a country and western song about the first man to die in Tennessee for 40 years. He was calm and fluent like a big river. All Americans seem created equally articulate. I always feel this must make life a breeze for American journalists, but no journalist seemed interested in Workman. Perhaps it had gone on too long.

He said "It's a nightmare. A daily, weekly, monthly, yearly threat. You can only threaten somebody so long with something and they're going to stay scared of it. Sooner or later that person's going to come to an acceptance within themselves - be it religion or just hardness of heart - and say 'If that's what you're gonna do, then do it.'"

There will be an audience. The warden said that the sheriff, a minister of religion and the families of both the victim and the condemned man would be invited. The nameplate on his desk said, informally, that his name was Ricky Bell.

Philip expected his daughter to be there. She was eight when, high on drugs, he was arrested for killing a policeman in an armed robbery. "I didn't have any business being married, let alone having a child. I told my wife 'Divorce me. Your life goes on and mine's coming to an end.'" She did divorce him but the child clung. "She refuses to believe it and I let her to a certain extent because I feel it helps her. She'll be here. Of course, I'd rather she'd not, but I know she will and there'll be people to comfort her." For the first time his voice shook. The dead policeman's daughter has begged for clemency.

Thirty-six hours before his execution, Tennessee judges voted to reconsider his case. Ballistic evidence suggested that, in the shoot-out, the policeman may have died from a police bullet.

Oh, Job? He said "Though He slay me, yet will I trust in Him."

Half Coronation Street (ITV) are on holiday in Blackpool. As half The Archers are arriving for their annual coach trip, I await the collision eagerly. Sid and Jolene should wipe the floor with Norris and Vera in the Henley's Double Glazing Rumba Cup. Though every second word Norris utters seems an unfortunate double entendre ("I've got a banana in me bag if me blood sugar droops" and "I've had something out") he cannot match Sid's pelvic thrust on the floor.

As Bernice said last night in Emmerdale (ITV) before proposing to the vicar: "I never thought such things took place in country villages." Oh, really?
