fields.headline: Science update
fields.trailText: >Core! What a scorcher! | Storming in to the rescue
fields.body:
Core! What a scorcher!

Britain's most powerful computer has calculated what the temperature is at the centre of the earth - with a little help from professors David Price and Mike Gillian from University College London. Naturally, no one has been down there to look, but the professors reckon that it's 5,500C, as hot as the surface of the sun. They believe the core is composed of liquid iron, and using the supercomputer, they determined that the pressure required to melt iron is in excess of three million times the pressure on earth's surface.

Storming in to the rescue

The movie The Perfect Storm features George Clooney battling against one of the century's fiercest storms. In the future, ships like the Andrea Gail may be given far more accurate advice about the weather at sea. The Harvard Ocean Prediction System (HOPS) has been developed by Professor Allan Robinson of the Office of Naval Research in America to predict oceanic weather, as well as providing information about ocean creatures from whales to algae. "We assimilate yesterday's data into today's forecast of tomorrow's weather," says Allen. So far HOPS has been used to predict where debris from the EgyptAir flight 990 would wash up, and in a naval war game to detect enemy subs hiding in the Gulf Stream.

Magic pill for plants

Aspirin, one of the best remedies for the morning after the night before, is now helping rid plants of pests. Salicylic acid, one of the main ingredients of aspirin, occurs naturally in plants, as part of their natural immune system.But a team led by Dr Marianne Verbene, from Leiden University in the Netherlands, genetically manipulated tobacco plants to produce vast amounts of the chemical. These genes are responsible for the creation of enzymes which are themselves involved in salicylic acid production. The manipulated plants had 500-1,000 times as much acid as normal plants and elevated resistance to tobacco mosaic virus and a mildew-causing fungus. (Source: Nature Biotechnology.)

fields.headline: Spot the difference
fields.standfirst: Humans and fruit flies have more in common than you'd think.  Henry Gee  on the gene sequence that binds them together
fields.trailText: Humans and fruit flies have more in common than you'd think. Henry Gee on the gene sequence that binds them together
fields.body:
The complete sequence of the human genome may be the crowning achievement of the 20th century, but the real work of understanding how all these genes work together to create a living, breathing organism is only just starting. In a report in today's Nature, George von Dassow and colleagues from the University of Washington in Seattle present a remarkable essay in simulating the activities of networks of genes as a logical system in a computer - genes in silicon.

The aim is to piece together decades of experimental work into a network representing how genes (and their protein products) interact to create biological structures. This would give an overall understanding of how genes work as a single, dynamic system, something greater than the sum of its individual genetic parts.

As pioneer complexity theorist Stuart Kauffman explains in the July 2000 issue of Scientific American, the future of biology will rest on thinking of organisms as "emergent properties" of genomes: the products not so much of genes, as of their myriad interactions. But as von Dassow and colleagues ruefully admit, their first essays in modelling nature were a dismal failure.

This failure, however, led to eventual success and a deeper understanding of genomic interaction.

Some might say that the goal of modelling genomic interactions is impossible. Why? Because computer scientists appreciate what molecular biologists have yet to grasp: how hard it is to model the interaction of even a small number of elements in a network. Working out the interactions between each of the approximately 50,000 human genes is an unfeasibly large problem. Even if each gene could occupy just two states - "on" or "'off" - the number of possible states would exceed by several orders of magnitude the number of particles in the universe.

Happily, some biologists have suspected that genes may operate not on a homogeneous, genome-wide scale, but as local consortia whose members look inwards, interacting more strongly with one another than with genes outside. This is the so-called "modular" approach to biology, and it has the benefit of reducing a miraculously hard problem into one that is merely migraine-inducing.

One of these "modules" is the network of genes that creates the body segments of flies such as the fruit fly, Drosophila. These genes have picturesque names such as wingless, hedgehog, patched and cubitus interruptus. (Geneticists are clearly enjoying themselves. The Guardian reader's favourite gene ought to be radical fringe.) Significantly, this same, small group of about five genes creates segments in grasshoppers, beetles and other insects - even though these animals develop in different ways from that of the fly.

This same segmentation "module" also creates segment-like structures in the brains of vertebrates such as you and me. The segmentation module, then, has been conserved in evolution. In network-speak, it is "robust" against external perturbation.

Even though the segmentation module is small and relatively well known, turning it into a mathematical model was far from trivial. Even a dramatically simplified expression of the segmentation module required 136 equations and 50 free parameters - things such as the rates at which protein products of genes diffused across cells, the strengths with which they bond to each other, and so on. To make matters worse, almost nothing is known about these biochemical nuances.

To sidestep this problem, the researchers asked a simple question: what range of parameter values, real-life or not, creates a pattern that looks plausibly like segmentation? Intuition told them that the segmentation module was a delicate structure, and that each parameter (strength of diffusion, binding, and so on for each protein) would work only within a very narrow range.

What they did not expect was that the model would not work at all.

Picking themselves up from this setback, they looked critically at the network and found that it was simply not capable of generating segmentation, by virtue of the way it was connected.

To make the network function at all, at least two more connections were logically required, representing biological interactions of which experimenters were only dimly aware. (One example was a link in which the protein product of the wingless gene regulated the action of the wingless gene itself, in a feedback loop.)

Von Dassow and colleagues added the necessary fudges, and - kerpow! - the network produced segmentation all over the place. Segmentation just fell out of the network, even if parameters were varied over many orders of magnitude. It was as if the network couldn't help itself. Almost irrespective of the behaviour of any one of its members, the network produced segmentation as a consequence of being connected.

This result has three implications. The first is predictive power. Looked at positively, the fudge factors that the researchers introduced were necessary to get the network to behave in a realistic, lifelike way. In an important sense, the model predicted the existence of these necessary interactions, in the same way that particle physicists use theory to predict the existence of particles. This will force an entirely new way of thinking in molecular biology.

The second is robustness. Almost irrespective of individual parameter values, the module as a whole produced segments. This explains why the segmentation module can be recognised as a distinct and discrete entity in animals as diverse as flies and people, which have otherwise very different developmental "logic circuits".

The third is emergence. From the raw sequence of wingless, patched and so on, you could never tell that the outcome of their interaction would be a robust module whose almost inevitable product was segmentation. This confirms the Kauffman view of life: that the whole is very much greater than the sum of the parts.

The human genome project may seem like a milestone, but it barely counts as the warm-up. Game on.

 Henry Gee is a senior editor of Nature magazine. His book, Deep Time: Cladistics, the Revolution in Evolution, is published by Fourth Estate.

Niagara

(Henry Hathaway, 1953)

4pm, Sky Cinema

Hathaway uses Niagara Falls here the way Hitchcock used Mount Rushmore in North By Northwest, turning the tourist resort into a colourful, ironic backdrop for black deeds. The camera lingers too on the form of Marilyn Monroe, a floozy who, with young stud Richard Allan, plots to murder her husband, disturbed Korean war veteran Joseph Cotten; the whole sordid business witnessed by two horrified newlyweds. Hitch would have played it for laughs; this is a little overwrought, but steamy enough.

Lethal Weapon 4

(Richard Donner, 1997)

8pm, Sky Premier

Yes, the odd-couple cops routine is pretty stale, but the ever-efficient Donner is still at the helm this fourth time around, injecting real punch into the frequent action scenes. And the friendship between Mel Gibson's mad Riggs - now about to become a dad - and Danny Glover's family man Murtaugh remains sparky and engaging. And there's a hell of a good baddy in Jet Li's Triad boss-cum-martial arts master.

My Name Is Joe

(Ken Loach, 1998)

10pm, FilmFour

Loach's romance between the unemployed, alcohol-dependent Joe (Peter Mullan, pictured) and middle-class social worker Sarah (Louise Goodall) beautifully points up social rifts in 90s Britain. Joe is getting by, coaching a local football team, but has to take another job - running drugs - to help heroin addict Liam (David McKay), and suddenly his relationship with Sarah is endangered. Perceptive, tender and funny.

Mute Witness

(Anthony Waller, 1995)

3.45am, FilmFour

A wrenching opening half-hour has a mute American woman (Marina Sudina) running for her life from Russian gangsters in Moscow. She's one of a trio of visitors making a cheap horror film there, and has stumbled on real-life horror: the making of a snuff movie. After the bravura start, this settles into less breathtaking routines; but it's well-made, despite the dodgy script, and there's a surprising appearance from Alec Guinness as a low-key Mr Big.

webTitle: Straw shrugs off 'barking' critics of rights law

fields.headline: Straw shrugs off 'barking' critics of rights law
fields.standfirst: Home secretary insists incorporation of European convention later this year will not affect time honoured British public school practices
fields.trailText: Jack Straw has rounded on "green ink brigade" critics of the government's new human rights legislation, describing them as "completely barking" for claiming that the new law will mean public school heads could be sued for banning gay sex.
fields.body:
Jack Straw has rounded on "green ink brigade" critics of the government's new human rights legislation, describing them as "completely barking" for claiming that the new law will mean public school heads could be sued for banning gay sex.

The home secretary, in an interview with the Guardian, said it was nonsense for critics to claim that the incorporation of the European convention on human rights into British law from October 2 will lead to the outlawing of such eccentric English practices as public school "fagging" or forcing pupils to take early morning runs followed by cold showers.

Ministers are confident that the courts will not buckle under a deluge of cases after the Human Rights Act comes into force in October and that judges and magistrates will use their new powers wisely. The legislation will mean that in future British citizens will not have to go Strasbourg and wait five years at an average cost of £30,000 a time to take out a human rights case under the convention.

Instead redress will be available in British courts. Mr Straw said there were still some Tory MPs who fervently believed incorporation of the European convention was a plot by the European central bank to foist the euro on Britain by the back door of a court judgment: "There are some people on the Tory benches who when you say 'Europe', they bark." He was pleased to see that the Tory front bench was now citing the convention in aid of foxhunting and arguing for a human rights case to be mounted to challenge any forthcoming government ban.

Complain

The home secretary said the "green ink brigade" had already started to complain to the Home Office about the alleged impact of the human rights legislation: "We had a bloke who wrote in to say that his local authority's requirement that he put his wheelie bin out was in breach of one of the articles of the convention.

"I had another one, which now enjoys some fame inside the Home Office, when I discovered, by complete chance, that a proposed bylaw banning drinking in the street was turned down on the grounds that it was against an article of the convention about the right to property. Well, that particular article is about not allowing nationalisation without compensation and things like that, and not about cans of Tennants lager being chucked in the bin.

"The other point made by the green ink brigade is that it will force headteachers to ban gay sex amongst their pupils. Well, gay sex amongst minors is illegal anyway. It is an off the wall idea. Public school heads are in loco parentis and have a duty to stop their charges committing criminal offences. It is completely barking." If the practice of fagging remains in any British public school it too will be safe in Jack Straw's hands: "There is something called the margin of appreciation which gives the benefit of the doubt for the particular culture of the country involved in the case.

"Because we have not processed the law within our own domestic courts up to now it has been quite difficult for us but I think the European court on human rights at Strasbourg would regard fagging and cold showers as a piece of English eccentricity which if people want to go in for then it is up to them."

Missed out

Mr Straw says the serious point is that in the past Britain has missed out as one of the few countries which has not incorporated the convention into its domestic law by not contributing to the development of Strasbourg case law: "This is one reason why we have been overturned more frequently than many comparable countries in Strasbourg. We have not had the full benefit of the margin of appreciation." He says that the experience in Scotland, where incorporation has already taken place, is evidence that the courts are not run by the green ink brigade: "There have been 900 challenges in Scotland and 98% of them have failed."

He believes that the sky will not fall in on the English courts. If anything Scots law is more vulnerable to challenge under the European human rights convention as it is much more based on common law practices than English law which relies more heavily on statutes.

Complied

The home secretary believes that the scale of change involved is less of a judicial Everest and more of a "relatively small English hillock" as Edward Garnier, the shadow attorney general, has put it.

England is a "rule conscious society" and many public authorities have for many years complied with the rights in the convention. Mr Straw says the European convention has been crucial in ensuring that there is a greater degree of justice for people - particularly unpopular people - available in the courts and that the secret state has been subject to proper regulation. He is convinced that the Thatcher government would not have put the security services or phonetapping on a statutory basis in the 1980s if it had not been for a series of Strasbourg court judgments against Britain.

But what about his own legislation? Would Mr Straw insisted that football hooligans banned from leaving Britain on the suspicion of a police officer had to be brought before a magistrates' court within 24 hours if it had not been for the convention? "I think I would have done it anyway. The fact that we are subject to the convention is a very important check on arbitrary powers. That is a good thing. The thing to remember is that it is the same Jack Straw who is introducing the human rights act and who is introducing the football bill. It neatly illustrates the government's approach to about providing rights and making sure they are balanced by responsibilities."

fields.headline: Yesterday bad day
fields.trailText: Website of the day
fields.body:
Website of the day

A Scottish speculator has failed to find a buyer for the internet address www.williamhague.co.uk after asking a reserve auction price of just £100 for it. But the Conservatives should beware. Someone has already registered the alternative www.williamhague.com. Visitors to the site are greeted by a picture of the opposition leader with the caption: "I wonder if I'll ever be PM." The picture then disappears and is replaced with a picture of Michael Portillo and the caption "No chance."

Match of the day

Defence secretary Geoff Hoon opened a military sports centre in Aldershot and decided to play a leisurely game of squash. Unfortunately his opponent turned out to be 17-year old army champion, private Alex Smith, and Mr Hoon was trounced. He gasped: "I thought I would be set up against the local MP."

Today

Commons: Opposition debate on "relationship between parliament and the executive", led by William Hague and Tony Blair. Football (disorder) bill, second reading. Lords: TV licences (disclosure of information) bill,report. Regulation of investigatory powers bill, report.

webTitle: Novelist Lessing likens 'philistine' Blair to Mugabe

fields.headline: Novelist Lessing likens 'philistine' Blair to Mugabe
fields.trailText: The veteran novelist Doris Lessing yesterday joined the literary assault on the "philistinism" of the prime minister by comparing him to Robert Mugabe.
fields.body:
The veteran novelist Doris Lessing yesterday joined the literary assault on the "philistinism" of the prime minister by comparing him to Robert Mugabe.

Lessing, 80, the writer of the Good Terrorist and The Golden Notebook, claimed Tony Blair and New Labour played the "class card" by bashing so-called cultural elites every time it got in trouble in the same way the Zimbabwean prime minister played the race card.

The criticism, from a woman who was made a Companion of Honour by Labour, is if anything more wounding than the blistering attack on Mr Blair and his methods by the novelist VS Naipaul earlier this week, who accused him of being a pirate at the head of a socialist revolution which is "destroying the idea of civilisation in this country".

Naipaul, 68, who has made no secret of his distaste for what he sees as a trend for dumbing down in public life, said: "Every day you hear on the radio some minister from this appalling government saying something about things no longer being for the privileged few ... It is terrible, this plebeian culture that celebrates itself for being plebeian."

Although Lessing distanced herself from Naipaul's wilder comments, she told Radio 4's Today programme that she too was alarmed by this "very philistine" government's tendency to rubbish high culture. However, she believes the real damage to the arts, libraries and universities was done under the Thatcher governments.

Their worries echo the dogged criticism of government arts policy from the theatre director Sir Peter Hall, who formed a shadow arts council two years ago to monitor New Labour's "hollow anti-elitism for the sake of it". Although this has since petered out, the resentment in some quarters which it represented has not. Only this week there was disquiet about the composition of London mayor Ken Livingstone's new cultural strategy group, which although it contains a magician, had no room for a representative of "serious music and opera".

The arts minister, Alan Howarth, strongly rejected the claims of philistinism and said both Lessing and Naipaul were confused about the nature of the government's anti-elitism. "It is surprising that such a distinguished man of letters as VS Naipaul should fall into that trap. This government is unapologetically elitist in the sense of supporting cultural excellence. Equally, we are unapologetically anti-elitist in our commitment to create opportunities, to widen access to the widest range of people to enjoy cultural excellence."

He claimed there was an "element of ritual" in Hall's denunciations. "We usually get this sometime around the time of the summer solstice."

He said the arts had got their best-ever funding settlement in the last spending review.

fields.headline: Community spirits
fields.standfirst: Once excluded from Brazil's carnivals, the Afro-Brazilian troupe Ile Aiye has become their focus. Now it is coming to London. By  Mark  Espiner
fields.trailText: Once excluded from Brazil's carnivals, the Afro-Brazilian troupe Ile Aiye has become their focus. Now it is coming to London. By Mark Espiner
fields.body:
"This area is called Pelourinho. It's Portuguese for whipping post. They used to whip slaves publicly here." The taxi judders along cobbled streets lined with crumbling colonial buildings as Rita Santos takes me through Salvador, Brazil's former capital and one-time centre of its slave trade. Brazil did not abolish slavery until 1888. "The population of Salvador is 80% black, and Brazil is 50% black," Santos continues, "and although people don't admit it, there is still a great deal of racism. That's why Ile Aiye was set up exclusively for black people."

Ile Aiye - "It means house life," says Santos - is the black-power Afro-Brazilian bloco (organised carnival troupe) that each year takes part in the city's carnival procession in March. The blocos that parade through Salvador's streets used to exclude black people. While white bloco members danced behind the large trucks carrying the bands, black people worked as security, separating bloco members from non-bloco members who had not paid to be in the troupe and could only watch from the sidelines or follow at a distance.

This manifestation of racism prompted Antonio Carlos dos Santos to set up Ile Aiye in 1974. He made the strong proviso that the participation of whites was to be forbidden. His move sparked accusations of apartheid, but 100 black people joined the procession in 1975; the next year this figure rose to 450, and the following year they numbered 750. Now 3,000 or more join the carnival parade.

Ile Aiye is for many the highlight of carnival. Its beauty has been celebrated by the best in Brazilian music and song: Caetano Veloso has sung "Ile Aiye/What wonderful beauty to behold", while Virginia Rodrigues's lyrics - "Kiss me, possess me, but let me go when Ile passes/I want to see Ile Aiye pass" - speak volumes for the theatrical power the bloco possesses.

It has become much more than a carnival troupe. Ile Aiye has developed into an organisation that promotes Afro-Brazilian and black culture: it has established a percussion school, a primary school, a football team and a textile production line to manufacture the brightly coloured carnival costumes.

Ile Aiye puts the Candomble religion - brought to Brazil by African slaves who mixed their Yoruba roots with Roman Catholicism - at the centre of its spiritual and musical identity. The rhythms played in a Candomble ceremony to the religion's saints (orixás) were fused with samba patterns to produce what is called the Ijexa style of percussion and music, now copied throughout Brazil.

Our taxi pulls up at the Fort of Santo Antonio, where a competition is being held to choose the song that Ile Aiye will perform at the next carnival. Santos's cousin, Vania Marao, is taking part. On a makeshift stage in the courtyard, above a huge drum orchestra, competitor after competitor steps up to sing their songs - first solo and then with a drum accompaniment. Some are lyrical celebrations of Ile Aiye; others energetic songs about black figures from Brazil's history, including Zumbi - leader of the slaves' revolt.

The sound is huge, the voices powerful. The drummers stand swinging to their beats, drums slung around their waists. The atmosphere is intoxicating, the sound awesome - and this is only a rehearsal. There's a party spirit that erupts when the judges announce the winner - who sees his victory as an opportunity to sing his song again and again.

Santos shrugs and commiserates with Marao. Neither of them seems too upset by her losing, though. It is clearly the music of the moment that matters, the community, the celebration and the support. For Ile Aiye is now far more than music - it's a way of life. "Just wait till carnival," says Marao. "It is going to be beautiful. Ile Aiye will be the best."

Ile Aiye's touring group performs at the Barbican, London EC2 (020-7638 8891), on Sunday.

fields.headline: I was a Tokyo hostess
fields.standfirst: A British woman has been abducted from a hostess club in Japan.  Sally James has also worked in one and wouldn't recommend the experience
fields.trailText: A British woman has been abducted from a hostess club in Japan.  Sally James has also worked in one and wouldn't recommend the experience
fields.body:
It was 1992 and south-east Asia was full of western travellers either "finding themselves", or fed up with their lives in their home countries. Everyone seemed to follow the same route, the Philippines, Thailand, Hong Kong, China, India. I was working as a waitress in Hong Kong when a sister of a friend arrived full of tales of Japan and how easy it was to make lots of money there.

I'd been travelling for a year with my friend Kirsty and though we'd been working we hadn't saved much money. We wanted to continue travelling and this seemed the ideal way. "It's the same as working in a bar," she told us. "It's a laugh and you get paid £20 an hour." Our guide book described hostessing as "psychological prostitution" but to our 22-year-old eyes it all seemed like a great adventure.

We arrived in Tokyo on a rainy May morning, with no warm clothes and not much money. We got a room in a Gaijin house (a hostel for foreigners) just outside Tokyo and almost at once set about finding work. The house was full of other travellers with a mix of occupations. There were teachers, hostesses, waiters, models and even the odd divine healer. No one was very friendly and when we approached the other girls about working in hostess bars they were very hostile and protective of their clubs. Another girl from London took pity on us and gave us a list of places to try, with a warning not to go to her club because they weren't looking for any new faces.

We set off that night, dressed to the nines, wearing more make-up than we'd ever worn before and feeling rather foolish. The clubs ranged from small spaces that looked like your grandmother's living room to large, flashy discotheques. You were asked three questions: your name, your age and your nationality. The rest of the interview consisted of someone sizing you up.

We eventually found jobs on the third night and were asked to start immediately. Hostessing in Japan is an accepted part of the culture. It is a way of life for businessmen, who don't relax in pubs or bars, but go to hostess clubs where they entertain business associates. And most companies insist that their employees entertain clients at these places. On the first night, the female boss told me the rules: do not cross your legs; if a customer touches you, you are permitted to hit his hand away and then call for assistance; no socialising after work with the customers. I'm not sure whether the last one was for our personal safety or whether the boss was afraid of losing money. We were encouraged to go to dinner with the customers before the club and got paid extra for bringing them in afterwards.

There were eight of us and we all sat at tables waiting for the first customer to arrive. As they walked through the door we'd stand up to welcome them with a small bow. The customer would order his whisky and then offer us a drink. We poured the drinks and lit their cigarettes, then the conversation would begin, every night they asked the same questions: "What's your name? Where do you come from? What's your purpose for visiting Japan?."

The first few weeks were fun and exciting. It was a job I'd never imagined I would do, but I thought it would strengthen my character, and, besides, I was earning a lot of money. We were given gifts of minidisc players and cash. And it was a laugh. We got drunk, ate food we couldn't usually afford, sang karaoke, and didn't care.

After a few months, things began to change, the stories we'd heard started to ring true. There was one circulating about a girl, who had worked at a club for 18 months. webTitle: Does a scene like this make you want to die?

fields.headline: Does a scene like this make you want to die?
fields.standfirst: New research suggests one woman in seven has felt so stressed, she has wanted to kill herself.  Jenni Murray examines the facts behind this figure
fields.trailText: New research suggests one woman in seven has felt so stressed, she has wanted to kill herself.  Jenni Murray examines the facts behind this figure
fields.body:
Uh, oh! Here we go again. One woman in seven has felt suicidal due to the stress of modern life, according to a survey carried out for Good Housekeeping magazine. Two thousand interviewees were found to have poor diets and insufficient time to exercise or visit their GP (which, frankly, doesn't say much for their good housekeeping); 40% of women who stay at home and 46% of women who go out to work said they turned to alcohol and comfort food to help them cope with increasing demands on their time.

Add this to other research published recently that suggests three-quarters of women would quit their jobs if they could, mix in the endlessly familiar headlines that tell us so-and-so who runs a major drinks company is going home to spend more time with her family or such-and-such a city trader is leaving her high-profile job, stir in the contention that housework is the new rock'n'roll and the strongest signal of affluence in a family is a mum who's there to bake cakes at teatime, and you could assume that women really can't stand the heat and were far better off in a perfectly formed kitchen, cooking up this month's exciting recipes, all, no doubt, with the GH seal of approval.

Why do newspapers and magazines never survey men? When is the last time you saw a sociological or scientific report that bemoans the fact that men eat junk food? But they do. Have a look in your works canteen or glimpse any transport café and watch them piling on the cholesterol.

Where are the headlines that scream anxiety at male smoking and drinking habits? But if you nip down the local of an evening, you'll be hard pressed to so much as see the number of pints consumed through the grey haze of the smoke-filled room. Who is worried that so many of them are overweight? Except, maybe, for the wives and girlfriends who watch them crawl into their cars every morning, doing their best to position the paunch between the seat and steering wheel.

Does anybody care that they are too knackered to stagger to the squash court after work in the evening? Do we worry that they can spend two hours a night watching the Simpsons or that the beer-guzzling, doughnut-scoffing Homer has become a male superhero, a model for the energetically challenged?

Is there a national outcry because they have to be dragged kicking and screaming to the doctor's surgery, even when faced with incontrovertible evidence of impending cardiac arrest, and why is it not public knowledge that they'd all pack up work tomorrow if they could find some other sucker to pay the bills? We don't know because nobody bothers to ask. Because it's in no one's interests to lay guilt on the male population for wanting to have it all. But women? We've been here once or twice before. We used to call it The Backlash.

So what of this suicide question? The claim that an extraordinary one in seven women is so exhausted by her lifestyle, she's thinking of topping herself? Are we such poor little things that we can't hack it? Are hundreds and thousands of us driving ourselves to a self-inflicted early grave? Of course we're not. Sure, we get up in the morning, make big decisions in front of the wardrobe, stuff a bit of toast into anyone who'll have it, school run, work, shopping - and heavens, it's hard to choose between 15 different soap powders and 57 varieties of breakfast cereal.

You meet a pal over coffee (or, if the survey is to be believed, several bottles of dry white wine) and she asks: "How was your day?"

"God, I'm so depressed, so exhausted, if I don't get a break, I'll kill myself."

Depression, suicide, they've become the common currency of everyday discourse and, maybe just occasionally, standing in a slow-moving queue at the supermarket with screaming toddlers riffling through the sweet stands, you do feel, for a few ghastly moments, that death would be a welcome release. But you don't mean it.

Sarah Kane meant it when, after years of psychiatric treatment for debilitating depression, she finally wrote a chilling play called 4.48 Psychosis - that time of the morning when depression really kicks in and the risk of suicide is greatest. Kane managed to kill herself, even though she was in hospital. The doctor husband of a friend of mine meant it when he injected himself with what he knew would be a lethal cocktail and lay down to die. A young father in Glasgow meant it when, at the weekend, he slashed his own throat, leaving his baby son unharmed. Friends say he was afraid the boy's mother was seeing someone else.

The Samaritans published figures in May that showed the suicide rate among young males is five times as high as it is for young females. There is no doubt that the stress of modern life impinges on both sexes. Women can suffer from depression when they're postnatal, when they're menopausal or when, like Kane, they are clinically ill, but it is still relatively rare for us to take the ultimate step. A woman who suffers from MS interviewed last week said that she had thought of suicide but was stopped by the thought of her mother and the intense pain it would cause her. Maybe she gives a clue to the lower figures for females. Maybe women just think more about the devastation they'll create in other people's lives.

Those of us who glibly answer with a yes magazine questionnaires that ask whether stress makes us feel suicidal, diminish the anguish of those who have taken their own lives and those who have faced the abyss, but stepped back for the sake of someone close to them. As a cry for a bit of help with the housework, it's totally over the top.

fields.headline: Good news from Reuters
fields.trailText: Shares in Reuters, the global news and information group, climbed 65p to £13.40 yesterday after CSFB analysts increased their valaution of the stock to £15.27.
fields.body:
Shares in Reuters, the global news and information group, climbed 65p to £13.40 yesterday after CSFB analysts increased their valaution of the stock to £15.27.

The increase was driven chiefly by the rerating of Tibco - a Nasdaq-quoted networking specialist in which Reuters has a 45% stake - and by the expectation of strong first half results, which are due on July 25.

CSFB expects the figures to reflect the strength of trading volumes at Instinet - the electronic brokerage division - and an improvement in margins from the information division.

With news likely to remain positive - Reuters has announced plans to migrate its core financial business to the internet - 2000 could prove to be a watershed year for the group. But investors should be prepared for a volatile ride: Reuters shares have traded as low as 715p and as high as £17.15 this year.

fields.headline: Talking dirty
fields.trailText: null
fields.body:
"I swore to myself that I would never take my clothes off because I didn't want anybody to tell me, 'You see - a model. You take your clothes off.' That's why I've never done any nudity. But I'm not a prude. I'm German. I have no problem lying completely naked in Munich in the park"
Claudia Schiffer, Elle

"Marry Prince William? I would love that. After all, who wouldn't want to be a princess?"
Britney Spears, Sun

"It's being able to psych out a patient before she has a panic attack and tries to rip her dressings off. Everything may look all right on the surface until you take hold of the patient's hand and she dissolves in tears, pouring out her life story. Psychologically it is so much better for cosmetic surgery patients to be receiving care from another female who understands what she's gone through - and can see the end when the patient cannot. After all, what brought her to the surgeon was the hope of looking on the outside the age she feels inside - and none of us is over 25 in our hearts. But in those first few days she looks in the mirror and says, oh my God, what have I done? However positive your reasons for surgery, you are going to experience loss. You've lived with that face for a long time and what's looking back at you from the mirror is someone totally different"
Barbara McKeon, assistant manager of California's £400 per night Shanteque retreat, on its benefits for women who've had cosmetic surgery, Woman's Journal

"20 Reasons Why Dogs Are Preferable To Men ... Dogs miss you when you're gone. Dogs can be house-trained. Handsome dogs don't know they are handsome. Dogs admit it when they are lost. Dogs don't mind when you put on weight. Dogs aren't threatened if you earn more money than they do. Dogs feel very guilty if they have done something wrong. You never wonder if your dog is good enough for you. Dogs don't have problems expressing their affection in public. Dogs admit it when they are jealous. Dogs understand what 'no' means. Dogs do not laugh at your throw when you play games with them. Dogs are very direct about wanting to go out. Dogs don't criticise your friends. Dogs are happy to see your relatives. Dogs think that everything you feed them is delicious. Dogs always look you in the eye. Dogs don't correct your stories. Dogs don't talk when you are watching a film. Dogs think with their nose"
Why a girl's best friend is her dog, Aura magazine

fields.headline: The new race relations
fields.standfirst: Latest in the long line of literary genres to arrive in Britain from America is books on black relationships.  Helen Kolawole  reports
fields.trailText: Latest in the long line of literary genres to arrive in Britain from America is books on black relationships.  Helen Kolawole  reports
fields.body:
Just what can American author Don Spears teach black British women about how to have successful relationships with black men? For a start, they might need, "taking down a couple of notches". More so if they've failed to "stem signs of self-sufficiency". And, lest we forget, "one of the worst things any woman can do to a 'real' black man is try and push him around". These are just a few pointers from Spears' sensitively titled self-help book, In Search of Goodpussy.

Spears is the latest in a line of US authors who have come to Britain to plug their theories on black relationships and it is largely women who have taken the bait. Just what Spears has to teach anyone is questionable. If the title of his ponderings isn't enough to send black British women running for the hills, a glance at the cover (with Spears in a dinner jacket, holding an apprehensive-looking moggy) should suffice. Yet it was women who helped Spears reach number five in America's Blackboard bestseller list and this weekend women will no doubt pack the south London venue where he will be discussing his thoughts on "black love".

Putting aside Spears' retrogressive ramblings, the popularity of the genre can be attributed to the current perceived crisis in black relationships. The decline in marriage, the rise of single parent households, black women's greater socioeconomic status and even the increase in interracial dating are causing concern both in America and here. A stream of books has appeared in response, including Monique Jellerette Dejongh's How to Marry a Black Man and Ten Choices that Ruin Black Women's Lives by Grace Cornish.

So what's their appeal? While not overly impressed with Spears' effort, magazine publisher Barbara Campbell enjoys the genre and is acutely aware of the social undercurrents that sustain the books' popularity. "I read them to see how the other half lives," she says, adding that she believes they have given her an insight into the black male psyche.

But does she believe black couples face specific problems? "There are definitely issues we cannot get over, like this idea that a man can't understand that a woman needs to assert her own identity and it needn't be at his expense. I'm not saying black men are turning away from black women, but there are reasons why they may feel wary. One friend told me when he approaches black women, they will often look at him in a challenging way; when he approaches white women, they smile and are friendly. I think a lot of women think of men as dogs and if a dog approaches you, you're not going to smile at him, you're going to growl."

The old chestnut that has black women as argumentative Amazons perhaps explains Spears' views on interracial dating. "The black man loves his strong black woman," he says, "but sometimes he wants some soft pink frailty to convince him he's still a force to be reckoned with."

While the quality of books in this genre can vary, all agree on one thing: the negative effect of the stereotypes enforced on black men and women. This is traced back to slavery, where crude behavioural patterns such as hardened self-sufficiency in black women and the "stud mentality" of black men have their foundations.

Often though, the impact of patriarchy is overlooked. "Some men do think equality is going too far and that women are castrating them," Campbell says. "I don't think it's true but this is the way some black men feel and men have fragile egos."

Inevitably, most of the books in this genre conclude that greater understanding between the sexes is needed. Finance worker Roselind Ashman, 31, who has been with her partner - a black man - for four years, wouldn't disagree. "It's interesting to read about relationships from a black male perspective," she says, "because men aren't good at communicating their feelings."

For her, there is also a desire to understand the particular strains black men face in society, "the reputation that hangs over them and how unfair it can be. My dad certainly wasn't irresponsible, he didn't abandon his children. But with my generation, expectations can be low on both sides. These books reflect the fact that some people approach black relationships as war. A lot of the issues, like black men being unwilling to commit, are clichés - but they are based on something and being aware of the issues means you can at least deal with them. If these books, no matter how tacky, mean we talk about our problems, that's not a bad thing."

Finance worker Roselind Ashman, 31, who has been with her partner - a black man - for four years, wouldn't disagree. "It's interesting to read about relationships from a black male perspective," she says, "because men aren't good at communicating their feelings." For her, there is also a desire to understand the particular strains black men face in society, "the reputation that hangs over them and how unfair it can be. My dad certainly wasn't irresponsible, he didn't abandon his children. But with my generation, expectations can be low on both sides. These books reflect the fact that some people approach black relationships as war. A lot of the issues, like black men being unwilling to commit, are clichés - but they are based on something and being aware of the issues means you can at least deal with them. If these books, no matter how tacky, mean we talk about our problems, that's not a bad thing."

fields.headline: Sage advice aids software firm
fields.trailText: Over the past month, persistent speculation about an imminent profit warning has undermined the performance of software accountancy specialist Sage .
fields.body:
Over the past month, persistent speculation about an imminent profit warning has undermined the performance of software accountancy specialist Sage .

Its shares have underperformed the FTSE All-Share index by 11.9% in that time, on fears that it would follow smaller US rival Great Plains Software and warn that it could not meet its full-year profit forecasts (the consensus is for pre-tax profits of £109m).

However, it seems the fears have been overplayed. After meeting Paul Walker, Sage's chief executive, on Tuesday, analysts at Deutsche Bank reckon that in the short term at least there will be no warning.

News of Deutsche's comments helped push Sage's shares up 22p to 553p, even though the broker sounded a note of caution. While pre dicting short-term progress for the stock, Deutsche sees better value in Misys , which closed up 25p at 546p.

"This would not be our preferred pick in the sector. We would rather have exposure to Misys," the broker said.

Leading shares on the whole recorded an impressive performance thanks to a strong Vodafone AirTouch (up 8.5p at 312.5p) and weak earnings figures which helped fuel speculation that domestic interest rates might have peaked. The FTSE 100 closed 42.7 points stronger at 6,518.5, with Vodafone - which makes up around 13% of the blue-chip index - delivering 23 points of the upside.

British Telecom had a tough day. As its chairman was explaining to angry investors the reasons behind the 39% plunge in the company's value this year, its shares fell 18p to 900p. While some blamed the decline on fears that BT will face legal action over delays to the unbundling of the local loop, the real reason was a downgrade from heavyweight broker Merrill Lynch.

Ahead of BT's first-quarter results on July 27, Merrill slashed its full-year pre-tax profit forecast by 26% and re duced its price target to £11.50.

HSBC , up 43p at 848p, was the outstanding feature in the banking sector. Analysts at Fox-Pitt Kelton said the rise was related to the closure of its £6.6bn acquisition of French bank CCF yesterday. This forced arbitrageurs to cover their short positions in HSBC by buying more stock.

Royal Bank of Scotland advanced a little more than 30p to £10.08 after Goldman Sachs upgraded its stance. Goldman also upgraded Barclays , 19p better at £15.19, but lowered its ratings on Bank of Scotland and Woolwich , which fell 7.5p to 565p and 3.25p to 259.25.

Mining stocks were back in fashion, helped by results from US aluminium producer Alcoa. Billiton rose 13.5p to 287p while Lonmin advanced 37p to 795p.

ICI was in demand, up 25p to 510p after German rival Bayer posted strong sales figures, and Railtrack firmed 32.5p to £10.88 as Deutsche Bank issued "strong buy" advice. Railtrack is scheduled to meet brokers today to discuss its first quarter performance.

Among second-tier stocks, British Energy enjoying another session of healthy gains. It shares appreciated 32.5p to 250p, as the market warmed to its plan to lease two Canadian nuclear plants.

Internet auction house QXL rose 17p to 86p on speculation of a bid from US rival EBay. But IT service group Diagonal fell 60p to 257.5p after revealing a 47% decline in first-half profits.

Elsewhere, software firm DCS tumbled 175p to 380p after issuing a warning on profits. But there was good news for shareholders in Britain's largest independent petrol station owner, Save Group . Its shares closed up 12p at 67.5p on news that it has held takeover talks with more than one party.

Communications group Huntsworth rose 10p to 40.5p after shareholders who hold a near 30% stake called for a meeting to remove directors.

Aim debutant Compass Software closed at 170p, a 20p premium on its offer price.

fields.headline: At this price?
fields.trailText: In the mid-1990s, at the end of the first bio-tech investment boom, Andrew Porter, an analyst, cleared his desk at investment bank UBS to move into the industry he had been researching.
fields.body:
In the mid-1990s, at the end of the first bio-tech investment boom, Andrew Porter, an analyst, cleared his desk at investment bank UBS to move into the industry he had been researching.

It was an example of the golden bandwagon-chasing in the past year, when highly paid City experts have hung up their suits, donned the chinos and recreated themselves as internet entrepreneurs.

In Mr Porter's case, the result was Alizyme , a Cambridge company that would rid mankind of ailments and make its financial backers rich. There were no cures, of course, and investors were left holding a share which between 1996 and the beginning of this year stayed below its flotation price by bobbing between 30p and 50p.

A couple of years ago, Richard Palmer, a research and development man from Glaxo Wellcome, and Tim McCarthy from Peptide Therapeutics took over as managers. When the second biotech investment boom took hold earlier this year Alizyme stock was a prime beneficiary, with the shares charging towards 250p before falling back to just over 100p over the past few months.

But yesterday the company showed that it really is beginning to grow up with modest goals in mind. Through Nomura, the Japanese investment bank, Alizyme has placed £14m of stock with institutions at 100p apiece and is now offering a further £6.2m of paper to private shareholders through an open offer.

A couple of earlier cash raisings brought in around £5m a time The new money should give a real boost to early-stage trials on a range of remedies, covering everything from obesity to constipation and irritable bowel syndrome.

For existing shareholders the moment has probably arrived to back this company. With the market price down 4p at 107.5p, stock should be taken up through the open offer.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Crossing Continents/Kings Of The Ring
fields.body:
Britain is far from alone in its concern about asylum seekers. Julian Pettifer starts the new season of Crossing Continents (11.0am, Radio 4) at a rally in Turin, where the Northern League is attracting growing support by setting up vigilante patrols in districts with a large immigrant population. It's reckoned that 2.6 per cent of the Italian population are immigrants, mostly illegal. But these "clandestini" may yet prove an industrial godsend to the nation with the world's lowest birthrate.

Ray Winstone tells the remarkable, and eventually distressing, story of the boxer Joe Louis (pictured) in Kings Of The Ring (9pm, Radio 5 Live). The Brown Bomber defended his world heavyweight title a record 25 times and retained it for nearly 12 years. But, though he became an icon for America's blacks, he could never escape the Jim Crow laws of the period. His nervous managers forced him severely to restrict his personal life lest he get into trouble.

webTitle: Telefonica's golden boy tarnished by scandal

fields.headline: Telefonica's golden boy tarnished by scandal
fields.standfirst: Critics dish the dirt on Spain's flamboyant telecoms groundbreaker
fields.trailText: Juan Villalonga, the rumbustious chairman of Telefonica, the Spanish telecoms group, was until recently the industry's golden boy, credited with pitching the company into the global arena.
fields.body:
Juan Villalonga, the rumbustious chairman of Telefonica, the Spanish telecoms group, was until recently the industry's golden boy, credited with pitching the company into the global arena.

But now, following allegations of insider trading, he is fighting for his job while relations with his old schoolfriend, Spain's prime minister, Jose Maria Aznar, are in shreds. Worse is that his much-applauded move to merge with Dutch group KPN fell through yesterday. The question whispered around the Spanish markets is what went wrong?

A lawyer and economist with an MBA from Barcelona's Iese school, he had all the right credentials. He began his career working for a bank set up by his great-uncle, before acquiring international experience with management consultancy McKinsey and then running Bankers Trust in Spain. He had also, helpfully, been in the same class as Mr Aznar at Madrid's elite Pilar school.

Wooing partners

Mr Villalonga was appointed to head and complete the privatisation of Telefonica when Mr Aznar's centre-right government came to power in 1996. The new chairman, then 43, took to the job with characteristic relish. He began buying up Latin American telecoms companies, breaking new ground in the mobile phone and internet markets, moving into radio and television, and wooing European partners, including BT.

His strategy, based on establishing a core business around the use of Castilian Spanish, spoken by more than 400m people worldwide, appeared entirely in keeping with Mr Aznar's aim of putting Spain at the centre of a business and cultural revival in the Hispanic world.

Under his tenure, Telefonica's value increased more than five-fold. It has become the biggest telecoms operator in Latin America. Earlier this year, the company's shares accounted for a quarter of Madrid's stock market value.

As Mr Villalonga warmed to the role of international tycoon, he began to raise hackles at home. His plan to reward senior executives, and himself, with millionaire stock options was made public during the March general election campaign and embarrassed Mr Aznar.

The opposition Socialists made much of the wealth Mr Villalonga had acquired largely, they said, as a result of his friendship with Mr Aznar. In the end, voters turned a deaf ear to the allegations of cronyism. Mr Aznar was re-elected with a substantial majority but the damage had been done.

Rumours started that Mr Villalonga might leave or be pushed off the Telefonica board. Instead he shored himself up with alliances at home and abroad that seemed designed to put him beyond the control of government and the sniping from the Spanish media.

On the personal front, Mr Villalonga distanced himself from Spain. In 1998 he began a relationship with Adriana Abascal, a former Mexican beauty queen who had been the mistress of a Mexican media mogul, Emilio Azcarraga, 40 years her senior and known as The Tiger. The follow ing year Mr Villalonga left his wife and their three teenage children to live with Ms Abascal in Miami, which is the base of the Hispanic jetset that includes the singers Gloria Estefan and Julio Iglesias, who are friends of the couple. Last May Ms Abascal gave birth to their daughter, Pauline.

That did not go down well with Mr Aznar's wife, Ana Botella, a powerful figure in her own right and a close friend of Mrs Villalonga. The magnate's estranged wife was one of 80 guests invited for dinner at the prime minister's palace to celebrate Mr Aznar's reelection.

Mr Villalonga, meanwhile, continued his international expansion. He bought Endemol, a Dutch TV production company and European leader, which included the Big Brother show among its successes, and gave his Madrid-based internet service provider ,Terra, a US arm with the purchase of Lycos, the American internet portal. Critics in Spain said he was paying too much for them.

He also caused a storm in Madrid by suggesting Telefonica's headquarters move to Miami, and annoyed company staff and shareholders alike by announcing plans to merge with the Dutch telecoms company KPN. That statement was made by videoconference from Miami, Mr Villalonga wearing a casual, pink polo shirt.

In the event, the government scotched the scheme. KPN is partly state-owned, and plans for its full privatisation had to be approved by the Dutch parliament.

An almightly row followed involving the Dutch government and the European Commission. Sources close to Mr Villalonga claimed there was a witch hunt against him.

Under investigation

Then, last month, the government-friendly daily El Mundo began to print a series of allegations that the tycoon used inside information about merger talks with American operators WorldCom and MCI to buy Telefonica shares in 1998. He sold them soon after, netting $119,000. An investigation by Spain's stock market watchdog ruled there had been no wrongdoing but it has been reopened. Mr Aznar has stressed that he hopes it will do a thorough job.

Mr Villalonga continues to fight back. Last week Telefonica completed a $13.4bn buyout of its Latin American affiliates in Peru, Argentina and Brazil, and restructured the group along product instead of geographical lines. He also survived the latest troubled board meeting with a spirited defence of his performance.

But his main shareholders, the Spanish banks BBVA and La Caixa, remain unhappy. Telefonica's shares have become volatile and there are fears that Mr Villalonga's strategy is designed more to ensure his survival than the wellbeing of the company. He might try to revamp the board to reflect its global interests and include non-Spanish directors who are impervious to government influence. At present 19 out of 20 directors are Spanish.

However, few Spaniards rate his chances of survival.

fields.headline: Work in progress
fields.standfirst: Luke Haines, musician
fields.trailText: Luke Haines, musician
fields.body:
I don't know if my new video has even been shown anywhere, I'd imagine not as it's kind of art. To my mind it's completely accessible, but Britain at the moment seems to be a nation of Blue Peter presenters. A nation of babies. If you look at all television from the moment it starts in the morning till it closes down, which it now never does, it's all aimed at children. There's no adult TV in this country. It's all aimed at 14 year olds.

I made my first record in 1987 and I can honestly say nothing whatsoever has changed. MP3 won't change anything. All this talk about the Napster - I mean, have these people never heard of the public library! You can get free music there. Actually that's what MP3 is doing, closing down the libraries; record companies have nothing to worry about [laughs].

It's pretty damn easy to make a record, it's not like digging holes in the road or sewing mailbags. I find it amusing that bands like Radiohead can potter around for three years on their latest "effort". It's quite amazing, I mean there's about nine of them! The Auteurs is just me, same with Baader-Meinhof. With Black Box Recorder there's three of us. That's not many and we still manage to bash 'em out. In the old days bands like Queen would release a complex and accomplished LP every six months, I reckon.

The next record I'm doing will be The Hate Socialist Collective for my dear friends at Hut. And I've just done a soundtrack for a film called Christie Mallory's Own Double Entry. It's not a porn film, it's about an urban terrorist and it's jolly good. But in this world of sloth that I paddle around in I actually seem to be hard-working.

Black Box Recorder's new single The Art Of Driving is out now on Nude Records.

fields.headline: Notes and queries
fields.standfirst: Scots' Darien disaster * Humans' lifespan * Lost holidays * The wrongs of ticket touting
fields.trailText: Scots' Darien disaster * Humans' lifespan * Lost holidays * The wrongs of ticket touting
fields.body:
Apparently a Scottish colony was established in South or Central America around the 16th century. Does anyone know more about this?

* The colony, called Caledonia Bay, was located on the Caribbean coast of what is now eastern Panama in the Darien region. It was the brainchild of economist William Paterson and established under the auspices of the Company of Scotland Trading to Africa and the Indies.

In July 1698 five ships set out with 1,200 colonists, arriving in November. The territory was already claimed (though not occupied) by Spain. The Scots had inappropriate trade goods which they could barely give away in Darien, and had no money to buy food from passing ships. Once the rainy season began in April, malaria, yellow fever, typhoid and scurvy began to take their toll.

By April 1699, hundreds of the settlers had died and in June the Scots abandoned Caledonia Bay and headed for New York, but because of various misadventures in the Caribbean few of them reached it.

By a series of unfortunate coincidences the first news of the disaster reached Edinburgh hours too late to stop a second expedition departing. This fleet fared no better than the first: 950 of the 1,300 settlers were dead within a year. In addition to infighting, hunger and disease, the Spanish attacked and in April 1700 forced the Scots to evacuate the area for good. None of the ships reached New York. William Paterson survived, a broken man, and returned to Scotland where he lived in poverty for the rest of his life.

The crippling financial cost of the fiasco - more than £250,000 - virtually bankrupted Scotland. Details of this episode can be found in The Golden Isthmus (1966), by David Howarth.
J Hildrop, Matlock Moor, Derbys.

* I enjoy reading the Guardian, though some of its metropolitan provincialism can get a bit tiresome. Given the fact that any non-brain-dead person in Scotland knows all about the Darien colony, and how its collapse, hastened by English piracy, helped force the Act of Union in 1707, can I suggest a couple more posers for you?

1. Apparently there was some kind of war in England around the 13th century when the different sides wore different coloured flowers. Does anyone know about this?

2. Apparently England won some kind of international sporting competition with the help of a short-sighted match official, sometime around 1956. Does anyone know about this?
Wilson McLeod, Isle of Skye.

Does the human race have a future longer than its past?

* Current knowledge of human origins places the first appearance of our species (homo sapiens sapiens) in southern Africa around 150,000 years ago. If an average is taken for length of persistence in the fossil record for all the mammalian species that have ever lived, a figure of 4m years will be the result. So unless we become the agents of our own destruction, we have hardly begun our allotted span on earth.
Russell Hughes, Walthamstow, London E17.

* Once we spread far beyond the solar system, cosmic events which can threaten widely spaced colonies are exceedingly rare. If we can learn to live in peace, the human race could last indefinitely. After all, in the movie Matrix we are described as a cosmic virus. In the eternally optimistic book, Physics of Immortality, cosmologist Frank Tipler shows that it is humankind's destiny to colonise and control the entire universe, and maybe even cosmic time.
Prof Joss Hawthorn, Anglo-Australian Observatory, Sydney.

Has any tennis player ever actually poured themselves a glass of barley water during a match at Wimbledon?

Vladimir Voltchkov poured himself an orange barley water just before last Friday's semi-final with Pete Sampras. I think it unlikely that he did so simply in response to this query, published the previous day.
Michael Grosvenor Myer, Haddenham, Cambridge.

My wife, as a schoolgirl in Wensleydale before the war, recalls reciting the lines: "29th of May, Royal Oak Day, if you don't give us a holiday, we'll all run away." Why should this memory of the 17th-century civil war persist in children's doggerel?

* A popular one in south Manchester early in the last century ran:

"Pancake Tuesday's a very happy day

If you don't give us holiday, we'll all run away.

Where will we run to? Up Nell Lane.

Here comes teacher with a big fat cane."

Shrove Tuesday was always a half-holiday in those days.
Patricia Antell, Saffron Walden, Essex.

A detailed investigation of the history of this holiday (Oak Apple Day, Royal Oak Day, Restoration Day, Yak Bob Day) is provided by Ronald Hutton, The Stations of the Sun (1996).
Audrey Douglas, Sedbergh, Cumbria.

If we live in a market economy and pride ourselves on being a trading nation, how can ticket touting at sporting and artistic events be considered wrong or even illegal?

* The original ticket vendors are no doubt miffed at seeing others cashing in with little effort, and taking money which their own profit-making failed to acquire, resulting in influential business types insisting on government action. As many touts will pay no tax, such pressure for new laws, etc, is likely to be favoured by the authorities.

And since ticket touts can demand many times the face value of very popular tickets, forcing those to pay up or miss out, they thereby expose the fundamentally obscene nature of market economics - "can't buy, can't have" - and so represent a threat to far bigger, far richer touts doing precisely the same thing through asset ownership rights.
Max Hess, Folkestone, Kent.

A tourist leaflet in Austria tells me that Salzburg is one of the three most beautiful cities in the world. What are the other two?

* Leningrad and Prague.
William Benton, Hall Green, Birmingham.

I keep getting emails inviting me to obtain an International Drivers Licence which can never be suspended or revoked. Apparently this privilege is guaranteed by a 1949 United Nations Convention and a 1958 World Court decision. Is this true?

* The International Drivers Licence is one of a number of scams that regularly do the rounds on the internet. There is such a thing as an International Drivers Permit (IDP), but it is only a booklet that contains the information on your driving licence translated into a number of languages. While some countries require you to carry an IDP it is intended to supplement, not replace, your existing driving licence. Most major motoring organisations will be able to supply you with details.
Andrew Larcombe, Ashford, Middlesex.

I bumped into a friend the other day but had forgotten his name. I know that he had forgotten mine too. How do you get out of such an embarrassing situation?

* Here in Australia we solved this dilemma long ago. We call everyone "mate". "G'day, mate, haven't seen you for years, how's it going?" "Yeah, good, thanks, mate". "Well, gotta go now - see you round, mate". "Yeah, see you, mate". Problem solved.
Matthew Rosser, Perth, Australia.

* The same thing happened to me and a woman friend the other day. We cheerfully owned up and laughed. I wonder if men tend to find such situations more embarrassing than women. Just remember: if amnesia is well advanced, you can always enjoy the pleasure of making a new friend.
Kathryn Smits, Auckland, New Zealand.

Any answers?

Just outside London's Liverpool Street station, between the tracks and the arches, there are a number of small "memorial-type" statues. What are they?
Kerry Luter, London WC2.

I have heard locally the term "Tyson's tale" to describe a story having little or no factual basis, generally told by someone credited with little intelligence. How widespread is the term and what is its derivation?
Mick Stothard, Uppermill, Lancs.

In July last year, a Panorama programme revealed that the "Capton" wiring fitted to most aircraft can explode into flames simply through friction heat. US military planes were stripped of it but there has there been little further publicity. Why?
Richard Burch, Exeter.

Why do cigarette packets in vending machines contain only 16 fags?
Rosie Brennan, London NW1.

The Philippoussis-Schalken match was the second longest in Wimbledon history, averaging 3 mins 38 secs for each of its 83 games. The 112-game Pasarell-Gonzales match in 1969 had an average game length of 2 mins 47s. Given that there are now more aces and fewer long rallies, why do today's games last so much longer?
Mitchell Sandler, Edgware, Middx.

webTitle: Austria is winning EU sanctions battle

fields.headline: Austria is winning EU sanctions battle
fields.standfirst: The Austrian far right in power: special report
fields.trailText: Romano Prodi, the president of the European commission, yesterday gave his clearest signal to date that he views the sanctions imposed on Austria for allowing the far-right Freedom party to join its coalition government were an error of judgment and should be swiftly lifted.
fields.byline: Andrew Osborn  in Brussels and Kate Connolly  in Vienna
fields.body:
Romano Prodi, the president of the European commission, yesterday gave his clearest signal to date that he views the sanctions imposed on Austria for allowing the far-right Freedom party to join its coalition government were an error of judgment and should be swiftly lifted.

Mr Prodi's comments, which are likely to embarrass hardcore proponents of the sanctions such as France and Belgium, came after the Austrian chancellor, Wolfgang Schüssel, gave a firm pledge that his country would not retaliate by sabotaging EU business out of spite.

It was a good day for Mr Schüssel, who was on his first visit to the commission's Brussels headquarters since the row erupted in February.

The European court of human rights yesterday named a three-man panel to pronounce whether the sanctions should be rescinded or left in place.

The so-called "wise men" will now produce a report which is seen as a face-saving strategy giving the 14 EU member states a pretext to declare that the measures are no longer needed. Several EU countries, including Italy, Ireland, Finland and Greece, have made it clear behind the scenes that they want the sanctions lifted.

The panel, named by the Strasbourg court as the former Finnish president Martti Ahtisaari, the former Spanish foreign minister Marcelino Oreja, and the German lawyer Jochen Frowein, will now begin investigating the way that Austria deals with ethnic minorities, immigrants and refugees. Diplomats said yesterday that most EU governments believe it is only a matter of time before the sanctions are lifted.

In his most frank outburst to date Mr Prodi - who was not consulted over the sanctions - made it clear where he stood on the issue.

"I do not think in general that sanctions in such cases give better results than those achieved in a serious in-depth dialogue," he stated, adding that he wanted the wise men to finish their report "as quickly as possible".

In a further sign that he is keen to see the measures annulled, he called on the panel to work through the summer and for the Austrian government to forgo its holidays if it will speed the process up.

Yesterday, Mr Schüssel was careful to strike a moderate tone and went out of his way to rubbish suggestions from the former Freedom party leader, Jörg Haider, and members of his own government that Austria will hit back at the EU by holding up enlargement moves and blocking internal reforms.

"The Austrian government was and is very patient and moderate, and words such as threat, veto and blackmail should be deleted from our vocabulary. We're not going to block important processes."

He argued that Austria in fact supported enlargement and even wanted a date to be named for the first countries to enter the union, something which other member states are loath to do.

He admitted, however, that the idea of a panel examining Austrian government policy to ensure it was "in the European spirit" was hard to stomach.

But Vienna would cooperate with the panel, he stressed, and was hopeful that the sanctions could be lifted by the autumn.

In a bizarre riposte reminiscent of the cult 1970s television show The Prisoner, Mr Schüssel denied that he was under the influence of Mr Haider. "I'm not a hostage, I'm a free man. I've come here voluntarily," he said.

He also mounted a vigorous defence of the way Austria treats its refugees. There was, he claimed, no country which had absorbed more refugees than Austria and only Luxembourg had successfully integrated a higher proportion of foreigners into its society. The only sour note was linked to Austria's move to hold a referendum on the fairness of the sanctions later this year, a development which Mr Prodi openly condemned, and Mr Schüssel played down.

However, in an interview with German weekly Rheinische Merkur, Mr Schüssel suggested that a referendum could be avoided "very easily" if the wise men started work immediately.

The assumption up to now has been that the sanctions will be lifted in January when Sweden takes over the EU presidency from France. However, the mood in Brussels yesterday suggested a breakthrough may come earlier.

Despite the fact that the sanctions are relatively minor and include measures such as bans on cultural and sporting events and secondary military accords, Austria feels humiliated and the row has soured the atmosphere at European Union meetings.

webTitle: Launch of astronaut hotel salvages space station

fields.headline: Launch of astronaut hotel salvages space station
fields.standfirst: Space exploration: special report
fields.trailText: The international space exploration programme was brought back to life yesterday when a Russian rocket blasted off flawlessly from the desert in Kazakhstan, carrying the living quarters to allow a permanent crew to live on the new multi-national station 200 miles above the earth.
fields.body:
The international space exploration programme was brought back to life yesterday when a Russian rocket blasted off flawlessly from the desert in Kazakhstan, carrying the living quarters to allow a permanent crew to live on the new multi-national station 200 miles above the earth.

Delayed for two years by Russia's financial crises and by technical troubles, the Zvezda (Star) module went safely into orbit early yesterday morning 10 minutes after lift-off.

The thundering roar of the successful take-off was greeted with glee by Russian and US space officials at the launchpad. Any hitch at this stage in the construction of the international space station (ISS) would have been disastrous, and could even have caused the $60bn (£40bn) project to be suspended.

Zvezda contains the space station's flight controls, sleeping quarters and sewage disposal system; the whole weighs about 20 tonnes. The long delays to Russia's completion of this key phase have brought the programme to a standstill.

The next two weeks will be a time of nervous tension as the unmanned Zvezda makes its way to meet two partner modules which have been orbiting earth for two years in anticipation of its arrival.

If everything goes smoothly, on July 26 the new segment will be connected to the others by remote control from the Russian space centre in Baikonur, Kazakhstan. If the automatic docking fails, three astronauts are on standby, ready to go into orbit to try to make the connection manually.

Once the three modules become a unit, the first team of cosmonauts could begin living and working on the station as soon as October. The successful docking of Zvezda will trigger a whole series of shuttle flights, ferrying an array of equipment from the Kennedy Space Centre in Florida.

Once finished - which will take another 35 missions - the station will span an area nearly as large as two football pitches. The earliest completion date is put at 2005. Also involved are Japan, the EU and Canada.

The barrel-shaped living quarters now hurtling through space were described by one former US astronaut as "better than the best hotel in the world".

Earthlings may differ: the size of a large bus, the module contains small closets, with sleeping bags fixed inside, a bathroom designed for washing in zero-gravity, a cooking galley, mini-gym with a treadmill and exercise bike and an entertainment centre with books, videos and CDs.

Dan Goldin, head of the US space agency NASA, stressed the Russian space agency's achievement yesterday in the face of extreme adversity. "The Russians have gone through all sorts of difficulty with their economy, the political changes and a whole variety of other problems - and they came through," he said.

Russia was awarded the Zvezda contract in the expectation that it would cost less for them to construct. According to some estimates, the delays have instead cost NASA around $3bn.

Emblazoned 30 feet high on the side of Zvezda's booster rocket is evidence of how strapped for money the Russian space programme is: a massive advertisement for Pizza Hut. The food company is thought to have paid around $1m of the $320m cost of the Zvezda segment of the project.

The Russian agency is also reported to be in sponsorship negotiations with Donatella Versace's fashion house, which is said to be ready to pay highly for the chance to design some of the astronauts' suits.
