webTitle: Triple alliance to battle for 3G billions

fields.headline: Triple alliance to battle for 3G billions
fields.trailText: Three self-styled musketeers - Hong Kong's Hutchison Whampoa, Holland's KPN Telecom and Japan's NTT DoCoMo - yesterday formed an alliance to conquer Europe's €100bn (£63bn) third-generation mobile phone market.
fields.body:
Three self-styled musketeers - Hong Kong's Hutchison Whampoa, Holland's KPN Telecom and Japan's NTT DoCoMo - yesterday formed an alliance to conquer Europe's €100bn (£63bn) third-generation mobile phone market.

The flamboyant team, designed to take on industry leaders such as Vodafone, France Telecom and Deutsche Telekom, set its sights on capturing lucrative positions in the third-generation UMTS (universal mobile telecommunications system) networks being set up in Britain, Germany, France, Belgium and, perhaps, Italy.

DoCoMo, which was squeezed out of the recent £24.5bn auction for five British UMTS licences, is paying £1.2bn for a 20% stake in Hutchison's venture which won the fifth licence with a £4.4bn bid. It is also taking a £15% stake in KPN for £2.5bn.

KPN, a regularly jilted bride, is paying £900m for 15% of Hutchison 3G UK Holdings, which won the licence via Telewest International Wireless, a Canadian operation that has been paid £50m to reduce its option to buy into the venture from 10% to 6.5%.

Yesterday's transactions value the Hutchison third-generation venture at £6bn, a 32% premium to the cost of the fifth British licence, renewing fears that competing groups are paying way over the odds to enter a market that might not deliver the promised returns for some considerable time - if at all.

Canning Fok, Hutchison Group's managing director, said nevertheless that the aim was to float off the new pan-European venture in due course. He expects the British and French units to break even by 2005.

Apart from British aspirations, Hutchison and KPN's mobile business, E-Plus, are attempting an assault on Germany's UMTS market where the auction for licences starts on July 31.

They are forming a 50/50 joint venture called E-Plus-Hutchison but, if they are successful, will then compete against each other in offering services.

Joop Drechsel, a KPN director, said that the group aimed to capture a substantial market share among the 200m potential subscribers in the four European countries initially targeted.

In France, where four licences are to be awarded at a fixed price of £3.25bn each next year, the musketeers could team up with local groups such as Bouygues and Vivendi.

The latter has, however, a close relationship with Vodafone through their Vizzavi internet portal joint venture.

The three hope to enlist partners ahead of a Belgian UMTS licence auction and could join the fray in Italy.

All told, 14 European countries are staging or have held auctions. Mr Fok, a leading player in building up Orange, the mobile phone operator recently bought by France Telecom, said the new venture could spend £5bn building the British infrastructure alone.

That added to market fears that the three, especially the Dutch musketeer, might not all survive in the face of ferocious competition from the industry's big players. But Mr Drechsel insisted that there could be more "dream teams" formed to take on the cardinals.

 EDP, the Portuguese electricity company, is seeking a large international partner to compete for one of four UMTS licences due to be auctioned next month at a flat fee.

The Portuguese government wants to encourage technological competition among the bids and EDP said it would need a technical operator as a partner in order to compete.

DoCoMo, which was squeezed out of the recent £24.5bn auction for five British UMTS licences, is paying £1.2bn for a 20% stake in Hutchison's venture which won the fifth licence with a £4.4bn bid. It is also taking a £15% stake in KPN for £2.5bn. KPN, a regularly jilted bride, is paying £900m for 15% of Hutchison 3G UK Holdings, which won the licence via Telewest International Wireless, a Canadian operation that has been paid £50m to reduce its option to buy into the venture from 10% to 6.5%. Yesterday's transactions value the Hutchison third-generation venture at £6bn, a 32% premium to the cost of the fifth British licence, renewing fears that competing groups are paying way over the odds to enter a market that might not deliver the promised returns for some considerable time - if at all. Canning Fok, Hutchison Group's managing director, said nevertheless that the aim was to float off the new pan-European venture in due course. He expects the British and French units to break even by 2005. Apart from British aspirations, Hutchison and KPN's mobile business, E-Plus, are attempting an assault on Germany's UMTS market where the auction for licences starts on July 31. They are forming a 50/50 joint venture called E-Plus-Hutchison but, if they are successful, will then compete against each other in offering services. Joop Drechsel, a KPN director, said that the group aimed to capture a substantial market share among the 200m potential subscribers in the four European countries initially targeted. In France, where four licences are to be awarded at a fixed price of £3.25bn each next year, the musketeers could team up with local groups such as Bouygues and Vivendi. The latter has, however, a close relationship with Vodafone through their Vizzavi internet portal joint venture. The three hope to enlist partners ahead of a Belgian UMTS licence auction and could join the fray in Italy. All told, 14 European countries are staging or have held auctions. Mr Fok, a leading player in building up Orange, the mobile phone operator recently bought by France Telecom, said the new venture could spend £5bn building the British infrastructure alone. That added to market fears that the three, especially the Dutch musketeer, might not all survive in the face of ferocious competition from the industry's big players. But Mr Drechsel insisted that there could be more "dream teams" formed to take on the cardinals.  EDP, the Portuguese electricity company, is seeking a large international partner to compete for one of four UMTS licences due to be auctioned next month at a flat fee. The Portuguese government wants to encourage technological competition among the bids and EDP said it would need a technical operator as a partner in order to compete.

fields.headline: Pick-and-mix mistakes
fields.standfirst:
The government is putting liberal values at serious risk as it spends its time trying to assess the public mood

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: The government is putting liberal values at serious risk as it spends its time trying to assess the public mood
fields.body:
The government's difficulties over the past few weeks are symptoms of a deepening malaise. It came to power with the project of giving voice to the values of Britain's liberal majority. In office, however, its strategy has been to seek to win favour from what it mistakenly believes is an implacably conservative electorate.

The result has been distinctly uninspiring. An undignified scramble to outbid William Hague in populist initiatives has left the government with a reputation for ingrained illiberalism and weakening support among the voters. Its panicky efforts to shore up its radical credentials have only made matters worse. Broadsides against elitism are no substitute for well-focused policies. All they do is reinforce the perception that this is a government that does not know its own mind.

There is a contradiction at the heart of the Blair government: on the one hand it aims to heal the split on the centre left that allowed the Tories to be the dominant party for most of the 20th century; on the other it appears to harbour a deep-seated suspicion of liberal values. Tony Blair has argued that Britain's social democratic and liberal traditions have always had much in common. Rightly, the PM has insisted that the future must lie in overcoming their historic division. Yet his government has repeatedly shown a timorous or cavalier disregard for liberal values.

Across a wide field, policies have been disappointingly -and, in terms of public opinion, often unnecessarily - illiberal. True, the government has taken a lead in reforming some of the laws which discriminate against gays. But in their treatment of asylum seekers government policies owe more to an opportunistic Tory agenda than to a balanced response to the complex humanitarian and human rights issues that are at stake. Again, the government's largely punitive stance on drug use is out of touch with public attitudes -more so, incredibly, than that which is being advocated in some sections of the right-wing press. And, despite some welcome concessions, its bill to allow monitoring and interception of email traffic has an Orwellian flavour that has attracted criticism from civil liberties groups and from business.

All this shows a worrying tendency to pick and mix policies according to the government's assessment - frequently erroneous - of the public mood. The result is not only a continuing leakage of support from Labour's traditional allies in the media and the professions. It is to put at risk the whole future of the government - even, in some measure, that of liberal values in this country.

The government's ambivalence about liberal values has enabled William Hague to represent his reactionary prejudices as the beliefs of most voters - and to chip away at Labour's claim to speak for the British majority.

The time when the Blair government could claim hegemony - if there ever was one - is over. By itself it cannot hope to achieve the fundamental change it promised the voters in 1997. And on present trends the prospect can no longer be ruled out of Labour returning to office with a majority not much larger than that with which John Major's last government began. In that event, it would probably not be long before the government's control of the political agenda crumbled away entirely.

In circumstances like these it is inevitable that the axis of voter support should begin to shift. There are clear signs that this is happening - not in a pendulum swing back to the Tories, but a tilt towards the Liberal Democrats. In a general election the tactical voting that produced their astonishing triumph in Romsey may not be widely repeated. Even so, over the coming years, Charles Kennedy seems set to become the pivotal figure in British politics. In his low-key, understated way, the Liberal Democrat leader has carved out a highly distinctive position for his party. Where the government has wavered on issues such as civil liberties, the Liberal Democrats have been consistently principled.

Perhaps only fleetingly, the circumstances are right for a historic realignment on the left. But it cannot last without a change in the voting system for the Commons. Unfortunately it is precisely on this point that cooperation threatens to come unstuck. If, for many in Labour first-past-the-post is the ark of the covenant, the same is true of PR for many Liberal Democrats. Both groups regard AV - the Australian alternative vote system whereby voters rank candidates in order of preference - as a shabby compromise which is unworthy of serious consideration.

In fact, it is AV that is most likely to give voice to Britain's liberal majority. Contrary to some claims, AV does not permanently disadvantage the Tories. What it does do is empower the centre. On reasonable assumptions, AV will enfranchise the Liberal Democrats very substantially. At the same time, by forcing the Tories to compete for second preference votes, it will compel them to return to the middle ground. Either Hague will start to sing from a different hymn sheet, or he will soon be replaced by someone who will. Under AV, only a centrist Tory party has a future.

Ending the split on the left was at the core of the project with which the government came to power. It remains so today. That requires closer cooperation between Labour and the Liberal Democrats - including, crucially, a workable agreement on electoral reform - and a much firmer commitment to liberal values on the part of the government. Will this historic opportunity be seized? Or will the government go down in history as a failed experiment in pick-and-mix politics?

John Gray is professor of European thought at the LSE.

comment@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Newspapers' poetic past
fields.trailText: As general editor of the new edition of Robert Southey's Poetical Works (to be published by Pickering and Chatto in 2003), I was fascinated to read your article (Unknown work of Romantic poet discovered, July 11) on Christopher Goulding's discovery of a previously unknown poem by the 19th-century poet laureate.
fields.body:
As general editor of the new edition of Robert Southey's Poetical Works (to be published by Pickering and Chatto in 2003), I was fascinated to read your article (Unknown work of Romantic poet discovered, July 11) on Christopher Goulding's discovery of a previously unknown poem by the 19th-century poet laureate.

However, although the 37 lines you reproduced were not included in Southey's 10-volume collected works (1837-8), they were actually published during his lifetime. The blank verse, unsigned poem, entitled A Morning Landscape, appeared in the London newspaper, the Morning Post, on July 22, 1799. It was one of more than 200 poems Southey contributed to the anti-Pittite Morning Post in 1798-9, 1801 and 1803.

Although he was a born controversialist who broadly shared the politics of the newspaper, the main motivation behind his prolific output for the Morning Post was financial - he earned on average a guinea a week.

In his work for the Morning Post, Southey tended to draw heavily on familiar scenes. As he did not visit Edinburgh until October 1805, it is highly likely that the landscape and Arthurian legends conjured up in a Morning Landscape belong to the south west of England where Southey was born.

At the end of his writing life, in 1838, Southey recalled with gratitude his first (newspaper) "laureateship" for the Morning Post and assessed its impact upon his literary career: "a very considerable part of those Minor Poems which I have thought worth preserving ... otherwise would not have been written". A Morning Landscape's publication history is a salutory reminder of the role played by the late 18th and early 19th-century press in the dissemination of contemporary poetry.

Dr Lynda Pratt
Queen's University,
Belfast
l.pratt@qub.ac.uk

fields.headline: Branch out
fields.trailText: Mark Cocker's Country Diary on the benefit of cutting down trees (July 10) is a timely reminder of how detached we have become from age-old sustainable countryside management practices. For centuries we preserved woodland by regularly harvesting a proportion of its good trees in a planned way. The timber was used for buildings, furniture, fuel, on the farm and in many other industries
fields.body:
Mark Cocker's Country Diary on the benefit of cutting down trees (July 10) is a timely reminder of how detached we have become from age-old sustainable countryside management practices. For centuries we preserved woodland by regularly harvesting a proportion of its good trees in a planned way. The timber was used for buildings, furniture, fuel, on the farm and in many other industries.

The decline in the economic viability of this system, supplying into local markets, has left the health of our woodlands, both the trees and the wildlife, in far greater danger from neglect than from the chainsaw.

The dark and overgrown neglected wood, threatened as much by the panic about cutting as by the fear of lurking undesirables and dumped waste, needs care if it is to survive.

Alex Argyropulo
National Small Woods Association, nswa@woodnet.org.uk

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: The first step on the road to what would be the Diary's most audacious coup has been taken: contact has been made with Rolls-Royce regarding the blue convertible Corniche in which Boris the Jackal Johnson has been spotted.
fields.body:
The first step on the road to what would be the Diary's most audacious coup has been taken: contact has been made with Rolls-Royce regarding the blue convertible Corniche in which Boris the Jackal Johnson has been spotted. There is one small problem: R-R is now owned by BMW, with whom relations have been shaky ever since they grassed me up to the Old Bill for speeding in Roehampton (for which I have now paid with a £40 fine and three points). Tentatively, then, my colleague Richard Adams rings R-R HQ in Crewe to ask for the car. "Is this for an automotive or lifestyle section?" asks Sarah Perris. Oh, lifestyle. And automotive. Everything, really. "Well, unlike the other manufacturers we only have one press car," says Sarah, "but of course it is worth a quarter of a million pounds." Of course. Would that be the Jackal's, with the RR1 plate? "That's ours." So if we don't mind waiting a bit, we can have it? "Well, um" Marvellous. All we need now is a date.

 The Diary hat is doffed to Robin Oakley, svelte out- going political editor of the BBC, whose surprise pleasure boat party thrown by colleagues I clumsily ruined with an item last week. By way of belated apology, we sent over a couple of bottles and a note on Tuesday, and yesterday morning he rang from outside Downing Street to say thanks. "Well, it was a wonderful party," said Mr Oakley when the apology was reiterated. No hard feelings, then? "I had a mutter at the time, but all is forgiven." You wouldn't get manners like that from Andrew Marr. What a gent.

 And so at last to Book of the Month, Paul Daniels's Under No Illusion (Blake Publishing, £16.99). Early in his life, in the north-east town of South Bank, Paul commits a faux pas. "Sitting around the table one Sunday, I managed to disgrace myself when asked how I was getting on at school. I replied that... I hated only one teacher, Mrs Twates. 'We call her Twatty Twates,' I added." From such small acorns. A smack on the bottom instilled in Paul a hatred of bad language that persist to this day. "I still don't like swear words, probably because I was brought up to dislike them and was taught that they were an unnecessary part of the English language." Fascinating, absolutely fascinating. More soon.

 The annual meeting of the Royal Economics Society, at St Andrews, received an urgent call from David Blunkett's private office demanding a copy of some research on the New Deal, due to be discussed yesterday at the conference. "We haven't received this," said David's aide sternly. "The prime minister wants a copy as well, and I want this faxed through instantly. There's a press conference at 10am, and it's a quarter to now." It was only at this point that this impudent bag-carrier was informed that the Department of Education and Employment had put out a press release on the same research on Monday, and had indeed funded the research itself. Do get a grip, David.

 Jon Waldman rings to report a trip to Ripon races on Monday evening, where among the 21 runners in the 6.55, a selling race, was Blair. It was trained by William Haigh from Yorkshire. Blair came fifth, says Jon, and a glance at the Racing Post reveals the following write up: "held up, headway when no clear run well over two furlongs out, switched left well over one furlong out, stayed on, never able to challenge." Early promise, then, but not a lot of stamina. Still, switched left.

 Meanwhile Diary pundit Steptoe, conqueror of TV's Thommo (45) in the Great Tipster Stakes of 95, is planning one positively final comeback. The West Highland terrier, widely regarded as the world's leading canine soothsayer, is preparing the odds on the succession to the Labour leadership should Mr T stop a bus or jack it in, in disgust at the sneerers.

webTitle: 36% rise in reports of data misuse

fields.headline: 36% rise in reports of data misuse
fields.standfirst: Privacy on the net: special report
fields.trailText: A record rise in the number of complaints - 36% in one year - have been made to Elizabeth France, the data protection registrar, over the misuse of personal files held on computers, the agency revealed yesterday.
fields.body:
A record rise in the number of complaints - 36% in one year - have been made to Elizabeth France, the data protection registrar, over the misuse of personal files held on computers, the agency revealed yesterday.

The 4,570 complaints is the largest number made to the agency. As a result it has overburdened agency staff who say they are facing "substantial backlogs" in handling them.

The surge has led to 587 visits by compliance staff to companies to check files for criminal offences. Another 11 search warrants were obtained to raid businesses run by private investigators who were illegally obtaining confidential information on people.

Some 145 cases went to court, with 130 businesses and organisations found guilty of illegally using or procuring the information.

Successful prosecutions detailed in the annual report include the Rugby Football Union, fined £1,500, R and B Consultancy Services in Swaffham, Norfolk, which was fined £4,000 for two offences, and Apex Computer Recruitment of Kingston, Surrey, which was fined £3,000.

Many of the cases involve misusing personal information for direct marketing or misusing consumer credit information held on computers.

In the report, Ms France warns the home secretary, Jack Straw, against overweening powers to obtain details of people's emails and to force internet providers to hand over encryption codes to fight cybercrime.

Mr Straw's plans would only be acceptable "provided that strict conditions were laid down in a national law in which an order or notice could be issued," she says.

As regards emails she calls for an amendment to the regulation of investigatory powers bill - now being challenged in the Lords - saying that interception must take place only after a judge or independent authority has ruled that there are grounds for doing so.

Ms France also says that membership organisations should make it clear to members how widely their details will be made available and for what purposes."

fields.headline: Our anti-Jewish bias
fields.trailText: Norman Finkelstein argues in extracts from his forthcoming book (G2, July 12 and 13) that Holocaust remembrance has become an exploitative industry used to justify Israel's policies and that the campaign by Jewish survivors for compensation for assets lost under Nazi occupation and slave labour is directed by gold diggers.
fields.body:
Norman Finkelstein argues in extracts from his forthcoming book (G2, July 12 and 13) that Holocaust remembrance has become an exploitative industry used to justify Israel's policies and that the campaign by Jewish survivors for compensation for assets lost under Nazi occupation and slave labour is directed by gold diggers.

More disturbing is the Guardian's decision to promote Finkelstein's views in such a high profile way. We are not among those who obsessively search for media bias. However, it seems to us the Guardian has consistently given a prominent forum to imbalanced and often bigoted views on Jewish issues. In the past four months you have run articles on the trial of Iranian Jews in Shiraz suggesting that pressure from the west - in response to Jewish lobbies - was responsible for the unfair anti-government reporting of the trial. You published a report on the Israeli withdrawal from Lebanon that referred to the residents of northern Galilee as "settlers", setting up a mis guided association between these people and the settlers in the occupied territories. You printed a comment piece by Martin Kettle on Israel's 52nd anniversary arguing it had been born in original sin through expulsion of Palestinians, and a long review about a celebrated documentary on the massacre of Israeli athletes at the 1972 Munich Olympics in which Edward Said ranted against Zionist bias and provided an entirely distorted view of the film.

We are both active supporters of the Israeli peace movement and strongly endorse critical discussion of Israeli policies and Jewish issues. We certainly agree it is appropriate to question the excesses of particular Holocaust groups. But there is a significant difference between critical discussion and a systematic defamatory agenda. We doubt the Guardian would publish long articles by right-wing authors denouncing the "African-American slavery industry", or the "Armenian genocide remembrance business". It seems that Jews are fair game for crank provoca tions. We find it remarkable that a newspaper which flatters itself as the voice of progressive liberal opinion in Britain indulges in this bizarrely illiberal practice.

Prof Shalom Lappin
Kings College, London shalom.lappin@kcl.ac.uk
Dr Colin Shindler
School of Oriental and African Studies

 Half of my family were murdered by Lithuanian and Latvian Nazis - victims of the only "Holocaust industry". I shall shortly revisit their mass graves.

On my return I shall continue to campaign for the extension of Holocaust education, not only to commemorate the hideous past but as a beacon of warning against genocide miseries of the present and future - despite Finkelstein's nauseous approach to the Holocaust.

Lord Janner of Braunstone QC
Chairman,
Holocaust Educational Trust

 I'm offended that Johannes Asamer, an Austrian gravel producer, says compensation for slave labourers is unnecessary because "those who did the real forced labour are no longer alive" (Austrian slave fund is rejected, July 10).

My father worked for five years as a slave labourer in the stone quarries of Mauthausen camp in Austria. He died in May, having spent his last days reliving the horror of his time there. It has taken too long to compensate victims like him; how dare these wealthy businessmen hold the process up even longer?

I say thank goodness that "the Jews are exerting so much pressure". Without their determined lobbying, there would be no justice for any of the slave labourers, Jewish or not.

Christina Strupinska
London

fields.headline: Race, class and cricket
fields.trailText: Wakey, wakey! It's the 21st century (Venus the new torchbearer, Sport, July 10). It might surprise you to learn that some of your readers are black. It's just possible that one or two of them might not even be middle-class.
fields.body:
 Wakey, wakey! It's the 21st century (Venus the new torchbearer, Sport, July 10). It might surprise you to learn that some of your readers are black. It's just possible that one or two of them might not even be middle-class.

Natalie Minnis
Alexandria,
Dunbartonshire
natalie@ecosse.net

 So the irrepressible whirlwind of social change we have experienced since Tony Blair strode into 10 Downing Street is "a socialist revolution", according to VS Naipaul (Report, July 11). As this assessment cannot be ignorance, from such an educated author, I can only assume Sir Vidia comes from that long tradition of Indian spinners.

Patrick Dodd
London

 I see Alistair Campbell is now playing cricket for Zimbabwe (Sport, July 11). Is he a spin bowler?

Charles Sandeman-Allen
Rye,
E Sussex

 The newspaper of the Revolutionary Communist Party (Letters, July 10) was not The Next Step; it was the next step. Even in the 70s. the postmodernists of LM were obsessed with style above substance.

Roland Rance
London

 The "affluent Liverpool parish" criticised by the bishop (Parishioners urged to put 5% of pay on plate, July 11) should have been commended for good stewardship. Communion wine from church supplies is often inferior and expensive, compared to, say, a Muscatel bought at a supermarket. Someone should organise a tasting of communion wines to decide what is the best buy.

Rev Paul Gatenby
Wellingborough,
Northants

 My daughter has been invited to apply for her first Gold American Express card. She is 14 and has a monthly income of £5. Is this a record?

Colin Billett
Bewdley,
Worcestershire

fields.headline: Man of courage
fields.standfirst:
An archbishop who persevered for truth
Religion in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: By the end of the 80s, the Rt Rev Robert Runcie had fallen into disfavour. He was badly damaged by the Crockford's preface debacle and the suicide of its author, his old friend and shrewd critic, Gary Bennett, whose stinging verdict was: "He nailed his colours firmly to the fence."
fields.body:
By the end of the 80s, the Rt Rev Robert Runcie had fallen into disfavour. He was badly damaged by the Crockford's preface debacle and the suicide of its author, his old friend and shrewd critic, Gary Bennett, whose stinging verdict was: "He nailed his colours firmly to the fence." His stock fell further after he had left Lambeth Palace, as implicit blame fell on his shoulders for leaving his successor with a church in such a parlous state. Nor did the 1995 biography by Humphrey Carpenter help, exposing his honest doubts in a cruel light.

But history is already revising such judgments, and Lord Runcie's reputation is on the rise again - deservedly so. Above all, he was a man of remarkable courage, which he demonstrated early in life on the battlefield (he won a Military Cross), but went on to display in even more terrifying circumstances: he incurred the wrath of Lady Thatcher at the Falklands' war commemoration service by praying for Argentine victims and their relatives. Still more significantly, he commissioned the Faith In The City report - the first principled critique of the social devastation caused by market economics. It contributed and articulated a growing unease with Thatcherism and took the institution he headed into a direct clash with an ideologically driven government. This was an historic shift for the Church of England, ending its reputation as the Tory party at prayer, and bringing it closer to the wartime mission of William Temple, the 20th-century's greatest Archbishop of Canterbury.

That provided a new horizon for the unwieldy armada that is the Church of England; he plotted its course judiciously, using his diplomatic skills and charm to cajole and flatter. At heart, his courage was also brought to bear on the dilemmas of faith at the end of the century. His own faith came close to a kind of agnostic Christianity inspired by an idealism and compassion with which many with or without faith can identify.

fields.headline: Something to celebrate
fields.standfirst: A big advance for human rights in Britain
fields.trailText: The home secretary, Jack Straw, yesterday signed the commencement order to bring the Human Rights Act into force in October. The modest celebration deserved much greater prominence: it was a historic step in British constitutional history. For the first time, we will have our basic rights enshrined in domestic legislation.
fields.body:
The home secretary, Jack Straw, yesterday signed the commencement order to bring the Human Rights Act into force in October. The modest celebration deserved much greater prominence: it was a historic step in British constitutional history. For the first time, we will have our basic rights enshrined in domestic legislation. For over 50 years, we have had to travel to the continent to avail ourselves in Strasbourg of the vision and ideals of British civil servants who drafted the European Convention of Human Rights; it cost us years of delay and huge legal expenditure to do so. Now such rights will be within reach in every court in the land.

Furthermore, this act alters the very hard-wiring of our constitution: it marks a shift of power from the executive to the judiciary. So, despite the charge that this government is run by control freaks, it is ceding power to the courts to call it to account and expand a role of protecting and developing the rights of the individual. It will be left to the courts to resolve potential conflict with existing legislation (such as, possibly, the Official Secrets Act). Yet all this good news rarely gets a mention. How many headlines have we had extolling this policy com mitment delivered on time? No, instead we have a steady supply of scare stories - such as yesterday's claiming that fagging in public schools will be outlawed. The government has become so alarmed by ignorant right-wing panic-mongering (there is a widespread, erroneous belief that the convention is a creation of the European Union) that it has, unusually, hidden its light under a bushel.

We need a more robust government counter-offensive. The act will not lead to a flood of cases through the courts - judges will use their discretion to throw out trivial cases. And it will give us statutory rights to privacy and to freedom of speech. The government should be triumphantly claiming credit, and throwing the its full weight behind the act's permeation of every aspect of British life. The £69m earmarked for training for the judiciary, legal aid and public education is a good start. Setting up a Human Rights Commission, along the lines of that for racial equality or equal opportunities, is the next step to achieve that laudable aim. In the meantime, congratulations are in order for this suddenly bashful government and, even more unusually in this leader column, for Jack Straw.

fields.headline: Catching the cheats
fields.trailText: There is bound to be a risk of cheating, however small, in any examination and testing system (The big cheat, July 11). QCA and the awarding bodies recognise the damage done to the credibility of assessment by cheating and have procedures to deal with it rapidly and effectively.
fields.body:
There is bound to be a risk of cheating, however small, in any examination and testing system (The big cheat, July 11). QCA and the awarding bodies recognise the damage done to the credibility of assessment by cheating and have procedures to deal with it rapidly and effectively.

The GCSE case Nick Davies highlights resembles a case an awarding body dealt with last year, down to the numbers involved and the text studied. Their procedures quickly alerted examiners and enabled them to deal with it. In that case a teacher was disciplined.There is no evidence that markers are reluctant to report suspected malpractice or that cheating is widespread. In 1999, 70 of the 208 cases QCA investigated were brought to our attention by markers. Almost 2m pupils take national tests each year, so systematic cheating by teachers would imply there is a huge conspiracy. It is scarcely credible that malpractice on a large scale could be concealed. Moreover the professionalism of teachers would not allow it.

As Nick Davies acknowledges, a great deal of emphasis is placed on maintaining standards, but this sentiment sits uneasily beside some of the anecdotal evidence he cites. It is certainly not true that a "pass" mark for any of the English tests is attainable by ticking multiple-choice boxes and it is bizarre to suggest any QCA official would say so.

Dr Nicholas Tate
Chief executive, Qualifications and Curriculum Authority

 Nick Davies vividly describes the Dutch approach to vocational education and the efforts of schools in Barking and Dagenham to introduce GCSE vocational qualifications modelled on it (July 12). This has been possible only with the continued support of the Department for Education and Ofsted. Chris Woodhead visited one of our schools three weeks ago to see a GCSE vocational class and he expressed his personal support. Of course, there are sometimes concerns over the length of time it takes to innovate, but at no time has the DfEE or Ofsted intervened to prevent progress of our developmental work. We have received sustained and positive support throughout.

AP Larbalestier
Director of Education
Barking

 You report (July 7) that children "who have been permanently excluded from school are 50 times more likely to commit murder than the rest of the population ..." Surely, it is the other way round. Children who are likely to commit murder are 50 times more likely to be excluded from school.

Nigel de Gruchy
General secretary NASUWT

webTitle: How to net the digitally disadvantaged

fields.headline: How to net the digitally disadvantaged
fields.trailText: The internet e-mancipation of a wider section of society is easier than is generally anticipated (The country's digital divide widens, July 11).
fields.body:
The internet e-mancipation of a wider section of society is easier than is generally anticipated (The country's digital divide widens, July 11). Digital TV providers are already providing access to email through interactive television. World wide web access the same way is only a step away. Unfortunately what is currently offered as "TV internet" is a carefully controlled, limited and poor imitation of the real thing. The next few years will see a large-scale take up of digital TV across the whole social range and the consequent demand for full internet access via TV - a "must" in every home compared with a PC - will become unstoppable.

Jeremy Sutcliffe
Oldham,
Lancs

 The digital divide means not just that existing poor adults will remain deprived of this crucial skill - and thereby locked in to a culture of deprivation- but their children too. Even when they're just playing computer games, children acquire not only basic technical skills such as moving the mouse, but spelling, arithmetic, problem-solving - and knowledge. Deprivation in the home is not compensated for by the exiguous access to computers in the classroom, especially in early years. Of course, those in well-heeled schools have lots more - as usual - and will remain well-heeled when they're grown-up

Peter Worsley
London

 The digital revolution should enfranchise those who were previously disad vantaged, for example, those minority groups and individuals who need access to different languages, help-groups or are house-bound. The practical solution, in our service-based economy, is for the government, in partnership with the private sector, to recognise that the internet and web access is part of the basic infrastructure of a progressive economy and treat it as a utility, like water. That way, access is there for all, and those of us who are earning can contribute through the usual forms of taxation or charge. However, the real challenge is still to find ways of encouraging and empowering the disadvantaged to use the facilities. This is a matter of motivation, education and access.

Graham Buxton-Smither
Windsor,
Berks

webTitle: Threat to sell German assets in Greek war case

fields.headline: Threat to sell German assets in Greek war case
fields.trailText: A court case over a Nazi massacre more than 50 years ago was raising heat between Greece and Germany yesterday after bailiffs acting on behalf of the victims started an attempt to seize German state property in Athens.
fields.body:
A court case over a Nazi massacre more than 50 years ago was raising heat between Greece and Germany yesterday after bailiffs acting on behalf of the victims started an attempt to seize German state property in Athens.

The process has been approved by Greece's highest court, although a treaty was agreed by the two countries in final settlement of all claims in the 1960s. Under it, Germany paid Greece 115m deutschmarks (£38m at today's value) to compensate victims of the Nazi occupation between 1941 and 1944.

Police were called to intervene on Tuesday when bailiffs walked in to the Athens building of the Goethe Institute - Germany's state-backed cultural arm, similar to the British Council - to start appraising the property with a view to auctioning it to pay those involved in the court case.

After mild skirmishes in front of Horst Deinwallner, the institute's incredulous director, the appraisal went ahead.

Ignoring the protests of Berlin, the bailiffs said they would be evaluating other sites. These include the German High School and the German Archaeological Society.

Athens says it opposes any auction; but it will have to walk a careful political course through an emotive issue. At present, the judicial system seems to be driving events.

Another driving force is Ioannis Stamoulis, the local governor. "Berlin has repeatedly refused to pay its debts to those who suffered in Distomo," said Mr Stamoulis, a former socialist MEP who initiated the campaign. "Short of Germany making amends, the property will be put up for auction this September and the damages meted out that way."

The massacre in Distomo - a village near Delphi - was similar to those carried out by the Nazis in France, Italy and elsewhere as a reprisal when German soldiers or functionaries were killed by local people.

In Distomo's case, partisans killed seven German soldiers, and what happened next remains one of the darkest moments of that time for Greeks. A Waffen-SS unit drove into the village one June day in 1944. Five hours later it left, having slaughtered 218 men, women and children, killing babies in their cots.

In April, Greece's supreme court, the Areos Pagos, ordered Germany to pay $30m (about £20m) to survivors and relatives. It upheld a judgment they won three years ago in a Greek district court, and it said German assets could be sold.

A Berlin foreign ministry spokesman said Greece was a trusted EU partner but, he told the Guardian, this ruling "violates international public law .... if anyone has a claim against Germany they have to bring it here".

With last week's $5bn settlement with surviving slave labourers and their relatives, Berlin thought it was near the end of decades of compensation deals - reached by negotiation and agreement - with a range of states and groups.

A senior Greek official alleged that Athens had been warned by the German government that "life could become quite difficult for Greece" if court officers pressed ahead with the seizure process. "There have been noises about EU infrastructure funds," he said.

As the poorest EU member, Greece has received an estimated DM30bn (£10bn at current value) in aid from Berlin.

A Berlin foreign ministry spokesman said Greece was a trusted EU partner but, he told the Guardian, this ruling "violates international public law .... if anyone has a claim against Germany they have to bring it here". With last week's $5bn settlement with surviving slave labourers and their relatives, Berlin thought it was near the end of decades of compensation deals - reached by negotiation and agreement - with a range of states and groups. A senior Greek official alleged that Athens had been warned by the German government that "life could become quite difficult for Greece" if court officers pressed ahead with the seizure process. "There have been noises about EU infrastructure funds," he said. As the poorest EU member, Greece has received an estimated DM30bn (£10bn at current value) in aid from Berlin.

fields.headline: Climbers banned from sacred peak
fields.standfirst: Indian Buddhists win a battle to stop treks up the world's third highest summit, Kanchenjunga
fields.trailText: Indian Buddhists win a battle to stop treks up the world's third highest summit, Kanchenjunga
fields.body:
It has long been regarded as one of mountaineering's greatest challenges. Only three teams have ever reached the summit of Kanchenjunga by ascending its perilous north-east face.

But that route up the world's third highest mountain appears to have been shut off for good following a revolt by local Buddhists, who are incensed by what they regard as the desecration of the mountain by godless foreigners.

The government of the north-east Indian state of Sikkim has now banned expeditions to Kanchenjunga and seven others sacred peaks - just as 18 unclimbed mountains elsewhere in India have been opened for the first time.

"It is a gesture of respect for the religious sensitivities of the people who regard the mountain as a deity," Sikkim's former chief minister, BB Goorong, said.

Kanchenjunga, which straddles the border between India and Nepal, is viewed by the Sikkimese as both a god and the abode of gods. The legendary yeti, called Nee-gued in Sikkim, is believed to roam its slopes.

The controversy erupted in April when the state government allowed an Austrian team to attempt the near-vertical trek up the 8,598-metre (28,208ft) peak in exchange for $20,000. The team, led by the climber Willie Bauer, tried to assuage Buddhist feeling by agreeing to turn back 10 metres short of the top.

The mountain - which is smaller only than Mount Everest and K2 - was first climbed in 1953 by the Briton Charles Evans from its Nepal side. A ban on foreigners was imposed in 1955.

Reaction to the Austrians' presence on the sacred peak was furious. The Concerned Citizens of Sikkim, a non-governmental organisation, accused local rulers of selling out and wrote an acid letter comparing "trampling on Kanchenjunga" to leaving rubbish on a statue of Jesus.

It pointed out that Sikkim's last choygal, or king, Palden Thondup Namgyal, never permitted anyone up the mountain. "We cannot allow them to hurt our religion in the name of tourism," Dhammapa, a local monk, added.

Ironically, the row comes at a time when India is falling over itself to welcome foreign climbers following a long period of hostility. The government has this summer opened up 18 "virgin" peaks and 176 lesser summits which have never been climbed. Some do not even have names and most are in previously restricted border areas, including the disputed province of Jammu and Kashmir.

The move was prompted by India's traditional foe Pakistan, which recently scrapped booking fees for all but its highest mountains, and by the lure of hard currency.

Some 43 foreign teams have applied for permits this season to climb in the Indian Himalayas, a fourfold increase on last year. "With more peaks on offer and the virgin peaks as an additional attractions, the number of expeditions will increase to over 100 by the year 2003," said Swadesh Kumar, of the Adventure Tour Operators Association.

The Sikkim assembly decided to press ahead with its ban on foreign climbers even though the Austrians did not make the summit. The team was hit by a vicious snowstorm at 6,500 metres and was forced to turn back.

Speaking from his home in Austria, Mr Bauer, whose grandfather tried and failed twice to climb Kanchenjunga, said the ban was wrong. "We revere mountains in Austria too," he added. "Climbing does not mean the mountains and landscape cannot be preserved, but it does give the locals an opportunity of making some money.

"It is one of the most difficult 8,000 metre climbs in the world. Only K-2 is harder."

The peak is often climbed from its Nepal side, but it was not until 1977 that an Indian team, led by Colonel Narinder Kumar, conquered it from Sikkim. Col Kumar yesterday said he was "totally against" a ban. "I planted my flag 6ft from the top," he said. "Nobody is doing a disservice to God. The mountain is very tough. It is so steep the snow does not stick to it. Being at the top was a wonderful feeling, actually."

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Kremlin insider in tax inquiry
fields.body:
Kremlin insider in tax inquiry

In the strongest indication yet that Vladimir Putin's new government is intent on eliminating corruption in Russia, police yesterday said they had opened a criminal tax-evasion case against the country's largest car manufacturer, Avtovaz, associated with the tycoon Boris Berezovsky.

The company manufactures Lada cars and Niva off-road vehicles, and had "concealed huge sums", said tax police chief Vyacheslav Soltaganov. AP, Moscow

Afghans evict American 'spy'

Afghanistan's ruling Taliban movement ordered a US aid worker detained last Sunday to leave the country within 24 hours yesterday, accusing her of spying.

Mary MacMakin, 74, has to leave Afghanistan or face being deported. Seven of her female Afghan staff also arrested will be released. Their detention came after the Taliban issued an order banning Afghan women from working in aid projects. Reuters, Kabul

Buddha to hit new heights

A California-based Buddhist organisation will build a Buddha statue near Bodh Gaya, in the eastern Indian state of Bihar, which it says will be the tallest statue in the world.

Project officials said the $150m (£100m) complex will consist of a 152-metre bronze statue sitting on a 32-metre throne which will house a temple and a cinema hall, screening films on the life of the Buddha. Reuters, Patna

Sprinter fails latest test

Banned Canadian sprinter Ben Johnson raced again in Rome yesterday, but the prize was not a medal - it was his wallet containing about £3,200. Johnson, 38, was robbed by a group of gypsy children, one of whom he caught but the one with the wallet managed to do what many professional athletes could not - outsprint him. Reuters, Rome

Heatwave foils suicide attempt

A heatwave that has killed 12 people in Turkey saved the life of a suicidal woman who fainted before she could hurl herself from a cliff near the southern resort of Antalya. Her first words when she awoke were "Aren't I dead?" Reuters, Ankara

fields.headline: Medicine moves to bionic age
fields.trailText: Scientists using a new technique called bioengineering have restored at least some sight in two groups of patients with damaged corneas. And an Austrian team has taken a step towards a bionic world by fitting children with artificial knee joints that grow as the children do.
fields.body:
Scientists using a new technique called bioengineering have restored at least some sight in two groups of patients with damaged corneas. And an Austrian team has taken a step towards a bionic world by fitting children with artificial knee joints that grow as the children do.

Teams from Taiwan and California took cells from a healthy cornea and implanted them in damaged corneas, they report today. The Taiwanese group, reported in the New England Journal of Medicine that they selected six patients with damaged tissue in one eye, and transferred cells from the healthy eye.

The group at the University of California, Davis, did the same, but used corneal cells donated by close relatives.

One patient, George Norman, a 69-year-old from Colusa, California, who lost most of his vision when ammonia splashed in his eyes 27 years ago, underwent six corneal transplants: none of them helped.

The Davis team gave him another, this time supplemented with corneal cells from his 38-year-old son. The vision in his left eye improved.

The scientists used a technique called bioengineering: they took corneal stem cells and grew them in a laboratory dish. Ivan Schwab, an ophthalmologist at UC Davis, who reports with colleagues in the journal Cornea, said the research was an important step towards "off-the-shelf" corneas.

Austrian scientists report in Nature today that they successfully fitted expanding artificial joints to 13 children. As the children grew, so the "endoprosthesis" slowly telescoped, keeping both limbs at equal length.

fields.headline: Student's lights voted best design
fields.trailText: Super Patata, a range of squishy lights with the bulbs embedded in brilliantly coloured latex balloons, won student designer Hector Serrano the Oxo/Peugeot 2,000 design award last night and £16,000 in prize money.
fields.body:
Super Patata, a range of squishy lights with the bulbs embedded in brilliantly coloured latex balloons, won student designer Hector Serrano the Oxo/Peugeot 2,000 design award last night and £16,000 in prize money.

The cheap and cheerful lights may soon make him considerably wealthier, as discussions are advanced with a manufacturer to produce them commercially.

The lights, which can be stacked, or manipulated to change the intensity of colour, were praised by the judges as a modest but inspired design.

They have proved irresistible at the exhibition linked to the awards at the Oxo tower on London's South Bank, where almost every visitor has poked and prodded them.

This year the awards were open to both young and established designers. Mr Serrano, 26, who graduates this year from the Royal College of Art, beat off several short-listed professionals, including Tavs Jorgenson, of Dartington Pottery, who won a commendation and £2,500. The 11 finalists each received £1,000. Their designs, and almost 300 others, are on display until the end of July, and then go on a national tour.

fields.headline: Time called on island's school
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The smallest school in Wales will close next week, marking the end of more than a century of primary education for an island community.
fields.body:
The smallest school in Wales will close next week, marking the end of more than a century of primary education for an island community.

The school, on Caldey island, a mile off the Pembrokeshire coast, is being closed because there are no longer enough pupils to keep it going.

Three of the four children will leave to start their secondary education on the mainland when term ends a week tomorrow, which would have left eight-year-old Jonathan Miller as the only pupil.

Headteacher Frances Allen said the school's closure would be a sad day for the island.

Mrs Allen's own children, Kirsten, 11, and Thomas, 10, are two of the last pupils and the family has decided to move to the mainland so they can complete their schooling.

The two other pupils, Victoria Purchase, 11, and Jonathan will board in Tenby during the week when the new term starts and make the boat trip back to Caldey at weekends, weather permitting.

fields.headline: Chips are down
fields.standfirst:
New guidelines on school meals
Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Chips and beans will remain firmly on the school menu, the government confirmed yesterday, as it published the first nutritional standards for school meals for 20 years.
fields.body:
Chips and beans will remain firmly on the school menu, the government confirmed yesterday, as it published the first nutritional standards for school meals for 20 years.

The standards, which will come into force next April, specify that chips or other fried potatoes can continue to be served in primary school meals, although not more than three times a week. However, baked beans must be served to primary pupils no more than once a week.

Secondary schools will be able to dish up chips every day, although a healthy alternative such as pasta must also be offered.

But earlier plans to restrict how much of such food could be eaten in school dining rooms have been dropped, along with a legal limit on the number of times red meat could appear on the menu.

Labour's decision to revive nutritional guidelines, scrapped by the Tories in 1980, has reignited a debate about how practical it is to enforce such guidelines, and whether they should be based on scientific nutritional values or on ingredients.

The Local Authority Caterers' Association had warned that the earlier draft guidelines had been "over-prescriptive" and "patronising" to school kitchen managers. Yester day the Child Poverty Action Group accused the government of selling out to the catering industry, and said the guidelines should be based on nutritional values.

Campaigns officer Sue Brighouse said: "We think the caterers have won the day because what they are saying is that it would be too difficult to implement nutrition-based standards."

But, launching the new guidelines yesterday at a conference in London, the junior school standards minister, Jacqui Smith, said: "These are modern standards which will be easy for caterers to implement and monitor, and, perhaps more importantly, easy for children to understand in the context of healthy eating".

The guidelines also specify that cheese can be served up "freely as a main protein dish", and that meals should include fresh fruit at least twice a week and fruit in a dessert at least once a day.

webTitle: Gang steals pop concert charity cash

fields.headline: Gang steals pop concert charity cash
fields.trailText: The promoter of last weekend's T in the Park pop festival was yesterday robbed of charitable donations collected at the event by a gang of masked men who broke into his home.
fields.body:
The promoter of last weekend's T in the Park pop festival was yesterday robbed of charitable donations collected at the event by a gang of masked men who broke into his home.

Stuart Clumpas was tied up and threatened by three men who forced their way into his house wielding sticks. They stole up to £20,000: money which was destined for a children's hospice.

The raid happened yesterday morning when the gang confronted Mr Clumpas at his home in Auchinden, near Glasgow. The men demanded money before making off in the family car.

Mr Clumpas's partner and their children, aged three and eight months, were in the house at the time of the robbery. They were not tied up but were badly shaken by their ordeal.

The money stolen by the robbers was donations made by those with guest passes to the Perthshire event.

Detective Chief Inspector Gordon McKenzie, leading the hunt for the gang, said: "This robbery would have taken a considerable amount of pre-planning."

Around 100,000 people attended the two-day festival to watch headline acts such as Macy Gray, Moby and Travis.

fields.headline: Bandy thief walks into trouble
fields.trailText: Armed robber John Saunders wore a mask and gloves but there was something he could not disguise - his funny walk. He was caught out when security film of raids on jewellery shops showed his bow legs.
fields.body:
Armed robber John Saunders wore a mask and gloves but there was something he could not disguise - his funny walk. He was caught out when security film of raids on jewellery shops showed his bow legs.

Haydn Kelly, an expert in biomechanics - the way the body moves - told the Old Bailey there was no doubt the gait of the robber on video matched Saunders's crooked walk. Dr Kelly told the court that only 5% or less of the population had the same walk as Saunders.

Saunders, 38, of Bierley, Bradford, was convicted yesterday of conspiracy to rob and a firearms offence. He will be sentenced later this week with other members of his gang who specialised in stealing Rolex watches from jewellery shops in the south of England.

Their robberies netted £700,000 before Saunders was arrested in November last year, after police marksmen shot out the tyres of a car outside a jewellery shop in Kingston, Surrey.

Edward Brown, prosecuting, said Saunders was the leader of the gang which had carried out robberies in Brighton, East Sussex, Reigate, Surrey, and Knightsbridge, central London, over an 18-month period. They were arrested after a long police surveillance operation.

webTitle: Firms 'knew of leaded petrol dangers in 20s'

fields.headline: Firms 'knew of leaded petrol dangers in 20s'
fields.trailText: Three of the world's largest companies were accused this week of deliberately introducing lead into petrol in the 1920s knowing it would poison millions of people and manipulating the science for more than 50 years to avoid censure and loss of lucrative sales.
fields.body:
Three of the world's largest companies were accused this week of deliberately introducing lead into petrol in the 1920s knowing it would poison millions of people and manipulating the science for more than 50 years to avoid censure and loss of lucrative sales.

Car magazine carried out a two year investigation into the history of tera-ethyl lead additive in petrol and compared the conduct of General Motors, duPont and Standard Oil (now ExxonMobil) to that of the tobacco companies which hid the effects of nicotine.

Although lead in petrol has been phased out in the US and Europe, it is still widely in use in the rest of the world. Ninety per cent is manufactured in Britain by Associated Octel, which employs 600 people in its Ellesmere Port factory in the Wirral.

The company, now independent of the oil and motor groups that once owned it, is accused by Car magazine of continuing to market the product even though scientific evidence of health effects, particularly brain damage in children, is well known. The company said it was not promoting the product, merely continuing to supply lead additive until it was phased out in the developing world.

Jamie Kitman, a New York lawyer and US editor of the magazine which did the research, discovered the consequences of leaded petrol were clearly identified by public health officials and scientists 75 years ago, and well known to the company's executives. The potential consequences were denied and then endlessly debated by its inventors.

General Motors, duPont and Standard Oil were making billions of dollars worldwide from selling the lead formula which they had patented while paying for and controlling the research into the health effects for more than 40 years. The research always favoured the industry's pro-lead views or was suppressed, Mr Kitman found.

Other safer performance-boosting additives in wide use today, among them ethanol, were known to the industry before the lead additive was discovered and patented. These alternatives were "denied, then fought, suppressed and unfairly maligned for decades" to preserve the lucrative monopoly of leaded petrol.

In a final irony Mr Kitman says that the lead additive, which was billed as great for performance and good for cars, damaged them.

The issue of lead in petrol arose in the 1920s because petrol on its own did not allow high performance and engines "knocked", or vibrated. Alcohol, easily made and used but frowned on in prohibition America, did the trick and so did the lead compound. The advantage of tera-ethyl lead was that it could be patented and royalties charged.

Yandell Anderson, professor of applied physiology at Yale and inventor of the gas mask, was among those who warned about lead poisoning in 1924.

Documentation unearthed by Car shows that the three companies colluded with the then US surgeon general Hugh Cumming to avoid the product being killed off by health fears.

It was not until 1965 that Clair Patterson, a geochemist, proved that lead in human bodies had increased 100 times since the introduction of lead in petrol. The US environment protection agency finally moved in 1976 to abolish lead in petrol.

Since the US began to phase out lead, the average American's level of lead in blood has declined by nearly 80%.

But in the developing world lead in petrol is still standard. In Mexico City, 4m cars pump 32 tonnes of lead into the atmosphere each day. According to the World Bank, 1.7bn city dwellers in developing countries are in danger of lead poisoning, including brain damage, high blood pressure and heart disease from airborne lead. In 1996, 93% of all petrol sold in Africa contained lead, 94% in the Middle East and 30% in Asia.

Heather Ashcroft, for Associated Octel in Manchester, said "Mr Kitman is using 20/20 hindsight. We do not accept the history as he tells it. We are not actively trying to get people to buy leaded petrol now either. We are selling tel (tera-ethyl lead) to those customers who still need to use it until their refineries can be converted to providing non-lead petrol. We accept that leaded petrol will be phased out worldwide. We are being responsible realising that it will cause disruption if we stop supplying it, both economic and environmental."

Clif Webb, for DuPont, issued a statement. "We do not agree with the view of events related. DuPont stands by its actions as a responsible corporation with respect to this product."

General Motors and Exxon were not prepared to comment.

The Effects:

Acute lead poisoning leads to blindness, brain damage, kidney disease, convulsions, cancer and death.

Children exposed to lower levels have lower IQs, reading and learning disabilities, impaired hearing, reduced attention span, hyperactivity, behavioural problems and growth interference.

Adults can fall victim to blood pressure increases, hypertension, cardiovascular disease and death.

webTitle: Outlaw doctor on trial for murder

fields.headline: Outlaw doctor on trial for murder
fields.trailText: A doctor who continued to find work after being jailed for poisoning ambulance workers has been accused of murdering three patients and is suspected of killing up to 32 more.
fields.body:
A doctor who continued to find work after being jailed for poisoning ambulance workers has been accused of murdering three patients and is suspected of killing up to 32 more.

Michael Swango, 45, faces the death penalty if he is convicted of giving three patients fatal injections in 1993.

"Instead of using his medical licence to become a healer, Swango embarked on a career as a killer," said US attorney Loretta Lynch. "He used his skills to search for victims and take their lives."

James Stewart, a Pulitzer prize-winning writer who produced a book about the former doctor, said: "It's shocking that he was even hired. It's the starkest evidence that the medical profession cannot adequately police itself."

Swango is suspected of poisoning patients in four US states and in Zimbabwe.

No motive has been suggested but Mr Stewart, the author of Blind Eye: The Terrify ing Story of a Doctor who got away with Murder, said: "The easy answer is he's a psychopath. He did it for the thrill, the sense of omnipotence, the godlike power of making decisions of life and death over unsuspecting victims."

The three murder charges relate to three elderly patients at a medical centre in North port, New York, seven years ago; tests on their bodies showed fatal doses of drugs that had not been prescribed.

In 1984, Swango was found guilty of putting arsenic in the food and drink of five ambulance workers. He was jailed for two years and his medical licence was withdrawn. But he was later able to find work in South Dakota and Newport by claiming that his conviction was for brawling in a bar.

By the time law enforcement agencies started to investigate his case, he was in Zimbabwe, where he is suspected of involvement in the deaths of five patients. He was arrested when he returned to the US to apply for a visa.

webTitle: West's blind eye opens to third world corruption

fields.headline: West's blind eye opens to third world corruption
fields.trailText: An emerging war against corruption in several countries in southern Africa is changing the economic and political climate and challenging old ideas of sovereignty in unexpected ways.
fields.body:
An emerging war against corruption in several countries in southern Africa is changing the economic and political climate and challenging old ideas of sovereignty in unexpected ways.

Big business and non-governmental organisations, such as Transparency International (TI) and Global Witness are forming unusual alliances in the changing political scene.

Research from Harvard and UN organisations has shown that the cost of corruption can be counted not just in the sums of money lost but also in retarded development and increased inequalities.

The region is prey to drug and crime syndicates and a cynical political class which has come to accept corruption as normal, according to many influential Africans.

But suddenly the questions of corruption being raised by many groups in civil society, backed by these outsiders, have become a key part of the motor for change.

In Angola, a political sea change has begun. One of the most monolithic of one-party states in Africa has been weakened by charges of corruption in the oil and diamond industries and by its failure to confront its humanitarian crisis.

Previously, decades of threat from Unita, backed by the US and apartheid South Africa, meant the ruling MPLA was unchallenged.

But corruption was not an issue there until the latest phase of the war, according to Shawn McCormick, senior policy adviser to BP Amoco, which was the only oil company to throw open its books to an Angolan government monitoring team, according to the IMF.

Well before last year's Global Witness report on Angolan oil sales revealed claims of high-level corruption or allegations of kickbacks from the French oil company Elf circulated, groups began campaigning for an anti-corruption candidate to stand against President Eduardo Dos Santos.

At a conference sponsored by TI in London this week some of the most egregious cases of corruption were discussed in detail, notably the Lesotho Highland Water Development Project.

Currently, 19 corporations and individuals are being prosecuted in the Lesotho courts, accused of bribing an official. Five British companies are involved and the accusation is that £2m was paid in bribes.

Dr John Makumbe, from TI's chapter in Zimbabwe, said: "We have daily corruption, in schools, hospitals, prisons, the private sector, and the public sector, including the army, but our law actually says that nothing can be investigated in the president's office, the army or the police."

However, he pointed out that most corruption is imported - "60% imported in our case".

TI's chairman, Laurence Cockcroft, told the conference: "There is no doubt about the urgency for these countries of rolling back corruption, and the UK has a critical responsibility both to support the efforts of weaker governments _ and to ensure that anti-bribery legislation is brought in in this country to act against companies such as those involved in the Lesotho project."

"The fight against corruption is essential for prosperity," said Michael Spicer, the executive vice-president of Anglo-American, who is also deputy chairman of South Africa's Business Against Crime agency.

"There's been a lot of concentration on diamonds as a potential resource for corruption, and for wars, but in fact the oil industry brings the largest scale of corruption in Africa - though with the very honorable exception of Global Witness no one has tried to expose it," he added.

"The arms trade is similarly key, but European governments turn a blind eye."

webTitle: Icon will not throw in sponge

fields.headline: Icon will not throw in sponge
fields.trailText: Julia "Butterfly" Hill, who became an environmentalists' icon by living in a tree for more than two years to prevent the felling of a northern Californian redwood forest, is trying to sting the advertisers who made use of her image.
fields.body:
Julia "Butterfly" Hill, who became an environmentalists' icon by living in a tree for more than two years to prevent the felling of a northern Californian redwood forest, is trying to sting the advertisers who made use of her image.

As admirers followed her progress on a website, an ad started appearing in glossy magazines in which a woman much like her sat on a platform up a tree with the paraphernalia of open-air survival.

She was holding an OmniSky wireless internet device and a man below with two large buckets had a logo on his jacket proclaiming his allegiance to "sponge-bath.com".

Her case against OmniSky, AT&T, and the ad agency TBWA Chiat/Day says it is "beyond comprehension" that a woman who "endured severe physical, mental and spiritual challenges and risked her life in support of her efforts to save old-growth forests would use a wireless Internet and email service to call a man to bathe her and would endorse [the] defendants' products".

AT&T, which provides the network used by OmniSky, says it had nothing to do with the ad, and OmniSky says it has discontinued the campaign.

But like the loggers who finally agreed in December to leave her beloved trees standing, the defendants may find that they have met their match.

Her maxim most frequently quoted on environmentalist websites is: "Those things of real worth in life are worth going to any length in love and respect to safeguard."

webTitle: Call to Africans: fight to free the young from Aids

fields.headline: Call to Africans: fight to free the young from Aids
fields.standfirst:
Unicef chief urges states to mobilise all their human and material resources in struggle for social survival
International Aids Conference
UN Aids programme
fields.trailText: Nothing short of a "war of liberation", mobilising every resource available, will defeat the scourge of HIV/Aids, which is undoing the last 10 years of progress in Africa, the United Nations Children's Fund said yesterday.
fields.body:
Nothing short of a "war of liberation", mobilising every resource available, will defeat the scourge of HIV/Aids, which is undoing the last 10 years of progress in Africa, the United Nations Children's Fund said yesterday.

"Virtually every society understands what it means to wage a struggle for liberation," Unicef's executive director, Carol Bellamy, said, adding that the words had a special resonance in Africa.

"It means mobilising every available resource; it means involving men and women on an equal basis; it means accepting the vital role to be played by young people; and it means sparing no effort and brooking no diversions until all of society is liberated. That's what is needed now - nothing less."

She was launching Unicef's annual report on the health and human rights of children, the Progress of Nations, at the international Aids conference in Durban, South Africa.

Each year for the past 10 years the report has focused on a threat to children, from malnutrition and polluted water to gender-based violence and abuse. But Aids, she said, was "a threat of such magnitude that the others almost pale by comparison".

Young people were in the frontline of the struggle to come, she said. One in three women and one in seven men aged 15 to 24 in Botswana was HIV positive. Six people under the age of 24 were infected every minute: 7,000 young people and 1,000 infants a day.

They were the most vulnerable to infection: in some cultures young girls were preyed on by older men who gave them gifts for sex, and they lacked the negotiating skills to ensure that the man wore a condom. Some men appeared to believe the pernicious myth that sex with a virgin can take away HIV infection.

Defeating HIV/Aids requires widespread changes in attitudes and behaviour, but the report reveals a shocking and dangerous lack of knowledge about the virus among young people, particularly girls. Half the sexually active 15-19 year olds in Zimbabwe, where 30% of pregnant women have HIV, do not think they are at risk. In 15 developing countries surveyed, half or more of the girls aged 15 to 19 did not know that someone who looked healthy could be infected with HIV and transmit it to others.

"Current infection rates should never have reached such catastrophic levels," the report says.

Ms Bellamy writes that Aids in Africa "is very dangerously eroding already very fragile social structures and the abilities of communities and nations to respond."

In an interview with the Guardian, she accepted that the UN might have been slow to realise the scale of the disaster in Africa.

"As usual, one comes to things late. The UN isn't the entity that is going to solve the HIV/Aids problem - first and foremost have to be heads of state themselves.

"That doesn't mean the UN couldn't have been a little more active sooner. In the last two-and-half to three years Unicef has dramatically increased its work. But should I have been saying this a year or two ago?

"Maybe yes. But we monitor these issues, and sometimes a sense of what is really having the impact doesn't really present itself."

Among the leaders of the worst affected African countries, she said, there had been for too long a conspiracy of silence, "with the exception of Uganda, and a little bit Senegal".

But South Africa was now talking about Aids, and there was some movement in Malawi, Zambia and Nigeria. "But it has taken too long."

In the west, the silence was compounded by the discovery of drugs to keep the virus in check. Aids went off the agenda.

When she put her Aids lapel pin in her jacket for a meeting last year, Ms Bellamy said, people kept saying to her: "I haven't seen one of those for so long."

"I believe responsibility lies largely with the [African] heads of state," she said.

An all-out effort was needed. "The whole fabric of society in some of these countries is at risk here. We're not just talking about truck drivers or sex workers."

Last year 860,000 children in sub-Saharan Africa lost their teacher to Aids. And orphaned children had little chance of an education, because they were assumed to the HIV positive -often wrongly- and shunned.

Young people are the worst hit by Aids, but they are also the solution, Ms Bellamy believes. In South Africa, a television programme called Let's Talk, featuring trained teenagers who roam the country talking to other teenagers on camera about sex, is topping the ratings.

Condom use by young people seems to be rising, but there is a long way to go in improving the status of women and enabling them to refuse sex or negotiate protection with men.

Even without Aids there would be a "mixed report card" on children's rights this year, Ms Bellamy said.

Fewer children were dying from preventable causes, there had been a dramatic improvement in immunisation, severe malnutrition had declined. More children were in school than ever before. But there was little progress in reducing maternal mortality and increased conflict had been a significant drag on health protection and development.

Poverty, HIV/Aids and war were "the huge obstacle mountains as we enter the 21st century".

But she is hopeful that great progress can be made through a new focus on the early years of a child's life, on which a healthy future can be built, and continued stress on the empowering education of girls.
